headline: What's on Today
summary: 4:45 A.M. (TCM) 48 HOURS OF HORROR! Turner Classic Movies goes for goose bumps in films, starting with ''The Thing From Another World'' (1951), in which the crew of a remote Arctic base fights off a murderous monster from outer space, and ending with Katsuo Nakamura, above, in ''Kwaidan'' (1964), Masaki Kobayashi's collage of love and the supernatural in exotic settings, at 2 a.m. 11 A.M. (NBC) THE MARTHA STEWART SHOW In this Halloween-themed episode, Rosie O'Donnell does a candy-wrapper decoupage project with Ms. Stewart and then joins the Broadway Kids for song and dance.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 7:30 A.M. (Turner Classic Movies) RICARDO MONTALBAN TRIBUTE TCM turns its daytime schedule over to the ''Fantasy Island'' star, left, who died on Jan. 14. The tribute begins with his first starring role, in the musical ''Fiesta'' (1947), opposite Esther Williams and Cyd Charisse, and ends at 6 p.m. with ''The Singing Nun'' (1966), in which his priest comes to the aid of Debbie Reynolds's musical nun. 9 A.M. (CBS) THE DOCTORS Joan Rivers discusses her experiences with plastic surgery.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (13, 49) NATURE: THE WOLF THAT CHANGED AMERICA In 1893 Ernest Thompson Seton, right, an animal trapper and naturalist, traveled into the canyons of New Mexico on a mission to kill a wolf called Lobo, the leader of a cattle-killing pack. Known as the King of Currumpaw, Lobo had a mythical ability to cheat death, and after eventually trapping Lobo, Seton found he couldn't kill him. Lobo ultimately died from his injuries, and Seton returned east, recording his findings in the book ''Wild Animals I Have Known'' and using his popularity to push for the creation of national parks and lay the groundwork for the Boy Scouts of America. ''Ever since Lobo,'' Seton said, ''my sincerest wish has been to impress upon people that each of our native wild creatures is in itself a precious heritage that we have no right to destroy or put beyond the reach of our children.'' 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS WITH CHRIS WALLACE The House majority leader, Steny Hoyer of Maryland, and the House minority leader, John A. Boehner of Ohio, discuss the proposed bailout of the automotive industry.

headline: ABC, CBS and NBC Will Join Forces for a Prime-Time Cancer Fund-Raiser
summary: ABC, CBS and NBC have agreed to set aside the same hour of prime-time television on the first Friday night in September for a live, joint telethon benefiting cancer research, representatives for the networks said in interviews. Among those who encouraged the networks to put aside their competitive instincts, albeit temporarily, was Katie Couric, anchor of the ''CBS Evening News,'' who will appear on the fund-raiser alongside her principal rivals, Brian Williams of NBC and Charles Gibson of ABC. All three have had immediate family members die of the disease, and another principal, Jeff Zucker, the president and chief executive of NBC and Ms. Couric's former boss, is a colon cancer survivor. To publicize the benefit, which is being called Stand Up to Cancer, Ms. Couric will return on Wednesday to NBC's ''Today,'' the program she left in 2006 after more than a decade. (Her former partner, Matt Lauer, teased her return on Tuesday's program, coyly saying she was coming back to make a major announcement.) On ''Today,'' Ms. Couric will be joined by Mr. Gibson and Mr. Williams, who are also expected to appear with her on Wednesday on ''Good Morning America'' on ABC and ''The Early Show'' on CBS.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) THE 63RD ANNUAL TONY AWARDSNeil Patrick Harris is the host of this three-hour ceremony, honoring the best of Broadway and broadcast live -- and in high-definition, the better to see all the stars more clearly -- from Radio City Music Hall. The program will feature performances from the nominated shows ''Billy Elliot,'' ''Guys and Dolls,'' ''Hair,'' ''Next to Normal,'' ''Pal Joey,'' ''Rock of Ages,'' ''Shrek the Musical'' and ''West Side Story,'' as well as Dolly Parton, Elton John, Liza Minnelli, Stockard Channing and the band Poison. Edie Falco, Jane Fonda, James Gandolfini, Marcia Gay Harden, Anne Hathaway, Jessica Lange, Frank Langella, Angela Lansbury, Susan Sarandon and Kevin Spacey are among those scheduled to present. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton discusses the most pressing foreign affairs facing the Obama administration.

headline: What's On TODAY
summary: 8:30 P.M. (HBO) 24/7 Two lean, mean pummeling machines -- Roy Jones Jr. (52 wins, 4 losses, 38 knockouts), left, of Pensacola, Fla., and Joe Calzaghe (45 wins, no losses, 32 knockouts) of Newbridge, Wales -- prepare for their long-anticipated heavyweight showdown on Nov. 8 in a new season of this boxing reality series. Three all-access matches between the men will be shown on Sunday, Nov. 2 and Nov. 6. The Nov. 8 match is a pay-per-view event broadcast live from Madison Square Garden. Liev Schreiber narrates. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY WITH CHRIS WALLACE Gov. Tim Kaine of Virginia, Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania and Karl Rove, former White House senior adviser, talk about campaign strategy.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 11 P.M. (HBO) RUSSELL SIMMONS PRESENTS BRAVE NEW VOICESQueen Latifah narrates this new series, which listens in as six teams of teenage wordsmiths from across the country prepare to compete at the 2008 Brave New Voices National Youth Poetry Slam in Washington. Among those hoping to be heard: B. Yung, a Brooklynite who says he has a ''fire in my chest''; Britney, a New Yorker who fearlessly speaks out, despite having cerebral palsy; Jasmine, who struggles with the debilitating effects of sickle cell anemia; and April, a member of the Navajo tribe who seeks to preserve her culture through words. Above, a scene from the show. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS Dr. Susan E. Rice, United States Ambassador to the United Nations, is the guest.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (ABC) THE BACHELORETTE Jillian Harris, who wound up third in the heart of Jason Mesnick in the last edition of ''The Bachelor'' -- and who, after all the Melissa Rycroft-Molly Malaney back and forth, probably feels that she came out on top -- gives love another go. In a twist she gets 30 potential suitors rather than the usual 25, the better to find someone who can make up his mind, we're guessing. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Caroline Kennedy, Lisa Rinna, and John Walsh are guests. A segment looks at home predators.

headline: I'm Honored. No, Actually, I Can't Afford It.
summary: WHEN Terry J. Lundgren, the chief executive of Macy's, received Carnegie Hall's Medal of Excellence in April 2008, he beamed with pride. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg presented the award, which goes to a business leader who supports the arts. More than 1,000 guests, including Martha Stewart, Leonard Lauder and Tommy Hilfiger, cheered from their tables in the Waldorf-Astoria's Grand Ballroom. Tony Bennett sang his heart out. And Carnegie Hall raised $4.2 million. But when it came time to select an honoree for this year's medal, Carnegie Hall's board and management were stumped. They canceled the benefit.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9:30 P.M. (ABC) BETTER OFF TED This Season 2 premiere finds Veridian Dynamics trying to pair off its employees based on their genetic compatibility in the hope of saving on health insurance bills resulting from imperfectly bred children. Ted and Linda (Jay Harrington and Andrea Anders, right) think it's a lousy idea -- until they meet their matches, Danielle (Virginia Williams) and Greg (Taye Diggs). Meanwhile, Veronica (Portia de Rossi) learns that Lem (Malcolm Barrett) is supposedly the man for her and urges him to make a donation to a sperm bank. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Matt Lauer and Al Roker report live from Kabul, Afghanistan, Tuesday and Wednesday.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths SANDO, STEVE
summary: SANDO--Steve, passed away suddenly December 23. He was just 48 years old. Steve's television career began in the Midwest after playing football at North Dakota State. His incredible talent and personality eventually brought him to New York, where he was head of operations for WCBS-TV. He moved on to CBS News, where he ran operations for Special Events, Europe and Washington. Steve nurtured field crews, editors and anchors, and lived for the big event. Whether it was Moscow, Gaza, Mogadishu, Kuwait, Kosovo, Haiti, Steve got you on the air .... anytime, everytime and from anywhere. Upon leaving CBS he took the freelance production world by storm. But that was just the resume. Steve was unique. Always bigger than life, brilliant, passionate, musical, deeply loyal and the funniest guy we knew. If we weren't so sad, he'd still have us laughing. Steve leaves behind a mother, brother and sister --all in the Seattle area --and friends everywhere he went. Steve was a great partner and will be missed by all lucky enough to have known him. Eric Ober, Jamie Stolz, Lane Venardos

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (Showtime) A BRONX DREAM Thirty-two children from an impoverished school district in the Bronx learn about Irish dance, language and culture. Then they make their first trip outside of the United States to visit Ireland. And they perform for its president. This documentary follows the fancy footwork of the students, including these girls, above. 8 P.M. (CBS) NCIS The death of a boxer leads Vance (Rocky Carroll, right) to begin his own investigation, and soon enough Gibbs (Mark Harmon) has his dukes up. The episode features the song ''Nasty Little Perv'' by Perry Farrell. Paula Newsome and Obba Babatundé are guest stars.

headline: Championship Ratings Are Lower
summary: North Carolina's 89-72 victory over Michigan State to win the N.C.A.A. men's basketball championship Monday night on CBS generated a 10.8 rating, 11 percent below last year's, and the lowest rating for the event recorded by Nielsen Media. The game's average viewership of 17.6 million fell 10 percent from last year, and was the third lowest ever. The full tournament produced a 5.7 rating, up from 5.6 last year. Pittsburgh Coach Jamie Dixon has been named the Naismith men's coach of the year after leading the Panthers to a university-record 31 victories and the N.C.A.A. tournament's Round of 8. Dixon, in his sixth year as coach, guided Pittsburgh to its first top seed in the tournament and its first No. 1 ranking in the Associated Press top 25. dixon (AP)

headline: Glassware That Is Cheaper By the Dozen
summary: DO newlyweds really need expensive wine glasses that, because of fear of breakage, probably will never leave the cupboard? In fact most couples (and their guests as well), would be better served by inexpensive stemware and tumblers by the dozen. There is plenty of well-priced glassware -- clear and colored -- to set stylish tables and stock bars that will serve a crowd.

headline: Soothing or Salting Wounds From Election 2000
summary: ''Every vote counts'' is one of those platitudes, like ''Watch your step,'' that doesn't have much meaning until that first really bad fall. It certainly had resonance in the 2000 presidential election, when the Florida voting ended in a hairline finish that took 36 days and a Supreme Court decision to resolve. It was historic and historically awful, until the Sept. 11 attacks wiped away much of the anguish and slapstick. For a while, at least, the Florida vote count seemed as trivial and irrelevant as the results of the Henley Regatta after August 1914.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (13, 49) SECRETS OF SHANGRI-LA Two National Geographic reports present journeys to the remote kingdom of Mustang, between Nepal and Tibet, where mysterious, hand-carved caves high in the Himalayas have long shrouded glorious treasures, like hand-inked Tibetan folio pages, above, and ancient human remains. In this first entry the mountaineer Peter Athans leads an expedition of climbers, archaeologists, anthropologists and art historians on a mission to rescue valuable Tibetan texts from their deteriorating shelter before looters find them. A confrontation results, involving a political group from a nearby village, the king of Mustang and even the rights of the divinities that are believed to inhabit the area. In ''Lost Cave Temples of the Himalaya,'' at 9, Liesel Clark chronicles the 2007 expedition of Mr. Athans, who is her husband, and the big-wall climber Renan Ozturk as they maneuvered into the crumbling caves, where each vertical move was a step into a lost world unoccupied for hundreds, if not thousands, of years. 9:45 A.M. (Fox Business Network) FOX BUSINESS Jenna Lee reports on the newest products and services at the 2009 Streaming Media West show in San Jose, Calif. Marc Whitten, general manager of Xbox Live; Tim Harader, senior product manager of Microsoft Silverlight; and Anthony Wood, founder and chief executive of Roku, are interviewed.

headline: What's on Today
summary: 8 P.M. (13) SHAKESPEARE ON THE HUDSON The drama at the Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival is often as much offstage as on. This documentary journeys to Boscobel, a 19th-century estate in Garrison, N.Y., to follow the preparations for ''Twelfth Night'' from auditions and call-backs to the final moments before the opening-night performance. Interviews with the cast members Maia Guest, Paul Bates, Wesley Mann (above, with Gabra Zackman) and Max Polski are interspersed with rehearsal footage; Kristin Chenoweth is host. The production itself will be shown in ''Twelfth Night: The Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival'' at 9. 8 P.M. (CW) SMALLVILLE As they search for Clark (Tom Welling) in this Season 8 opener, members of the Justice League run up against Tess Mercer (Cassidy Freeman), the new chief executive of Luthorcorp. Meanwhile Chloe (Allison Mack) is held prisoner by a group that has discovered her powers while Clark has been relieved of his by Jor-El (Terence Stamp).

headline: Joost, Struggling, Reinvents Itself Again
summary: Joost, an online video company, is starting over with a new service and business model, the third in three years. The company, which will continue to offer free television shows and movies online, announced last week that it would shift its energies to providing an online video platform that other media companies could use -- essentially licensing its technology to broadcasters and other media companies that want to offer video on their sites.

headline: Drake Loses Its Appetite After a Loss
summary: About a dozen pizza boxes were stacked on a table in the Drake locker room, a perfect meal for a college victory party. Nobody felt like eating, though, in the wake of a stunning 101-99 overtime loss to Western Kentucky on Friday. ''It's just tough, after all that, getting beat by a buzzer-beater,'' Drake guard Leonard Houston said.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 8 P.M. (Fox) BONES The series moves into a new time slot with back-to-back episodes. In the first, Brennan (Emily Deschanel) and Booth (David Boreanaz) join a circus as a knife-throwing act to uncover the killer of conjoined twins. The suspects include the ringmaster (Andy Richter, above), a strong man and some rather devious clowns. At 9, Booth becomes a suspect in the murder of a hockey player with whom he had come to fisticuffs in the past, and Brennan gets a new F.B.I. partner (Marisa Coughlan) to help with the case. The former N.H.L. star Luc Robitaille appears as himself. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Emily Post's great-great-granddaughter discusses wedding etiquette. Other segments look at Academy Award nominees and Air Force One.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (Bravo) FIRST CLASS ALL THE WAY Partridge hunting, anyone? Flying in the face of the economic meltdown, this new series is an exercise in excess. Sara Ryan Duffy, right, recently crowned an A-list travel agent by Travel & Leisure magazine, fulfills the outrageous demands of her well-heeled clients, starting by sending five wealthy, presumably real housewives (it's Bravo, after all) to Monaco for a private tour of that royal family's art collection and a meeting with Albert II, Prince of Monaco. Watch it and weep. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY A final election poll, and Darrell Hammond and Fred Armisen of ''Saturday Night Live'' do their thing.

headline: Let's Go to the Videogame
summary: It was no iPhone line, but 40 or so fans of the Madden video game franchise lined the sidewalk outside Game Stop in Manhattan's Herald Square on Thursday, awaiting the release of the latest Madden game at midnight. From 10-year-old boys to 43-year-old doctors to gift-giving girlfriends, each future Madden 10 owner had a rationale for braving the cool summer night, be it a sentimental tie to the game or a competitive edge.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths O'Connell, Ted
summary: O'CONNELL--Ted. Died of cancer at his home December 23. Ted was a CBS executive for 36 years, retiring in 1988 as VP Affiliate Relations. He is survived by his wife Molly King-O'Connell and children Jessie, Amy, and Ted. Memorial service Saturday, January 19, at 2pm, St. Michael's Church, Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society.

headline: Reinventing TV As Viewers Reinvent Life
summary: DURING a recent evening shoot the wardrobe trailer for ''The Good Wife'' on CBS sat outside a courthouse in Jamaica, Queens. The clothes in it were trial-ready: sober, simple and uniformly dark. ''My biggest challenge on this show is black,'' Daniel Lawson, the show's costume designer, said with a sigh. A year ago Mr. Lawson was dressing the leads on ''Lipstick Jungle'' for their stiletto-stomping adventures in the glittering precincts of Manhattan. ''On that show, it was all about the clothes,'' he said. ''They wore sequins at home. Who wears sequins at home?''

headline: For Lease
summary: $75/sq. ft.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (Fox) GORDON RAMSAY: COOKALONG LIVE Now you, too, can cook with Chef Ramsay -- in the safety of your own home. In this hourlong special Mr. Ramsay, above, slices and dices his way through a three-course meal while offering step-by-step instructions, presumably without his infamous tirades. The menu features angel-hair pasta with shrimp, chili peppers and tomatoes; steak Diane with sautéed potatoes and peas; and tiramisu. A list of the required ingredients, utensils and cookware is at fox.com/cookalong. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Anna Kendrick (featured in ''The Twilight Saga: New Moon'' and ''Up in the Air'') and Julian Lennon are guests.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (Planet Green) LIVING WITH ED All Ed Begley Jr. wants for his 60th birthday is free time in which to tinker with his new wind turbine. His wife, Rachelle, has other ideas. While Mr. Begley (above, with his wife and daughter) is off giving a speech on environmentally conscious living, Ms. Begley is plotting a surprise. So what does hubby discover when he returns home from his tour and a side trip to Jay Leno's garage? A birthday party -- with fancy cake and vegan menu -- for 300 of the Begleys' closest friends, including Jeff Garlin, Sharon Lawrence and the governor of California. 7 A.M. (ABC) GOOD MORNING AMERICA Catherine Zeta-Jones and Angela Lansbury talk about their roles in the Broadway revival of ''A Little Night Music''; Barbara Walters previews her list of the year's most fascinating people (see below). Ms. Zeta-Jones moves over to ''Live With Regis and Kelly'' at 9.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (Discovery) GLOBAL WARMING: THE NEW CHALLENGE WITH TOM BROKAW In this follow-up to his Emmy Award-winning 2006 program, ''Global Warming: What You Need to Know With Tom Brokaw,'' Mr. Brokaw (above right, with Michael Oppenheimer, a climate scientist), interviews experts about what Americans should be prepared for in the coming years and how climate change is shaping the inner workings of the nation, from New York City to Yellowstone National Park and the Everglades. The program also looks at promising scientific, technological and economic advances in the fight against global warming. 11 A.M. (NBC) THE MARTHA STEWART SHOW It's dogs today with Martha. There will be a dog show and new pet products, and training questions will be answered.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths NOLL, MAESTRO RONALD W.
summary: NOLL--Maestro Ronald W. , 78, a retired Emmy Awardwinning Music Supervisor with CBS-TV, and Conductor and Music Director, Pianist spanning 50 years for the Village Light Opera Group, died January 15th at Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck, NJ, of complications from Diabetes and Heart Disease. He is survived by his loving wife, Sara Ann Noll, devoted daughter, Christiane Noll, and son-inlaw, Jamie LaVerdiere. A memorial concert will be held in the spring in NYC celebrating his life and music. Memorials may be sent to The Ronald W. Noll Music Foundation, c/o Bartolomei Pucciarelli, LLC, 2564 Brunswick Pike, Lawrenceville, NJ 08648.

headline: Defining Network Success Downward
summary: Over the last three decades, the most popular sitcoms or dramas of each season have reached an ever-smaller audience. 1978-79 ''All In The Family'' (CBS); Rating: 30.5*

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. and 11:30 P.M. (ABC) DICK CLARK'S NEW YEAR'S ROCKIN' EVE WITH RYAN SEACREST 2010 Dick Clark and Ryan Seacrest host the annual New Year's Eve party in New York with performances in Times Square by Jennifer Lopez and Daughtry. In Las Vegas, Fergie picks up hosting duties with live performances there by the Black Eyed Peas, Selena Gomez, Justin Bieber, Keri Hilson, Colbie Caillat, Robin Thicke and Orianthi. (Above, from left, Fergie, Mr. Clark and Mr. Seacrest.) The programming runs from 10 to 11 p.m., then picks back up at 11:30 in time for Mr. Clark to count down the last few seconds of the year as usual. Performances continue from both cities well past midnight. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Topics include financial and fitness resolutions for the new year as well as beauty tips.

headline: News Summary
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 Bush Urges Anti-Iran Unity

headline: Clemens Plans to Present His Side
summary: Roger Clemens, who has essentially made himself unavailable to reporters since he testified before Congress in February 2008, is scheduled to be interviewed on ESPN's ''Mike & Mike in the Morning'' on Tuesday, the show said in a statement. Shortly after the Mitchell report was released in December 2007, Clemens was interviewed by Mike Wallace on CBS's ''60 Minutes.'' In that interview Clemens adamantly denied the assertions in the report by his former trainer Brian McNamee that Clemens had used steroids on numerous occasions from 1998 to 2001. In February 2008, Clemens and McNamee testified before the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform and, after Clemens's testimony contradicted that of McNamee, the committee asked the Justice Department to investigate Clemens for perjury. Since then, Clemens has said little publicly.

headline: Unsettled Ground
summary: Despite Senator Barack Obama's strong showing in recent primaries, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton continues to hold onto more support from superdelegates, the Democratic Party elites, according to a survey by The New York Times and CBS News. The current count is 189.5 superdelegate votes for Mrs. Clinton and 142.5 for Mr. Obama. But in a similar survey conducted last month, Mrs. Clinton led Mr. Obama by 204 to 99. About 8 percent of the total 795 superdelegates changed their minds over the last few weeks, as many states held their primaries and caucuses. Few delegates switched allegiance from one candidate to the other; the main changes were among the undecided delegates. Among the previously undecided delegates who now are endorsing a candidate, Mr. Obama got more of their support. Some of Mrs. Clinton's previous supporters are now undecided.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths LYONS, JOSEPHINE
summary: LYONS--Josephine, died on April 5, 2009. We honor the memory of Josephine Lyons, a girl from Cincinnati who came to New York in her twenties, stayed at the Barbizon, became a Miss Subways, produced (famously) for NBC news, worked for Arthur Godfrey, CBS, Benton & Boles, Ted Bates, Kenyon & Eckhardt, and covered presidential conventions for radio news. A unique and amazing character, Jo adored theater, museums, and great restaurants, and introduced her nephews and nieces to the arts and culture of the city. She was a good friend of the International Center for Photography, a member of the Coffee House and the Overseas Press Club, and a founding member of New York Women in Film. An enthusiastic traveler, Jo had friends in the great cities of the world. A lifelong democrat, Jo fundraised for Hillary Clinton. Jo was loved by many friends and family members who will carry on her torch. A remembrance party will be held on May 23 in New York City. For information -- jolyonsservice@gmail.com

headline: Obama Speaks at Cronkite Memorial
summary: President Obama spoke at a memorial service honoring Walter Cronkite, the CBS news anchor who died in July. Video by NBC.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: LEAVING HIS LEGACY Friday is Bill Gates's last day at Microsoft, marking the unofficial end of his career as a leader of the business he co-founded in 1975. STOCKS TUMBLE The abrupt reversal in the stock market reflects the realization among investors that the troubles plaguing the economy may be worse than initially feared. [C1.]

headline: Obama's Busy Week | Sept. 20-26
summary: THE NEWS Seeking to reclaim the health care debate, President Obama appeared on five morning TV talk shows on Sunday. BEHIND THE NEWS The interviews, taped the previous Friday, underscored Mr. Obama's decision to move forward on health care with -- or without -- Republicans. ''What I'm trying to do is explain the facts, which are if we don't do anything, a lot of Americans are going to be much worse off,'' he said. On Monday, he went on the ''Late Show'' with David Letterman, trading jokes but also discussing issues. He left with a heart-shaped potato, a gift from an audience member. ''This is remarkable,'' he said.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (ABC) DESPERATE HOUSEWIVES In the wake of a plane crash, the women contemplate how their choices have affected their lives. Susan (Teri Hatcher) imagines a life with Karl (Richard Burgi), and Bree (Marcia Cross) imagines a life without Orson (Kyle MacLachlan). Lynette (Felicity Huffman) wonders about her future with twins, and Carlos (Ricardo Antonio Chavira) pictures Gaby (Eva Longoria Parker) as a mom. Gloria Garayua, above, is featured. 10 A.M. (FOX) FOX NEWS SUNDAY WITH CHRIS WALLACE Mr. Wallace will speak with John Brennan, assistant to the president for homeland security and counterterrorism, and Senator Christopher S. Bond, Republican of Missouri, about the future of American counterterrorism initiatives and Northwest Flight 253 to Detroit.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (NBC) THE BIGGEST LOSER The series prepares to top itself in this Season 9 premiere, in which the heaviest contestants ever are subjected to cringe-inducing public weigh-ins in their hometowns. Then it's off to the weight-loss ranch, where each team of two must log 26.2 miles on stationary bicycles before a surprise twist raises the ante, and the first player is eliminated. Bob Harper, above right (with Darrell, a contestant), and Jillian Michaels return as the trainers without mercy; Alison Sweeney hosts. Ms. Michaels also appears alongside Kim Kardashian on ''The Jay Leno Show'' at 10. 11 A.M. (ABC) THE VIEW The women chat with Maggie Gyllenhaal about her latest film, ''Crazy Heart''; Mary J. Blige performs.

headline: What's On TODAY
summary: 10 P.M. (Logo) SHIRTS & SKINS The Rockdogs, above, a San Francisco basketball team, won the gold medal at the 2006 Gay Games but then disbanded. Now the founders have rallied the former members to defend their title at the National Gay Basketball Championship in Chicago. This new series checks in a month before the tournament as teammates get to know one another again both on and off the court. The competition from their first challengers, a team from the San Francisco Fire Department, is fierce. But things turn even more heated when Rory, a 29-year-old forward, and Jamel, a 24-year-old swing man, get into a debate about whether being gay is a choice. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOWLynne Cheney discusses her latest book, ''We the People.'' Also, nannies reveal what they really think about their jobs and employers.

headline: What's on Tonight
summary: 8 P.M. (Sundance) MARC JACOBS & LOUIS VUITTON Fashion critics agree that Marc Jacobs -- at 44, the creative force behind both his own American line and the French house of Louis Vuitton -- may well be the most influential designer of his generation. This documentary by Loïc Prigent follows Mr. Jacobs, above, as he works on his spring 2007 ready-to-wear collections for the two labels and finds connections between such disparate themes as cookies and Cubism. The film is part of ''Ready to Watch,'' a six-night salute to Fashion Week; highlights include ''Karl Lagerfeld Is Never Happy Anyway,'' a profile of the Chanel designer, at 7:30 on Wednesday, and ''Yves Saint Laurent: 5 Avenue Marceau 75116 Paris,'' which trails the designer around his atelier for eight weeks, at 7:30 on Thursday. 7 P.M. (Food Network) EMERIL LIVE The singer John Boutté joins Emeril Lagasse in the kitchen for a meal of New Orleans classics, including ''debris'' po' boys and Creole white beans with shrimp. In ''Anthony Bourdain: No Reservations'' at 10 on the Travel Channel Mr. Bourdain gnaws his way through the same city.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (Fox) HOUSEMos Def, above, plays a man injured in a bicycle accident who now has locked-in syndrome and is unable to move or speak. He can hear his doctor, though, who concludes that he is brain dead and discusses organ donation. Luckily House (Hugh Laurie) is in the next bed after his own accident. 8 P.M. (CBS) THE BIG BANG THEORY Penny (Kaley Cuoco) feels threatened by a new, and attractive, female neighbor.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: HELPING THE UNINSURED Many states and Congress are beginning to address ways to ease the high costs of health insurance for small-business owners and their workers. BOEING BACK IN PLAY The Department of Defense said it would reopen a $35 billion contract to build midair refueling tankers, giving Boeing a second chance to beat its rivals. [C1.]

headline: Support for the Public Option
summary: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll found solid support for a government-run insurance plan, or so-called public option, that would compete with private insurers. Other surveys have found similar results. But what the public seems to prefer and what Congress plans to give them may not be the same thing.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths MILLER, SCOTT
summary: MILLER--Scott. We mourn the passing of our friend Scott Miller. Scott was a gifted professional and trusted colleague, who in a short period of time, had built close bonds with our people across the country. He was a warm, outgoing, helpful human being who was always willing to lend a hand and approached every challenge with enthusiasm. We offer our condolences to his wife, Evelyn; their three children; his parents, Ed and Carole, and the entire Miller Family. Scott's passing has left a void in our hearts. CB Richard Ellis Group, Inc.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) YES, VIRGINIA After a playground bully spoils her illusion, 8-year-old Virginia O'Hanlon heads to New York City with her friend Ollie to search for verification that Santa Claus does exist. Her exploration inspires her to write a letter, above, to The New York Sun, where, after a little persuasion, the editor Frances P. Church responds with the answer, ''Yes, Virginia, there is a Santa Claus,'' in what was to become one of the most famous newspaper editorials ever written. This animated tale, featuring the voices of Jennifer Love Hewitt, Neil Patrick Harris and Alfred Molina, is inspired by the holiday story from 1897. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY It's a day of divas, with a performance by Aretha Franklin here; Jennifer Hudson on ''Good Morning America,'' at 7 on ABC; and Angie Stone on ''The Wendy Williams Show,'' at 10 on Fox, 10 p.m. on MyNetworkTV and midnight on BET.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths RAUCHENBERGER, LOUIS J.
summary: RAUCHENBERGER--Louis J.,passed away on Sunday, November 22, 2009 at the age of 79. He is survived by his wife Elaine, and their six children Mary, Louis, Rich, John Stephen and Catherine as well as ten beautiful grandchildren. Lou served in the Navy during the Korean War. He was the Treasurer of CBS when he retired after 35 years of service. Louis and Elaine had recently celebrated their 50th wedding anniversary. Reposing will be at the Doyle B. Shaffer Inc. Funeral Home, Little Neck Pkwy. at Northern Blvd., Little Neck, NY on Tuesday 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial on Wednesday, 9:45am at St. Anastasia Church, Douglaston, NY. Interment at St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths RAUCHENBERGER, LOUIS
summary: RAUCHENBERGER--Louis J., passed away on Sunday, November 22, 2009 at the age of 79. He is survived by his wife Elaine, and their six children Mary, Louis, Rich, John Stephen and Catherine as well as ten beautiful grandchildren. Lou served in the Navy during the Korean War. He was the Treasurer of CBS when he retired after 35 years of service. Louis and Elaine had recently celebrated their 50th wedding anniversary. Reposing will be at the Doyle B. Shaffer Inc. Funeral Home, Little Neck Pkwy. at Northern Blvd., Little Neck, NY on Tuesday 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial on Wednesday, 9:45am at St. Anastasia Church, Douglaston, NY. Interment at St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (HBO) FLIGHT OF THE CONCHORDS Bret (Bret McKenzie, left) and Jemaine (Jemaine Clement, right) are forced to move in with their No. 1 (and only?) fan, Mel (Kristen Schaal), and her husband, Doug (David Costabile), in this season's finale. And their hapless manager, Murray (Rhys Darby), tries to make money off the Conchords' adventures with a stage play. 10:30 A.M. (NBC) MEET THE PRESS Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York City, Gov. Edward G. Rendell of Pennsylvania, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California and Tom Brokaw are among the guests.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: WALL ST. IN A SPIN The stock market experienced its worst day in nearly a year after a business survey provided another sign that the United States might be heading into a recession. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 370 points. [C1.] THE POSITIVE SIDE OF SEEING RED A year after the rock star Bono, below, started Red, a campaign that combined consumerism and altruism, consumers have generated more than $22 million to fight H.I.V. and AIDS in Rwanda. But some say the campaign is more marketing than charity. [C1.]

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths WALLACE, WARREN
summary: WALLACE--Warren, 85, born in Bad Axe, Michigan, 8 July 1922. Died, New York City, 11 February 2008. Educated at Amherst College, St. Andrews University and Trinity College, Cambridge. Writer and producer of radio programs for Voice of America and BBC. Writer and director of documentaries for CBS, ABC, NBC and PBS. Won numerous awards, including several Emmys. His fictionalized memoir, Up Home, was published in the O. Henry Best Short Stories of l987. Predeceased by his first wife, Catherine, and a daughter, Sarah Cogan. Survived by three daughters and their husbands: Rebecca and Michael Fass; Amelia and Neil Mendoza; Lucy and John Eustice; and by his grandchildren, Sarah and Aaron Hiatt; Daniel Fass; Alfred and Violet Mendoza; Pearl and George Eustice. He is also survived by his son-in-law Marc Cogan; his ex-wife Doris Gruber; and his companion Carol F. Lewine. He lived the life he wanted.

headline: Recession Anxiety Seeps Into Everyday Lives
summary: Anne Hubbard has not lost her job, house or savings, and she and her husband have always been conservative with money. But a few months ago, Ms. Hubbard, a graphic designer in Cambridge, Mass., began having panic attacks over the economy, struggling to breathe and seeing vivid visions of ''losing everything,'' she said.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths Wallace, Warren
summary: WALLACE--Warren, 85, born in Bad Axe, Michigan, 8 July 1922. Died, New York City, 11 February 2008. Educated at Amherst College, St. Andrews University and Trinity College, Cambridge. Writer and producer of radio programs for Voice of America and BBC. Writer and director of documentaries for CBS, ABC, NBC and PBS. Won numerous awards, including several Emmys. His fictionalized memoir, Up Home, was published in the O. Henry Best Short Stories of l987. Predeceased by his first wife, Catherine, and a daughter, Sarah Cogan. Survived by three daughters and their husbands: Rebecca and Michael Fass; Amelia and Neil Mendoza; Lucy and John Eustice; and by his grandchildren, Sarah and Aaron Hiatt; Daniel Fass; Alfred and Violet Mendoza; Pearl and George Eustice. He is also survived by his son-in-law Marc Cogan; his ex-wife Doris Gruber; and his companion Carol F. Lewine. He lived the life he wanted.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (13); 9 P.M. (49) MEDAL OF HONOR Dating from the Civil War, the Medal of Honor -- the highest United States award for valor in combat -- is presented to soldiers for service ''above and beyond the call of duty.'' Only 3,473 medals have been awarded, and since the Vietnam War just seven have been given, all posthumously. This program tells the stories of 13 recipients, including Sgt. Paul Smith, above, the first soldier to receive a Medal of Honor in the Iraq war; Sgt. Alvin York, portrayed by Gary Cooper in the 1941 film ''Sergeant York''; and Gen. Smedley D. Butler, one of only 17 to receive the medal twice. Butler, who served in every conflict from the Spanish-American War through World War I, eventually became an outspoken critic of the American military's interventionist policies. He tried to return his medal for service in Vera Cruz, Mexico, but his superiors ordered him to keep it. 11 A.M. (ABC) THE VIEW Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is the guest.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (CW) GOSSIP GIRL Blair (Leighton Meester, above) is devastated by recent changes and reacts by embarking on a wild lifestyle, which seriously concerns Serena (Blake Lively) and Chuck (Ed Westwick). Vanessa (Jessica Szohr) tries to persuade Nate (Chace Crawford) to forgive his mother's relatives, who abandoned Nate and his mother when they needed them most. And with the silly idea of being completely honest, Lily (Kelly Rutherford) and Rufus (Matthew Settle) agree to make lists of their past lovers. 8 P.M. (ABC Family) THE SECRET LIFE OF THE AMERICAN TEENAGER In the season finale Amy (Shailene Woodley) finally has her baby. At the hospital the father, Ricky (Daren Kagasoff), and the future stepfather, Ben (Ken Baumann), decide to become friends.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (Comedy Central) FUTURAMA: THE BEAST WITH A BILLION BACKS Billy West lends his voice to Philip J. Fry, the 25-year-old pizza delivery man who accidentally freezes himself on Dec. 31, 1999, and wakes up 1,000 years later, in a new two-hour installment of this Emmy Award-winning animated series. Fry and his friends, including Turanga LeeLa (Katey Sagal), the tough but tender one-eyed alien, and Bender (John DiMaggio), the angry robot, discover a giant hole in the universe and an alluring alien on the other side. And then Bender takes up with the League of Robots and plots to take over Earth. Above, a scene from the show. 10:30 A.M. (CBS) FACE THE NATION The topic is battleground states; the guests are Gov. Tim Kaine of Virginia; Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz, Democrat of Florida; Gov. Matt Blunt, Republican of Missouri; and former Representative Rob Portman, Republican of Ohio.

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 9 P.M. (CBS) BIG BROTHER Sixteen teammates, above, submit to around-the-clock surveillance in this series's ninth installment -- and its first nonsummer season, thanks to the writers' strike -- which will be seen three times a week: Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Sundays. Julie Chen is host. Showtime 2 will continue to broadcast ''Big Brother: After Dark,'' the slightly naughtier, uncensored companion series, nightly between midnight and 3 a.m. 8 P.M. (13) ASTROSPIES ''Nova'' reports on the clandestine American effort in the 1960s to develop a manned space program that would carry out military intelligence, and talks to some of the men who were trained in secret to be military astronauts but never went into space.

headline: Inside the Times, February 27, 2009
summary: International BISHOP ISSUES APOLOGY

headline: 'Sunday Night' Is No. 1
summary: NBC's ''Sunday Night Football'' has achieved what ABC's ''Monday Night Football'' never did, even in the 1970s: it is the No. 1 program in prime time. For now. It will almost certainly lose the race after the season ends and Fox's ''American Idol'' returns to the air in January. Through 10 weeks, ''Sunday Night'' viewership (19.8 million), household rating (12.0) and all key demographic ratings placed it at No. 1. The numbers are slightly less dominating for the TV season, which began on Sept. 21 and excluded NBC's first three games. By that calculation, ''Sunday Night'' is No. 1 in the critical adult 18-49 demographic but second to CBS's ''NCIS'' in ratings and viewership. RICHARD SANDOMIR

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (Starz) RACHEL GETTING MARRIED (2008) Rachel (Rosemarie DeWitt, above right, with Anne Hathaway) may be the one getting married, but the film is mostly about her younger sister, Kym (Ms. Hathaway). A model who has been furloughed from rehab for the occasion, Kym arrives ''at her father's rambling Connecticut clapboard house on a toxic cloud of snark, cigarette smoke and wounded narcissism,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, summing her up as ''a bottomless repository of guilt, destructiveness and general bad feeling.'' Soon, simmering tensions boil over. Bill Irwin plays the father whose attention Kym always seems to deflect from Rachel; Debra Winger is the mother who has never quite come to terms with Kym's past. Mr. Scott added that while this film from Jonathan Demme may have its faults, it is ''so persuasively forgiving of the flaws of its inhabitants that you can only respond, in like spirit, with love.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Kim Lawton chronicles the tradition of the Festival of Lessons and Carols; also, a look at the House, an after-school refuge for poor urban high school students in Washington.

headline: THE WEEK AHEAD | APRIL 19-25
summary: Television Ginia Bellafante

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 8 P.M. (ABC) LOST The series gears up for another adventure with this hourlong primer recapping the island's mysteries and inhabitants from the first four seasons. In the Season 5 premiere, at 9, Jack (Matthew Fox, above left) and Ben (Michael Emerson, above right) prepare to reunite the Oceanic 6 for their return to the island -- with Locke's body -- and the rescue of the remaining survivors. But -- surprise, surprise -- unknown forces lurk. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Highlights from the inauguration of President Obama.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (13) TOSCA ''Great Performances at the Met'' begins its fourth season with Luc Bondy's controversial staging of this Puccini opera, starring Karita Mattila, left, in her debut as the prima donna of the title; Marcelo Álvarez as her hot-headed lover, the painter Cavaradossi; and George Gagnidze as Baron Scarpia, the twisted chief of police. Paul Plishka rounds out the cast as Sacristan; Joseph Colaneri conducts. When the opera had its premiere on Sept. 21, Anthony Tommasini, in The New York Times, noted that Mr. Bondy and the production team were jeered when they came out at curtain calls, while Ms. Mattila and Mr. Álvarez received enormous ovations. ''Still, the booing, if a little unfair, was understandable,'' he wrote of the production, which replaces Franco Zeffirelli's from 1985. ''Mr. Bondy's high-concept staging featured stark, spare, cold sets and dispensed entirely with many of the familiar theatrical touches that audiences count on: Tosca placed no candles by the body of the villain Scarpia after murdering him, and did not exactly leap to her death at the end. Mr. Bondy had scoured the work, it seemed, looking for every pretense to flesh out, literally, the eroticism of the lovers and the lecherous kinkiness of Scarpia.'' 10 A.M. (ABC) RACHAEL RAY Aretha Franklin whips up a holiday dish and performs.

headline: ON NYTIMES.COM
summary: Kentucky's Spelunker Bliss Mammoth Cave National Park in Kentucky offers a journey into the history of the native people who explored its caves 4,000 years ago. Cavers are still discovering the unknown in the park's roughly 367 miles of tunnels, adding a mile or two to the underground maps each year.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (MTV) 50 CENT: THE MONEY AND THE POWER The rapper 50 Cent, above, commits to investing some big-time change -- $100,000 -- in the future of an aspiring entrepreneur in this new competition series. But first the 14 contestants have to endure a kind of boot camp and compete in challenges, starting with a five-mile run ending at Camp Curtis, the Brooklyn warehouse that is their home away from home. The winners are invited to a barbecue with the big guy; the losers have to build the winners' beds and then sleep on cots. 9 A.M. (CBS) THE DOCTORS An allergist describes the latest methods of testing and treatment, and offers tips for keeping a home allergen free. Also, near-death experiences and tummy tucks.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths ISHAM, HEYWARD
summary: ISHAM--Heyward, died June 18 of cardiac arrest, at 82 years of age. Mr. Isham was born in New York City, attended Phillips Academy, earned his BA from Yale and studied at Columbia University's Russian institute in Garmisch, Germany. Mr. Isham had a long and distinguished career in the U.S. State Department, beginning in 1950 with the U.S. Mission in Berlin serving under U.S. High Commissioner John McCloy and rising to Ambassador to Haiti and Assistant Secretary of State and Director of the Office for Combating Terrorism. Mr. Isham also served in the US Embassy in Moscow under Ambassador Charles Bohlen, during the height of the Cold War and US Consulate in Hong Kong where he was one of the first to recognize the emerging Sino-Soviet rift. In 1971-1972 Mr. Isham served as Deputy and Chief of the US Delegation to the Paris Talks on Vietnam negotiating directly with the North Vietnamese which resulted in the Paris Peace Accords signed on January 17, 1973 ending more than 10 years of direct US military involvement in Vietnam. Secretary of State, Henry Kissinger said of Mr. Isham's work, "He made a tremendous contribution." In retirement Mr. Isham became a senior editor at Doubleday publishing the memoirs of Andrei Gromyko, Soviet Foreign Minister during the more tense time of the cold war and authored two important books in 1995 and in 2001 introducing new Russian writers to the world. In 1990 Mr. Isham became Vice President and Ambassador-in-Residence at the East-West Institute in New York. For the past 15 years, the Ishams' principal home has been in Sagapon- ack where he was a known and loved member of the community. Mr. Isham is survived by his wife of 59 years, the noted artist Sheila Eaton Isham, and two sons Christopher E. Isham, Vice President and Washington Bureau Chief for CBS News, and Ralph H. Isham, Managing Partner, GH Venture Partners, LLC in New York City and nine grandchildren. His daughter Sandra Isham Vreeland died in 1996. In lieu of flowers please send donations to Hopital Albert Schweitzer Haiti, PO Box 81046, Pittsburgh, PA 15217 or visit: www.hashaiti.org

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths LISTER, WALTER
summary: LISTER--Walter, of Larchmont, NY, newspaper man with the New York Herald Tribune for 17 years and producer with CBS News for 25 years passed away on December 30, 2009. Beloved husband of Marion, loving father of Wendy Root, cherished grandfather of Megan, Griffin, Kyle and Lindsay, dear brother of Peter and John. Funeral service Tuesday, January 5, 2010, 1pm at Larchmont Ave. Church, 60 Forest Park Ave., Larchmont, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be in Walter Lister's name to the CUNY Graduate School of Journalism Student Scholarship Fund, 219 W. 40 St., New York, NY 10018.

headline: Edwards to Clinton: Be Careful
summary: John Edwards, the former senator from North Carolina, has still not endorsed anyone in the Democratic race, but Sunday he cautioned that Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton ''has to be really careful that she's not damaging our prospects'' by staying in the contest against Senator Barack Obama. Appearing on ''Face the Nation'' on CBS, Mr. Edwards said that he saw little chance that Mrs. Clinton could manage a come-from-behind victory.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 9 P.M. (ABC) BOSTON LEGAL Strike up the funeral march. After five seasons this series calls it quits with a two-hour finale, which finds Crane Poole & Schmidt plunged into dire financial straits and forced to contemplate a buyer. Shirley Schmidt (Candice Bergen) and Carl Sack (John Larroquette) plan their nuptials, and Alan Shore (James Spader) heads to the Supreme Court to persuade it to allow Denny Crane (William Shatner, above right, with Mr. Spader) to take an unapproved drug that could slow the rapid progress of his Alzheimer's disease. But Denny has an important question for his friend. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY William Shatner makes the morning show rounds in support of his new talk show, ''Shatner's Raw Nerve.'' At 9 he moves to ''Live With Regis and Kelly'' on ABC. James Spader, Mr. Shatner's ''Boston Legal'' sidekick, appears on ''The Ellen DeGeneres Show'' at 10 a.m. on Channel 55 and 3 p.m. on NBC.

headline: Recent Lease
summary: $18/SQUARE FOOT $77,400 approximate annual rent

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (Discovery) DISCOVERING ARDI ''Ardipithecus is not a chimp,'' says Tim White, a paleontologist with the Human Evolution Research Center at the University of California, Berkeley. ''It's not a human. It's what we used to be.'' And what we used to be, right, was apparently a woodland creature with a small brain, long arms and short legs that could walk but also climb trees, using its long fingers and big toes to grasp like an ape. This two-hour program reports on the 4.4-million-year-old female partial skeleton -- now the oldest remains from the hominid branch of the primate family -- that was discovered in an Ethiopian desert 17 years ago and has opened a new chapter in human evolution. At 11, Paula Zahn hosts ''Understanding Ardi,'' an hourlong panel with members of the research team, including Mr. White, Yohannes Haile-Selassie, Giday WoldeGabriel and Owen Lovejoy, and Ann Gibbons, a science journalist. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH JOHN KING Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, speaks about the awarding of the Nobel Peace Prize to President Obama.

headline: President's Approach To Selling Health Care Becomes More Focused
summary: Last week, President Obama held just one health care event in public, when he stood in the Rose Garden with white-coated doctors from every state. On the dais with him were physicians from Maine, Nebraska, Arkansas and Florida -- all states with senators whom Mr. Obama is courting. ''These states were not picked out of a hat,'' Dan Pfeiffer, deputy director of communications at the White House, said in an interview, laughing.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (VH1) 2009 HIP HOP HONORS Tracy Morgan, below right, hosts this annual ceremony, broadcast from the Brooklyn Academy of Music, which this year salutes the 25-year legacy of Def Jam Recordings and the men who made the label what it is -- among them, Rick Rubin, Russell Simmons, L. A. Reid and Jay-Z. Performers include the artists EPMD, Fabolous, Ghostface Killah, Ludacris, Method Man, Public Enemy, Rick Ross, Scarface, Warren G, Onyx and Redman and the Roots, as well as Ashanti, Eminem, Kid Rock and Mary J. Blige. ''Behind the Music,'' at 8, leads up to the festivities with an overview of the hard-knock life of Curtis Jackson III, a k a 50 Cent. 6 A.M. (Fox News Channel) FOX & FRIENDS The band Foreigner performs live and takes a few questions.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (Fox) LIE TO ME Dr. Cal Lightman (Tim Roth) returns for a second round of deciphering facial expressions and body language to crack cases that law enforcement and government agencies can't. Dr. Gillian Foster (Kelli Williams, above with Mr. Roth) plays Lightman's psychologist partner, who keeps her eye on the bigger picture while he scrutinizes the details. Ria Torres (Monica Raymund), Eli Loker (Brendan Hines) and Agent Ben Reynolds (Mekhi Phifer) of the F.B.I. fill out the team. In this season premiere Lightman tries to figure out whether a woman with multiple personalities (Erika Christensen) is the killer or the witness to a murder. He also delves into what a possible Supreme Court nominee is really thinking. 10 A.M. (ABC) LIVE WITH REGIS AND KELLY All week long, Regis Philbin and Kelly Ripa will announce the winners of the 2009 Relly Awards, which honor the best guests from the show's previous year. Up first: favorite funny guests, selected from Seth Rogen, Jamie Foxx, Craig Ferguson, George Hamilton and, from ''Shrek the Musical,'' Christopher Sieber.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: NEWS MEDIA AND EXONERATIONS As resources in newsrooms have dwindled, opponents of the death penalty say they have been losing an ally in exonerating wrongly accused prisoners. Barry Scheck, above, a founder of the Innocence Project, said the situation was ''extremely troubling.'' ON THE ROAD FOR THE HOLIDAY More Americans are expected to travel by car this Memorial Day weekend than last year, when gas was more than $4 a gallon. The cost is lower this year, but it has been rising rapidly. [B1.]

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) THE BIG BANG THEORY The nerds refuse to take care of Sheldon (Jim Parsons, above, with Kaley Cuoco) while he's sick because he is just an awful patient, so Penny (Ms. Cuoco) is talked into nursing him back to health. At 8:30 on ''How I Met Your Mother,'' a mystery woman sabotages Barney's (Neil Patrick Harris) love life. And at 9 on ''Two and a Half Men,'' Alan (Jon Cryer) dates one of his ex-wife's friends, and Ryan Stiles returns as a guest star. 8 P.M. (13) ANTIQUES ROADSHOW The first of three episodes in Spokane, Wash., will feature an impressive necklace, an aerial map of Spokane and items signed by Abraham Lincoln.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 9 P.M. (CBS) THE GRAMMY NOMINATIONS CONCERT LIVE! COUNTDOWN TO MUSIC'S BIGGEST NIGHT For the first time, nominations for the Grammy Awards in at least six categories will be announced live in prime time, backed by performances from past winners. Celine Dion, Foo Fighters, B. B. King (above), John Mayer, Christina Aguilera, Mariah Carey and Taylor Swift are scheduled to perform at the Nokia Theater in Los Angeles. L L Cool J and Ms. Swift are the hosts. The show also celebrates the opening of the Grammy Museum. The Grammy Awards will be shown on CBS on Feb. 8. 6:30 P.M. (HBO) JACQUES D'AMBOISE IN CHINA: THE OTHER SIDE OF THE WORLD As a principal dancer with New York City Ballet and then as founder of the National Dance Institute, Mr. D'Amboise has inspired countless young people, quite simply, to move. This documentary follows Mr. D'Amboise, children from New York and alumni of the institute as they travel to Shanghai, where they collaborated with the dancer Dou Dou Huang and more than 100 Chinese youngsters in a performance that merges hip-hop, freestyle jazz and traditional Chinese folk dance in honor of the 2007 Shanghai Special Olympics.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (History) WWII IN HD Drawing on diary entries, these firsthand stories of 12 Americans during World War II -- soldiers, nurses and reporters -- are told in this 10-hour mini-series across five consecutive nights, using archival film footage converted into high definition. First: ''Darkness Falls,'' which covers the attack on Pearl Harbor and the first bloody battles at Guadalcanal and in North Africa. (Above, sailors working on an engine before the North Africa campaign.) In ''Hard Way Back,'' at 10, Charles Scheffel (voiced by Ron Livingston), an Army captain from Enid, Okla., eager to carry on his family's military tradition, battles Rommel's forces in Tunisia; and Jack Werner (Justin Bartha), a Jewish émigré from Vienna who enlisted in the Army just days before Pearl Harbor, faces combat in the Pacific theater. Gary Sinise narrates. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY WITH CHRIS WALLACE Former New York City Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Senator Jack Reed, Democrat of Rhode Island, weigh in on the decision to try Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, who is accused of planning the 9/11 attacks, and four other men reportedly involved in the plot, in federal court in New York.

headline: Primal Needs (Reality Edition)
summary: REALITY shows are usually classified along structural lines -- competition shows, makeover shows, dating shows, etc. This snapshot of the 2008 fall reality television season takes a different approach. We've grouped the shows by the primal human need to which they respond. Because reality isn't worth much without a roof over your head, some food on the table and a new pair of harem pants, after all. Defining a reality show is also a subjective exercise. We've taken a broad view: any nonfiction (and nonnews, nonsports or nontalk) show that's roughly in prime time (sorry, ''Flip This House''); is on one of the six major English-language broadcast networks or one of the Top 25 nonnews cable channels, as they were ranked by Nielsen at the beginning of the year (sorry, Animal Planet, CMT, National Geographic, Oxygen, Travel and WE, among others); and is presenting new episodes between now and the end of the year (sorry, ''Deadliest Catch'' and ''American Idol''). The resulting 120-plus shows represent a good share of what's new in reality. Some of these series won't actually appear, and shows that aren't on this list will, because when it comes to reality, the networks will change their minds on a dime (or for a dime). MIKE HALE

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths RUSS, MARION
summary: RUSS--Marion . Teacher, poet. July 26, 1912-March 4, 2008. Marion died in Mountain View, California on March 4. Widow of Ben Russ, a CBS technical director who worked with Sinatra and other stars in the golden age of live television, from 1957-1974 Marion pioneered teaching science fiction and mass media in New York City schools. She then moved to California, was a writing consultant to Palo Alto schools and led widows bereavement groups. A gifted poet, she eulogized many who predeceased her. She's survived by her son Dr. Jonathan Russ and his wife Louise of Los Altos, California, and their daughters, Melanie and Elisabeth. Also surviving are grandchildren Jennifer and Benjamin Russ, children of the late Dr. Kenneth Russ and his late wife Linda of University City, Missouri. A memorial service was held Friday, March 14, at Congregation Etz Chayim in Palo Alto. Donations in Marion's name may be made to Kara grief counseling center at 457 Kingsley Ave, Palo Alto, CA 94301.

headline: An Overhaul And a Separate Bill To Fix Medicare
summary: ''A.M.A. Opens Bid to Kill Medicare.'' That was the blunt headline that appeared in The New York Times on Jan. 27, 1965, as Congress prepared to take up legislation to provide government health insurance to Americans 65 and over.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths LISTER, WALTER
summary: LISTER--Walter, of Larchmont, NY, newspaper man with the New York Herald Tribune for 17 years and producer with CBS News for 25 years passed away on December 30, 2009. Beloved husband of Marion, loving father of Wendy Root, cherished grandfather of Megan, Griffin, Kyle and Lindsay, dear brother of Peter and John. Funeral service Tuesday, January 5, 2010, 1pm at Larchmont Ave. Church, 60 Forest Park Ave., Larchmont, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be in Walter Lister's name to the CUNY Graduate School of Journalism Student Scholarship Fund, 219 W. 40 St., New York, NY 10018.

headline: Spare Times
summary: AROUND TOWN

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (BBC America) FRIDAY NIGHT WITH STREISAND AND ROSS Jonathan Ross devotes the entire episode (even changing the title of his program, ''Friday Night With Jonathan Ross'') to Barbra Streisand, above with Mr. Ross. She offers a few star-studded nuggets, like how she wanted Elvis Presley for ''A Star Is Born''; loves nothing more than staying at home with her husband, James Brolin; injured her thumbs giving Robert De Niro a massage in ''Meet the Fockers''; and will not watch herself on-screen, ever. Yet in spite of her famous aversion to performing before a live audience, she gamely does so here. 8 P.M. (NBC) LAW & ORDER After an aspiring musician is found dead behind a trash can, a bag of cash leads to the suspect, who admits killing the victim because his daughter has been kidnapped. But when she shows up at home with her cellphone missing, Detectives Lupo (Jeremy Sisto) and Bernard (Anthony Anderson) suddenly have a terrorist plot on their hands.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 9:20 P.M. (Fox) OSBOURNES: RELOADED The wacky and lovable Osbourne family -- above from left, Ozzy, Sharon and Jack; Kelly is also taking part -- is back with this six-episode variety show, or what Fox calls an ''alternative entertainment show,'' which will include pranks, hidden cameras and ''Littlest Osbournes'' segments in which young versions of Ozzy and Sharon will re-enact moments from their early lives. 4 P.M. (ABC); 7 P.M. (55) THE OPRAH WINFREY SHOWMichael J. Fox discusses Parkinson's disease.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (Starz) CADILLAC RECORDS (2008) Jeffrey Wright, Mos Def and Beyoncé Knowles, above, star as Muddy Waters, Chuck Berry and Etta James in this celebration of Chicago blues and the founding of a recording company in the 1950s by Leonard Chess (Adrien Brody), who sees a potential gold mine in ''race music.'' Darnell Martin's film ''is not -- thank goodness -- another dutiful musical biopic, but rather the group portrait of a remarkable, volatile constellation of artists,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, adding that it would be worth seeing for the music alone. ''Mr. Wright's renditions of Muddy Waters's signature songs are more than respectable, while Ms. Knowles's interpretations of Ms. James's hits -- 'At Last' and 'I'd Rather Go Blind,' in particular -- are downright revelatory. And so, it should be said, is Ms. Knowles's performance.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY An interview with the theologian Harvey Cox, who recently retired from Harvard University after 44 years. Also, the organist and composer Thomas Beveridge discusses his Yizkor Requiem.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (MTV) PEDRO (2008) Alex Loynaz stars in this drama based on the life of Pedro Zamora, right, who learned that he was H.I.V. positive when he was 17 and went on, in 1994, to star in ''The Real World: San Francisco'' and to raise AIDS awareness around the world. After his death from the disease at 22 in November 1994, one day after the final ''Real World'' episode was broadcast, Mr. Zamora was praised by President Bill Clinton and other leaders for his work in AIDS education. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY A segment looks at how to save $30,000 a year. Keith Urban performs before moving to ''The Ellen DeGeneres Show,'' at 10 a.m. on Channel 55 and 3 p.m. on NBC.

headline: Don Hewitt Memorial
summary: Friends and colleagues of Don Hewitt, the television news pioneer and executive producer of ''60 Minutes,'' will celebrate his life in a memorial service at 11 a.m. on Monday the Rose Theater at Jazz at Lincoln Center, on the fifth floor of the Time Warner Center at Broadway and 60th Street. Mr. Hewitt died on Aug. 19. The speakers will include Leslie Moonves, the president of CBS; the CBS correspondent Morley Safer; Jeffrey Fager, who succeeded Mr. Hewitt as executive producer of ''60 Minutes''; Joan Ganz Cooney, one of the founders of the Children's Television Workshop; and the actor Alan Alda. The memorial is open to the public.

headline: G.M. Chief Quits After Pressure From Administration
summary: The chairman and chief executive of General Motors, Rick Wagoner, resigned Sunday as part of a broad agreement with the Obama administration to funnel more government aid to the ailing auto giant, according to people close to the decision.

headline: An Infomercial, Big, Glossy and Almost Unavoidable
summary: Senator Barack Obama broadcast a half-hour prime time infomercial on Wednesday on three of the major broadcast networks -- Fox, NBC and CBS -- as well as Univision, BET, TV One and MSNBC. It was the first program of its kind in 16 years. THE PROGRAM The program gave a new meaning to the word ''infomercial'' and, for that matter, to all notions of political advertising. Executed with high standards of cinematography, with help from the director of ''An Inconvenient Truth,'' Davis Guggenheim, the infomercial was part slickly produced reality program; part Lifetime biography; and part wonkish policy lecture with music that could have come from ''The West Wing.''

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8:30 P.M. (TV5Monde) FALAFEL (2006) In his feature-film debut, Michel Kammoun tells the story of a young Lebanese man (Elie Mitri) who discovers, as he wanders the streets of Beirut on the way to a party, that a ''normal'' life is a luxury beyond reach. In ''A Lost Man'' (2007), above, at 9 on the Sundance Channel, the director Danielle Arbid contemplates the Western presence in the Middle East in this tale about the encounter between Thomas (Melvil Poupaud), a French photojournalist on a road trip in Syria and Jordan, and Fouad (Alexander Siddiq), an itinerant Lebanese with a mysterious past. Thomas wants Fouad to act as his translator and to help him with a project: to photograph himself having sex with scores of random women. 4 P.M. (ABC); 7 P.M. (55) THE OPRAH WINFREY SHOWNicholas D. Kristof, a columnist for The New York Times, and his wife, Sheryl WuDunn, a former reporter and editor for The Times, discuss changing the world by empowering girls living in poverty.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 A.M. (NBC) THE 82ND MACY'S THANKSGIVING DAY PARADE The parade will make its annual trek from 77th Street and Central Park West down Broadway with a lineup featuring 13 giant helium balloons (including Super Cute Hello Kitty, left), 28 floats, 10 marching bands, 900 clowns, 1,700 cheerleaders and performers including Miley Cyrus, David Archuleta, Kristin Chenoweth, James Taylor, Darius Rucker, Trace Adkins, Lang Lang and Andy Williams. Meredith Vieira, Matt Lauer and Al Roker are the hosts. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW A preview of the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade, a visit with veterans home for the holidays and an interview with the Rev. Billy Graham.

headline: 50 Years Of Going Its Own Direction
summary: AFTER 50 years in the United States, the Honda name has blended into the culture alongside Sony, Nestlé and Adidas, another foreign brand now embraced as a reliable provider of high-quality, well-conceived products. That is a noteworthy achievement for a company that made its name selling a puny plastic-clad motorcycle just as Detroit was birthing its most flamboyant whales. For a broad swath of American consumers, Honda -- a brand applied not only to cars and motorcycles but also to generators, lawn mowers and anything else the world's largest engine maker could power -- is the maker of unpretentious good stuff at accessible prices. Usually without flashy or distinctive styling, Honda's products can be said to define the leading edge of ordinary.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 7 P.M. (Lifetime) SHERRI Sherri Shepherd of ''The View'' moves to prime time in this new series about another Sherri who shares a few things -- single mother, part-time actress -- with the woman who plays her. After that, fiction takes over. This Sherri supports herself as a paralegal while trying to re-enter the dating scene after divorcing the husband who cheated on her. James Avery plays Sherri's father; Kali Rocha is her difficult boss; and Michael Boatman a potential beau. In this premiere episode Sherri learns that the 20-year-old girlfriend of her ex (Malcolm-Jamal Warner, above, with Ms. Shepherd) is pregnant. In the Season 2 premiere of ''Rita Rocks,'' at 7:30, Rita (Nicole Sullivan) takes her daughter, Hallie (Natalie Dreyfuss), to the doctor for a discussion about birth control and receives some unexpected news. 6 A.M. (Fox Business Network) IMUS IN THE MORNING The premiere of Don Imus's syndicated radio program on Fox Business Network. The show will be simulcast in high-definition and is to feature frequent appearances by FBN's Jenna Lee, Connell McShane and Ashley Webster.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths Schein, Harvey
summary: SCHEIN--Harvey, 80, passed away on May 13th peacefully at his home in New York City after a heroic battle with cancer. Beloved husband of Joy, devoted father to Mark and Justin and their wives Maria and Eden, ever-proud grandfather to Aaron, Sophia and Micah. Born in the Bronx and raised in the East New York section of Brooklyn, he went on to serve as editor of the Harvard Law Review in 1951-1952. His career in the entertainment industry spanned many decades. As the president of CBS Records International in the 1960s he helped build their world-wide company. As the president and CEO of Sony America in the 1970s he was of the first Americans to head a Japanese subsidiary, building Sony America into major company and helping to pioneer the concept of home video recording. He also served as head of PolyGram and an executive at Warner Communications and News America Corp. He retired to his homes in Washington, CT and Sanibel, FL where he was devoted to the support of the arts including helping the community build a performing arts center on Sanibel Island. His brilliant mind for business was matched only by his love for his family. He was one of a kind and we miss him dearly. Memorial services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel at 180 W. 76th Street. Thursday, May 15, at 11:15am. Donations can be made to the Palliative Care Institute c/o Dr. Diane Meier, Mt. Sinai Hospital, Box 1070, NY, NY 10029.

headline: College Basketball Propels CBS Forward
summary: With a boost from its afternoon coverage of the N.C.A.A. college basketball tournament, CBS eked out a slight ratings victory on Sunday, edging past ABC as the night's most watched network. According to Nielsen's overnight estimates, the 23-minute college basketball overrun into the 7 p.m. time slot meant that more than 17 million viewers were tuned in to CBS during the first half-hour of prime time. Directly after the live coverage ended, CBS drew about 12.3 million viewers for ''60 Minutes,'' followed by an above-average audience of 8 million viewers for CBS's ''Big Brother.'' Despite its second place finish, ABC outpaced CBS among adults 18 to 49 thanks to ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' at 8 (12.8 million) and ''Oprah's Big Give'' at 9 (11.3 million). Fox was third for the night in that demographic, trailing both ABC and CBS with its animated comedy lineup. NBC, which drew slightly more total viewers than Fox, finished a distant fourth in the 18-to-49 set. NBC broadcast repeats from 9 to 11, following a special showing of MSNBC's ''Countdown With Keith Olbermann'' at 7 (3.4 million) and ''Dateline'' at 8 (6.7 million).

headline: Popular Demand
summary: The 2008-9 baseball season has started, after the usual drama of off-season trades and the unusual drama of the Mitchell Report and Congressional hearings. The Nationals beat the Braves in the season opener in their new stadium, and the Yankees and the Mets have begun the long goodbyes at their home fields (Oliver Perez, above, pitched on opening day at Shea). The fantasy baseball season has also begun. Yahoo had the biggest share in the fantasy category for the week ending April 5, with 28 percent, followed by CBS Sportsline (10 percent) and ESPN (8 percent). SHELLY FREIERMAN

headline: This Year, FedEx Cup Is Still Up for Grabs, and Still Relevant
summary: When the finale of the 2009 PGA Tour playoffs for the FedEx Cup begins Thursday at East Lake Golf Club in Atlanta, many of the questions about the success of the multimillion-dollar conclusion to the official golf season in the United States will have been answered. Yes, the No. 1 seed is Tiger Woods, and he is the odds-on favorite to win the Tour Championship. And, yes, he could just as easily lose the Cup if any of the remaining top five seeds -- Steve Stricker, Jim Furyk, Zach Johnson or Heath Slocum -- can pull off a victory at East Lake.

headline: Inside The Times
summary: International U.S. MISSILES SAID TO HAVE KILLED

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (13); 9 P.M. (49) CRAFT IN AMERICA Season 2 of this Peabody Award-winning series continues its exploration of the country's craft culture, starting with the movement's origins and several artists whose work has its genesis in early techniques -- and who generously pass on their expertise to others. Among those featured are Philip Simmons, a South Carolina blacksmith; Vernon Owens, a North Carolina potter; Teri Greeves, a Kiowa tribe bead worker; Jim Bassler, a California weaver and world cultures professor; and Paul J. Stankard, a New Jersey glass artist. PROCESS, the second installment, at 9 on Channel 13 and at 10 on Channel 49, explores the inspiration behind craft careers and shows how artists acquire skills at schools like the Kansas City Art Institute, where the ceramicist Cary Esser teaches (above left, with a student), and the North Bennet Street School in Boston, which offers classes in subjects like violin making.

headline: What's On Today
summary: NOON (NBC) FIFTH ANNUAL NATIONAL HEADS-UP POKER CHAMPIONSHIP Sixty-four elite poker players, including 12 former World Series of Poker champions, compete in a series of ''heads-up'' -- one-on-one games of no-limit Texas Hold 'em -- for $1.5 million in prize money. Above, the poker pro Annie Duke (seen lately on ''Celebrity Apprentice'') and the comedian Brad Garrett (doing his best Donald Trump impersonation), who pair off in the first round. Other competitors in this event, taped in March at Caesars Palace in Las Vegas, are Chris Ferguson, the returning champion; Paul Wasicka, the 2007 champion; and the celebrities Don Cheadle, Jennifer Tilley and Orel Hershiser. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY Senator Evan Bayh, Democrat of Indiana, and Senator Tom Coburn, Republican of Oklahoma, discuss pirates and the economy.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths Russ, Marion
summary: RUSS--Marion. Teacher, poet. July 26, 1912-March 4, 2008. Marion died in Mountain View, California on March 4. Widow of Ben Russ, a CBS technical director who worked with Sinatra and other stars in the golden age of live television, from 1957-1974 Marion pioneered teaching science fiction and mass media in New York City schools. She then moved to California, was a writing consultant to Palo Alto schools and led widows bereavement groups. A gifted poet, she eulogized many who predeceased her. She's survived by her son Dr. Jonathan Russ and his wife Louise of Los Altos, California, and their daughters, Melanie and Elisabeth. Also surviving are grandchildren Jennifer and Benjamin Russ, children of the late Dr. Kenneth Russ and his late wife Linda of University City, Missouri. A memorial service was held Friday, March 14, at Congregation Etz Chayim in Palo Alto. Donations in Marion's name may be made to Kara grief counseling center at 457 Kingsley Ave, Palo Alto, CA 94301.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (CMT) CROSSROADS: DEF LEPPARD AND TAYLOR SWIFT Def Leppard, the British arena rock band, has sold more than 65 million albums, and its 14th and latest studio album, ''Songs From the Sparkle Lounge,'' had its debut at No. 5 on the Billboard Top 200, the band's highest since 1992. The country sensation Taylor Swift became the youngest person, at 17, to write and sing a No. 1 single (''Our Song''); a year later she is consistently ranked the top country artist on MySpace and has been named the best new female vocalist by the Academy of Country Music. In this concert taped this year in Nashville, Def Leppard's lead singer, Joe Elliott, and Ms. Swift, both above, traded lyrics and leads on hits including the band's ''Photograph,'' ''Hysteria'' and ''Pour Some Sugar on Me,'' and Ms. Swift's ''Picture to Burn'' and ''Love Story.'' 9 A.M. (CBS) THE DOCTORS Pillow talk: the top five medical reasons to have sex; a discussion with a couple that had sex for 101 days in a row; and how to take sex from ordinary to extraordinary in under five minutes.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (ESPN) 30 FOR 30 In ''Who Killed the USFL?,'' the third of 30 films created to celebrate ESPN's 30th anniversary, Mike Tollin chronicles the history of the United States Football League, which kicked off in 1983 with 12 teams, whose players included three Heisman Trophy winners from the National Football League; crowds averaging 25,000 a game; and respectable television ratings. But soon enough an impatient owner named Donald Trump, above, found himself at odds with the league's founders. Three seasons later the league was reduced to waging an antitrust lawsuit against the N.F.L. -- and in the process put itself out of business. 4 P.M. (ABC); 7 P.M. (55) THE OPRAH WINFREY SHOW Five women discuss how they fell victim to a man convicted of using sex as a deadly weapon.
