summary: International EIGHT PALESTINIANS KILLED IN GAZA,

headline: A Soaring Number of Viewers
summary: More than 60 million viewers watched prime-time, election-night coverage on ABC, NBC, CBS and the three main cable news networks, an increase of nearly 10 percent over 2004, according to early estimates provided Wednesday by Nielsen Media Research. When adding in the viewership of eight other channels -- including Black Entertainment Televison and the Spanish-language networks Univision and Telemundo -- Tuesday night's combined viewership ballooned to 71.5 million, more than in either 2004 or 2000.

headline: What's On Today
summary: NOON (TCM) THE FAMILY CLASSICS The network continues its countdown of Disney comedies, starting with ''The Shaggy Dog'' (1959), in which an ancient spell cast by the Borgias turns the teenage son (Tommy Kirk) of a canine-loathing mailman (Fred MacMurray, above right) into a large sheep dog. The roster continues at 2 with ''The Shaggy D.A.'' (1976) before picking up with the Herbie series, about a Volkswagen with a brain: ''The Love Bug'' (1968) at 4; ''Herbie Rides Again'' (1974) at 6; ''Herbie Goes to Monte Carlo'' (1977) at 8; and ''Herbie Goes Bananas'' (1980) at 9:45. The evening wraps up with Jan-Michael Vincent as a Tarzanesque competitor in ''The World's Greatest Athlete'' (1973) at 11:30 p.m. 9 A.M. (CBS) CBS NEWS SUNDAY MORNING Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice is the guest; Michael Feinstein performs.

headline: An Underground Campaign
summary: LAWMAKERS debating health care reform in recent weeks haven't been reticent about blaming trial lawyers for driving up the nation's medical costs by pursuing large malpractice awards.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 10 P.M. (Bravo) THE REAL HOUSEWIVES OF ORANGE COUNTY The ladies who started it all find that suburban life in a gated Orange County enclave isn't quite so sunny in the midst of the economic downturn. Season 5 begins, above from left, with Vicki Gunvalson, Lynne Curtin, Gretchen Rossi, Alexis Bellino and Tamra Barney. The other women say farewell to Jeana Keough and make room in their group for Ms. Bellino, a 32-year-old, stay-at-home mother of three with a 1950s attitude that means she puts her husband, Jim, and his needs first. 6 A.M. (Fox News Channel) FOX & FRIENDS This live report from the U.S.S. New York, a ship forged with steel of the World Trade Center, includes interviews with Gov. David A. Paterson, former Gov. George E. Pataki, former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the New York City police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (Nickelodeon) SPONGEBOB SQUAREPANTS: TRUTH OR SQUARE A constellation of celebrities -- Will Ferrell, Tina Fey, LeBron James, Rosario Dawson, Craig Ferguson, Pink, Triumph the Insult Comic Dog and Robin Williams -- lend their wattage to this 10th-anniversary movie, which finds Patchy the Pirate (Tom Kenny), president of the SpongeBob fan club in Encino, Calif., trying to put together a birthday extravaganza on dry land. Meanwhile in Bikini Bottom, SpongeBob, Patrick, Squidward and Mr. Krabs reminisce about the past in never-before-seen ''flashbacks'' after being locked in a freezer during the Krusty Krab's ''eleventy-seventh'' anniversary celebration 7 P.M. (Fuse) FUSE FEST: VOODOO 2009 Highlights from the 2009 Voodoo Experience in New Orleans include performances by Jane's Addiction, the Flaming Lips, Kiss, Silversun Pickups, Lenny Kravitz and Eminem.

headline: The Afternoon Tycoon
summary: No other captains of industry inspire such a deep, powerful sense of ambivalence as does Victor Newman, the affluent villain played by Eric Braeden on CBS's "The Young and the Restless."

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (Cinemax) FROST/NIXON (2008) In May 1977 the British television personality David Frost (played by Michael Sheen, far right) faced off against Richard M. Nixon (Frank Langella, above left), three years after Nixon left the presidency in disgrace. Mr. Frost was gambling with his money and future; Nixon, with public perception (though he earned $600,000 and 10 percent of the program's profits). The result was blockbuster ratings to rival those of ''Happy Days,'' starring Ron Howard, who directed this adaptation of Peter Morgan's play. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis described the film as ''a soothing, agreeably amusing experience, more palliative than purgative,'' adding that Mr. Langella and Mr. Sheen, who originated their roles on the London stage and later repeated them on Broadway, were ''first-rate.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY In honor of the 20th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall, Deborah Potter reports from the St. Nikolai Evangelical Lutheran Church in Leipzig, Germany, where Bach played the organ and where, starting in 1980, the pastor, Christian Führer, became involved in a ''peaceful revolution'' to bring down the barrier.

headline: INSIDE THE TIMES
summary: INTERNATIONAL MALIKI URGES ARAB NATIONS

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 8 P.M. (TCM) PRIME TIME FEATURE: DIRECTED BY BARRY LEVINSON When most film fans think about Mr. Levinson, they think about Baltimore, where he was born and where several of his movies are set. This three-film salute begins with ''The Natural'' (1984), starring Robert Redford as an aging baseball rookie who comes out of nowhere to save his team and redeem himself. In ''Rain Man'' (1988), at 10:30, Tom Cruise plays a con artist who discovers he has a wealthy savant brother (Dustin Hoffman). Mr. Hoffman won the Oscar for best actor, Mr. Levinson for best director. The evening ends with ''Diner'' (1982), Mr. Levinson's directorial debut, an autobiographical coming-of-age story about a group of Baltimore friends having trouble growing up, with, above from left, Kevin Bacon, Mickey Rourke, Daniel Stern and Paul Reiser. 7 A.M. (ABC) TODAY Ryan O'Neal and Alana Stewart talk about Farrah Fawcett's battle with cancer.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (Sundance) ICE PEOPLE (2008) The filmmaker Anne Aghion travels to the ''deep field'' of Antarctica to follow four geologists, above, as they search for evidence of an alpine lake ecosystem formed around 20 million years ago, when the continent was rich in vegetation. While witnessing the beauty of the six-month Antarctic night as it subsides, Ms. Aghion also documents the harsher reality of the scientists' painstaking fieldwork and the often strained dynamics between the handful of academics and the much larger support staff at the American-run McMurdo research station. Writing in The New York Times, Nathan Lee called Ms. Aghion a ''canny portraitist,'' adding: ''The film's hesitation, lack of rhetorical inflation and commitment to humble observation generate a tough poetry. 'Ice People' sticks in the mind.'' 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Reports from the 2009 Tony Award nominations; the cast of ''Billy Elliot'' performs.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (Nickelodeon) KIDS TO THE RESCUE! HELPING HOMELESS ANIMALS ''Nick News With Linda Ellerbee'' looks at children from across the country, including a few close to home in Brooklyn and New Rochelle, N.Y., who have come to the aid of some of the hundreds of thousands of cats and dogs that have been abandoned during the recession. It also tells the stories of celebrities who have welcomed rescued animals into their homes, including Lance Bass, Sophia Bush, Kellan Lutz, Tony Hawk, Tiffani Thiessen and Bonnie Hunt. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOSRobert Gibbs, the White House press secretary, discusses where the Obama administration stands on the issues that divide the House and Senate health care reform bills and what the president's priorities are for 2010. Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, weighs in on his party's strategy heading into the new year. Mr. Gibbs moves to ''Meet the Press,'' at 10:30 on NBC, alongside Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York; Newt Gingrich, the former House speaker; and Gov. Deval Patrick of Massachusetts.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 7:30 P.M. (SNY) METS YEARBOOK SportsNet New York turns back the clock to 1971 -- when Ralph Kiner could be found giving Ken Singleton hitting tips at Al Lang Field in St. Petersburg, Fla., and Satchel Paige pitched at an old-timers' game -- in the first of 27 recently unearthed half-hour films from 1962 to 1988 starring the New York Mets. Some of the vintage installments were created for television; others were intended as marketing tools to be shown at schools, churches and scout meetings. Highlights in this inaugural season include footage of Shea Stadium under construction and the final walk to the center-field clubhouse at the Polo Grounds by Casey Stengel, above, as well as interviews with Joan Whitney Payson, a founder and majority owner of the Mets, and the broadcasters Lindsey Nelson and Bob Murphy. A new round of ''Mets Hot Stove,'' at 7, serves up news and rumors surrounding the team. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY The arrival of the Christmas tree at Rockefeller center.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (13, 49) NATURE: VICTORIA FALLS It's the largest waterfall on the planet, dividing two natural worlds: the tranquil Zambezi River above, which bridges Zambia and Zimbabwe, and the raging abyss below. ''Nature'' visits the animals --elephants, lions, hippos, crocodiles, buffalo, zebra, monkeys, mongoose and 35 different raptor species -- that call the land surrounding the river home. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY The Rev. Richard McBrien and the Rev. Frank Pavone discuss President Obama's commencement address at the University of Notre Dame.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths ISHAM, HEYWARD
summary: ISHAM--Heyward, died June 18 of cardiac arrest, at 82 years of age. Mr. Isham was born in New York City, attended Phillips Academy, earned his BA from Yale and studied at Columbia University's Russian institute in Garmisch, Germany. Mr. Isham had a long and distinguished career in the U.S. State Department, beginning in 1950 with the U.S. Mission in Berlin serving under U.S. High Commissioner John McCloy and rising to Ambassador to Haiti and Assistant Secretary of State and Director of the Office for Combating Terrorism. Mr. Isham also served in the US Embassy in Moscow under Ambassador Charles Bohlen, during the height of the Cold War and US Consulate in Hong Kong where he was one of the first to recognize the emerging Sino-Soviet rift. In 1971-1972 Mr. Isham served as Deputy and Chief of the US Delegation to the Paris Talks on Vietnam negotiating directly with the North Vietnamese which resulted in the Paris Peace Accords signed on January 17, 1973 ending more than 10 years of direct US military involvement in Vietnam. Secretary of State, Henry Kissinger said of Mr. Isham's work, "He made a tremendous contribution." In retirement Mr. Isham became a senior editor at Doubleday publishing the memoirs of Andrei Gromyko, Soviet Foreign Minister during the more tense time of the cold war and authored two important books in 1995 and in 2001 introducing new Russian writers to the world. In 1990 Mr. Isham became Vice President and Ambassador-in-Residence at the East-West Institute in New York. For the past 15 years, the Ishams' principal home has been in Sagapon- ack where he was a known and loved member of the community. Mr. Isham is survived by his wife of 59 years, the noted artist Sheila Eaton Isham, and two sons Christopher E. Isham, Vice President and Washington Bureau Chief for CBS News, and Ralph H. Isham, Managing Partner, GH Venture Partners, LLC in New York City and nine grandchildren. His daughter Sandra Isham Vreeland died in 1996. In lieu of flowers please send donations to Hopital Albert Schweitzer Haiti, PO Box 81046, Pittsburgh, PA 15217 or visit: www.hashaiti.org

headline: When Legislation Goes Into Overtime
summary: Sometimes it ain't over even when it's over. With Democrats having worked feverishly to pass sweeping Senate and House health care bills before year's end, it is worth remembering that legislative success can be short-lived.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 9 P.M. (Fox) HELL'S KITCHEN Season 5 of the reality cooking show commences with 16 neophyte chefs hoping to make a favorable impression on Gordon Ramsay's discriminating palate. Contestants are on trial not only for their skills but also for their resilience in the face of the notoriously hot-tempered Mr. Ramsay, above. The winner of the new season will become head chef at the Borgata Hotel Casino & Spa in Atlantic City. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Guests are Sandi Richards, the author of ''Dinner Survival,'' and the actor-musician Harry Connick Jr.

headline: Recent Lease
summary: $48.50/SQ. FT. approximate annual rent $1.21 million

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: INAUGURATION COVERAGEBarack Obama (above, with Joseph R. Biden Jr., at the Democratic convention in August) will be sworn in as the 44th president on the steps of the United States Capitol amid performances by Aretha Franklin, Yo-Yo Ma, Itzhak Perlman, Gabriela Montero, Anthony McGill, the United States Marine Band, the United States Navy Band Sea Chanters and the San Francisco Boys Chorus and Girls Chorus. Elizabeth Alexander will recite a poem she has written for the event. The Rev. Rick Warren of Saddleback Church will give the invocation before Mr. Biden takes his oath as vice president, administered by John Paul Stevens, associate justice of the Supreme Court. John G. Roberts Jr., chief justice of the United States, will administer the oath of office to Mr. Obama. The Rev. Joseph E. Lowery, a founder of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, will offer a benediction. The inauguration will be followed by a parade along Pennsylvania Avenue. The ceremony will start at about 10, with Mr. Obama's swearing in at noon. Coverage begins at 5 a.m. on CNN; 6 a.m. on C-Span; 7 a.m. on ABC, CBS, NBC and TV One; 8:30 a.m. on Fox News Channel; 9 a.m. on Fox and MyNetworkTV; 9:30 a.m. on CBS; 10 a.m. on MSNBC and Channel 41; 11 a.m. on BBC America, BET Jazz, CNBC, TV5Monde and Channels 13 and 49; and 11:30 a.m. on BET, Current and Channel 47. 8 P.M. (ABC) THE NEIGHBORHOOD BALL: AN INAUGURATION CELEBRATION President and Mrs. Obama are to have their first dance of the evening at these festivities, held at the Washington Convention Center. Beyoncé, Mary J. Blige, Mariah Carey, Faith Hill, Jay-Z, Alicia Keys, Shakira and Stevie Wonder will perform; Nick Cannon, above, will be the D.J. ''A Moment in History: The Inauguration of Barack Obama,'' at 10, will report from inaugural balls in Washington and explore reactions from around the world to the Obama presidency as well as to the significance of the day to African-Americans. Charles Gibson, Diane Sawyer and George Stephanopoulos will report. A special edition of ''Nightline,'' at 11:30, will look back over the day's events.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) ENDGAMEWilliam Hurt portrays Prof. Will Esterhuyse, the leader of an unofficial delegation representing white South Africa, and Chiwetel Ejiofor, above left, is Thabo Mbeki, the head of a group of exiles from the African National Congress (and the country's future president), in this ''Masterpiece Contemporary'' presentation. Based on ''The Fall of Apartheid'' by Robert Harvey, the film is set in the bleak mid-1980s, as civil war loomed. Jonny Lee Miller plays Michael Young, a public affairs specialist for Consolidated Gold Fields, who, despite the fact that his company has long benefited from apartheid, argues that economic and political chaos will result if the racist system is not dismantled. Derek Jacobi is the company's chairman, who agrees to finance Young's mission, and Clarke Peters is Nelson Mandela. Pete Travis directed this real-life political thriller; Paula Milne wrote the screenplay. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH JOHN KING The Afghan presidential candidate Abdullah Abdullah discusses the coming runoff here and on ''Fox News Sunday With Chris Wallace'' on Fox at 10.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (13) GIL SHAHAM AND ORPHEUS AT THE PENTHOUSE Mr. Shaham, the violinist, above, pays tribute to the centenary of the death of the violinist and composer Pablo de Sarasate with a performance of his Spanish dances, opera transcriptions and original compositions, works Mr. Shaham called ''full of imagination and melody, impeccably clean and concise.'' The Orpheus Chamber Orchestra, the pianist Jonathan Feldman and the violinist Adele Anthony, who is Mr. Shaham's wife, provide accompaniment on this ''Live From Lincoln Center'' presentation broadcast from the Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse. 6 A.M. (Fox News) FOX & FRIENDS Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California talks about the state's economy and recent wildfires, the future of the Republican Party and how he plans to show his support for President-elect Barak Obama.

headline: Winners at the 61st Emmy Awards
summary: Comedy Series: ''30 Rock'' (NBC) Drama Series: ''Mad Men'' (AMC)

headline: For Sale
summary: $19.75 MILLION 449 Broadway (between Howard and Grand Streets)

headline: What's on Tonight
summary: 10 P.M. (CBS) CSI: NY In the final new episode, for now, Detectives Taylor and Bonasera (Gary Sinise, right, and Melina Kanakaredes) and their colleagues investigate the suspicious death of a person who drowned in a self-cleaning public restroom. The real question, of course, is how the victim found a self-cleaning public restroom in the first place. 8 P.M. (13, 49) AMERICA'S BALLROOM CHALLENGE It's American Rhythm week, which means competition in the bolero, cha-cha, mambo, rumba and swing.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (History) THE BEATLES ON RECORD From ''Please Please Me'' to ''Abbey Road,'' 60 classic songs, as well as rare film footage and photographs and outtakes from recording sessions, chronicle the development of the Beatles as musicians and songwriters. The narration includes the voices of, above from left, George Harrison, Paul McCartney, John Lennon and Ringo Starr, and the group's producer George Martin. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Bon Jovi performs on the plaza at Rockefeller Center to promote ''The Circle,'' its second consecutive No. 1 album, and the fourth of its career.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths WEIL, MYRON B
summary: WEIL--Myron B. Jr. ''Bud,'' September 20, 1923-January 9, 2009. Son of the late Myron B. Weil and the late Eleanor Newman Weil, brother of the late Natalie Sinsheimer, husband of Sondra James, father of Nancy Nilsen and Carolyn Weil, grandfather of Kyra Leigh and Ryan Nilsen and Addison McDowell, step-father of Michael and Marc Shenkman. WWII Veteran, DGA Member, TV camera man, producer, director and stage manager from the earliest days of television at ABC and CBS. Donations to Simon Wiesenthal Center or the Actors' Fund.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths Isham, Heyward
summary: ISHAM--Heyward, died June 18 of cardiac arrest, at 82 years of age. Mr. Isham was born in New York City, attended Phillips Academy, earned his BA from Yale and studied at Columbia University's Russian institute in Garmisch, Germany. Mr. Isham had a long and distinguished career in the U.S. State Department, beginning in 1950 with the U.S. Mission in Berlin serving under U.S. High Commissioner John McCloy and rising to Ambassador to Haiti and Assistant Secretary of State and Director of the Office for Combating Terrorism. Mr. Isham also served in the US Embassy in Moscow under Ambassador Charles Bohlen, during the height of the Cold War and US Consulate in Hong Kong where he was one of the first to recognize the emerging Sino-Soviet rift. In 1971-1972 Mr. Isham served as Deputy and Chief of the US Delegation to the Paris Talks on Vietnam negotiating directly with the North Vietnamese which resulted in the Paris Peace Accords signed on January 17, 1973 ending more than 10 years of direct US military involvement in Vietnam. Secretary of State, Henry Kissinger said of Mr. Isham's work, "He made a tremendous contribution." In retirement Mr. Isham became a senior editor at Doubleday publishing the memoirs of Andrei Gromyko, Soviet Foreign Minister during the more tense time of the cold war and authored two important books in 1995 and in 2001 introducing new Russian writers to the world. In 1990 Mr. Isham became Vice President and Ambassador-in-Residence at the East-West Institute in New York. For the past 15 years, the Ishams' principal home has been in Sagapon- ack where he was a known and loved member of the community. Mr. Isham is survived by his wife of 59 years, the noted artist Sheila Eaton Isham, and two sons Christopher E. Isham, Vice President and Washington Bureau Chief for CBS News, and Ralph H. Isham, Managing Partner, GH Venture Partners, LLC in New York City and nine grandchildren. His daughter Sandra Isham Vreeland died in 1996. In lieu of flowers please send donations to Hopital Albert Schweitzer Haiti, PO Box 81046, Pittsburgh, PA 15217 or visit: www.hashaiti.org

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths Weil, Myron B.
summary: WEIL--Myron B. Jr. "Bud," September 20, 1923-January 9, 2009. Son of the late Myron B. Weil and the late Eleanor Newman Weil, brother of the late Natalie Sinsheimer, husband of Sondra James, father of Nancy Nilsen and Carolyn Weil, grandfather of Kyra Leigh and Ryan Nilsen and Addison McDowell, step-father of Michael and Marc Shenkman. WWII Veteran, DGA Member, TV camera man, producer, director and stage manager from the earliest days of television at ABC and CBS. Donations to Simon Wiesenthal Center or the Actors' Fund.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8:30 P.M. (HBO) TROUBLE THE WATER (2008) Kimberly Rivers Roberts (above, with her husband, Scott Roberts), a resident of the Lower Ninth Ward in New Orleans, documented Hurricane Katrina and its aftermath with her video camera; the filmmakers Tia Lessin and Carl Deal met Ms. Roberts at a Red Cross shelter and made her the centerpiece of this movie, which was nominated for an Academy Award for best documentary feature. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said the filmmakers ''have created an ingeniously fluid narrative structure that, when combined with Ms. Roberts's visuals, news material and their own original 16-millimeter film footage, ebbs and flows like great drama.'' 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAYBeyoncé Knowles uses two names to promote her new film, ''Obsessed,'' before moving to ''The View,'' at 11, on ABC, where Meghan McCain is a guest host. Amy Poehler talks about her latest endeavor, ''Parks and Recreation,'' on ''Today'' and then moves to ''Live With Regis and Kelly,'' at 9, on ABC.

headline: Looking Ahead: THE ROUND OF 16
summary: MIDWEST Louisville gets No. 12 Arizona in Indianapolis. The Cardinals should overwhelm the Wildcats with depth, pressure defense and a homecourt edge. Because of defections and attrition, Arizona really goes only six deep. Look for Louisville to outlast Michigan State, which has the talent and tenacity to fight past Kansas.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 5 P.M. PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION COVERAGE Election results will be carried by networks and cable channels throughout the evening, beginning with MSNBC at 5, and BBC America, CNN, CUNY, Fox Business and Fox News at 6. ABC, CBS, CNBC, Fox, NBC, TV One and Channels 41 and 47 will begin coverage at 7; BET, MyNetworkTV and New York 1 at 8; and Channels 13 and 49 at 9. CW will intersperse its regular programming with election updates. And DirecTV subscribers can watch a little of everything on the interactive Election Mix Channel (Channels 102 and 352), which will include feeds from each of the four broadcast networks, as well as CNN, Fox News, MSNBC, Comedy Central and BBC America, on one screen. 10 A.M. (ABC); 2 P.M. (55) RACHAEL RAY Joy Behar of ''The View'' discusses politics with her fellow host Elisabeth Hasselbeck.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 7 P.M. (Nicktoons) IRON MAN: ARMORED ADVENTURES Tony Stark, the heir to a billion-dollar fortune turned metal-clad superhero, models his high-tech outerwear in this new animated series created in conjunction with Marvel Entertainment. Unlike the Stark played by Robert Downey Jr. last year in the blockbuster film ''Iron Man,'' this Tony is a teenager. 7 A.M. (ABC) GOOD MORNING AMERICA Jamie Foxx talks about playing a homeless cellist in his new film, ''The Soloist,'' before moving over to ''Live With Regis and Kelly'' at 9 on ABC.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) PLACE OF EXECUTIONJuliet Stevenson stars as Catherine Heathcote, a television journalist and single mother bent on solving the 1963 disappearance of a 13-year-old girl whose body was never found -- despite a murder conviction in the case. In flashbacks more than 40 years earlier, Lee Ingleby plays George Bennett, a high-level police official whose career took off with the case and who is now the subject of Catherine's latest documentary. Philip Jackson is George as an older man. Greg Wise, above with Ms. Stevenson, plays the girl's arrogant stepfather; Tony Maudsley is George's garrulous sergeant; and Elizabeth Day is Catherine's rebel daughter, who can't stand her mother but is fascinated by her project. Then there are the suspects: a schoolmate (Mikey North) who had secretly kept photographs of the victim, and the victim's uncle (Ryan Anthony-Jones), a known sexual offender. But most troubling are the local villagers, who for more than four decades have withheld information. This two-part ''Masterpiece Contemporary'' production is based on a thriller by Val McDermid (''The Wire in the Blood''); David Tennant (''Dr. Who'') is host. Part 2 will be broadcast on Nov. 8 at 9. 8 A.M. (NBC) MEET THE PRESS Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner discusses the economy, jobs and health care; David Plouffe, President Obama's campaign manager, talks about his new book, ''The Audacity to Win: The Inside Story and Lessons of Barack Obama's Historic Victory.''

headline: Macy's Animated Christmas Ad Campaign
summary: In Macy's animated feature "Yes Virginia," which will appear on CBS-TV, the department store aims to answer kids' perennial holiday question: Is there really a Santa Claus?

headline: Square Feet: Hints the Worst May Be Over for Office Space in New Jersey
summary: The market for office space in New Jersey took a beating in 2009. The vacancy rate swelled to about 22 percent. Rents sank by at least $1 a square foot. And despite its traditional strength as a white-collar job base, the state lost office jobs at a faster clip than the nation at large. The question now seems to be whether some faint signs of life will continue in the new year.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) GEORGE CARLIN: THE MARK TWAIN PRIZE Jon Stewart, Bill Maher, Garry Shandling, Lily Tomlin, Denis Leary, Joan Rivers, Lewis Black, Richard Belzer and Margaret Cho pay tribute at the Kennedy Center to the life and humor of Mr. Carlin, left, who died in June a week after learning that he had won the Twain Prize for American humor. This is the first time the award has been presented posthumously. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW A preview of Katie Couric's interview with Justin Timberlake. Jennifer Aniston and Steve Martin are guests.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 9 P.M. (CBS) THE COURAGEOUS HEART OF IRENA SENDLER (2009) Anna Paquin (far right, with Marcia Gay Harden) plays Sendler, a Polish Catholic social worker who in the early 1940s led a conspiracy of women who, disguised as nurses from the health department, smuggled some 2,500 children to safety from the Nazis. In 2007 Sendler was nominated for a Nobel Peace Prize; she died the next year at 98. Ms. Harden, Nathaniel Parker and Goran Visnjic also star in this ''Hallmark Hall of Fame'' production. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS Gen. Michael Hayden, former director of central intelligence, talks about the impact of the release of memos detailing interrogation methods.

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 9 P.M. (Sundance) A GUIDE TO RECOGNIZING YOUR SAINTS (2006) A writer thinks back on his childhood in a rough neighborhood in Astoria, Queens, in this coming-of-age drama from Dito Montiel, based on his memoir. Shia LaBeouf, above, plays the artist as a young man who dreams of flight with his new best friend, Mike (Martin Compston); Robert Downey Jr. is Dito as a grown-up. ''What sets the film apart, and makes it one of the more remarkable American directing debuts in recent years, is Mr. Montiel's passionate, almost reckless engagement with the possibilities of the medium,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''Working with a large, mostly young cast, he has made a picture so full of life and feeling that the screen can hardly contain it.'' 7:30 P.M. (Cartoon) GEORGE OF THE JUNGLE A new version of the adventures of this cartoon Tarzan makes its debut with two consecutive episodes, including one in which George loses his loincloth.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (Military) SATELLITE SHOOT-DOWN Remember when a dying 5,000-pound spy satellite loaded with toxic fuel was headed straight toward Earth? If it seems like a distant memory, that's probably because the United States Navy incinerated it more than 130 miles above the Pacific Ocean in February, averting a minor environmental disaster. This one-hour special examines the science and technology, like that above, used to intercept and destroy the ailing satellite. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY WITH CHRIS WALLACE Adm. Michael Mullen, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, discusses a recent trip to Iraq. Senator Joe Lieberman, independent of Connecticut, and Senator Evan Bayh, Democrat of Indiana, talk about Senator Barack Obama's trip to Iraq.

headline: Corrections
summary: A chart in the Stocks in the News section on Tuesday misstated the Monday closing price and other stock data for the real estate firm CB Richard Ellis. It closed at $8.41, not $18.35. A corrected chart is at nytimes.com/corrections.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 10 P.M. (21) GLOBE TREKKERBradley Cooper retraces the steps of the Incas from Cuzco to Ollyantaytambo, the site of their last great battle. (Above, a scene from that journey.) He then travels to the glacial Ausangate Mountain, where he joins in the merriment for the Qollyur rit'i festival. Meanwhile in the Amazon, Eils Nevitt travels by boat from Manaus to Anavilhanas Island, where she fishes for deadly black piranha and samples a coconut maggot. 4 P.M. (Discovery Health) A LYON IN THE KITCHEN Nathan Lyon, a former contestant on ''The Next Food Network Star,'' prepares a healthy, tea-tinged dish of milo-crusted black cod with herb rice.

headline: Turnover or Not?
summary: Turnover or Not? On the final play of the Bengals' loss Sunday at Oakland -- which seemingly took place in front of more seagulls than people -- Carson Palmer heaved a desperation pass that was intercepted on the 7-yard line by Nnamdi Asomugha. The CBS play-by-play announcer Kevin Harlan described it as ''another turnover for the Bengals.''

headline: "Walter Was Such a Good Friend"
summary: Andy Rooney, the CBS journalist, spoke at the funeral service for his friend, the legendary TV new anchor Walter Cronkite, in Manhattan.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: BANKS BALK AT DEAL Clear Channel Communications and its two private buyers may go to court to force several banks to complete the $19.5 billion sale. [C1.] FACEBOOK FOR ATHLETES A Hollywood talent agency and a hedge fund are planning to start WePlay.com, a social networking site for youth sports.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) YOUNG AND RESTLESS IN CHINA ''Frontline'' follows nine young Chinese adults across four years as they balance tradition and Westernization while grappling with a freewheeling economy. Those profiled include Wang Xiaolei, a rapper, above; Lu Dong, a 32-year-old businessman starting his own Internet-based tailoring company; Miranda Hong, a marketing executive; Ben Wu, an Internet cafe entrepreneur; and Zhang Yao, a medical resident. 9 A.M. (ABC) LIVE WITH REGIS AND KELLY Kelly Preston talks about her latest film, ''The Tenth Circle,'' based on the novel by Jodi Picoult; Idina Menzel performs.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9:30 P.M. (NBC) 30 ROCK Liz (Tina Fey) and Jack (Alec Baldwin) travel south to the hometown of Kenneth (Jack McBrayer, above) in search of ''all-American'' talent. Jenna (Jane Krakowski) tries to get in good with the writers before the new cast member of ''TGS'' is hired. And Tracy (Tracy Morgan) fears for his life after two celebrities die -- and he decides he's next. Betty White and the ventriloquist Jeff Dunham are the guest stars. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Wanda Sykes promotes her new late-night Fox series. Next stop: ''The View'' at 11 on ABC.

headline: Recent Lease
summary: $26/SQ. FT. approximate annual rent $45,084

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 8 P.M. (ABC) DANCING WITH THE STARS A recap of the sixth-season routines so far (above, Fabian Sanchez and Marlee Matlin). 8 P.M. (CW) BEAUTY AND THE GEEK In the first episode the geeks were sad to learn that they would be working against, not with, the beauties this season. Instead of being paired up and rooming with a good-looking member of the opposite sex, they are right where they started: hanging with other geeks. Perhaps the personal growth the show promises will be stunted this time around? In tonight's episode the teams go head to head in a football game, and it's hard to tell who has the advantage, the skinny nerds or the ditsy women.

headline: A Refresher On Colts' Strategy
summary: Coach Jim Caldwell subscribes to the Tony Dungy school: being healthy and fresh for the playoffs takes priority over finishing undefeated. So Indianapolis (12-0) will probably sit its players in the final weeks. But recent history suggests a different approach. Last season, the Colts rested players in Week 17, then lost their playoff game at San Diego in the wild-card round. The year before, the Colts rested players in Week 17, only to lose their first playoff game in the divisional round (also against San Diego).

headline: Rugs That Pack a Punch
summary: WHEN it comes to area rugs, size is not the only thing that matters. A small carpet with a bit of pattern can deliver a lot of impact per square foot, transforming the look of a space. This season's carpets come in graphic patterns, in bright as well as neutral colors, that can bring a room to life. 1. Hulda Stämpel is a rug made of synthetic yarn that is just shy of 5 by 7 feet. It was designed by Jon Eliason, and costs $29.99 in Ikea stores; www.ikea.com for store locations or (800) 434-4532.

headline: CITY ROOM BLOGGING AT NYTIMES.COM/CITYROOM.
summary: A PIANO PRACTICED In the Travel Arts

headline: The Week Ahead | Jan. 13- Jan. 19
summary: Television Ginia Bellafante

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: AN EXECUTIVE'S LEGACYSumner M. Redstone, chairman and controlling shareholder of Viacom and CBS, turns 85 years old next month and questions are arising about his legacy, his plans for the companies and his various business and family relationships. TRIBUNE'S OUTLOOK The Tribune Company, acquired in December by Sam Zell, faces a host of problems that could force the company to default on its debt -- a development that could push one of the country's oldest and greatest newspaper companies into bankruptcy. [C1.]

headline: What's on Tonight?
summary: 8 P.M. (ABC) DANCING WITH THE STARS A dozen more celebrities with potential for some serious footwork -- among them the nine-time Grand Slam tennis champion Monica Seles (right, with Jonathan Roberts); the Olympic gold medal skater Kristi Yamaguchi; and Marissa Jaret Winokur, who won a Tony Award for her turn in ''Hairspray'' -- try to outdance one another. Other competitors include Adam Carolla, Cristián De La Guenta, Shannon Elizabeth, Steve Guttenberg, Mario, Marlee Matlin, Penn Jillette, Priscilla Presley and Jason Taylor. Professional dancers like Julianne Hough, Cheryl Burke and Edyta Sliwinska return to guide the celebrities through the steps. Carrie Ann Inaba, Bruno Tonioli and Len Goodman retain their seats at the judges' table. Tom Bergeron and Samantha Harris are the hosts. 8 P.M. (Fox) CANTERBURY'S LAW Elizabeth (Julianna Margulies) isn't sure she believes her client, an accused murderer played by Pruitt Taylor Vince, when he says he can communicate with the dead. But then he divulges information about her missing son.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 8 P.M. (TCM) 75TH ANNIVERSARY OF THE SCREEN ACTORS GUILDTurner Classic Movies salutes the birth of the labor union that brought stability to the lives of actors and the performers who conceived of it. This two-part tribute begins with ''Movie Crazy'' (1932), starring Harold Lloyd as a Kansas boy bamboozling his way into Hollywood. The evening continues with ''The Kennel Murder Case'' (1933), which introduced William Powell as the society sleuth Philo Vance, at 9:45; ''The Kid From Spain'' (1932), with Eddie Cantor as a Brooklyn artist who becomes one of the world's great bullfighters, at 11:15; ''The Mask of Fu Manchu'' (1932), starring SAG member No. 9, Boris Karloff, above, at 1 a.m.; ''The Last of Mrs. Cheyney'' (1937), the film that set Joan Crawford on a downward career spiral, at 2:15; and ''For Me and My Gal'' (1942), the overlooked Judy Garland classic that brought in $4.8 million on an $800,000 investment. It was also Gene Kelly's film debut. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOWMary Jo Buttafuoco talks about life after the tabloids.

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 8 P.M. (13, 49) CRACKING THE MAYA CODE The Maya of Central America inscribed their intricate hieroglyphic script on monuments and pottery and in bark-paper books, only four of which survived destruction by European conquerors. One is pictured above. The language remained a mystery until a recent series of breakthroughs allowed scholars to decipher the New World's most highly developed ancient writing system. This ''Nova'' episode looks at the research of modern-day experts like David Stuart and Simon Martin as well as that of earlier scholars. 9 P.M. (Sundance) BIG IDEAS FOR A SMALL PLANET Three designers offer tips on how to decorate a home without using environmentally toxic materials and furnishings. In the documentary ''Manufactured Landscapes,'' at 9:35, Jennifer Baichwal dissects the photographs of Edward Burtynsky, whose latest project looks at China's transformation into an urbanized society.

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 8 P.M. (BBC America) RAMSAY'S KITCHEN NIGHTMARES The 120-seat Curry Lounge has recently undergone a million-dollar renovation, with décor right out of Bollywood. But the menu is do-it-yourself, which makes life more than difficult for the head chef, who must concoct unfamiliar dishes for each order. Here Gordon Ramsay, above right with the chef Zahir, tries to fix his first Indian restaurant. 6:30 P.M. (Cinemax) THE ONE PERCENT Jamie Johnson, a great-grandson of the founder of Johnson & Johnson and the Emmy-nominated director of the documentary ''Born Rich,'' in which several young heirs did the unthinkable and talked about their family money, focuses this time on the growing gap between the rich and everyone else in America. Specifically, he examines the 1 percent of society that controls nearly half of the nation's wealth. Among those offering their opinions: the economist Milton Friedman; the billionaire Adnan Khashoggi; Roy O. Martin, a Louisiana lumber tycoon who spends with the Bible as his guide; Chuck Collins, a great-grandson of Oscar Mayer who gave up his inheritance for moral reasons; and Bill Gates Sr., the father of the richest man in the United States.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (NBC) THE OFFICE Jim and Pam (John Krasinski and Jenna Fischer, kissing at left) take their colleagues to Niagara Falls to celebrate their wedding in this hourlong episode. But no one is supposed to mention the ''P'' (as in pregnancy) word. The staffers try to hook up with the other guests, and Michael (Steve Carell) and Dwight (Rainn Wilson) meet twins. 6 A.M. (Fox News Channel) FOX & FRIENDS Jeb Bush, former governor of Florida, discusses Excellence in Action 2009: A National Summit on Education Reform, being held in Washington on Thursday and Friday.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths Cohn, Sam
summary: COHN--Sam. Sam, you were one heck of a guy to share an office with at CBS. I valued knowing and working with you. Condolences to family. Stanley Stempler

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 8 P.M. (TMC) ELECTION (1999) A high school political campaign takes a misguided turn in this comedy starring Matthew Broderick and Reese Witherspoon, above. Mr. Broderick plays Jim McAllister, a teacher determined to squash the admittedly overzealous and just plain irritating ambitions of his student, Tracy Flick (Ms. Witherspoon). But of course Tracy isn't easily defeated. Janet Maslin of The New York Times called it ''a deft dark comedy with a resemblance to 'Rushmore.' It's smart no matter what.'' 8 P.M. (ABC Family) GREEK In the season premiere Rusty (Jacob Zachar) and Casey (Spencer Grammer) start the battle to restore their place in the Greek system.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (Bravo) PROJECT RUNWAY The gang's all here (above, from left): Michael Kors, Heidi Klum, Tim Gunn and Nina Garcia are still the in group in the fifth season of this fashion design competition series. In a statement Mr. Gunn declared that he was on pins and needles waiting for the premiere of what he said was the most drama-filled season yet -- a reference, perhaps, to the legal maneuvering that will send the series to Lifetime after this season. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Gary Oldman talks here about his role as Lt. James Gordon in ''The Dark Knight,'' while on ''Today,'' at 7 on NBC, Maggie Gyllenhaal discusses her turn as Batman's romantic interest, Rachel Dawes. Also on ''Today,'' Amanda Seyfried promotes the summer musical ''Mamma Mia!'' Meryl Streep, who plays Ms. Seyfried's on-screen mother, does a rare publicity turn on ''Live With Regis and Kelly'' at 9 on ABC.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (CBS) THE 32ND ANNUAL KENNEDY CENTER HONORS The opera singer Grace Bumbry, above left, the actor Mel Brooks, center, and the rocker Bruce Springsteen, right, are honored with the actor Robert De Niro and the jazz pianist Dave Brubeck for their contributions to American culture in this ceremony, taped on Dec. 6 with President Obama; the first lady Michelle Obama; and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. in attendance. Caroline Kennedy is the host for the seventh consecutive year. Performers and presenters include Jack Black, Matthew Broderick, Harry Connick Jr., Simon Estes, Melissa Etheridge, Aretha Franklin, Angela Gheorghiu, Herbie Hancock, Ben Harper, Harvey Keitel, Jane Krakowski, Frank Langella, John Mellencamp, Jennifer Nettles, Edward Norton, Carl Reiner, Martin Scorsese, Martin Short, Jon Stewart, Ben Stiller, Sting, Sharon Stone, Meryl Streep and Eddie Vedder. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Robert De Niro is the guest; hosts discuss consumer predictions for the coming year and how to throw a retro New Year's Eve cocktail party.

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 9 P.M. (CBS) CELINE DION: THAT'S JUST THE WOMAN IN ME Ms. Dion, right, performs her first concert since ending her five-year run in Las Vegas in this hourlong special, taped at the Wiltern Theater in Los Angeles, featuring some of her hits, including ''Because You Loved Me,'' ''My Heart Will Go On'' and ''Taking Chances,'' and appearances by Josh Groban, Will.i.am and Joe Walsh. She'll also answer questions from V.I.P. guests like Corbin Bleu and David Foster. 8 P.M. (Ovation) LUST FOR LIFE (1956) Kirk Douglas plays Vincent van Gogh in this drama from Vincente Minnelli, based on the fictionalized biography by Irving Stone about van Gogh's tortured life. Anthony Quinn won his second Oscar for best supporting actor for his portrayal of Paul Gauguin.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: NO LOOKING BACK Real estate agents and executives are seeing a new willingness by homeowners facing default to walk away from their mortgages. LAWMAKERS AT ODDS Republicans and Democrats in Congress clashed over how to prevent further damage from the growing housing crisis. [C1.]

headline: 'Dancing' Waltzes To a Ratings Win
summary: ABC dominated the ratings on Monday night, as 20.3 million viewers tuned in to ''Dancing With the Stars,'' according to Nielsen's estimates. The reality competition easily earned the largest audience in prime time. Fox edged past CBS for second place with ''Bones'' (8.4 million) and ''24'' (10.3 million). CBS was a close third despite a lineup of mostly repeats, while NBC finished a distant fourth with ''Chuck'' (6 million), ''Heroes'' (6.4 million) and ''Medium'' (7.4 million). On Friday the cable channel Nickelodeon came within striking distance of the broadcast networks with a ''SpongeBob SquarePants'' episode guest starring Johnny Depp. The show delivered 5.8 million viewers.

headline: More Blackouts Possible
summary: Reduced season-ticket sales for some N.F.L. teams could result in a greater than usual number of local television blackouts. ''It's all part of the challenges that we're seeing in the economy and what our clubs are going through,'' Roger Goodell told reporters Tuesday at the Washington Redskins' training camp in Ashburn, Va. ''Our clubs have been working hard in the off-season to create other ways to try to get people in the stadiums and to have policies that are a little more flexible, and hopefully, they're going to pay dividends for us.''

headline: Recent Lease
summary: $31.50/SQ. FT. approximate annual rent $186,000

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths SIEGEL, ANN FAY
summary: SIEGEL--Ann Fay. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn with profound sadness the loss of Ann Siegel, beloved mother of Stephen B. Siegel, whose enduring commitment and generosity strengthen our ability to care for those in need and enrich the New York Jewish community and the lives of millions of people around the globe. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Stephen and his entire family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO SIEGEL--Ann Fay. It is with great sadness that we send our most heartfelt condolences to our dear friends, Stephen and Michael Siegel, and their families, for the loss of their beloved and cherished mother Ann Fay Siegel. Our thoughts and prayers are with you in your time of mourning. Scott and Michael SIEGEL--Ann Fay, born May 30, 1921, passed away peacefully January 15, 2008, in Boca Raton, Florida. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Devoted and loving mother of Stephen B. (Wendy) and Michael. Adoring grandmother of Kenneth (Karen), Jonathan, Melissa, Allison, Jared and Cassandra. Great - grand mother of Sophia and Sarah. Sister of Pearl, Gerry, Margie, Debbie, Sandy and the late Lillian. Private services will be held for family only. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the Lower East Side Tenement Museum. You were the best mother in the world, and we cherish the values and traditions you instilled in us. We will always treasure your memory, and you will remain in our hearts forever. SIEGEL--Ann Fay. Steve and Michael, all of your friends at CB Richard Ellis extend our condolences on the passing of your mother, Ann. We know how cherished she was by you and your family. You are all in our thoughts and prayers.

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (HBO2) GEORGE CARLIN AT U.S.C. Over two nights this channel will present 11 comedy specials made for HBO by Mr. Carlin, above, who died on Sunday at 71. The tribute begins with this 1977 broadcast. At 11 p.m. the channel dusts off ''Carlin at Carnegie'' (1982), which features the comedian's expanded edition of ''Seven Dirty Words,'' recited from a scroll. 4 P.M. (ABC) THE OPRAH WINFREY SHOW Interviews with YouTube celebrities, including Judson Laipply, whose ''Evolution of Dance'' has been viewed more than 89 million times and is the most popular clip on that video-sharing site.

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 9 P.M. (13) MY BOY JACK Daniel Radcliffe (left with Kim Cattrall), moves out of the shadow of Harry Potter and into the role of Rudyard Kipling's son in this ''Masterpiece'' adaptation of the play by David Haig. Mr. Radcliffe plays Jack Kipling, who, under age, cursed with poor eyesight and sharing his father's belief in the power of war, desperately longs to join the fight at the outbreak of World War I. After Jack fails his induction eye exam twice, his father uses his influence to gain his son, not yet 18, an officer's commission in the Irish Guards. And then, in the Battle of Loos, Jack goes missing. Mr. Haig plays Rudyard Kipling; Ms. Cattrall is his American wife, Carrie. 1 P.M. (G4) HALF BAKED G4 goes up in smoke for the day with programming extolling the virtues of cannabis culture, beginning at 1 p.m. First, this comedy starring Dave Chappelle, Guillermo Díaz and Jim Breuer as party guys hatching a scheme to bail a friend out of jail. Other highlights include ''Attack of the Show: Jamaica,'' at 3, which reports on the state of marijuana consumption in Toronto, Vancouver, Los Angeles and San Francisco; ''Code Monkeys: The Story of 420,'' at 5; the cult classic ''Reefer Madness,'' tweaked with new characters and voices in ''Reefee's Madhouse,'' at 6; and at 7, the best scenes from the Troma horror flick ''Class of Nuke 'em High'' in ''Grindcore.''

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (USA) A.F.I. LIFE ACHIEVEMENT AWARD: A TRIBUTE TO WARREN BEATTY It's easy to see how he could have been the subject of Carly Simon's song ''You're So Vain.'' Mr. Beatty, right, is one of two people ever to get writing, directing, producing and acting Oscar nominations for a single film. He did this twice, for ''Heaven Can Wait'' (1978) and ''Reds'' (1981). Orson Welles did it only once, for ''Citizen Kane'' (1941). Former President Clinton, Jane Fonda and Dustin Hoffman attended this ceremony, which had prerecorded tributes by Barbra Streisand and Senator John McCain. It was taped on June 12 at the Kodak Theater in Los Angeles. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW The cast of ''Big Brother 10'' is introduced, and Kyra Sedgwick talks about a new season of ''The Closer.'' At 9, Ms. Sedgwick moves on to ''Live With Regis and Kelly'' on ABC, where Bernadette Peters will discuss her animal-adoption program and her book ''Broadway Barks.''

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths KNUTSON, DONALD I.
summary: KNUTSON--Donald I.,Ph.D., 68, Mathematician 1941-2009. On Friday, Donald Knutson, son of Charlotte and Henry Knutson, died at his home in Park Slope twenty-five months after being diagnosed with brain cancer. At M.I.T., Dr. Knutson earned his bachelor's degree, his doctorate and his wife, Andrea Allen Knutson. Don's 1968 doctoral thesis, "Algebraic Spaces", is still widely read today by those pursuing algebraic stacks. Don taught at Boston College, Columbia, where he guided doctoral students, and Fordham. In 1978, after receiving an M.B.A. from Columbia, Don started a 29-year career as a financial executive at CBS Television Network. Early in his career he was asked to determine what CBS should bid for the Olympics and NFL contracts. For the latter, Don's first step was to ask what the letters NFL meant. Later he developed many of the analytical systems that are in use at CBS today, and which he was still improving up until the day before he was diagnosed with a tumor in the center of his brain. After his surgery he attacked his neurological problems with a no-fuss cheerful curiosity. He relearned the alphabet using his grandson's puzzles, rejoined the Brooklyn Conservatory Chorale, attempted to dine in every Park Slope restaurant, and hiked the hills of Prospect Park, the Berkshires and the Swiss Alps. Even after last winter when a second tumor paralyzed his right side, he regarded dressing himself one-handed as an interesting project and continued to attend at least two plays or concerts weekly. The only challenge that he found heartbreaking was the decline in his ability to play the piano. Don is survived by his wife Andrea, his children Allen and Miranda, his grandchildren Fionn and Taran, his brother Robert, his five cats and his 5,000-book library. The wake will be held at the family home, 618 6th St., Brooklyn on Tuesday, 3-9pm. Contact: mknutsonw@gmail.com. A memorial concert at the Brooklyn-Queens Conservatory of Music is planned for the fall. Donations may be made in Don's memory to the Brooklyn-Queens Conservatory: bqcm.org/support.htm.

headline: LOOKING AHEAD

CORPORATE EARNINGS Reports will come from Clorox, Ford Motor and Humana (Monday); Archer Daniels Midland, Cablevision Systems, Hartford Financial Services Group, Kraft Foods, Marathon Oil, MasterCard, Medco Health Solutions, Royal Caribbean Cruises and Viacom (Tuesday); Allstate, Cisco Systems, Comcast, GMAC, Marsh & McLennan, Molson Coors Brewing, the News Corporation, Prudential Financial, Pulte Homes, Qualcomm, Time Warner and Whole Foods Market (Wednesday); and Activision, CBS, Cigna, CVS, DirecTV, Dynegy, E.W. Scripps, MGM Mirage, Nasdaq OMX Group, Sara Lee, Starbucks, Thomson Reuters, Time Warner Cable and the Wendy's/Arby's Group (Thursday).

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) INSPECTOR LEWIS ''Masterpiece Mystery!'' opens the season with Kevin Whately, above, reprising his role as Robbie Lewis, a long-suffering police sergeant, in the first season of this spin-off of the ''Inspector Morse'' series. This episode finds Lewis, now a detective inspector himself, trying to rebuild his life back in Oxford following the still-unsolved hit-and-run death of his wife two years earlier. When a middle-aged Oxford graduate is discovered dead near his houseboat, Lewis and his erudite sidekick, Detective Sergeant James Hathaway (Laurence Fox), find themselves sniffing along a trail peppered with literary references and leading back to the victim's undergraduate days, when he was a member of a club built upon the Greek myth of Dionysus. 9 A.M. (NBC) MEET THE PRESS Brian Williams sits in the moderator's seat as Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, and Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, discuss the coming election.

headline: After 21 Years, Winning Shot Still Resonates for Smart
summary: Keith Smart will sometimes run into an acquaintance that he has not seen for a while. ''Hey, I saw you last night,'' the person will say.

headline: THE QUAD
summary: All Eyes on SpongeBob MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. -- After Miami's 21-20 victory over Oklahoma on Saturday night, Hurricanes quarterback Jacory Harris made an announcement meant to keep his teammates grounded after their 3-1 start and No. 11 ranking.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (TV Guide) I DREAMED A DREAM: THE SUSAN BOYLE STORY She seemingly came from nowhere and took the world by storm, and now, Susan Boyle, above, says, ''I don't want the dream to end.'' Piers Morgan hosts this special, which follows the trajectory of Ms. Boyle. She was plucked from obscurity in the village of Blackburn in Scotland and catapulted to stardom -- with a few bumps along the way -- after performing on ''Britain's Got Talent,'' for which Mr. Morgan, along with Simon Cowell and Amanda Holden, is a judge. Ms. Boyle will sing ''Who I Was Born to Be'' and ''Cry Me a River'' from her new album, as well as her signature song, ''I Dreamed a Dream,'' from ''Les Misérables,'' introduced by a rendition of ''One Day More'' performed by the show's London cast. Several of Ms. Boyle's friends, family members and fans, including the comedy duo Ant and Dec, will offer their perspectives on her unexpected celebrity. 10 A.M. (FOX) FOX NEWS SUNDAY WITH CHRIS WALLACE Senator Judd Gregg, Republican of New Hampshire, and Senator Claire McCaskill, Democrat of Missouri, will discuss the job creation measures and financing proposed by the Obama administration.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 11 P.M. (Bravo) CHEF ACADEMY Jean Christophe Novelli, left, is a Michelin-star chef with restaurants in Britain, France and South Africa. In this new series the French-born Mr. Novelli, who lives in London, journeys to Los Angeles with his pregnant fiancée, Michelle Kennedy, and his aptly named right-hand man, Steven Kitchen. Mr. Novelli's mission: to test, within an eight-week trial run, the possibility of opening a cooking academy. But first he needs nine students, which he selects based on their ability to cook an egg in this season premiere. They'll learn everything from preparing bread to gutting fish. But three slips of the carving knife, and they're out. 9 A.M. (CBS) THE DOCTORSBarbra Streisand discusses her support for heart health awareness for women. Also, a look at a new compound that may hinder the aging process and improve heart and liver function.

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 9:30 P.M. (TCM) THOU SHALT NOT: SEX, SIN AND CENSORSHIP IN PRE-CODE HOLLYWOOD This new documentary examines the era before the Production Code was enforced, beginning in 1934. It was one of the most intriguing periods in Hollywood history, shaped by social, financial and moral forces. TCM will also screen a few provocative examples, starting at 8 with ''The Divorcee'' (1930), starring Norma Shearer as a betrayed wife who retaliates, and continuing with ''Night Nurse'' (1931), in which Barbara Stanwyck (above right with a gun-wielding Ben Lyon and Clark Gable, left) plays a nurse who untangles a plot to murder two children, at 10:45; ''Three on a Match'' (1932), starring Joan Blondell, Bette Davis and Ann Dvorak as childhood schoolmates on very different paths, at midnight; ''Female'' (1933), with Ruth Chatterton as the head of an automobile company and George Brent as her right-hand man, at 1:15 a.m.; and ''A Free Soul'' (1931), starring Shearer again, this time as a lawyer's rebel daughter who is drawn to a thug (Gable). 8 P.M. (ABC) THE ROYAL FAMILY Barbara Walters takes viewers behind the palace walls for a glimpse into the private lives of the British royal family in this documentary pieced together from hundreds of hours of film taken in public and private settings over the course of a year.

headline: Vox Populi in Dispute
summary: Spoiler alert: The House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, and the House minority leader, John A. Boehner, disagree on the popularity of the public option. The two leaders debated the issue Thursday via their weekly news conferences. Mr. Boehner, an Ohio Republican, said he had yet to talk to anyone -- besides some in Washington -- who backed a government-run insurance option.

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 8:30 P.M. (Sundance) BLACK WHITE + GRAY: A PORTRAIT OF SAM WAGSTAFF AND ROBERT MAPPLETHROPE (2007) Sam Wagstaff was a dashing museum curator and photography collector from an old-money New York background. The photographer Robert Mapplethorpe (above right, with Wagstaff), whom Wagstaff called ''my shy pornographer,'' was a punk from Queens. Together they climbed the art-world ranks -- ''a diabolical power couple who lived and died in a mad pursuit of aesthetic perfection and erotic sensation,'' Stephen Holden wrote in a review of this documentary in The New York Times. James Crump wrote and directed; Truman Capote, Dominick Dunne and the curator Henry Geldzahler, among others, ruminate on the couple. 8 P.M. (CBS) THE PRICE IS RIGHT MILLION DOLLAR SPECTACULAR Contestants bid and spin for a load of cash. Drew Carey eggs them on.

summary: INTERNATIONAL IRAN'S LEADER ASKS PROSECUTOR

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (CBS) THE VICTORIA'S SECRET FASHION SHOW Alessandra Ambrosio, Miranda Kerr, Doutzen Kroes, Marisa Miller and the winner of a model search voted on by the public will sashay down the runway in an assortment of holiday skivvies -- like the $3 million Harlequin Fantasy bra designed by the Italian jeweler Damiani -- to the strains of the Black Eyed Peas. The host is Heidi Klum, right, who made a surprise walk down the runway at this show taped late last month, just six weeks after giving birth to her fourth child. 8 P.M. (ABC, CBS, CNBC, CNN, Fox, Fox Business Network, Fox News Channel, MSNBC, NBC, NY1, 13)PRESIDENTIAL ADDRESSPresident Obama, speaking from the United States Military Academy at West Point, outlines his strategy to ''finish the job'' in Afghanistan, which may include the addition of troops and an exit plan.

headline: Obama Weighs Quick Undoing Of Bush Policy
summary: President-elect Barack Obama is poised to move swiftly to reverse actions that President Bush took using executive authority, and his transition team is reviewing limits on stem cell research and the expansion of oil and gas drilling, among other issues, members of the team said Sunday. As Mr. Obama prepared to make his first post-election visit to the White House on Monday, his advisers were compiling a list of policies that could be reversed by the executive powers of the new president. The assessment is under way, aides said, but a full list of policies to be overturned will not be announced by Mr. Obama until he confers with new members of his cabinet.

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 8 P.M. (13) THE NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC LIVE FROM NORTH KOREA ''Great Performances'' broadcasts the historic concert by the Philharmonic in Pyongyang, North Korea. (Despite the ''Live'' in the title, it actually takes place early Tuesday morning, Eastern time.) Lorin Maazel, above, is scheduled to conduct the orchestra in works by Dvorak, Wagner and Gershwin. Bob Woodruff of ABC News provides coverage of the event.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: NICE DEAL IF YOU CAN GET IT The Ford Motor Company is offering its factory workers the most lucrative mix-and-match buyout plan ever. HOMEOWNER AID IS CRITICIZED Some cities and states that are lending money to homeowners to help them meet mortgage payments are being criticized by people who say the aid resembles taxpayer bailouts. [A1.]

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 8 P.M. (Sundance) BEFORE THE RAIN (1994) Milcho Manchevski directed this haunting, Oscar-nominated film in which three intertwined narratives explore violence and hatred between Macedonian Christians and ethnic Albanian Muslims. Grégoire Colin plays Kiril, a young Macedonian monk who has taken a vow of silence; Labina Mitevska is Zamira, a desperate Albanian girl; and Katrin Cartlidge is Anne, an English photo editor. At their center is Aleksandar Kirkov, played by Rade Serbedzija, above, a London-based war photographer who has returned home to Macedonia to find his village divided into hostile factions. Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times, ''Mr. Manchevski tells his story elegantly and leaves his audience with a warning too strong to be ignored.'' 8 P.M. (CBS) THE PRICE IS RIGHT MILLION DOLLAR SPECTACULAR Contestants bid and spin for a load of cash under the amused eye of Drew Carey.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths Calamita, Frank
summary: CALAMITA--Frank, died peacefully in his sleep in Warwickshire, England on Sunday, June 28, 2009. Born in Brooklyn to Nicola and Grace Calamita, Mr. Calamita moved to Manhattan as a young man and joined CBS Records in 1962. On September 3, 1966 he was married to Alyda Jansen. Their only child, Nicolas Jansen, was born in 1968. In his career of over 40 years Mr. Calamita was a senior executive with CBS Records and later with Sony Music Entertainment, and served on the boards of numerous charitable organizations including The American Management Association and the Brookhaven Memorial Hospital Medical Center. The Calamita's maintained homes in Manhattan and Bellport, LI. Alyda Jansen Calamita was deceased on April 27, 2000. Mr. Calamita is survived by his son and daughter-in-law, Nancy S. Eisenhauer, who are both academics in Oxford, England and their son, Nicolas Johannes Ides Calamita. In addition he is survived by the families of his late sister Angela Schiralli and Ann Iorio. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Monday, July 13, 2009 at 10:30am at Most Precious Blood Roman Catholic Church, 113 Baxter St., NYC. Burial will be private. The family requests that in lieu of flowers donations be made in Mr. Calamita's memory to The Association for Children with Down Syndrome (ACDS), 4 Fern Place, Plainview, NY 11803-4725 or Cancer Research UK, Halifax Road, Melksham, SN12 6YY, United Kingdom. A web page at Cancer Research UK has also been created in Frank's memory.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (Fox) DOLLHOUSE Summer Glau of ''Firefly'' reunites with Joss Whedon, that series's creator, when she joins the cast of his latest show, ''Dollhouse,'' as an employee who shares a past with Echo (Eliza Dushku) in this Season 2 premiere. Daniel Perrin plays a United States senator on a mission to track down the organization; Jamie Bamber, above with Ms. Dushku, is Echo's new husband. And Keith Carradine portrays a nemesis of Adelle (Olivia Williams), the leader of the Dollhouse, who comes looking for trouble. 9 A.M. (ABC) LIVE WITH REGIS AND KELLYJude Law talks about his star turn in ''Hamlet'' on Broadway; Jo Frost (''Supernanny'') and John Krasinski (''The Office'') promote the new seasons of their shows. Jeff Probst (''Survivor'') is the guest host.

headline: Faces to Watch
summary: Julianna Margulies, 'The Good Wife' Julianna Margulies has appeared on television only sporadically since she left ''ER'' nearly a decade ago, and for this viewer absence did not make the heart grow fonder. Her appearance as a hard-drinking, ethics-schmethics defense lawyer on the short-lived Fox drama ''Canterbury's Law'' only made the heart grow annoyed. But Ms. Margulies's hardened vulnerability leaves her perfectly suited to the title role on ''The Good Wife,'' a CBS series that seeks to capture the essence of the age as a net might trap a butterfly. Standing beside her philandering political husband at his penance-seeking news conference, Ms. Margulies deftly balances loss and disgust with a determination to reclaim an identity long ago submerged. She is a better Jenny Sanford than Jenny Sanford.
