headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (ABC) DANCING WITH THE STARS A new batch of 16 celebrities -- among them Donny Osmond, Kelly Osbourne, Macy Gray and Tom DeLay, the former House majority leader (above with Cheryl Burke) -- take to the floor in this Season 9 premiere. They will be dancing against a group that includes the Olympic gold medal swimmer Natalie Coughlin, the actress Debi Mazar and Mark Dacascos of the Food Network show ''Iron Chef America.'' Tom Bergeron and Samantha Harris are the hosts; Len Goodman, Bruno Tonioli and Carrie Ann Inaba return as judges. 7 P.M. (13, 49) THE NEWSHOUR WITH JIM LEHRER Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton discusses the United Nations and the Obama administration's agenda at the General Assembly.

headline: New Year's Day Bowl Games
summary: What you need to know before you start 2010 by consuming more than 12 hours of college football. OUTBACK BOWL

headline: What's on Tonight
summary: 9 P.M. (BBC America) LAST RESTAURANT STANDING Nine pairs of friends and relatives -- culinary novices all -- take over nine empty stores and try to create their own restaurants and open them to the public in this British series. Judges eliminate teams until only one couple is left standing, and they get to open their restaurant with the backing of the Michelin-starred chef Raymond Blanc. Each pair -- including Sam and Jackie, above, a married couple -- will live and work together 24 hours a day, and worse, have it all filmed for public consumption. In ''Ramsay's Kitchen Nightmares,'' at 8, Gordon Ramsay tries to muster some divine intervention to save the Priory, a buffet-style carvery in Sussex, England. 8 P.M. (CBS) SURVIVOR: MICRONESIA -- FANS VS. FAVORITES In the series's 16th installment, 10 fans of the show face off against 10 former castaways on the Rock Islands of Palau, Micronesia. Jeff Probst is host.

headline: THE WEEK AHEAD | Oct. 4 - Oct. 10
summary: Television Ginia Bellafante

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 8 P.M. (The Documentary Channel) DAMNED TO HEAVEN On May 2006 Warren S. Jeffs -- the leader of the Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, which believes that plural marriage is a requirement for entering heaven -- was put on the F.B.I.'s most-wanted list. His crime: acting as an accomplice to rape for his role in the ceremonial marriage of a teenage girl to an older cousin. In September of the following year, having already renounced his role as prophet, Mr. Jeffs, above, was convicted and is serving a prison term of 10 years to life. This documentary from Thomas Elliott and Pawel Gula explores the emotional and physical effects of polygamy on women and girls. In ''Banished: The Lost Boys of Polygamy,'' at 9:45, Stacey Butler examines the lives of boys 13 to 21 who have been pressured to leave the fundamentalist Mormon sect to reduce competition for wives. 8 P.M. (CBS) GHOST WHISPERER Melinda (Jennifer Love Hewitt) worries about the safety of her son, Aiden (Connor Gibbs), when the ghost of a girl who died from leukemia (Madison Leisle) befriends him -- and warns Melinda to stay out of her way.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (HBO Signature) JOE'S PALACE (2007) Michael Gambon plays Elliot Graham, a billionaire recluse, and Danny Lee Wynter (above left, with Mr. Gambon) is Joe, the teenage caretaker of Elliot's grand but empty London house -- and his conduit to the outside world. When Elliot allows a philandering politician (Rupert Penry-Jones) to conduct an affair with his married mistress (Kelly Reilly) in the house, Joe becomes close to the lovers. But in time the house comes to feel more like a prison for all the characters, forcing Elliot to examine the dark secrets of his past. This drama, written and directed by Stephen Poliakoff (''Gideon's Daughter''), is the first of two set against the backdrop of this gloomy mansion and linked by Joe, a highly individualistic young man whose lower social status renders him invisible to those around him. ''Capturing Mary,'' the second film, starring Maggie Smith, will be shown Tuesday at 9. 8 P.M. (NBC) HEROES Claire (Hayden Panettiere) tries to get at the truth behind the sorority rush attacks. But H. R. G. (Jack Coleman) intervenes, only to discover that he may be the cause of her troubles.

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 8 P.M. (CW) GOSSIP GIRL REVEALED ''Gossip Girl,'' whose first season ended after its 13 completed episodes ran out, returns to the schedule on a new night with a rebroadcast of the pilot and DVD-style extras -- cast interviews, deleted scenes, soundtrack information -- in a 90-minute special. (Left, Blake Lively as Serena.) 8 P.M. (13, 49) ANTIQUES ROADSHOW In the first of three episodes taped in Orlando, Fla., Mark L. Walberg, the show's host, and Arlie Sulka, an appraiser, visit nearby Winter Park and the Charles Hosmer Morse Museum of American Art to look at works by Louis Comfort Tiffany. At the Orange County Convention Center, experts offer their assessments of a photograph signed by the cast of ''Bonanza,'' a Tiffany vase and a collection of etchings and drypoints by James McNeill Whistler.

headline: Bernie Brillstein, 77, Innovator in Hollywood
summary: Bernie Brillstein, a Hollywood manager and producer who helped mold the shape of television with his contributions to series like ''Saturday Night Live'' and ''The Muppet Show,'' died here on Thursday night. He was 77. The cause was chronic pulmonary disease, said Nicole Caruso, a publicist for Brillstein Entertainment Partners. In a 52-year show business career, Mr. Brillstein represented entertainers who ranged from the stand-up comedian Norm Crosby and the singer Frankie Laine to a later generation of comic rebels that included John Belushi, Dan Aykroyd, Gilda Radner, Lorne Michaels, Martin Short and others.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (HBO) CURB YOUR ENTHUSIASM Cue laughter: Larry (Larry David) misses out on some quality time with Cheryl (Cheryl Hines) when he returns a favor in this Season 7 finale, in which the stars of ''Seinfeld'' -- Jerry Seinfeld (above right), Jason Alexander (above left), Julia-Louis Dreyfus and Michael Richards -- reunite. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS Senator Tom Coburn, Republican of Oklahoma, and Senator Ben Nelson, Democrat of Nebraska, are among those debating the health care bill and mammogram guidelines. The discussion continues on ''Face the Nation,'' at 10:30 on CBS, with Senator Jon Kyl, Republican of Arizona; Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York; and Dr. Jennifer Ashton, CBS News medical correspondent; and on ''Meet the Press,'' at 10:30 on NBC, with Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois; Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison, Republican of Texas; Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California; Nancy Brinker, founder of Susan G. Komen for the Cure; and Dr. Nancy Snyderman, NBC News chief medical editor.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths CALAMITA, FRANK
summary: CALAMITA--Frank, died peacefully in his sleep in Warwickshire, England on Sunday, June 28, 2009. Born in Brooklyn to Nicola and Grace Calamita, Mr. Calamita moved to Manhattan as a young man and joined CBS Records in 1962. On September 3, 1966 he was married to Alyda Jansen. Their only child, Nicolas Jansen, was born in 1968. In his career of over 40 years Mr. Calamita was a senior executive with CBS Records and later with Sony Music Entertainment, and served on the boards of numerous charitable organizations including The American Management Association and the Brookhaven Memorial Hospital Medical Center. The Calamita's maintained homes in Manhattan and Bellport, LI. Alyda Jansen Calamita was deceased on April 27, 2000. Mr. Calamita is survived by his son and daughter-in-law, Nancy S. Eisenhauer, who are both academics in Oxford, England and their son, Nicolas Johannes Ides Calamita. In addition he is survived by the families of his late sister Angela Schiralli and Ann Iorio. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Monday, July 13, 2009 at 10:30am at Most Precious Blood Roman Catholic Church, 113 Baxter St., NYC. Burial will be private. The family requests that in lieu of flowers donations be made in Mr. Calamita's memory to The Association for Children with Down Syndrome (ACDS), 4 Fern Place, Plainview, NY 11803-4725 or Cancer Research UK, Halifax Road, Melksham, SN12 6YY, United Kingdom. A web page at Cancer Research UK has also been created in Frank's memory.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (13, 49); 10 P.M. (21) THE NATIONAL PARKS: AMERICA'S BEST IDEAKen Burns, who directed, and Dayton Duncan, who wrote the script, tell a story they say is as uniquely American -- and just as radical -- as the Declaration of Independence: that the most prized places in a nation should be preserved not just for royalty or the rich, but also for everyone. This six-part documentary series travels from Acadia, Yosemite and Yellowstone to the Grand Canyon, the Florida Everglades and the Gates of the Arctic in Alaska to chronicle the evolution of national parks across nearly 150 years. The first episode, ''The Scripture of Nature (1851-1890),'' examines how John Muir, a Scottish-born wanderer, led Congress to pass the 1864 act that protected the Yosemite Valley in California for ''public use, resort and recreation,'' and how a second act in 1872 christened Yellowstone, a ''wonderland'' of geysers, mud pots and sulfur pits in the northwest corner of the Wyoming territory, America's first national park. Above, a Blackfeet Indian in Glacier National Park in Montana.

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) AFRICAN AMERICAN LIVES 2 ''We Come From People'' recounts the stories of the ancestors of the actor Morgan Freeman, right, whose great-grandmother described a life in slavery in an account found among the records of the Works Progress Administration, and the Rev. Peter Gomes, whose ancestors were freed and supported by Quaker families in Virginia in the late 1700s. ''The Past Is Another Country,'' the series finale, at 10, uses DNA analysis to link Henry Louis Gates Jr., the show's host, to a medieval Irish warlord. 8 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL The Top 24 are selected.

headline: LAUGH LINES
summary: CONAN O'BRIEN It's been reported that outspoken anti-immigration anchor Lou Dobbs is leaving CNN. Yeah. True story, yeah. He'll be replaced by a guy named Juan, who will do the same job for $5 an hour.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: TOO NICE A GUY? Many economists on Wall Street are beginning to grumble that the Fed chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, is so intent on building consensus among the Fed's policy makers that he appears reluctant to strong-arm his colleagues at the Federal Reserve the way his predecessors Alan Greenspan and Paul A. Volcker often did. TVS AND THE INTERNET The 2008 Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas has more than its share of new gadgetry. But this year the show is less about products than about partnerships, especially the chance for TV makers to make deals with Internet media sites like YouTube to provide programming direct to the televisions. [C1.]

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 9 P.M. (A&E) GENE SIMMONS FAMILY JEWELS A cosmetically refreshed Gene Simmons (above with, from left, his daughter, Sophie; his partner, Shannon Tweed; and his son, Nick) returns for a third season of rock 'n' roll meets family man reality. First: a lie detector test to find out whether Mr. Simmons, the Kiss frontman whose tongue is a legend in its own right, met the 4,800 women he claims to have been with before 1983, the year he committed to Ms. Tweed, a former Playboy centerfold. 8 P.M. (CW) BEAUTY AND THE GEEK In this fifth-season premiere, nine women and nine men learn that they'll be competing as two teams, the beauties against the geeks, instead of beauty-geek pairs. For the first challenge, the beauties are made to look unattractive and then must try to get phone numbers from men in a bar. The geeks are sent to a quiz room, after which one is sent home.

headline: N.F.L. ROUNDUP
summary: NBC KEEPS SUNDAY NIGHTS NBC extended its deal with the N.F.L. for two years, through 2013. The network's rights fee to carry ''Sunday Night Football'' will increase by 2 percent a year. Under its current agreement, it pays the league an average $600 million a year. NBC's extension comes three months after CBS and Fox agreed to add two years to their contracts, paying about the same increase as NBC.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths CHATZOPOULOS, GEORGE
summary: CHATZOPOULOS--George. The employees of CB Richard Ellis are deeply saddened by the tragic passing of our friend and colleague George Chatzopoulos. George was an exemplary professional, conscientious colleague and emerging leader in our Downtown office. He will be greatly missed. Our hearts go out to his mother, Noula; sister, Katie and brother, Michael.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths Leslie, Seymour M.
summary: LESLIE--Seymour M. A native and lifelong New Yorker, passed away on Sunday, January 6, 2008, at the age of 85, after 60 years of marriage to his beloved wife, Barbara. The man known to the world as "Cy" is survived by his loving daughters Ellen, Janie and Carol, and his adoring grandchildren Julie (Dan), David (Ariana), Sara and Ben. As an entrepreneur from start to finish, Cy helped shape the music and entertainment world and was recognized as a pioneer of the home video industry. His first business was a prerecorded greeting card service that turned into Voco Records; he went on to become Founder of Pickwick International, President of CBS Video Enterprises, Founder and Chairman of MGM/UA Home Entertainment, Founder of The Leslie Group, and Co-Chairman of Leslie/Linton Entertainment. Cy has been recognized as one of the 20th Century's most influential and outstanding leaders in the video industry: he was the Record industry's Man of The Year in 1975; he received the Presidential award from the National Association of Record Manufacturers in 1976; and Time magazine presented him with the Home Viewer/Time Magazine Man-ofThe-Year Award for special achievement in 1987. Cy was also Vice Chairman of the Songwriters Hall of Fame and an active member of the Motion Picture Academy of Arts and Sciences. In his professional life, Cy never stopped giving to the entertainment world, and in his personal life, he never stopped giving to those he loved, serving as the tower of strength to those who knew him intimately. He and Barbara had also dedicated their lives to supporting various organizations and institutions such as The JCC of the Greater Five Towns, Five Towns College, Parker Jewish Institute, B'nai B'rith, New York State Council on Humanities, Friars Foundation and the T.J. Martell Foundation. As a proud graduate of DeWitt Clinton High School, Cy received his Bachelor's degree from Syracuse University, before being deployed by the Army in World War II. Later, he received a degree from Harvard Business School, and has also received an honorary doctorate from Syracuse University. Cy will be remembered as a man of integrity, loyalty, and passion, and as a man who loved life and lived it fully. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The JCC of the Greater Five Towns, 207 Grove Avenue, Cedarhurst, NY, 11596 or the Anti-Defamation League, Department: RL, P.O. Box 96226, Washington, DC 20090. Services will be held on Tuesday, January 8, at 11:30 at Boulevard Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY. Shiva to follow at the home of Barbara Leslie at 810 Channel Road, Woodmere, NY.

headline: WALTER CRONKITE | THAT'S THE WAY IT WAS
summary: ''From Dallas, Tex., the flash, apparently official: President Kennedy died at 1 p.m. Central Standard Time, 2 o'clock Eastern Standard Time, some 38 minutes ago.'' -- Nov. 22, 1963

headline: What's On Today
summary: 2:30 P.M. (PBS) FROM VIENNA: NEW YEAR'S CELEBRATION 2010 Georges Prêtre, above, conducts this ''Great Performances'' presentation of the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra, live from the Viennese concert hall the Musikverein. On the program are Strauss waltzes, marches and polkas, as well as dance sequences performed by members of the Volksopera ballet, with music provided by the Vienna State Opera. The choreography is by Renato Zanella and the costume design by Valentino. Julie Andrews takes over from Walter Cronkite as host of the annual celebration. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Rob Thomas performs. Trudie Styler, Sting's wife, is a guest. And the hosts discuss personal finance in 2010, hangovers and a New Year's Day breakfast.

headline: Progress Toward Ending Hollywood Strike
summary: Informal talks between representatives of Hollywood's striking writers and production companies have eliminated the major roadblocks to a new contract, which could lead to a tentative deal as early as next week, according to people who were briefed on the situation. The agreement may come without renewed formal negotiations between the television and movie writers and the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers, though both sides still need to agree on specific language of critical provisions. If that process goes smoothly, a deal may be presented to the governing boards of the striking Writers Guild of America West and Writers Guild of America East by the end of next week.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (CBS) FASHION ROCKS Denis Leary, right, is host of the fifth installment of this annual event, taped on Friday at Radio City Music Hall and presented by the Condé Nast Media Group, celebrating music and fashion. Beyoncé, Black Eyed Peas, Chris Brown, Kid Rock, Duffy, Fergie, Justin Timberlake, L'il Wayne, Keith Urban, Mariah Carey, Rihanna, Chris Cornell, One Republic, Pussycat Dolls, Solange Knowles, Timbaland and Lynyrd Skynyrd were scheduled to perform. Ticket proceeds will benefit Stand Up to Cancer. ''Style Rocks the Red Carpet: Fashion Rocks 2008,'' at 8:30 on Style, features preconcert celebrity interviews and fashion commentary. 6 A.M. (FNC) FOX AND FRIENDS Brian Kilmeade interviews President Bush about Gov. Sarah Palin, the troop surge in Iraq and what it feels like not to be campaigning after eight years.

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 8 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL It's that time again, as if there were a time it ever really wasn't. The bedlam begins with the requisite freak audition footage, in two-hour episodes Tuesday night (filmed in Philadelphia) and Wednesday night (Dallas). Would-be contestants for the show's seventh season sing their hearts out before Randy Jackson, Paula Abdul and Simon Cowell, above from left, in hopes of becoming the next Jordin Sparks, Carrie Underwood or Fantasia. (Isn't America tired of this yet?) The real competition settles in next Tuesday at 8 p.m. The ubiquitous Ryan Seacrest is host. 7 P.M. (Cinemax) ANDREW JENKS, ROOM 335 When he was 19, on his summer break from Tisch School of the Arts at New York University, Mr. Jenks moved into an assisted-living facility in Florida, ostensibly to hang out. And, we're guessing, to make this documentary, which looks at the phenomenon of these facilities in a society that does not entirely embrace its older citizens. Among the stars is 95-year-old Tammy, who immediately informs Mr. Jenks that the medication in her pharmacy bag is ''birth-control pills.''

headline: BEST SELLERS: NONFICTION: Sunday, July 6th 2008
summary: Rankings reflect sales, for the week ending June 21, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Among those categories not actively tracked are: perennial sellers; required classroom reading; text, reference and test preparation guides; journals and workbooks; calorie counters; shopping guides; comics and crossword puzzles. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (MTV) 2009 MTV VIDEO MUSIC AWARDS The comedian Russell Brand returns as host of this ceremony, which will be broadcast live from Radio City Music Hall and feature a tribute to Michael Jackson by his sister Janet. Jay-Z, Alicia Keys, Lady Gaga, Beyoncé (right), Green Day, Pink, Taylor Swift and Muse are scheduled to perform; the rapper Wale and the go-go band UCB will join forces as the show's house band. Beyoncé and Lady Gaga lead the nominations with nine each; Britney Spears has seven; and Kanye West, Eminem and Coldplay each received four. Nominees for best new artist are 3OH!3, Asher Roth, Drake, Kid Cudi and Lady Gaga; voting will continue throughout the show until shortly before the award's announcement. Katy Perry, Jennifer Lopez, Ne-Yo, Chace Crawford, Megan Fox and 50 Cent are among the presenters. At 8, Ashley Green and Tim Kash will report from the red carpet. The post-show festivities begin at 11:15. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY WITH CHRIS WALLACE Representative Joe Wilson, Republican of South Carolina, explains his reaction to President Obama's speech on health care reform.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 8 P.M. (TCM) STAR OF THE MONTH: KAY FRANCIS She was the most popular actress at Warner Brothers before Bette Davis came along. This month Turner Classic Movies pays tribute each Thursday to Francis, an Oklahoma girl whose dark, statuesque beauty -- at 5 feet 9 inches she was the tallest leading lady in 1930s Hollywood -- and velvety voice helped make her a star. The 42-film salute features several of Francis's pre-code hits, beginning tonight with ''Raffles'' (1930), starring Ronald Colman as a British charmer who turns jewel thief by night but vows to change his ways for the love of a beautiful socialite (Francis). The evening continues with -- is there a theme here? -- ''Jewel Robbery'' (1932), at 9:15, with William Powell (above, with Francis); and ''One Way Passage'' (1932), at 10:30, about a shipboard romance between a man (also Powell) condemned to be executed and a woman (Francis) doomed to an early death. The vampish ''Divorce'' (1945), at 11:45, was one of three films Francis made for Monogram in an attempt to regain her lost stardom. 6 A.M. (FNC); 5 P.M. (C-Span); 6 P.M. (CNN); 7 P.M. (MSNBC); 8 P.M. (13, 49, TV One); 10 P.M. (2, 4, 7) REPUBLICAN NATIONAL CONVENTIONCoverage from Minneapolis-St. Paul, where Senator John McCain is to give his acceptance speech as the Republican presidential nominee. Other scheduled speakers include Gov. Tim Pawlenty of Minnesota; Gov. Charlie Crist of Florida; and Senator Sam Brownback of Kansas.

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 8 P.M. (Fox) TEEN CHOICE 2008 Surf's up! Miley Cyrus, left, is the host of this 10th annual ceremony honoring the performers whom teenagers love in the categories of music, television, film and sports. The winners will walk away with surfboard awards. ''Gossip Girl'' and its cast topped this year's list of nominees with 14; Chris Brown came in second with 9; Ms. Cyrus tallied 4 of her own; and Justin Timberlake racked up 3. The new ''Do Something'' award will recognize someone under 25 who is making an effort to change the world; $100,000 will go to the favorite cause of the winner of the online vote at TeenChoiceAwards.com. At 7 E! will chat up celebrities on ''Live From the Red Carpet.'' 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW An investigation into a new drug that would allow older women to give birth. Also, preparations for the Beijing Olympics.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths SIEGEL, ANN FAY
summary: SIEGEL--Ann Fay, born May 30, 1921, passed away peacefully January 15, 2008, in Boca Raton, Florida. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Devoted and loving mother of Stephen B. (Wendy) and Michael. Adoring grandmother of Kenneth (Karen), Jonathan, Melissa, Allison, Jared and Cassandra. Great - grand mother of Sophia and Sarah. Sister of Pearl, Gerry, Margie, Debbie, Sandy and the late Lillian. Private services will be held for family only. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the Lower East Side Tenement Museum. You were the best mother in the world, and we cherish the values and traditions you instilled in us. We will always treasure your memory, and you will remain in our hearts forever. SIEGEL--Ann Fay. Steve and Michael, all of your friends at CB Richard Ellis extend our condolences on the passing of your mother, Ann. We know how cherished she was by you and your family. You are all in our thoughts and prayers. SIEGEL--Ann Fay. It is with great sadness that we send our most heartfelt condolences to our dear friends, Stephen and Michael Siegel, and their families, for the loss of their beloved and cherished mother Ann Fay Siegel. Our thoughts and prayers are with you in your time of mourning. Scott and Michael

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 7 P.M. (TCM) PRIVATE SCREENINGS: LESLIE CARON (1999) Turner Classic Movies heralds the ''funny face'' -- and terrific legs -- of Ms. Caron, starting with this hourlong special in which she discusses her career with Robert Osborne. A four-film tribute follows, starting with ''Fanny'' (1961), a romance about a sailor (Horst Buchholz) who reunites with his lover (Ms. Caron) and the son he has never met. Maurice Chevalier plays Panisse, the older suitor who has married Fanny to save her reputation but is now dying. In ''Father Goose'' (1964), at 10:30, Cary Grant (with Ms. Caron above) plays a World War II beach bum in the South Pacific who finds himself protecting a beautiful French teacher (Ms. Caron) and her charges on the run from the Japanese. ''The L-Shaped Room'' (1962), at 12:30 a.m., finds Ms. Caron portraying a pregnant and unwed Frenchwoman trying to build a new life in a low-rent London boarding house. And in ''An American in Paris'' (1951), she trips the light fantastic alongside the man who discovered her: Gene Kelly. 8 P.M. (CBS) SYBIL (2008) Tammy Blanchard stars as the woman with 16 personalities whose name became synonymous with dissociative identity disorder in this adaptation of the book by Flora Rheta Schreiber. Jessica Lange is Dr. Cornelia Wilbur, the psychiatrist who begins to treat Sybil after she attempts suicide. And JoBeth Williams is Hattie, the mentally disturbed mother whose physical, emotional and sexual abuse caused Sybil to develop separate personalities, each distinct in age and appearance, to cope with the cruelty she endured as a child.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths Dealy, Francis X.
summary: DEALY--Francis X., Jr. (Bud), 71, of Greenwich, CT, passed away on August 10, 2009 after a lengthy illness. Beloved husband of Ellen, nee Fairbanks, for 25 years. Father of Patrick of Rhinebeck, NY, Brendan of Auburndale, MA, Christopher of New York, NY (sons of his first marriage to Jane, nee Sim), Maximilian, Samson, and John (Beau), all of Greenwich. Survived also by his sisters, Mary Pohlschroeder of Wilton, CT and Dona Dealy of San Francisco, CA, seven grandchildren and numerous nieces and nephews. Mr. Dealy was an advertising executive (Wells, Rich, Green), a magazine publisher (Dow Jones, New York Times and CBS), an award winning author (Win at Any Cost: The SellOut of College Athletics and The Power and the Money: Inside the Wall Street Journal). More recently he worked in real estate and wrote a popular weekly column for a local newspaper in Greenwich, CT. His abilities and passions were legendary: he was a tennis player, a marathoner, a cyclist, an orator and a skier. He loved his family, friends, the written word, Italy, the NYAC, Lake Kezar, London, and especially, in recent years, watching his younger sons play the sports he loved. He will be deeply missed. Calling hours are from 5-8pm on August 16th, at Leo P. Gallagher Funeral Home, 31 Arch Street, Greenwich, and a service will take place at 11am on August 17th at Christ Church, 254 East Putnam Avenue, Greenwich. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Boys and Girls Club of Greenwich would be appreciated.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 5 P.M. (C-Span); 6 P.M. (CNN); 7 P.M. (FNC, MSNBC); 8 P.M. (13, 49, TV One); 10 P.M. (2, 4, 7) DEMOCRATIC NATIONAL CONVENTION Coverage from the Pepsi Center in Denver, where Senator Barack Obama is the presumptive presidential nominee. The speakers include Michelle Obama, above, the evening's headliner; Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, speaker of the House and permanent chairwoman of the convention; Senator Claire McCaskill of Missouri; and Craig Robinson, Ms. Obama's brother. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Reports from the Democratic National Convention; little-known facts about Michelle Obama.

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 8 P.M. (CMT) GONE COUNTRY Seven rappers and rockers move into the Plowboy Mansion in Nashville and compete to break out as the next country superstar. But it isn't only about learning to croon. They also have to adapt to the lifestyle, from Southern cooking to off-roading on all-terrain vehicles. Each contestant will be guided by two songwriters in composing a country single that will receive its debut in the series finale, with the winner releasing his or her song on country radio. John Rich of Big & Rich, above center in black hat, plays mentor to the motley crew. Front row from left, Julio Iglesias Jr. and Diana DeGarmo; second row from left, Carnie Wilson, Dee Snider, Sisqó, Maureen McCormick and Bobby Brown. 8 P.M. (TCM) ALIAS JESSE JAMES (1959) Westward ho ho ho! Turner Classic Movies devotes the evening to comedy westerns, starting with this Bob Hope vehicle about a bumbling insurance agent who finds himself in a pickle when people start mistaking him for Jesse James (Wendell Corey). In ''Support Your Local Sheriff!'' (1969), at 9:45, James Garner plays a con man who winds up in law enforcement, and at 11:30 Mr. Garner is a runaway groom turned hired gun, alongside Suzanne Pleshette, in ''Support Your Local Gunfighter.'' The mayhem ends with ''The Law West of Tombstone'' (1938), about a cowardly judge (Harry Carey) who enlists the help of a hot young gunslinger (Tim Holt) to take out local outlaws.

headline: LOOKING AHEAD
summary: ECONOMIC DATA Reports will include the Institute for Supply Management's manufacturing index for July and construction spending for June (Monday); personal income and spending for June and pending home sales for June (Tuesday); the ADP employment survey for July and factory orders for June (Wednesday); and unemployment for July (Friday). COMPANY EARNINGS Reports will come from Clorox, Humana, MGM Mirage, Marathon Oil, Molson Coors, Pulte Homes and Tyson Foods (Monday); Archer Daniels Midland, CVS Caremark,D. R. Horton, Electronic Arts,GMAC, Kraft Foods and Whole Foods Market (Tuesday); Ambac Financial, Allstate, Cisco Systems, Fortress Investment, the News Corporation, Polo Ralph Lauren, Procter & Gamble and Prudential Financial (Wednesday); Beazer Homes, Blackstone, CBS, Comcast, Cooper Tire and Rubber, El Paso, Lenovo, MBIA, the Nasdaq OMX Group, Sirius XM Radio, Thomson Reuters and the Wendy's/Arby's Group (Thursday); and Berkshire Hathaway (Friday).

headline: Shows Are "Gnu" at CBS
summary: CBS pitches shows for its "Gnu" Monday lineup.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (BBC America) THE SECRET POLICEMAN'S BALLEddie Izzard, right, Graham Norton, Sarah Silverman, Jimmy Fallon and Chevy Chase yuk it up onstage at Royal Albert Hall in London to benefit Amnesty International. 9 A.M. (ABC) LIVE WITH REGIS AND KELLY Shirley MacLaine talks about channeling Coco Chanel for a new Lifetime mini-series; Wayne Brady performs.

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 8 P.M. (CW) ONE TREE HILL This teenage drama goes adult by fast-forwarding its characters four years, after they've graduated from college, in this two-hour fifth-season premiere. It also injects some new blood into the cast with the addition of Michaela McManus as a tough New York book editor assigned to work with Lucas (Chad Michael Murray) on his novel. Guest stars include Daphne Zuniga, as an intimidating executive who clashes with Brooke (Sophia Bush); Torrey DeVitto as the nanny of James, the son of Nathan (James Lafferty) and Haley (Bethany Joy Galeotti); and Kevin Federline as a cocky, self-absorbed would-be rock star, above. Now there's a stretch. 7 P.M. (C-Span); 8 P.M. (FNC); 9 P.M. (MSNBC); 11 P.M. (13) NEW HAMPSHIRE PRIMARY Tracking results of the year's first presidential primary vote.

headline: THE WEEK AHEAD | APRIL 26 - MAY 2
summary: Television Mike Hale

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 10 P.M. (MTV) P. DIDDY'S STARMAKERSean Combs (a k a P. Diddy), above, and Mark Burnett set out to find a stellar new recording talent with the help of industry experts in this competition series. Each week 14 performers will be coached by a team including Rodney Jerkins, a producer and songwriter for Beyoncé and Mary J. Blige; Tamara Conniff, the editor in chief of Billboard magazine; Laurie Ann Gibson, a choreographer with ''Making the Band''; the singer and actress Kimberly Caldwell; and the manager Johnny Wright, whose clients have included Janet Jackson, New Kids on the Block, Britney Spears and the Jonas Brothers. Lady Gaga, Pete Wentz, Nicole Scherzinger and Kelly Rowland will do stints as guest judges. The winner will receive a contract with Bad Boy Records and career guidance from Mr. Combs. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH JOHN KING The topic this morning is health care reform, and those discussing it include Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius, who also appears with Senator Arlen Specter, Democrat of Pennsylvania, and Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, on ''This Week With George Stephanopoulos,'' at 10 on ABC; Senator Kent Conrad, Democrat of North Dakota, and Senator Richard C. Shelby, Republican of Alabama, on ''Fox News Sunday With Chris Wallace,'' at 10 on Fox; Robert Gibbs, the White House press secretary, on ''Face the Nation,'' at 10:30 on CBS; and Senator Tom Coburn, Republican of Oklahoma, and Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, on ''Meet the Press,'' at 10:30 on NBC.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths Chatzopoulos, George
summary: CHATZOPOULOS--George. The employees of CB Richard Ellis are deeply saddened by the tragic passing of our friend and colleague George Chatzopoulos. George was an exemplary professional, conscientious colleague and emerging leader in our Downtown office. He will be greatly missed. Our hearts go out to his mother, Noula; sister, Katie and brother, Michael.

headline: What's On TODAY
summary: 8 P.M. (ABC) THE 60TH PRIMETIME EMMY AWARDS The five nominees for outstanding host for a reality or reality competition program -- from left, Ryan Seacrest (''American Idol''), Heidi Klum (''Project Runway''), Tom Bergeron, kneeling (''Dancing With the Stars''), Jeff Probst (''Survivor'') and Howie Mandel (''Deal or No Deal'') -- will host this ceremony honoring excellence in television. In addition to the usual starry list of nominees and presenters, the event, broadcast live from the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles, will feature a backdrop made of sets from shows like ''Desperate Housewives,'' ''Seinfeld,'' ''The West Wing'' and ''M*A*S*H''; trophy-presenter gowns designed by Christian Siriano (''Project Runway'') and Lauren Conrad (''The Hills''); a performance of great theme songs by Josh Groban; and an appearance by Oprah Winfrey. E! will cover celebrity arrivals and preparations in ''Countdown to the Red Carpet'' at 4 and then interview some of the more fashionably turned out in ''Live From the Red Carpet'' at 6. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOSHenry M. Paulson Jr., the United States Treasury secretary, makes the news-show rounds this morning, starting here, where he joins Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, and Representative John A. Boehner, Republican of Ohio. At 10:30 on CBS, Mr. Paulson moves to ''Face the Nation,'' where he joins Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, and Senator Richard Shelby, Republican of Alabama. He also appears on ''Meet the Press,'' at 10:30 on NBC, with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) WALLANDERKenneth Branagh, left, plays Inspector Kurt Wallander, Henning Mankell's scruffy Swedish sleuth, in this ''Masterpiece Mystery!'' production. The three-part series begins with ''Sidetracked,'' in which a search for the identity of a young woman who set herself on fire leads Wallander to suspect a serial killer who is scalping members of Sweden's high society. But looks are deceiving: a profiler tells Wallander that the murderer will probably appear to be perfectly normal. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH JOHN KING Gen. David H. Petraeus discusses the increasing violence in Pakistan here and later on ''Fox News Sunday,'' at 10 on Fox.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (A&E) JACKED ''I figure for every one you arrest, there are three are four more out there, stealing cars,'' says a policeman, a member of an auto theft task force in northern New Jersey. ''It's job security,'' his partner adds. In this series premiere a police helicopter pursues a speeding car thief. 10 A.M. (Fox) THE WENDY WILLIAMS SHOW Ms. Williams dishes with Cameron Mathison of ''All My Children''; Stacy London reveals the latest trends in handbags.

headline: Excerpt: 'Jesse Stone: Thin Ice'
summary: The CBS television movie, the fifth in a series starring Tom Selleck as a small-town police chief, has its premiere on March 1.

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 4 P.M. and 8 P.M. (NBC) U.S. FIGURE SKATING CHAMPIONSHIPS The top skaters in singles, pairs and ice dancing, including Kimmie Meissner, left, take to the rink at the Xcel Energy Center in St. Paul for a total of five hours on Saturday, and two on Sunday, in the nation's most prestigious figure-skating event. Giving the spin-by-spin from the broadcasting booth: Bob Costas, Dick Button, Tom Hammond, Scott Hamilton, Sandra Bezic, Tracy Wilson, Jamie Salé and David Pelletier. 2 P.M. (MTV) RANDY JACKSON PRESENTS: AMERICA'S BEST DANCE CREW Mr. Jackson, the mellow one among the ''American Idol'' judges, is head honcho of this new series in which hip-hop troupes compete for a cash prize and a touring contract. J C Chasez and Shane Sparks are the judges; Mario Lopez is host. Viewers will vote for their favorites, with the weakest two teams dancing it out for a chance to move on to the next round. The footwork begins with this live two-hour casting special.

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 9:30 P.M. (TBS) MY BOYS When last we saw P. J. (Jordana Spiro, above, with Jamie Kaler, left, and Michael Bunin), she was on her way to Italy without a man -- until three showed up in her life at the same time. This season premiere finds P. J. on the plane with her mystery date in the first-class cabin. Meanwhile in Chicago the gang is banished from Crowley's for two weeks after Mike (Mr. Kaler) sleeps with a waitress and doesn't call her afterward. 8:30 P.M. (GAC) THE ROAD HAMMERS No, it's not another series about men doing dangerous jobs. This eight-episode reality show follows the Canadian country music band the Road Hammers as it tries to make it big in Nashville.

headline: Breathing Life (and Death) Into Friday Night
summary: FRIDAY night used to be the place television shows went to die if they couldn't get a slot on Saturday. Then, five years ago, CBS put death itself on the menu: ''Ghost Whisperer'' presented an antiques-store owner, Melinda Gordon (Jennifer Love Hewitt), as a kind of travel agent for the deceased, helping unsettled souls enter the hereafter.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 8 P.M. (IFC) FARGO (1996) This Coen brothers' comic noir -- set mainly in Minnesota, despite the title -- features William H. Macy as Jerry Lundegaard, a down-on-his-luck, bumbling car salesman who hires two even more inept henchmen to kidnap his wife in hopes of a handsome reward from her wealthy father, who owns the dealership. Too bad for him, Marge Gunderson (Frances McDormand, above) is the persistent (and pregnant) investigator on the case. Writing for The New York Times, Janet Maslin said of ''Fargo,'' ''the filmmakers' absurdist humor and beautifully honed storytelling give it a winning acerbity, a quirky appreciation of the sheer futility captured on screen.'' Ms. McDormand won an Academy Award for her performance. 7 A.M. (ABC) GOOD MORNING AMERICA

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 9 P.M. (Sci Fi) GHOST HUNTERS INTERNATIONAL A crew of paranormal investigators applies its weird science to some of Europe's most infamous haunted locations in this ''Ghost Hunters'' spinoff. First: explorations of Chillingham Castle, billed as ''the most haunted castle in England,'' and Mary King's Close, an underground warren of vaults and tunnels that housed the destitute in 19th-century Scotland. The world travelers include the veteran sleuths Robb Demarest, Andy Andrews, Brian Harnois, Donna LaCroix (above, at Chillingham) and Barry Fitzgerald, as well as a newcomer, Shannon Sylvia. In ''Ghost Hunters: Return to St. Augustine Lighthouse,'' at 8, the original Taps squad performs another investigation on the historical St. Augustine Lighthouse in Florida.

headline: News Summary
summary: INTERNATIONALA3-14 Limbo for U.S. Women Reporting Assault in Iraq

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (Fox) HOUSE When last we saw House (Hugh Laurie), he was trying to piece his memories -- and his life -- back together after a bus accident that resulted in the death of Amber (Anne Dudek), Wilson's girlfriend. This season premiere begins as Wilson (Robert Sean Leonard, left) returns from an extended leave and announces that he's quitting Princeton-Plainsboro Teaching Hospital. House thinks that's a bad idea. And the timing is terrible since House has to figure out why the hard-working 37-year-old assistant to a feminist leader collapsed during a business meeting. Leave it to Cuddy (Lisa Edelstein) to try to broker a peace agreement. 11 A.M. (NBC) THE MARTHA STEWART SHOW Ms. Stewart's daughter, Alexis, and Jennifer Koppelman Hutt discuss their new series, ''Whatever, Martha!'' (see below).

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 10 P.M. (13) TODAY'S MAN From the time Nicky Gottlieb was an infant, his family knew he was not like other children. He had stellar math skills as a small child, yet couldn't carry on a conversation or connect with his peers. When he was 21, his condition was diagnosed as Asperger's syndrome, a high-functioning form of autism that was not recognized in the United States until 1994. In this ''Independent Lens'' documentary Lizzie Gottlieb, Nicky's sister (above, with Nicky), tries to make sense of his life and learn how to help him, as he struggles to venture beyond the security of his family home -- which he shares with his father, the editor Robert Gottlieb, and his mother, the actress Maria Tucci -- and his favorite television shows to become a functioning adult with a job, an apartment and friends. 8 P.M. (CBS) GHOST WHISPERER Melinda (Jennifer Love Hewitt) maneuvers through a tangle of gossip and romance as she tries to get to the bottom of the haunting at the new high school of Ned (Christoph Sanders).

headline: Product Placements Acquire a Life of Their Own on Shows
summary: In the season finale of ''CSI: NY'' in May, the show's characters gathered around videoconferencing screens to share information about a shooting. ''She wants everybody on a TelePresence call,'' says an investigator, Lindsay Monroe. ''O.K., we have a full house, network's secure, you're good to go, Stella.'' The unlikely supporting player in the episode was Cisco Systems, which wanted to show off its TelePresence videoconferencing system. Cisco's on-air cameo may seem puzzling to viewers more familiar with product placements for soft drinks or cars (who would rush out to buy a complex computer system after seeing it on CSI?), but the placement resulted from careful deal-making by the company's entertainment agency, Davie Brown Entertainment, with CBS and the show.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) THE NEW ADVENTURES OF OLD CHRISTINE Old feelings between Christine (Julia Louis-Dreyfus) and Papa Jeff (Scott Bakula), above, are reawakened at the wedding of Richard (Clark Gregg) and New Christine (Emily Rutherfurd) in this Season 4 cliffhanger. In the first-season finale of ''Gary Unmarried,'' at 8:30, Gary (Jay Mohr) and Allison (Paula Marshall) wind up in the bedroom. Together. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Brad Pitt and Larry King are guests.

headline: What's On TODAY
summary: 8 P.M. (TCM) PRIME TIME FEATURE: DIRECTED BY TONY RICHARDSONOne of the ''new wave'' of British directors who reinvented the country's film industry in the 1960s, Richardson made his feature debut with his adaptation of John Osborne's play ''Look Back in Anger'' (1958), starring Richard Burton, above, as a university graduate who spews vitriol at everyone in his path, especially his upper-class wife (Mary Ure, who was married to Osborne at the time). It is on at 10:15, preceded by ''Tom Jones'' (1963), Richardson's seductively bawdy Academy Award-winning drama about an 18th-century English country boy turned Casanova (Albert Finney), at 8. 10 A.M. (A BC) THIS WEEK WITH GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOSSenator Claire McCaskill, Democrat of Missouri; Carly Fiorina, former chief executive of Hewlett-Packard; and Alan Greenspan, former chairman of the Federal Reserve, are the headliners.

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 8 P.M. (13) MY MUSIC: DOO WOP LOVE SONGS R&B groups perform, including Little Anthony and the Imperials, the Tokens, Cleveland Still and the Dubs and original members of the Drifters, above (from left, Ben E. King, Charlie Thomas and Bill Pinkney). 8 P.M. (Discovery) DISCOVERY ATLASEdward James Olmos narrates a tour of Mexico; a masked wrestler, a cliff diver, an altar builder and others are profiled.

headline: Inside the Times
summary: International CLINTON EXPRESSES CONCERN

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) THE 61ST PRIMETIME EMMY AWARDSNeil Patrick Harris, left, who almost single-handedly boosted ratings as host of the Tony Awards, tries to spin the same magic for this ceremony, broadcast live from the Nokia Theater in Los Angeles -- and maybe take home a statuette for comedy supporting actor for ''How I Met Your Mother.'' Justin Timberlake, who on Sept. 12, at a ceremony for the 2009 Creative Arts Emmy Awards, became the first ''Saturday Night Live'' host to win for outstanding guest actor in a comedy series, is a presenter. So are Ellen Burstyn, Ricky Gervais, Sigourney Weaver, Michael J. Fox, Bob Newhart, Kevin Bacon, Kyra Sedgwick, Tracy Morgan, Tina Fey, Blake Lively and Kiefer Sutherland. A 17-piece band will feature the saxophonist Tom Scott, the guitarists Dean Parks and Ray Parker Jr., and the percussionist Lenny Castro. Sarah McLachlan will sing during the ''In Memoriam'' segment. And Maksim Chmerkovskiy and Karina Smirnoff will show off their sultry moves in a routine honoring dance on reality television. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH JOHN KING President Obama makes the Sunday morning talk show rounds, starting here with a discussion of the challenges facing his administration, including health care reform, the war in Afghanistan and the economy. He will also appear on ''This Week With George Stephanopoulos'' at 10 on ABC; ''Al Punto With Jorge Ramos'' at 10 on Univision; ''Face the Nation'' at 10:30 on CBS; and ''Meet the Press'' at 10:30 on NBC.

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 10 P.M. (NBC) LAW & ORDER: SPECIAL VICTIMS UNIT Robin Williams, above, unleashes his manic side to play Merritt Rook, an engineer who poses as a police officer to manipulate people into committing criminal acts. When Rook defends himself at trial and is set free, he uses his mind games to put Detectives Benson (Mariska Hargitay) and Stabler (Christopher Meloni) in danger. 7 P.M. (Cinemax) NANKING (2007) Bill Guttentag and Dan Sturman's documentary recounts the Japanese occupation of Nanking, China, in which an estimated 300,000 civilians were murdered and 80,000 women raped in a few weeks, and the efforts of a handful of Western expatriates to protect as much of the population as they could.

headline: Fox Business Network To Simulcast Imus Show
summary: Broadening its definition of business news, the Fox Business Network said Thursday that it would simulcast the ''Imus in the Morning'' radio show starting on Oct. 5. As expected, Fox said it had signed a multiyear deal with Don Imus, right, the host who was fired by CBS Radio and MSNBC two years ago after making racial remarks about the Rutgers University women's basketball team. His program was revived by the radio company Citadel and the rural television network RFD-TV, but Mr. Imus ended the television deal last month. The simulcast, to be shown from 6 to 9 a.m. Eastern time, is expected to buoy the low-rated Fox Business Network, which began in October 2007. Mr. Imus doesn't make financial news a regular part of his talk show, but Fox said the program ''will incorporate additional business news into its format.'' Notably, three of the anchors partially displaced by Mr. Imus's hiring will host a three-hour morning-news program on the network's Web site, FoxBusiness.com, from 6 to 9. The anchors of the Web show, Jenna Lee, Connell McShane and Ashley Webster, will also appear regularly on ''Imus in the Morning,'' Fox said. Alexis Glick, a vice president at Fox Business who now leads the network's 7 to 10 a.m. hours, will remain the host of the 9 a.m. hour. In a statement, Mr. Imus said: ''I love Fox. Roger Ailes is the pre-eminent genius of American broadcasting. Who wouldn't want to do this?''

headline: Cougars, Crime and Witchcraft
summary: Dates are subject to change. Times are Eastern and Pacific. SEPTEMBER

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 11 P.M. (SportsNet New York) BEER MONEY Think you know New York sports? Are you willing to bet on it? This new quiz show ventures into the five boroughs -- to stadiums, arenas, ballparks, tailgate parties and even Central Park -- to test New Yorkers' knowledge of their hometown teams. Chris Carlin, above right, and Julie Alexandria will ask each participant a series of three questions, worth $10, $20 and $100; those who answer a question incorrectly can watch their money, and any potential icy brew, go down the drain. The show moves into its regular slot on Sunday at 7 p.m. 8 P.M. (IFC) TRIBECA WRAP UP SPECIAL Highlights from this year's film festival.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (ABC) THE FORGOTTEN Alex Donovan (Christian Slater, above) and his investigative network take on the case of a Jane Doe in her 20s who was found strangled and dumped in an alley six weeks earlier. She is wearing an engagement ring, but her fiancé doesn't seem to be looking for her. 4 P.M. (NBC); 8 P.M. (55) THE ELLEN DeGENERES SHOW Drew Barrymore talks about her film ''Whip It,'' which she directed.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (Fox) ALL-STAR GAME The National League will try to break its 11-year losing streak in this fourth, and last, Major League Baseball All-Star Game to be played in Yankee Stadium, above. 8 P.M. (ABC Family) THE SECRET LIFE OF THE AMERICAN TEENAGER Ben (Kenny Baumann) and Amy (Shailene Woodley) share their first kiss. In the meantime Amy tells her sister, Ashley (India Eisley), about her pregnancy -- but not her parents.

headline: David H. Greene, 94, Scholar of Ireland
summary: David H. Greene, a leading scholar of Irish literature and one of the authorized biographers of the playwright J. M. Synge, the author of ''The Playboy of the Western World,'' died last Wednesday near his home in Boynton Beach, Fla. He was 94. The cause was pneumonia, his daughter Candy Moss said.

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 7:00 P.M. (NBC) THE AMERICAN DREAM WITH JIM CRAMER Just as soaring fuel prices and plummeting home values cause visions of the American dream to fade, Mr. Cramer finds signs of economic life in Nascar racing. In this one-hour special Mr. Cramer, above, the host of ''Mad Money W/Jim Cramer'' on CNBC, travels to Lowe's Motor Speedway in Charlotte, N.C., to talk about cars, winning and business with the drivers Kyle Busch, Jimmy Johnson, Carl Edwards, Casey Mears and Jeff Burton. 10:30 A.M. (NBC) MEET THE PRESS Carleton S. Fiorina, the former chief executive of Hewlett-Packard and an economic adviser to Senator John McCain's campaign, is a guest. Tom Brokaw is moderator.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) PBS SPECIAL REPORT ON HEALTH CARE REFORM Three PBS news programs band together to parse health care reform in this 90-minute report. ''Now on PBS'' examines the ways in which reform may change the lives of Americans, especially baby boomers who have their own coverage but are also responsible for aging parents and grown children. ''Nightly Business Report'' investigates the cost of and controversies surrounding employer-provided health care. And ''Tavis Smiley'' focuses on childhood obesity, particularly among minorities, and offers solutions to the crisis. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Mackenzie Phillips discusses her memoir, ''High on Arrival,'' and her relationship with her father, John Phillips of the Mamas and the Papas.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (13, 49) DARWIN'S DARKEST HOUR ''Nova'' and National Geographic Television collaborate on this dramatization of Charles Darwin's greatest personal crisis: the decision over whether to present his theory of natural selection to the public. Henry Ian Cusick, above with Frances O'Connor, plays Darwin, who, having spent years refining his ideas and writing his book ''On the Origin of Species,'' delayed publication because of concerns about a religious backlash until 1858, when he learned that the naturalist Alfred Wallace was about to publish ideas similar to his own. Ms. O'Connor portrays Darwin's wife, Emma, who clung tightly to her Unitarian beliefs. John Goldsmith (''Victoria and Albert'') wrote the screenplay. 9 A.M. (CBS) THE DOCTORS The experts explain what various body sounds mean and how to quiet them. Also, why cracking your back hurts more than it helps.

headline: No Skeletons Hiding in Here
summary: SOME closets need major renovations to make them more efficient, but most can be updated with the installation of new shelving systems. Others simply need a new shoe rack, or a dehumidifier to eliminate mildew in warm weather. 1. The Arturo armoire has a polished ebony finish, glass feet, brass fittings and pulls, and a natural maple interior. It comes with customized shelves, drawers and poles, and with LED lights that illuminate when the doors open; the unit shown is 67 3/8 inches by 55 inches by 21 inches, and the price starts at $23,645, at Georgetti USA, 200 Lexington Avenue (33rd Street). For information and locations in other cities: (888) 836-9100.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths COHN, SAM
summary: COHN--Sam. Sam, you were one heck of a guy to share an office with at CBS. I valued knowing and working with you. Condolences to family. Stanley Stempler

headline: Ravens (12-5) at Titans (13-3): 4:30 p.m., CBS Line: Titans by 3
summary: Quarterback Kerry COLLINS VS. THE BALTIMORE DefensE

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 8 P.M. (TBS and TNT) SCREEN ACTORS GUILD AWARDS Nominees are expected to show up for this ceremony, broadcast from the SilverScreen Theater at the Pacific Film Center in Los Angeles, which has been given a waiver by the striking writers guild and will not be picketed. They include George Clooney (above), Daniel Day-Lewis, Emile Hirsch, Viggo Mortensen, Cate Blanchett, Julie Christie, Marion Cotillard, Angelina Jolie, Ellen Page, Kevin Kline, Debra Messing, Queen Latifah, Vanessa Redgrave and Gena Rowlands. Charles Durning will receive the Life Achievement Award. E! will report on celebrity arrivals in ''Countdown to the Red Carpet'' at 5 p.m. and ''Live From the Red Carpet'' at 6 p.m. 8 P.M. (MyNetwork TV) STELLAR GOSPEL MUSIC AWARDS Kirk Franklin, CeCe Winans and Byron Cage are hosts of this ceremony, taped at the Grand Ole Opry earlier this month, which honors the year's best gospel music, with performers including Smokie Norful, Marvin Sapp, the Clark Sisters and DeWayne Woods. Ben Vereen and Edwin Hawkins will present Tramaine Hawkins with the James Cleveland Lifetime Achievement Award.

headline: Poll Shows Economic Woes
summary: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll shows that Americans are unsure about their economic future.

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 10 P.M. (NBC) ER Pratt (Mekhi Phifer, left) gets cold feet when Bettina (Gina Ravera) asks to take their relationship to a higher level in the show's last new episode for now. Neela (Parminder Nagra) joins Ortho's hockey team and gets a shock during the first game. And Julia (Reiko Aylesworth) tries to help a prison doctor assuage his guilt after he reveals that he gave lethal injections to criminals on death row. 8 P.M. (ABC) UGLY BETTY Betty (America Ferrera) and Henry (Christopher Gorham) start going out of their minds when Betty unwittingly begins wearing a lethal scent concocted by Fey Summers. Meanwhile Claire (Judith Light) goes on the stand for Fey's murder, Amanda (Becki Newton) withholds important information, and Wilhelmina (Vanessa Williams) tries new tactics to become a member of the Meade family.

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 10:30 P.M. (Comedy Central) RENO 911! If only law enforcement were always this much fun. This show's fictional Nevada cops, above, don their uniforms -- hot pants, anyone? -- and resume their failed attempts to keep the streets safe from, well, people like them. This fifth-season premiere reveals whether Garcia (Carlos Alazraqui) steals the husband of Dangle (Thomas Lennon) and just who exactly is the father of the baby of Deputy Wiegel (Kerri Kenney). Christina Applegate, Seth Green, Lisa Lampanelli, George Lopez and Ryan Stiles are to make guest appearances in coming episodes. 8 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL Night 2 of ear-plugging, eye-covering auditions, this time in Dallas, in preparation for the seventh season. Simon Cowell, Paula Abdul and Randy Jackson provide the requisite scurrilous criticism. Ryan Seacrest smoothes ruffled feathers.

headline: Don't Call 'Em Reruns, They're Classics
summary: Television lovers are easy to buy for: more than 100 new TV-on-DVD releases come out every month. Here are a few current selections, from cozy classics to newer and decidedly uncozy shows. MIKE HALE ALLY MCBEAL: THE COMPLETE SERIESCalista Flockhart's winsome lawyer lives out all five seasons of her existence in this 32-disc boxed set. (20th Century Fox, $199.98, not rated) DAVE KEHRANDY BARKER P.I.: THE COMPLETE SERIES The title is the first joke: this cult favorite detective comedy starring Andy Richter lasted just six episodes in the spring of 2007. They are all here, with extras like ''Writers Class 101,'' which features the veteran comedy writers Jonathan Groff and Jane Espenson. (Shout! Factory, two discs, $24.99, not rated) MIKE HALE

headline: Loose on Free Time
summary: John Edwards did not receive an endorsement from David Letterman on CBS's ''Late Show'' on Tuesday night, but he did receive eight valuable minutes to woo voters. Mr. Edwards even allowed Mr. Letterman to ruffle his hair at the end of the segment.

headline: The Pros and Cons of 60
summary: Sixty is the magic number for the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid. It is the number of votes he needs to overcome any Republican filibusters that might block the health care bill. It is also the number of senators in the Democratic caucus. But in many ways, 60 is also a mirage -- falsely raising Democrats' hopes, particularly those of more liberal senators, that they have the muscle to push the health care bill without making concessions to centrists in both parties.

headline: Inside the Times
summary: International IRAN'S PARLIAMENT FIRES OFFICIAL,

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 7 P.M. (NBC) AMERICA'S FAVORITE MOM In honor of the centenary of Mother's Day, Donny and Marie Osmond, above, will crown the woman who best exemplifies the American mother, as voted by viewers. As payback for all the diaper changing and dribble wiping, the winner will receive $250,000; a diamond-and-gold pendant; a year's worth of floral arrangements; a trip to New York, complete with beauty makeover and spa day; a family vacation to St. Lucia; and new kitchen and laundry appliances. Christina Aguilera, Tony Hawk, Alicia Keys, Hulk Hogan, Naomi Judd and Amy Poehler will make appearances, as will Opal Trundle, a mother of 6 and grandmother of 96 who was born on May 11, 1908. 8 P.M. (CBS) SURVIVOR: MICRONESIA -- FANS VS. FAVORITES In this two-hour season finale, the last immunity challenge and tribal council take place, after which the finalists are questioned by the jury members, who vote for the winner. At 10 the winner is announced, as the 20 castaways reunite to reminisce about island life.

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) THE 62ND ANNUAL TONY AWARDS The American Theater Wing and the Broadway League honor excellence on Broadway in this ceremony, broadcast live from Radio City Music Hall and featuring Whoopi Goldberg (above) in her debut as host. Performances are scheduled from the casts of the Tony-nominated musicals ''Cry-Baby,'' ''In the Heights,'' ''Passing Strange,'' ''Rodgers & Hammerstein's South Pacific, ''Sunday in the Park With George'' and ''Xanadu,'' as well as the previous winners ''Rent'' and ''The Lion King.'' 7 P.M. (Fuse) THE ROCK & ROLL ACID TEST Some think music can kill, and this new series attempts to prove it by using a bulldozer to simulate the forces in a mosh pit and experimenting with just how far you can turn up the amps before your eardrums explode.
