headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (NBC) MACY'S FOURTH OF JULY FIREWORKS SPECTACULAR More than 35,000 shells will explode over New York in the nation's largest Fourth of July fireworks extravaganza, whose theme this year is ''America Dances.'' Natasha Bedingfield, Kenny Chesney, Katharine McPhee and Jordin Sparks are scheduled to perform. Rob Fisher will conduct the New York Pops in patriotic classics and hip shakers like ''Good Golly Miss Molly,'' ''The Twist,'' ''Save the Last Dance for Me,'' ''Rock Around the Clock'' and ''The Tennessee Waltz.'' Macy's will also celebrate its 150th anniversary with a special fireworks display. Natalie Morales and Tiki Barber are the hosts. 7 A.M. (ABC) GOOD MORNING AMERICA Chaka Khan will perform. Sunny Anderson, host of ''Cooking for Real'' on the Food Network, discusses summertime cuisine.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 8 P.M. (ABC) SCRUBS In this eighth-season finale, titled ''My Finale,'' J. D. (Zach Braff, left, with Sarah Chalke) plans his departure from Sacred Heart. But first he has some tasks to complete, including learning the janitor's name. Meanwhile, Elliot (Ms. Chalke) starts surreptitiously furnishing his apartment. Maybe she knows something about the likelihood of this peripatetic sitcom's returning for a ninth season next fall. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW A woman who has been a foster mother to more than 100 children gets a makeover. Another segment looks at the characteristics of a high-functioning alcoholic.

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 10 P.M. (13) NA KAMALEI: THE MEN OF HULA Thanks to Hollywood movies and tourist tales, most of us think of the hula as a female tradition. Yet in ancient times men learned the dance along with martial arts in preparation for battle. That continued until the 1820s, when hula was suppressed by missionaries and went underground for 150 years. In this ''Independent Lens'' documentary Lisette Marie Flanary journeys to Hawaii to chronicle the story of the master teacher Robert Cazimero as his all-male hula school, the only one in Hawaii, prepares to compete in the world's largest hula festival, above. 8 P.M. (Sci Fi) THE SARAH JANE ADVENTURES In the conclusion of last week's episode, recruits are drafted via laser tag for an intergalactic war, and Luke (Tommy Knight) and Clyde (Daniel Anthony) wind up among the enlisted. At 8:30, in Part 1 of another two-episode story line, Sarah Jane (Elisabeth Sladen) and Luke (Mr. Knight) vanish as a meteor heads toward Earth, leaving Maria (Yasmin Paige) to navigate the time continuum to find her friends.

headline: Second Hand by Merce Cunningham
summary: "A Video Event" on CBS Camera Three, directed by Merrill Brockway.

headline: Alliance of Actors' Unions Ends as Bargaining Nears
summary: A sudden split between two actors unions over the weekend added an unhappy twist to Hollywood's troubled contract cycle. On Saturday, the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists suspended its bargaining alliance with the Screen Actors Guild, just before a board meeting where they had hoped to approve a joint negotiating strategy. The actors' contract with the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers expires on June 30, and talks about a new contract were to have begun within two weeks.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (VH1) BEHIND THE MUSIC Things weren't always rosy for Pink, left. Born Alecia Moore, she rebelled against authority, used drugs and repeatedly ran away from home before catching a break in the Philadelphia club scene as a member of Choice, a female R&B group. Soon she broke out on her own, defied the wishes of her record label and collaborated with her idol, Linda Perry, on ''Missundaztood,'' establishing her credentials as an expressive songwriter. Now 30, Pink reminisces about the wilder ways of her youth and her future as a mature musical force. In ''VH1 Divas (2009),'' at 9, Adele, Kelly Clarkson, Leona Lewis and Miley Cyrus take the stage at the Howard Gilman Opera House at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. 9 A.M. (CBS) THE DOCTORS Topics include causes of obesity, foods that dampen the libido and measuring body composition and shapes.

headline: Pregame With the President
summary: It's going to be awfully hard to avoid President Obama on television this Sunday. The president will appear on five Sunday talk shows -- five -- to press his case for changes to the health care system, White House officials said Monday. That is a presidential record.

headline: Poll Shows Economic Woes
summary: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll shows that Americans are unsure about their economic future.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (SNY) BEER MONEY SportsNet New York, the television home of the Mets, continues to offer sports fans a modest stimulus package with a new season of trivia-for-cash games. Chris Carlin and Alexi Panos (above left, with a contestant) wander the city, with stops at stadiums, arenas, tailgate parties and even Central Park, to pepper those versed in all things athletic with questions. Correct answers equal money -- and if you're lucky, enough cash to pay for those pricey home-plate tickets at CitiField. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Simon Baker talks about the season finale of his series ''The Mentalist.'' Also, a 10-year-old girl battles breast cancer.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: GLOBAL SHOCK WAVES UBS, the giant Swiss bank, wrote down $19 billion related to the American real estate market, and Deutsche Bank, Germany's biggest, said that it would take a $4 billion write-down because of the subprime crisis. AID FOR HOMEOWNERS A pledge of cooperation on Capitol Hill is a sign of consensus among political leaders for broader government action to help homeowners at risk of foreclosure. [A1.]

headline: IN DETROIT, FINAL FOUR IS A GROWTH INDUSTRY
summary: From one point of view, the Final Four in Detroit is an ambitious enterprise, set in an N.F.L. stadium (Ford Field) with more than 70,000 seats available and a chance to host the best-attended championship game in history. From another, it is a huge risk: the local economy is in tatters, and there is the prospect that many of those 70,000-plus seats could be empty.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (Syfy) ALICE (2009) Nick Willing reimagines Lewis Carroll's ''Alice's Adventures in Wonderland'' and ''Through the Looking-Glass'' to tell the story of Alice Hamilton (Caterina Scorsone, above), a modern-day martial arts instructor with commitment issues who -- after turning down a marriage proposal from her love, Jack Chase (Philip Winchester), and an heirloom engagement ring -- finds herself in the madcap Wonderland, a city of twisted towers and casinos built out of playing cards. Kathy Bates plays the Queen of Hearts, the devilish ruler of this parallel universe; Colm Meaney is her King of Hearts. The cast is rounded out by Andrew-Lee Potts, as Hatter; Tim Curry, as Dodo; Matt Frewer, as the White Knight; and Harry Dean Stanton, as Caterpillar. Part 2 will be shown on Monday at 9. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOSSecretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton and Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates discuss President Obama's military strategy for Afghanistan before moving to ''Face the Nation,'' at 10:30 on CBS, and ''Meet the Press,'' at 10:30 on NBC.

headline: What's On TODAY
summary: 9 P.M. (CBS) FRONT OF THE CLASS (2008) Jimmy Wolk, right, stars as Brad Cohen, who has Tourette's syndrome but defies the odds and becomes a gifted teacher. Patricia Heaton and Treat Williams play Brad's parents in this ''Hallmark Hall of Fame'' presentation, based on a true story. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY WITH CHRIS WALLACE Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice discusses her legacy and the state of the nation before moving on to ''This Week With George Stephanopoulos'' at 10 on ABC and ''Late Edition With Wolf Blitzer'' at 11 on CNN.

headline: What's On Today?
summary: 9 P.M. (NBC) MACY'S FOURTH OF JULY FIREWORKS SPECTACULAR Rob Thomas, Jewel and the Broadway cast of ''West Side Story,'' including the Tony Award-winning Karen Olivo, will perform in this 33rd annual spectacular, in which 40,000 shells -- about 1,500 per minute -- will explode from six barges on the Hudson River in honor of the 400th anniversary of its exploration by Henry Hudson on his ship, the Half Moon. Natalie Morales and Tiki Barber are hosts. NOON (13) THE OPEN MIND Mark Bauerlein, a professor at Emory University, discusses his book ''The Dumbest Generation: How the Digital Age Stupefies Young Americans and Jeopardizes Our Future (Or, Don't Trust Anyone Under 30).''

headline: Gameday Guide: Fred Bierman handicaps Saturday's best college matchups.
summary: NORTHWESTERN at 20 MINNESOTA Noon, ESPN2 After a 1-11 season last year, Minnesota has been one of the biggest surprises of the season. 19 TULSA at ARKANSAS 2 p.m., No TV This is a chance for Tulsa to remain undefeated and to make a statement against an SEC opponent.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 8 P.M. (Nickelodeon) MR. TROOP MOM (2009) George Lopez (above, with campers) plays Eddie Serrano, a Gucci-loafer-clad workaholic lawyer and widowed father who tries to bond with his daughter, Naomi (Daniela Bobadilla), by signing up for ''team mom'' duty at an action-game jamboree. Jane Lynch is Ms. Hulka, the camp's Pattonesque director; Jianna Ballard is Skyler, the leader of a clique of mean girls whose reason for existence seems to be to make Naomi and her friends miserable; and April Telek is Skyler's mother, Denise, who only has eyes for Eddie. This original Nickelodeon movie also features a performance by Nat and Alex Wolff of the Naked Brothers Band. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW A visit to the U.S.S. Intrepid Sea, Air and Space Museum; Earth, Wind and Fire and Chicago, now on tour together, perform.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 8 P.M. (Style) RUNNING IN HEELS In this foray behind the scenes at Marie Claire, a New York fashion magazine, three interns -- Ashley Gosik, Samantha Dezur (above left) and Talita Silva -- balance gofer jobs for their superiors, including Joanna Coles, the editor in chief, with their social lives (and, even in this first episode, some internecine cat fights). 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY Adm. Mike Mullen, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, discusses the Iraq and Afghanistan wars.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (CW) SUPERNATURAL The demon hunters Sam (Jared Padalecki) and Dean (Jensen Ackles, above right, with Mr. Padalecki, center, and Michael P. Northey) are taken aback when they come across a comic book titled ''Supernatural'' that is clearly based on them and chronicles their adventures in astonishing detail. They confront the writer (Rob Benedict), who says he has visions that compel him to write their stories. 7 A.M. (ABC) TODAYNoah Wyle reminisces about ''ER,'' which has its finale Thursday (see below). Stevie Nicks performs.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (TCM) GREAT DIRECTORS: FRANÇOIS TRUFFAUT A five-film tribute begins with ''Jules and Jim'' (1962), starring Jeanne Moreau as a tempestuous beauty who comes between college friends (Henri Serre and Oskar Werner, from left above, with Ms. Moreau). The evening continues with the semiautobiographical ''400 Blows'' (1959), about a 12-year-old (Jean-Pierre Léaud) who escapes his dysfunctional family by turning to crime, at 10; ''The Bride Wore Black'' (1968), with Ms. Moreau as a woman who seeks revenge on the five men who murdered her fiancé, at midnight; ''Small Change'' (1976), in which two boys (Geory Desmouceaux and Philippe Goldmann) from different backgrounds share the pain and humor of growing up, at 2 a.m.; and ''The Wild Child'' (1970), starring Truffaut as a crusading doctor who tries to civilize a boy (Jean-Pierre Cargol) raised in the wilderness by wolves. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Michelle Pfeiffer talks about her new film, ''Chéri.'' Also, a deserving father gets a makeover, and Mario Batali cooks.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (13, 49) WHY WE LOVE CATS AND DOGS Americans own 73 million dogs and 90 million cats, and for many the relationships are as complicated and emotional as those between best friends or even spouses. ''Nature'' dissects our affection for dogs and cats, and why the species are so polarizing, with interviews with Sarah Wilson, above, a dog behaviorist; Emily Weiss, a matchmaker who pairs pets and owners for the A.S.P.C.A.; and Dr. Nicholas Dodman, a veterinarian who thinks that cats can be as trainable as dogs. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH JOHN KING Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, discusses the stimulus package; Magic Johnson, Bill Russell, Chris Paul, Grant Hill and Steve Nash offer a critique of President Obama's basketball game.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (TLC) STAGER INVASION In this latest makeover show, pegged to the stagnant real estate market, Lisa Lynch, a ''home staging'' expert, helps frustrated owners make their residences buyer-friendly in just eight hours and on a budget of $1,000. In this series premiere she comes to the rescue of Chris and Michele Tune (above, with Ms. Lynch at left), who will face foreclosure on their country-themed home unless they can sell it immediately. The first step: painting over the chicken mural on the kitchen cabinets. At 8:30, Ms. Lynch focuses on the home of Marlene Federico, who, since her husband's unexpected death, can no longer afford her mortgage payments. The problem spots include a red and blue ''superhero room'' and a hole in the wall. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOWJosh Duhamel talks about his latest film, ''Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen.'' Also, a ride with a taxi driver who asks his passengers to create art.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 8 P.M. (Animal Planet) UNDERDOG TO WONDERDOG Abandoned shelter dogs are given a shot at being the pets they might have been, in this new canine makeover series that even Cinderella might envy. Led by Ryan Smith, a Wonder Team rescues and rehabilitates strays, after which they are trained by Andrea Arden, a dog behaviorist; groomed by Ali McLennan; and then placed in a loving home with a custom-designed doghouse built by David Leon. In this premiere episode, the fairy tale begins for Lucky, a Yorkshire terrier who was given up after being hit by a car and, after surgery and some T.L.C., is placed with the family of 11-year-old Olivia Maryanski, above with Lucky. NOON (13) THE OPEN MINDJudith S. Kaye, retiring chief judge of the State of New York, discusses a court system for the 21st century.

headline: Gameday Guide: Fred Bierman handicaps Saturday's best college matchups.
summary: 20 GA. TECH at 19 N. CAROLINA Noon, No TV Butch Davis has the Tar Heels in the running for their first conference title in almost 30 years. 3 PENN STATE at IOWA 3:30 p.m., ABC Penn State needs to keep winning and just let everything else sort itself out.

headline: Obama Says U.S. Must Seek Ways Out of Afghanistan
summary: The United States must look for a way out of the war in Afghanistan, President Obama said, signaling that the military buildup there is meant to open the door to seeing the eventual withdrawal of American and NATO troops from the country. ''There's got to be an exit strategy,'' Mr. Obama said in a wide-ranging interview that was aired on CBS's ''60 Minutes'' on Sunday. ''There's got to be a sense that this is not perpetual drift.''

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (BET) BET AWARDS '09 This ceremony honoring achievement by blacks and other minorities in entertainment and sports is dedicated to Michael Jackson and his influence on music and pop culture. Jamie Foxx, left, is host of the event, broadcast live from the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles. Monica, Keyshia Cole, Fabolous, Ne-Yo, Maxwell, Soulja Boy, Mary Mary and Beyoncé are scheduled to perform. Nominees include Keri Hilson, Jennifer Hudson, Jazmine Sullivan, T-Pain, Lil Wayne, Young Jeezy, Lil Mama, M.I.A., Regina Belle, Shirley Caesar, Idris Elba, Samuel L. Jackson, Will Smith, Rosario Dawson, Taraji P. Henson, Lisa Leslie and LeBron James. The O'Jays will be honored for lifetime achievement, and Alicia Keys and Wyclef Jean for humanitarianism. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOSDavid Axelrod, the senior White House adviser, is the guest before moving to ''Meet the Press,'' at 10:30 on NBC.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 8 P.M. (ABC) WIFE SWAP Gayla Long, a Missouri homemaker whose favorite things include fast food, 4x4s and paintball, trades places with Renee Stephens-Fowler, above, a Northern Californian life coach whose priorities include education, the environment and healthy living. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW An interview with the former evangelist Ted Haggard.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9:30 P.M. (ABC) SAMANTHA WHO? The amnesiac Samantha Newly (Christina Applegate, above left, with Jean Smart) resumes her quest for self-discovery in this season premiere by teaming up for a dance competition with her mother, Regina (Ms. Smart), so that they can beat Regina's nemesis (Cybill Shepherd). But whereas the old Samantha could rock the Casbah, the new Samantha has two left feet. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW An undercover F.B.I. agent talks about investigating the Gambino crime family. Also, how to help babies sleep through the night, and why men cheat.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (Travel) MOST HAUNTED LIVE! Yvette Fielding, left, and her team of paranormal sleuths travel to Gettysburg, Pa., for a seven-hour live investigation of the most historically significant locations and landmarks in and around the Civil War battlefield. Viewers will be able to monitor Web cams and communicate with the team by way of message boards, texting and something called psychic art. 10 A.M. (55); 3 P.M. (NBC) THE ELLEN DeGENERES SHOW Christina Applegate discusses her battle with breast cancer; Sheryl Crow, a breast cancer survivor, performs.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 2:30 P.M. (HBO) WE ARE ONE: THE OBAMA INAUGURAL CELEBRATION AT THE LINCOLN MEMORIAL HBO opens its signal so that viewers with access to cable or satellite television can watch this concert, to be held on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial with President-elect Barack Obama and Vice President-elect Joseph R. Biden attending. Scheduled performers include Beyoncé (left), Mary J. Blige, Sheryl Crow, Renée Fleming, Josh Groban, Herbie Hancock, John Mellencamp, Usher, Pete Seeger, Shakira, Bruce Springsteen, U2 and Stevie Wonder. Steve Carell, Jamie Foxx, Tom Hanks, Martin Luther King III, Queen Latifah, Laura Linney, Denzel Washington and others will give readings. The Rev. V. Gene Robinson will give the invocation. The live event will be rebroadcast at 7 and 11:30 p.m. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOSDavid Axelrod, a senior adviser to President-elect Barack Obama, talks about the goals and challenges for the Obama administration.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (Logo) 365GAY NEWS SPECIAL: HARVEY MILK On Nov. 27, 1978, Milk, a member of the San Francisco Board of Supervisors and the first openly gay man to be elected to public office in California, and Mayor George Moscone were assassinated by Dan White, a former city supervisor who had recently resigned but wanted his job back. In this report Ross Palombo, a CBS News correspondent, ventures inside San Francisco City Hall, the scene of the crime and a setting for ''Milk,'' the new film starring Sean Penn, above right with Josh Brolin. Another segment visits Harvey Milk Civil Rights Academy, the elementary school in the Castro district of San Francisco. Among those interviewed are Mayor Gavin Newsom of San Francisco and ''Milk'' cast members -- Mr. Brolin, James Franco, Alison Pill and Diego Luna. 10 A.M. (55); 3 P.M. (NBC) THE ELLEN DeGENERES SHOW Bette Midler and Pink perform at Caesars Palace in Las Vegas.

headline: Inside the Times
summary: International RIVAL OF IRAN'S LEADER DENIES ACCUSATIONS AGAINST BROTHER

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths SQUIRE, C.B
summary: SQUIRE--C.B. ''Chick'', editor and author, 88, died peacefully in his sleep January 4 of natural causes in Asheville, NC. Mr. Squire was born in Caldwell, NJ and attended Lincoln School of Teachers College, Columbia University, the University of Connecticut and New York University. Between 1940 and the present he had a long and varied career as an editor, author, correspondent or consultant for many different news organizations including Newsweek, CBS News, The Wilton (CT) Bulletin, The Ridgefield (CT) Press, The Bridgeport (CT) Post-Telegram, The New York Daily News, The Daily Star, Dar al-Hayat, in Beirut, Lebanon (founding editor), An-Nida, a weekly newspaper in English, in Beirut, The New York Times, The Religious News Service, McGraw-Hill Publications, The Chicago Tribune, London Illustrated News, Acorn Press, Inc. (Ridgefield, CT), Platt's Oilgram (managing editor), Early American Life, State Magazine, International Oil News, Petrochemical News, Grolier Encyclopedia, World Petroleum Magazine, and Mountain Xpress, in Asheville, NC. From 1942-1946 Mr. Squire served as a volunteer ambulance driver for the American Field Service with the British Eighth and Fourteenth Armies in the Middle East, North Africa, Italy and India, and received various British and Allied army campaign medals. He was instrumental in securing veterans' recognition for AFS volunteers who served with Allied forces in World War II. He was a founding member of the AFS International Scholarship Program, which continues today. In 1999 he received the Oscar Arias Foundation Peace Award. He served as trustee or board member for numerous organizations, including the North Carolina and Western Carolina chapters of the American Civil Liberties Union, the Asheville - Buncombe Library, The Fund for Investigative Reporting & Editing, AFS Archives & Museum, News & Observer Publishing Co., Gordon H. Greenwood Foundation, and the Mark Twain Library. He also served in a number of political offices during his life, including justice of the peace, State of Connecticut; Democratic Town Committee, Wilton, CT; Democratic State Convention delegate, Hartford, CT; registrar of voters, Buncombe County, NC; elections judge, Buncombe County, NC; Democratic Precinct Committee member, Buncombe County, NC. He was the author of ''Heroes of Conservation,'' (1973); co-author of ''Oil Industry U.S.A.'', (1977); co-author and general editor of The Saga of Section Six, (1994); and editor of ''The Liz Reader,'' (2002), a collection of shorter works by his beloved wife of 53 years, noted author Elizabeth Daniels Squire, who died in 2001. He is survived by three sons, J. Hart Squire, of Weaverville, NC, Mark M. Squire of Fairfax, CA, and Worth P. Squire of College Grove, TN, as well as seven grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to AFS Intercultural Programs, Inc., 71 West 23rd St., 17th Floor, New York, NY, 10010-4102.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (13) BETRAYED In March 2007 George Packer wrote an article for The New Yorker about interpreters who jeopardized their lives on behalf of Americans in Iraq. He turned his reporting into a play about three young Iraqis, two men and a woman, motivated to risk everything by the promise of freedom. Writing in The New York Times, Charles Isherwood said that ''the clarity of the writing, the urgency of the story being told and the fine performances give the play a sharp dramatic impact and a plain-spoken beauty.'' Mr. Packer will introduce this presentation of his Off Broadway play, which was nominated for a Lucille Lortel Award. The cast includes, from left above, Waleed F. Zuaiter, Mike Doyle and Sevan Greene; Pippin Parker directs. 7 A.M. (ABC) GOOD MORNING AMERICA Whoopi Goldberg talks about ''Sugar Plum Ballerinas,'' her children's book, here and on ''Live With Regis and Kelly,'' at 9 on ABC.

headline: CBS Extends SEC Contract
summary: CBS Sports announced a 15-year extension of its SEC deal to carry Saturday afternoon football, the conference championship game and regular-season basketball through the 2023-24 season.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 8 P.M. (13, 49) DANCE IN AMERICA: SAN FRANCISCO BALLET'S 'NUTCRACKER' In honor of its 75th anniversary last year, this company -- which gave ''The Nutcracker'' its United States premiere in 1944 -- reimagined the ballet as set during the 1915 Panama Pacific International Exposition, with choreography by the company's artistic director, Helgi Tomasson; sets by Michael Yeargan; and costumes by Martin Pakledinaz. It features Maria Kochetkova as Clara and Davit Karapetyan, above in mask, as her prince. Kristi Yamaguchi hosts this ''Great Performances'' presentation. 9 A.M. (ABC) LIVE WITH REGIS AND KELLY Tom Cruise discusses his latest film, ''Valkyrie''; Jamie Foxx performs.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (ABC) DIRTY SEXY MONEY This Season 2 premiere packs a wallop, starting with the birthday blowout hosted by Tripp (Donald Sutherland, left) and Letitia (Jill Clayburgh) on their yacht in honor of Nick (Peter Krause). Elsewhere, Brian (Glenn Fitzgerald) reunites with his son; Jeremy (Seth Gabel) tells Nola Lyons (Lucy Liu) about his feelings for Lisa (Zoe McLellan); and someone dies. After which someone else is arrested. 8 P.M. (13, 49) EXECUTED IN ERROR ''Secrets of the Dead'' re-examines evidence from the trial of Hawley Harvey Crippen, who was hanged in London in 1910 for the murder of his wife, and who some researchers now believe was innocent.

headline: THE DENNIS HAYSBERT ROUTE BALLPLAYER TO DOCTOR IN A COVERT GOVERNMENT PROGRAM TO SENATOR TO PRESIDENT.
summary: Mr. Haysbert may be the only man ever elected to the presidency despite having been captured on camera practicing voodoo wearing only a towel. That was in the 1989 baseball movie ''Major League,'' in which his character, the slugger Pedro Cerrano, spoke in the kind of thick Caribbean accent usually associated with the word ''ganja.'' Cerrano turned to voodoo rituals to overcome his inability to hit breaking balls, generally performing these rituals shirtless. (He was, for a future president, remarkably buff.) By 1999 Mr. Haysbert was a doctor in the CBS series ''Now and Again,'' advising a man whose brain had been implanted in a bio-engineered body. He was elected to the United States Senate in 2001, in time for the first season of the Fox series ''24,'' and by Season 2 he was President David Palmer.

headline: Age Is Only a Number
summary: While both campaigns have been trying to paint the candidates' ages as a negative factor, voters do not seem to share their views, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. The average age of a president of the United States when he takes office is 55. Both presidential nominees this year fall well outside of that average: Senator Barack Obama will be 47 at the inauguration on Jan. 20, and Senator John McCain will be 72 (which would make him the oldest first-term president in history).

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 10 P.M. (ABC) QUESTIONS FOR THE PRESIDENT: PRESCRIPTION FOR AMERICA In this special episode of ''Primetime,'' Charles Gibson and Diane Sawyer moderate a conversation with President Obama, broadcast from the East Room of the White House, about the future of the nation's health care system. The president will answer questions from an audience, selected by producers, of people with divergent opinions on the subject. Dr. Timothy Johnson, the ABC News medical editor, will also join the conversation, which will focus on how to fix the system and how proposed changes may affect the economy. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Mary Tyler Moore discusses juvenile diabetes; Katie Lee Joel grills pizza.

headline: What's On TODAY
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) TESS OF THE D'URBERVILLES Gemma Arterton trades the Bond-girl duds she wore as Strawberry Fields in ''Quantum of Solace'' for an airy frock to play Thomas Hardy's spirited 19th-century heroine in this two-part ''Masterpiece Classic'' production, the first with Laura Linney as host. In Part 1, Tess seeks employment from the aristocratic D'Urbervilles after being told she is descended from them, and is seduced by the family's ne'er-do-well son, Alec (Hans Matheson). Fleeing him, she falls in love with Angel (Eddie Redmayne, above with Ms. Arterton), an idealistic farmer. Part 2 will be shown Jan. 11 at 9. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY WITH CHRIS WALLACE Former President George H. W. Bush talks about his tenure in office, current issues facing the president-elect, the political future of his son Jeb and the legacy of his son George.

headline: Inside the Times
summary: International SWINE FLU TAKES HEAVY TOLL

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 8 P.M. (13) PETER GRIMES Anthony Dean Griffey, above, portrays the ultimate outsider in Benjamin Britten's tragic opera about a misfit English fisherman who may have caused the deaths of his boy apprentices. Taped in March, this ''Great Performances at the Met'' presentation features Patricia Racette as Ellen Orford, the schoolmistress who befriends Grimes; Felicity Palmer as the gossipy widow Mrs. Sedly; and Teddy Tahu Rhodes as the quack apothecary Ned Keene. Writing in The New York Times, Anthony Tommasini commended Mr. Griffey, in his breakthrough portrayal, as ''an elegant singer and courageous actor long overdue for a starring role at the Met.'' 8 P.M. (CW) SMALLVILLE Brainiac (James Marsters), under the guise of Kara (Adrianne Palicki), whom he imprisoned in the Phantom Zone, persuades Lex (Michael Rosenbaum) to go face to face with Clark (Tom Welling) in this seventh-season finale. Meanwhile Chloe (Allison Mack) gets cuffed by the Domestic Security Department, and Lana (Kristin Kreuk) awakens from her coma.

headline: Fall Calendar Fills Up
summary: An outline of the fall campaign is beginning to take shape, with debate plans completed and an apparent agreement between Senators John McCain and Barack Obama to take the stage, separately, at a forum in New York on Sept. 11, the seventh anniversary of the terrorist attacks. The debate schedule is as follows:

headline: Bracing for a Bailout Backlash
summary: The Obama administration is increasingly concerned about a populist backlash against banks and Wall Street, worried that anger at financial institutions could also end up being directed at Congress and the White House and could complicate President Obama's agenda. The administration's sharp rebuke of the American International Group on Sunday for handing out $165 million in executive bonuses -- Lawrence H. Summers, director of the president's National Economic Council, described it as ''outrageous'' on ''This Week'' on ABC -- marks the latest effort by the White House to distance itself from abuses that could feed potentially disruptive public anger.

headline: Strong Initial Ratings For CBS's 'Dog'
summary: ''Greatest American Dog,'' a new reality show on CBS, got off to a decent start on Thursday, leading most competitors with 9.5 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates. Although that was less than CBS's repeat of ''CSI'' at 9 p.m. (9.8 million), it was enough to compensate for the network's low ratings at 10 with ''Swingtown'' (5.4 million). CBS averaged the most viewers but trailed Fox in the 18-to-49 demographic. Fox's ''So You Think You Can Dance'' led the night in that group, even as it drew a more modest audience at 9 of 8.7 million total viewers. Fox's ''Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader?'' drew 7 million viewers but nearly overtook CBS's dog show to lead the 8 p.m. slot among the 18-to-49 set. NBC was third for the night, as ''Last Comic Standing'' garnered 5 million viewers from 9 to 11. ABC lagged behind in fourth, with repeats early in the night followed by ''Hopkins'' at 10 (5.5 million).

headline: What's On Today
summary: 11 A.M. (MSNBC); NOON (BET, CNN, CNN en Espanol, CNN International, Fox News, MTV, VH1, VH1 Classic, VH1 Soul); 12:30 P.M. (HLN); 1 P.M. (ABC, CBS, Fox, NBC, E!, TV One, TV Guide) MICHAEL JACKSON MEMORIAL A live broadcast of the memorial service for Mr. Jackson, who died on June 25, from Staples Center in Los Angeles. (Above, fans signing a poster in front of the center.) 8 P.M. (ABC Family) 10 THINGS I HATE ABOUT YOU Carter Covington (''Greek'') is the writer and executive producer of this new series, based on the 1999 film adapted from Shakespeare's ''Taming of the Shrew.'' Gil Junger, the film's director, is behind the camera for the pilot. Lindsey Shaw takes on the Julia Stiles part as Kat, the older, tart-tongued Stratford sister. Ethan Peck, Gregory's grandson, follows in the motorcycle boots of Heath Ledger as Patrick Verona, the bad boy of Padua High School. And Larry Miller reprises his role as Walter Stratford, who refuses to let his younger daughter, Bianca (Meaghan Jette Martin), date until Kat does. That could be awhile.

headline: Networks Firm Up Convention Lineups
summary: Those political aficionados wondering whether Senator Barack Obama looks better from the right or left, take note: in August visitors to the official Web site of the Democratic National Convention will be able to choose from a menu of camera angles as they tune in live, high-definition video streamed from the party gathering in Denver. Other viewers who prefer to leave the direction and analysis of their convention coverage to the broadcast and cable networks will have plenty of options too. In the days since Mr. Obama solidified his standing as the presumptive Democratic nominee, television news executives have begun to set their plans for covering the four-day Democratic convention, which begins on Aug. 25, and its Republican counterpart, which opens in St. Paul on Sept. 1, Labor Day.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths BIRNBAUM, BERNARD
summary: BIRNBAUM--Bernard, died November 26 at age 89. CBS News Producer since 1951. He greeted each day with enthusiasm, curiosity and passion and is deeply mourned by family, friends and colleagues. Husband of the late Ronnie Birnbaum, beloved father to daughters Deborah and Amy, sons-in-law John Kocay and Bernard Furnival, and adored grandfather of Sam, Emily, Eloise and Amelia. He was a legend in the news business, producing hundreds of documentaries for CBS while covering the major events of the 20th century. Joined the CBS program Sunday Morning in 1990. Services at 1pm, Tuesday, December 1st, Larchmont Temple, 75 Larchmont Ave, Larchmont, NY.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 8 P.M. (TCM) STARRING DENZEL WASHINGTON Four films pay tribute to Mr. Washington, whose honors include two Academy Awards, being named ''America's Favorite Movie Star'' in the 2006 and 2007 Harris polls, and kudos from People magazine as the sexiest man alive back in 1996 (but who's counting?). The salute begins with ''Glory'' (1989), for which Mr. Washington won a best supporting actor Oscar playing a soldier, above, in the first black regiment in the Civil War. It continues with ''Philadelphia'' (1993), at 10:15, in which Mr. Washington plays a homophobic lawyer who takes on the case of a gay lawyer (Tom Hanks) with AIDS; ''A Soldier's Story'' (1984), at 12:30 a.m., about the murder of a drill instructor in charge of a black platoon at an Army base in Louisiana; and ''The Mighty Quinn'' (1989), at 2:30, with Mr. Washington as a police chief searching for a childhood friend who may have murdered a businessman. 9 A.M. (CBS) THE DOCTORS Dr. Phil and Montel Williams explain the power of positive thinking; another segment looks at swine flu.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (NBC) THE BEIJING OLYMPIC OPENING CEREMONY: TV EVENT OF THE YEARBob Costas and Matt Lauer hosted the broadcast of the opening ceremony of the Beijing Olympics on Aug. 8, and they're also at the helm of this two-hour program featuring highlights from the event, which drew nearly two billion viewers. The show reprises some memorable moments from the games, including a few record-breaking swims by Michael Phelps, above, and hints at what to expect at the 2010 Vancouver Winter Olympics. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW A preview of 2009 in terms of employment, fashion, real estate and entertainment.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (DSC) PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC OF CAPITALISM In the third installment of this four-part series, Ted Koppel, above with a coal miner, examines China's hunger for cars. The country is adding 25,000 new vehicles to its already clogged roads every day, and automakers have taken notice. Buick is selling more cars in China than in the United States. 1:15 P.M. (TCM) DARLING LILI (1970) In this musical set during World War I, Julie Andrews plays a German spy, based in London, with no skill for the trade, as she allows herself to fall for a dreamy American pilot (Rock Hudson).

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (Style) CLEAN HOUSE: MESSIEST HOME IN THE COUNTRY 3 After a nationwide search, the award for slovenliness goes to ... the home of Sharon Baglien, a retired Cincinnati detective, a shopaholic and a hoarder of everything from holiday decorations to bargain-basement jackets, and her daughter, Brigitte, a college student who has begun to follow her mother's example by overstocking on beauty and bath products. This two-hour series finale captures the room-by-room revitalization; the record-breaking yard sale for charity; and the renovation, including new paint, furniture and appliances, that results in a tidy home for mother and daughter, intent on a fresh start. Above, Sharon Baglien, flanked by Brigitte and Niecy Nash, the show's host, takes a first look. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Segments look at growing roof gardens, turning old fitness clothes into stylish outfits and using a backyard grill safely.

headline: Inside the Times
summary: International INQUIRIES SEEK DESTINATION OF NORTH KOREAN WEAPONS

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) GREATEST AMERICAN DOG Mutts and show dogs start on equal footing in this new series in which 12 teams of dogs and owners compete for $250,000. The contestants (above with the host, Jarod Miller, right) include David, a doctor, and his charge, Elvis, a 2-year-old Parson Russell terrier; J. D., a dog entertainer, and his companion, Galaxy, a 9-year-old English pointer-border collie mix; Travis, a bartender, and his young boxer, Presley; and Beth Joy, who claims to be the acting manager of her primary client, Bella Starlet, a 10-year-old (take a breath) Chihuahua-Labrador retriever-Shih Tzu-Nova Scotia duck tolling retriever-Pomeranian mix. (Exhale.) Wendy Diamond, Allan Reznick and Victoria Stilwell are the judges. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Bobby Flay offers tips for summer grilling. Another segment examines rankings of the best children's hospitals.

headline: With Issues of War and Peace on Their Minds, Voters Make Choices
summary: MASSACHUSETTS A Generation Gap Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York won in a tight race that was marked by sharp generational divides, with voters ages 45 and older supporting Mrs. Clinton, and younger voters choosing Senator Barack Obama of Illinois, according to exit polls. Many voters had waited until the last minute to make a decision about whom they would support, with about one-third saying they did not decide whom to vote for until the final week of the campaign. Although Mrs. Clinton had held a lead for months, Mr. Obama appeared to get a significant bounce after receiving the backing of the state's senior senator, Edward M. Kennedy. One local poll this week showed Mr. Obama slightly edging ahead of Mrs. Clinton. The state's 93 pledged delegates are allocated proportionally between the two candidates, with 31 based on the statewide results and the remainder divided based on the vote in each of the congressional districts. Each candidate had raised considerable money in the state -- Mr. Obama $1.98 million, and Mrs. Clinton $1.88 million.

headline: With Issues of War and Peace on Their Minds, Voters Make Choices
summary: MASSACHUSETTS Favoring the Favorite Son Mitt Romney won in his home state, with both the party faithful and independents flocking to his side, according to exit polling. Mr. Romney, a former Massachusetts governor, matched Senator John McCain in attracting voters who identified themselves as moderate and took the vast majority of those who identified themselves as conservative. Mr. McCain surprised many by making a campaign stop in Boston on Sunday, where he watched the Super Bowl in a hotel lobby. Polls showed the contest tightening, and Mr. McCain told audiences that he believed he had a chance of winning the state's 43 delegates. Mr. Mc- Cain won the primary in 2000, defeating George W. Bush by nearly two to one. But Mr. Romney dismissed the 11th hour visit by Mr. Mc- Cain, saying, ''I've got a lot of friends there.'' Many observers had said that if Mr. Romney lost his home state, it would signal the end of the campaign. Although state officials had said they expected a record turnout, rain throughout the day seemed to temper that.

headline: Inside the Times
summary: International NETANYAHU'S TALK OF PEACE

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8:30 P.M. (Lifetime) RITA ROCKS Nicole Sullivan (above right, with Kelly Gould) plays Rita, a frazzled wife and mother who handles her identity crisis by forming a garage band with her letter carrier, Patty (Tisha Campbell-Martin), and her unemployed neighbor, Owen (Ian Gomez). Richard Ruccolo plays Jay, the husband with whom Rita would like to reignite a fire. The new series, which will be shown at 8:30 Monday to Friday this week and on Tuesday nights thereafter, is Lifetime's first original comedy in a decade. 7 A.M. (CBS) TODAY Elton John performs and Liza Minnelli is a guest.

headline: Revisiting Some Questions
summary: Can she have a do-over? Gov. Sarah Palin, the Republican vice-presidential nominee, became a late-night punch line after she could not answer some questions in her recent television interviews. In particular, she stumbled when Katie Couric of CBS News pressed her to name newspapers or magazines she read regularly (''whatever was in front of me'' was as specific as Ms. Palin got). And she could not name a Supreme Court decision besides Roe v. Wade that she disagreed with.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10:30 P.M. (Sundance) BLOOD, SWEAT + GEARS (2009) In response to the doping scandals rife in professional cycling, Jonathan Vaughters, left, a former racer, founded Slipstream, a team whose members agree to compete without the aid of performance-enhancing drugs. In this documentary Nick Davis chronicles the story of the ''clean team'' as it peddled its way through 2008 and won its first invitation to compete in the Tour de France. The team was led by David Millar, who was in the midst of a comeback after a doping scandal sidelined his career. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Megan Fox (''Transformers: Revenge of the Fall'') and Ray Romano (''Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs'') are the guests. Segments look at workout mistakes and affordable ways to dress up a table.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 8 P.M. (CW) EVERYBODY HATES CHRIS Chris (Tyler James Williams, above right, with Fred Willard) gets his driver's license, and Rochelle (Tichina Arnold) and Julius (Terry Crews) allow him to buy a car. But when it's stolen and vandalized, Chris is overwhelmed with the new responsibility. Rochelle, meanwhile, looks for her secret stash of cigarettes but comes across Julius's hidden racing form. 7 P.M. (CBS) N.C.A.A MEN'S BASKETBALL TOURNAMENT Regional semifinals in Indianapolis and Memphis.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 10 P.M. (13) HEART OF JENIN In 2005 Ahmed Khatib, a 12-year-old Palestinian from the West Bank city of Jenin, was killed by Israeli soldiers when they mistook his toy gun for a real one. In their grief, his parents decided to donate their son's organs to six Israeli children facing death. Ahmed's kidneys went to an Orthodox Jewish girl and a Bedouin boy. Ahmed's heart, which his parents had initially been reluctant to donate, now keeps a Druze girl alive. ''Wide Angle'' follows Ismael Khatib, above, Ahmed's father, on his journey from northern Israel to the Negev desert and finally to Jerusalem to visit these three recipients two years later. ''I see my son in these children,'' he says. 9 A.M. (CBS) THE DOCTORS Shocking health trends, a chair that offers a sitter a good abdominal workout while seated at a desk, and dance moves from Lisa Rinna.

headline: Excerpt: 'Worst Week'
summary: A clip from 'Worst Week,' which has its premiere on CBS on Sept. 22.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (CBS) THE 31ST ANNUAL KENNEDY CENTER HONORS Roger Daltrey and Pete Townshend of the Who, Twyla Tharp, Morgan Freeman, Barbra Streisand and George Jones, above from left, are honored for their contributions to American culture in this ceremony, taped on Dec. 7. The first lady, Laura Bush, will pay tribute onstage to Mr. Jones, one of her favorite singers. President Bush; Vice President Dick Cheney and his wife, Lynne; and Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice will also be in attendance. Caroline Kennedy is the host for the sixth consecutive year. Performers and presenters include Beyoncé, Clint Eastwood, David (Honeyboy) Edwards, Marcelo Gomes, Dave Grohl, Alan Jackson, B. B. King, Bettye LaVette, Idina Menzel, Ne-Yo, Kelli O'Hara, Pinetop Perkins, Queen Latifah, Koko Taylor, Rob Thomas, Lily Tomlin and Denzel Washington. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Barbra Streisand and Montel Williams are the guests.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 10:30 P.M. (HGTV) THE UNSELLABLES HGTV adds to its market-savvy lineup with this new series in which unsightly homes are redone, the better to get their owners out the door and to the bank with some extra cash. Sofie Allsopp, left, is the resident real-estate expert; the contractor Anthony Sayers helps with the nuts and bolts of the remodeling. The makeovers begin with Andrea's charming two-story home; she will soon be paying two mortgages if she doesn't get her old house spruced up and sold. 10 A.M. (ABC); 2 P.M. (55) RACHAEL RAY Kate Hudson bakes a berry trifle.
