headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (ABC) THE SUPERSTARS Eight athletes and eight celebrities team up at the Atlantis Resort in the Bahamas to undertake grueling challenges in this new show based on the classic ''Wide World of Sports'' series. The pairings are Terrell Owens of the Buffalo Bills and the model Joanna Krupa; the retired second baseman Jeff Kent and Ali Landry, the former Miss U.S.A. (above); the onetime N.B.A. player Robert Horry and the actress Estella Warren; the skier Bode Miller and Paige Hemmis of ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition''; the freestyle skier Kristi Leskinen and Maksim Chmerkovskiy of ''Dancing With the Stars''; Lisa Leslie of the Los Angeles Sparks and the actor Dan Cortese; the tennis player Jennifer Capriati and the singer and actor David Charvet; and the soccer player Brandi Chastain and the singer Julio Iglesias Jr. Events in this premiere episode include the ''Run and Ride,'' in which each team must run or cycle -- using only one bike -- a 1.1-mile course, and ''Kayak Rapids Relay,'' a boat race through the resort's artificial rapids. John Saunders is host, Warren Sapp is a correspondent, and Jenn Brown reports from the field. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOWAbigail Breslin talks about her latest movie, ''My Sister's Keeper''; Bobby Flay prepares a meal.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (History) THE CRUMBLING OF AMERICA The Romans had their roads and aqueducts; the Mayans, their pyramids and palaces. But what happens when a great civilization neglects its infrastructure? This two-hour report investigates the deterioration of highways, tunnels, dams, levees, ports and pipelines in the United States, including more than 70,000 bridges rated as structurally deficient and 25,000 miles of commercial waterways and locks that have exceeded their 50-year design life. One warning: the 2007 collapse of the Interstate 35W Bridge, above, in Minneapolis. One segment looks at structures on a ''worst of'' list. Another introduces technologies and detection techniques to prevent catastrophes. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Reba Toney talks about her book, ''The Rating Game: The Foolproof Formula for Finding Your Perfect Soul Mate''; also, the recession's effect on pets.

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 8 P.M. (NBC) MY NAME IS EARL The first new episode since the writers' strike is an hour and has a special bonus: Jeff Zucker, president of NBC Universal, will give viewers a recap of the show so far. Then the action will return to Earl (Jason Lee, above, with Alyssa Milano), who's now in a coma after he and Billie (Ms. Milano) were hit by a car. Adding to Earl's questionable karma: he experiences an alternate reality in which Paris Hilton makes an appearance. Luckily Randy (Ethan Suplee), Darnell (Eddie Steeples), Joy (Jaime Pressly) and Catalina (Nadine Velazquez) will do whatever it takes to ensure Earl's survival. 8 P.M. (13) GREAT PERFORMANCES AT THE MET: ROMÉO ET JULIETTE Anna Netrebko and Roberto Alagna star; Plácido Domingo conducts.

headline: PERSONAL SHOPPER | Stars Not Out? Just Add Some Twinkle
summary: THERE are outdoor lanterns and light fixtures to suit a variety of tastes this season, from ethnic or French country to sleek and modern. Some will hang gracefully from a branch; others are better for a ledge or a table, or for lining a walkway. Most shed twinkling candlelight, but one in this group has battery-operated L.E.D.s, a good choice for breezy settings.

headline: Excerpt: 'NCIS'
summary: "NCIS," a six-year-old series on CBS that lands on few magazine covers and enjoys almost no love from critics, is suddenly the hottest show on the air.

headline: Today In Business
summary: PROBLEMS AT CBS The story of Katie Couric might be dominating headlines about the CBS Corporation, but numerous other problems are simmering beneath the big print. Without a new hit television show, CBS will lose the crown of most-watched network to Fox; the radio division is lagging; pressure to make a digital acquisition is intensifying and advertising revenues are softening. TRACKING THE TORCH When the Olympic torch was carried through San Francisco last week, protestors supporting individual rights in Tibet tracked the location of the torch by communicating with text messages over cellphones. [C6.]

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (Nickelodeon) MERRY CHRISTMAS, DRAKE & JOSH Josh Peck, near right, and Drake Bell, far right, as well as Miranda Cosgrove, Scott Halberstadt and other alumni of the Nickelodeon series ''Drake & Josh'' are reunited for this two-hour holiday movie. The story involves public nudity, an uptight judge (Henry Winkler), an angry parole officer, a stint as department store Santas and a promise to a little girl (Bailee Madison). 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Chanticleer, the men's a cappella choir, and Brandy perform. George Hamilton is a guest. One segment looks at how to find the perfect Christmas tree.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (National Geographic) MARIJUANA NATION It's the most widely used illicit drug on the planet and illegal in most countries. In the United States the federal government places marijuana in the same category as heroin. Still, the plant, above -- one of the most complex, with 400 active chemicals and compounds -- is grown with abandon in national forests and parks and in suburban homes converted to greenhouses. In California alone, the marijuana trade outpaces the wine industry, making it one of the largest cash crops in the country. In this ''Explorer'' report, Lisa Ling examines the culture and economics of the plant. 7 A.M. (ABC) GOOD MORNING AMERICABritney Spears celebrates her 27th birthday.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (NBC) MEDIUM Allison (Patricia Arquette) grapples with violating the contract at her new job, which forbids her from sharing her dreams with anyone outside the company, and being sued for everything she's worth by her new boss (David Morse). But what if she holds the clues that could help capture the serial killer terrorizing Phoenix? In another new episode at 10, a comatose Allison's spirit enters the body of a middle-aged man (Jeffrey Tambor, above) who insists on living with Joe (Jake Weber) and the girls. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Elizabeth Edwards discusses her marriage, her battle with cancer and her new book, ''Resilience.'' Bill Gates and Randy Jackson are guests.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (Bravo) INSIDE THE ACTORS STUDIO Presto, changeo: James Lipton, the show's host, plays musical chairs in this 200th episode and allows himself to be interviewed by the comedian Dave Chappelle (above left, with Mr. Lipton) about favorite episodes (three hints: Tom Hanks, Sally Field and Mike Myers) and memorable moments. Clips of guests' favorite curse words and dance moves round out the merriment. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Little Richard does a whole lotta shakin' in a tribute to the 1950s.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (HBO) INTO THE STORM (2009) The charismatic leadership and soaring rhetoric of Winston Churchill played a vital role in the defeat of the Nazis in World War II. Yet his political prowess ultimately undermined his career and threatened his marriage. In this drama from the director Thaddeus O'Sullivan and the writer Hugh Whitemore, Churchill and his wife, Clemmie (Brendan Gleeson and Janet McTeer, right), go on holiday in France. As Britain heads to the polls to choose a postwar prime minister, the couple look back at the war years while pondering Churchill's fate. Len Cariou plays President Franklin Delano Roosevelt. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, and Senator John Cornyn, Republican of Texas, discuss the nomination of Federal Judge Sonia Sotomayor to the United States Supreme Court. The debate continues with Senator Arlen Specter, Democrat of Pennsylvania, and Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, on ''Fox News Sunday With Chris Wallace'' at 10 on Fox; Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, and Senator Jeff Sessions, Republican of Alabama, on ''Meet the Press'' at 10:30 on NBC; and Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, and Senator Jon Kyl, Republican of Arizona, on ''Face the Nation'' at 10:30 on CBS.

headline: Shannon Jacobs, Garrettson English
summary: Shannon Leigh Jacobs, a daughter of Nancy and Larry Jacobs of Lincoln, Neb., was married on Saturday evening to Garrettson Lane English, a son of Lane G. F. English of New Haven and James English III of Guilford, Conn. Associate Justice Barry R. Schaller of the Connecticut Supreme Court officiated at the home of the bridegroom's father. The bride, 36, will continue to use her name professionally. She is the vice president for corporate communications at CBS in New York. She graduated from the University of Nebraska.

headline: Assessing Candidate Appeal
summary: While almost half the voters in the latest nationwide New York Times/CBS News poll said they expect Senator Barack Obama to improve the country's image abroad if elected, Senator John McCain, a Navy veteran, is seen as more likely than Mr. Obama to be an effective commander-in-chief of the nation's military forces.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (USA) 133RD WESTMINSTER KENNEL CLUB DOG SHOWSome 2,500 dogs, representing 170 breeds and varieties, compete for top honors in the country's second-longest continuously held sporting event. (The first: the Kentucky Derby.) Labrador retrievers (47) and French bulldogs (42) are the largest categories, with German shorthaired pointers, golden retrievers, Australian shepherds and Bernese mountain dogs close on their heels. The only new breed for 2009 is the formidable-looking Dogue de Bordeaux. The judging begins with the hound, terrier, nonsporting and herding groups in this opening-night program, which will continue on CNBC at 9. Sporting, working and toy breeds will be judged in nontelevised rounds on Tuesday afternoon, followed by group judging and best in show in the evening rounds, to be broadcast on USA starting at 8. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Capt. Chesley B. Sullenberg, his family and his crew discuss the landing of US Airways Flight 1549 on the Hudson River. Also, highlights from the Grammy Awards.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (BET) WU: THE STORY OF THE WU-TANG CLAN (2007) In 1993 the Wu-Tang Clan -- including Raekwon, above -- came out of Staten Island and stormed the hip-hop world, generating more than $50 million in sales and stirring up intense critical admiration and not a little bad blood along the way. This documentary by Gerald K. Barclay, who grew up in the same neighborhood as some of the group's original nine members, includes rare film taken in the group's early years. 9 A.M. (CBS) THE DOCTORS The experts explain how to perform a tracheotomy, the signs and symptoms of hypothermia, and how to determine and respond to anaphylactic shock.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (Fox) FRINGE The first season ends with the appearance of someone frequently mentioned but never seen: William Bell, the founder of Massive Dynamics, played by Leonard Nimoy, left. Meanwhile, David Robert Jones (Jared Harris) returns; Walter (John Noble) disappears; the Observer (Michael Cerveris) emerges; Peter (Joshua Jackson) takes a journey into his past; and Nina (Blair Brown) is in bad shape. 9 A.M. (CBS) THE DOCTORS The experts discuss plastic surgery for children and what to do in a medical emergency.

headline: Letterman Reveals Extortion Attempt
summary: The late-night host said on his show that a person demanded $2 million not to reveal his sexual affairs with staff members.

headline: Nascar Wins Ratings
summary: Ratings were low all around for prime-time television over the Memorial Day holiday, as repeats on CBS ranked first on Monday, and Nascar coverage lifted Fox to No. 1 on Sunday. Opposite mostly low-rated repeats, Fox's live broadcast of the annual Nascar All-Star race drew an average of more than seven million viewers from 7 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates. One day later, on Monday, only reruns of CBS's regular Monday lineup managed to earn more viewers. Led by ''Two and a Half Men'' at 9, the night's most watched show with 10.7 million viewers, CBS easily outdrew its Monday competitors, ABC, NBC and Fox, which finished in a virtual tie for runner-up. ABC was closest, attracting 5.5 million viewers for ''The Bachelorette'' from 9 to 11. Meanwhile, NBC's ''American Gladiators'' delivered 5.2 million viewers from 8 to 9:30, followed by a 90-minute edition of ''Dateline,'' which also earned 5.2 million viewers. Fox broadcast an encore of its two-hour ''So You Think You Can Dance'' premiere from 8 to 10 (4.9 million).

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (History) THE WHITE HOUSE: BEHIND CLOSED DOORS It's a museum, a place of business, a home and one of the most photographed sites in the country. In this 90-minute special President and Mrs. Bush, right, give the first extended televised tour of the presidential residence since Jacqueline Kennedy invited cameras inside in 1962. Stops include the Lincoln Bedroom and the Oval Office, and we're taken behind the scenes at an official state dinner. The program also looks at White House history, from its burning by the British during the War of 1812 to the construction of the West Wing by Theodore Roosevelt and the modifications undertaken during the Truman presidency. Leslie and Leigh Keno of ''Antiques Roadshow'' offer insights on the White House's historic furnishings and decorative arts. 9 P.M. (Fox) THE MORNING SHOW WITH MIKE AND JULIET The Jonas Brothers and Trace Adkins perform; Paula Deen gives recipes for Southern Thanksgiving dishes; and how to avoid identity theft on Black Friday and Cyber Monday.

headline: Fallon Faces The Camera, Conscious Of the Web
summary: He looked nervous, even flustered, at first, and some of the prepared comedy was surprisingly lame. That doesn't matter. Jimmy Fallon's first few days don't really reveal how ''Late Night With Jimmy Fallon'' will fare. Monitoring the opening kinks and experiments of a new talk show is a spectator sport, and this entry comes with an added ''American Idol'' edge: NBC had the last word during the auditions, but Internet users are now expected to comment and cavil interactively and build -- or diminish -- Mr. Fallon's television audience.

headline: TRANSACTIONS | Recent Lease
summary: $83/SQ. FT. approximate annual rent $454,500

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: SUMMERS'S SIDE JOBLawrence H. Summers, the former Treasury secretary and now the chief economic adviser to the president, earned millions from one of the world's largest hedge funds, working there one day a week. I.B.M. ENDS SUN TALKS After weeks of talks, I.B.M. withdrew its $7 billion bid for Sun Microsystems, a day after Sun's board balked at a reduced offer, people close to the talks said. [B1.]

headline: What's On TODAY
summary: 10 P.M. (Starz) HEAD CASE This season finale trails Dr. Goode (Alexandra Wentworth) back to New York, where she tries to wiggle into the noggin of Jerry Seinfeld, above with Ms. Wentworth. Then she returns to Los Angeles, where she ponders writing it all down in a book. In the season wrap-up of ''Party Down'' at 10:30 the crew must collaborate on a gay wedding with their archenemies at the Adonis catering company, where all the servers look like gods. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Sharon Dorram demonstrates how to color hair at home for those who don't want to pay salon prices. Fall Out Boy and Ashanti perform.

headline: Dom DeLuise, Comic Actor And Chef, Is Dead at 75
summary: Dom DeLuise, a pudgy actor whose manic grin and air of desperation added comic bounce to films like ''The Twelve Chairs,'' ''Blazing Saddles'' and ''The Cannonball Run,'' died on Monday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 75 and lived in Pacific Palisades. His agent, Robert Malcolm, told The Associated Press that Mr. DeLuise had diabetes and high blood pressure, but gave no cause of death.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (13); 10 P.M. (49) MY FATHER, MY BROTHER AND ME In a new episode of ''Frontline,'' the journalist David Iverson, who has Parkinson's disease, explores this degenerative muscular disorder, which affects one million Americans, including his own father and brother, and is prominent in the political and ethical debate surrounding stem cell research. Mr. Iverson (above with his father in 1949) interviews his family members, as well as the actor Michael J. Fox and the writer Michael Kinsley, who both have the condition. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOWScarlett Johansson talks about her latest film, ''He's Just Not That Into You.'' Another segment looks at dressing to appear thinner so that in real life ''he'' might be persuaded to change his mind.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 7 P.M. (Bravo) INSIDE THE ACTORS STUDIORicky Gervais, above right, gets snarky with James Lipton, above left, about his life and career, from ''The Office'' and ''Extras'' to ''Ghost Town'' and ''Night at the Museum,'' Parts 1 and 2. 5 A.M. (CNN) AMERICAN MORNING John Roberts and Kiran Chetry report from the National Mall in Washington. At 9, Soledad O'Brien, Don Lemon and Roland Martin continue inauguration coverage on ''From M. L. K. to Today.''

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 9:30 P.M. (NBC) 30 ROCK Just as Jack (Alec Baldwin) is getting to know him better, his biological father, Milton (Alan Alda), has health problems in this Season 3 finale. Liz develops a reputation as a relationship expert after a talk-show appearance, and Tracy (Tracy Morgan) is invited to speak at his high school's graduation but needs help from Kenneth (Jack McBrayer) to overcome some memories. The guest roster includes Sheryl Crow and Adam Levine, above, as well as Sherri Shepherd, Mary J. Blige, Elvis Costello and Clay Aiken. 4 P.M. (ABC); 7 P.M. (55) THE OPRAH WINFREY SHOW Ms. Winfrey interviews Barbara Sheehan and Stacey Lannert, who killed the men who had abused them.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10:30 P.M. (IFC) HENRY ROLLINS UNCUT: NORTHERN IRELAND Mr. Rollins, right, finds parallels between the American occupation of Iraq and the British occupation of Northern Ireland, and talks with people who played significant roles during the ''troubles.'' Those interviewed include the civil rights leader Eamonn McCann; Peter Robinson, the first prime minister of Northern Ireland; and a former Irish Republican Army member who was sentenced to life in prison. 9 A.M. (CBS) THE DOCTORS The experts answer questions about common but mystifying bodily functions like yawning, hiccups and ''brain freeze.''

headline: Nascar Wins Ratings
summary: Correction Appended Ratings were low all around for prime-time television over the Memorial Day holiday, as repeats on CBS ranked first on Monday, and Nascar coverage lifted Fox to No. 1 on Sunday. Opposite mostly low-rated repeats, Fox's live broadcast of the Coca-Cola 600 drew an average of more than seven million viewers from 7 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates. One day later, on Monday, only reruns of CBS's regular Monday lineup managed to earn more viewers. Led by ''Two and a Half Men'' at 9, the night's most watched show with 10.7 million viewers, CBS easily outdrew its Monday competitors, ABC, NBC and Fox, which finished in a virtual tie for runner-up. ABC was closest, attracting 5.5 million viewers for ''The Bachelorette'' from 9 to 11. Meanwhile, NBC's ''American Gladiators'' delivered 5.2 million viewers from 8 to 9:30, followed by a 90-minute edition of ''Dateline,'' which also earned 5.2 million viewers. Fox broadcast an encore of its two-hour ''So You Think You Can Dance'' premiere from 8 to 10 (4.9 million).

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (Sundance) THE HIP HOP PROJECT (2006) Chris Rolle, above, was born in the Bahamas but spent most of his teenage years alone and homeless in Brooklyn. In 1999 he founded the Hip Hop Project to offer adolescents like him the opportunity to write and record. This documentary, directed by Matt Ruskin, follows Mr. Rolle, known as Kazi, as he coaches a group of New York teenagers in the art of transforming their experiences into rhyme. Jeannette Catsoulis, writing in The New York Times, called the film ''vibrant and soulful.'' 9 A.M. (ABC) LIVE WITH REGIS AND KELLYJonathan Rhys Meyers (''The Tudors'') and Zachary Quinto (''Star Trek'') are the guests; Ciara performs.

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (CBS) CBS ELITEXC SATURDAY NIGHT FIGHTS Kimbo Slice, right, an EliteXC heavyweight contender, is the headliner of this two-hour, mixed-martial-arts event broadcast live from the Prudential Center in Newark. Other competitors include the grisly-sounding (Ruthless) Robbie Lawler, who will try to hold onto his middleweight championship title in a match against Scott Smith, known as the Hands of Steel. As they say, ''No pain, no gain.'' 3:45 P.M. (IFC) IN AMERICA (2002) Johnny (Paddy Considine, near right, with Samantha Morton), an Irish actor, and his wife, Sarah (Ms. Morton, in the role that earned her an Oscar nomination for best actress), try to start over in New York after the death of their young son in this modest but sincere drama from Jim Sheridan. Djimon Hounsou is Mateo, a reclusive painter dying of what seems to be AIDS, whom Johnny and Sarah's daughters (above right, from left, Emma and Sarah Bolger) befriend. Mr. Sheridan (''My Left Foot'') wrote the screenplay with his own two daughters. ''This movie, from moment to moment, feels small, almost anecdotal,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''It is only afterward that, like Mr. Sheridan's other films, it starts to grow into something at once unassuming and in its own way grand.''

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (TNT) THE CLOSER This fourth-season winter premiere reveals the fate of Detective Julio Sanchez (Raymond Cruz), who was shot three times and airlifted to a hospital in the most recent episode. Meanwhile the team tries to determine whether a suicide was actually a murder. And the parents (Frances Sternhagen and Barry Corbin) of Deputy Chief Brenda Johnson (Kyra Sedgwick) drop by to help her and Fritz (Jon Tenney, above with Ms. Sedgwick) plan the wedding. 5 A.M. (Fox Business Network) WORLD ECONOMIC FORUM Alexis Glick and Ashley Webster report live from the 2009 annual meeting in Davos, Switzerland.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (Sundance) ICONOCLASTS Archbishop Desmond Tutu has devoted his life to fighting injustice, ending H.I.V. and serving as an advocate for troubled youth. He is also chairman of the Elders, a peacekeeping organization that helps with negotiations in conflict areas and was established in part by Richard Branson, the chief executive of the Virgin Group (above left, with Archbishop Tutu). In this season premiere, the two men talk about their inspirations and shared belief in the power of the individual to change the world. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Analysis of the final presidential debate.

headline: Recent Sublease
summary: $44/SQ. FT. approximate annual rent $360,800

headline: Excerpt: 'CSI'
summary: Laurence Fishburne, who will appear in his first episode of the CBS procedural crime drama on Dec. 11, will eventually play the show's lead investigator, replacing William Petersen.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 9 P.M. (ABC) GREY'S ANATOMY Derek (Patrick Dempsey) is about to perform his first surgery since his breakdown, and everyone is paying close attention. Izzie (Katherine Heigl) is also a reason for worry: she has to undergo a difficult operation. And Owen (Kevin McKidd, above left, with Mr. Dempsey) has another post-traumatic-stress episode that injures Cristina (Sandra Oh) and threatens the future of their relationship. 7 P.M. (CBS) N.C.A.A. MEN'S BASKETBALL TOURNAMENT Regional semifinals in Boston and Glendale, Ariz.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 8 P.M. (HBO2) THEY KILLED SISTER DOROTHY Daniel Junge's documentary examines the case of Dorothy Stang, above, a 73-year-old nun, born in Ohio, who became a Brazilian citizen. She campaigned for three decades for peasants' rights and sustainable development in the Amazon basin before she was killed in 2005, shot six times on a jungle road. The film draws on archival footage, photographs, letters and interviews with people involved in the subsequent trial, including two men who confessed to the murder. 8 P.M. (ABC) SCRUBS The hospital interns surprise the senior staff with their insight, and Dr. Cox (John C. McGinley) finally shows J. D. (Zach Braff) some respect.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 7 P.M. (HBO) SMILE PINKI (2008) About 35,000 children are born with cleft lips and palates in India each year; around a million live with the condition, one of the most common and curable birth defects. This Academy Award-winning documentary short, directed by Megan Mylan, follows Pinki, 5, above, and Ghutaru, 11, as they travel from their villages to the G. S. Memorial Plastic Surgery Hospital in the holy city of Benares. There free corrective surgery is performed by Dr. Sudbodh Kumar Singh and his team as part of the Smile Train, a nonprofit organization dedicated to repairing clefts in children from developing countries. 9 A.M. (CBS) THE DOCTORS Dr. Lisa Masterson travels to Africa with her charity, Maternal Fetal Care International. Also, a test that can be taken at home to detect potentially dangerous diseases.

headline: The Exhausting How of Players' Where and When
summary: The biggest tennis matches at the United States Open happen on the blue hardcourt of Arthur Ashe Stadium. But the center of the tournament is an obscure, windowless room in the stadium's bowels, behind a door marked Private. That is where the plot-twisting logistical calisthenics of producing the daily match schedule, or official order of play, take place.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 11 P.M. (Bravo) TIM GUNN'S GUIDE TO STYLE Mr. Gunn, who comes across more favorite uncle than harsh dictator while dispensing his fashion admonitions, begins a second season of repairing tattered wardrobes and frayed self-esteem. Gretta Monahan, the perky stylist behind Grettacole Spas and the attire of Rachael Ray and Katie Lee Joel, signs on as Mr. Gunn's ''fashion accomplice'' this season, replacing Veronica Webb. In the premiere episode Mr. Gunn and Ms. Monahan help Meredith Elliott (above with Mr. Gunn), a preppy politico from Washington who's starting a new life in New York, branch out from red and blue. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Reports from Washington University in St. Louis, the site of the vice presidential debate. Melissa Etheridge performs.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 8 P.M. (E!) YOUNG HOLLYWOOD: A TO ZAC: THE E! TRUE HOLLYWOOD STORY Step aside, Lindsays and Britneys of the world. This two-hour program scrutinizes the young and wholesome (relatively speaking) members of the Hollywood A-list. Highlights include a new interview with Taylor Swift, who is seen singing ''Twinkle Twinkle Little Star'' as a toddler; revelations from the Jonas Brothers' first agent, Shirley Grant, and some of their former teachers as well as Joe Jonas's former girlfriend Mandy, who made her way into one of the group's biggest hits; and a video of Zac Efron, above, in his school production of ''You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown.'' 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Jennifer Aniston talks about ''Marley & Me,'' her new movie about a very bad dog. Another segment looks at Labrador retrievers as pets.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (TCM) BEDKNOBS AND BROOMSTICKS (1971) Turner Classic Movies pays tribute to Roddy McDowall -- ''a child actor who was able to continue his career when he grew out of his 'cute' phase,'' as a release puts it, even though he played 14-year-old boys until he was 23. This triple bill begins with ''Bedknobs and Broomsticks,'' the Disney musical starring McDowall as Mr. Jelk, a London vicar, and his friend Angela Lansbury as Eglantine Price, the apprentice witch of Portobello Road. In ''Lassie Come Home'' (1943), a 10-year-old McDowall, above, plays the young master of the stoic collie in her film debut. And in ''Lord Love a Duck'' (1966), at midnight, he portrays a possibly deranged high school student who recalls his infatuation with an exchange student (Tuesday Weld) who, through his Svengali-like influence, goes on to become a star. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Topics include looking younger and understanding colleagues' body language. And the latest castoff from ''Greatest American Dog'' shows the audience some new tricks.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (CNBC) THE NEW AGE OF WAL-MART Last year Wal-Mart managed the unthinkable and sold more than $400 billion worth of goods, thriving as the economy tanked. Following ''The Age of Wal-Mart,'' his 2004 Peabody Award-winning documentary, David Faber (above left, with Michael T. Duke, Wal-Mart's chief executive) explores efforts being made by this retailer, the world's largest, to reinvent itself. He also tours stores in Beijing with C. Douglas McMillon, the new chief executive of Wal-Mart International, and follows a covert Wal-Mart team as it crisscrosses the United States to determine where to build a store. 7 P.M. (13, 49) THE NEWSHOUR WITH JIM LEHRER Paul Solman offers a preview of the G-20 meeting this week in Pittsburgh.

headline: The First 100 Days: Then and Now
summary: The First 100 Days: Then and Now Detentions along the Southwest border U.S. Customs and Border Protection

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths MacAllen, James
summary: MacALLEN--James, passed away on July 28th at the Englewood Hospital. He leaves behind his partner of 43 years, sister Sue, and nieces. James worked for CBS as a Director, and he also produced and directed the TV show "Camera Three".

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths MACALLEN, JAMES
summary: MacALLEN--James, passed away on July 28th at the Englewood Hospital. He leaves behind his partner of 43 years, sister Sue, and nieces. James worked for CBS as a Director, and he also produced and directed the TV show ''Camera Three''.

headline: CITY ROOM BLOGGING AT NYTIMES.COM/CITYROOM.
summary: POST TO PART WAYS With Liz Smith

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 9 P.M. (CMT) MOBILE HOME DISASTER When the trailer is the trash. This new makeover show turns dilapidated mobile homes into ''beautiful trailer park palaces,'' according to the people at CMT. A ''home disaster team,'' including Lori Lynn Lively, Joe DeRobbio and Kyle Carlson, nip and tuck the wheeled abodes of deserving families with upgrades including trendy appliances, fresh design elements and stylish furniture. (Before, above; after, top.) The comedian John Caparulo is host. 8 P.M. (ABC) AMERICA'S FUNNIEST HOME VIDEOS In this two-hour 18th-season finale, the three $100,000 winners compete for the grand prize, a vacation with Adventures by Disney.

headline: CITY ROOM | For Some Critics, Sexy and Taxi Don't Mix
summary: Is an ad for a gentlemen's club (a euphemism for strip club) perched on a taxi offensive, even if it does not show a woman's body? Some people believe it is. City Room received an e-mail message from a father who was alarmed by the number of taxi-top advertisements he had seen promoting New York strip clubs, like Flash Dancers and New York Dolls.

headline: Excerpt: 'The Mentalist'
summary: The series, which stars Simon Baker as a television psychic turned crime-solving sleuth, is a surprise hit for CBS.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (13) THE RICHARD TUCKER GALA: AN OPERA CELEBRATION Joyce DiDonato, above, is the host and joins Renée Fleming, Simon Keenlyside, Diana Damrau, Matthew Polenzani, Maria Guleghina and Luciana D'Intino to perform excerpts from ''Don Carlos,'' ''Il Barbiere di Siviglia,'' ''Der Rosenkavalier,'' ''Die Walküre,'' ''Les Pêcheurs de Perles,'' ''Candide'' and ''Aida'' at this annual event, taped at Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Yo-Yo Ma performs with Alison Krauss.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (Spike TV) 2008 VIDEO GAME AWARDS Jack Black, right, hosts this celebration of the video game industry with glimpses of what's coming next year, like Brütal Legend, Mafia 2, Uncharted 2 and God of War III. Will Wright will receive the first Gamer God award. Game of the Year nominees include Grand Theft Auto IV, LittleBigPlanet, Fallout 3, Metal Gear Solid 4: Guns of the Patriots and Gears of War 2. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS Senator John McCain gives his first Sunday morning interview since the presidential election.

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 8 P.M. (Disney); 9 P.M. (Starz) HANNAH MONTANA/MILEY CYRUS: BEST OF BOTH WORLDS CONCERT TOUR (2008) Not only did this movie catapult to the No. 1 spot after it had its theatrical premiere this winter, it also made public that Ms. Cyrus, left, uses a body double in concert -- to ''help speed the star's transition from Hannah to Miley,'' according to her public relations firm. In this 3-D documentary, filmed during a concert tour last summer, Ms. Cyrus plays her alter ego half the time, in songs like ''Rock Star,'' ''Life's What You Make It'' and ''Just Like You,'' and herself the rest of the time, performing ''Start All Over,'' ''See You Again'' and ''G.N.O.,'' as in ''Girl's Night Out.'' The Jonas Brothers, that boy band du jour, provide the interlude. Ms. Cyrus's father, Billy Ray Cyrus, guest stars as himself, soul patch intact. Noon (FNC) AMERICA'S ELECTION HQ From noon to 6 p.m., the Fox News Channel will present excerpts from Bill Hemmer's interview in London with Senator Barack Obama, who discussed his trip overseas, foreign policy and the war on terror.

headline: Putting Faith in Obama
summary: The Matthew 25 Network, a relatively new political action group aimed at Christian voters, began broadcasting two radio commercials on Monday on behalf of Senator Barack Obama. The spots are running on Christian music stations in several contested states, including Colorado, Indiana, Missouri, North Carolina, Ohio and Virginia.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (Science) SCIENCE OF THE MOVIES Nar Williams, the self-described geek in chief of AchieveNerdvana.com, analyzes famous film scenes to reveal the science behind the silver screen. In this premiere episode Mr. Williams, above, interviews John Dykstra, the Academy Award-winning special-effects pioneer for ''Star Wars'' and ''Spider-Man 2'' who invented the Dykstraflex, a motion-control rig used to film the explosion of the Death Star in ''Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope.'' Mr. Williams also demonstrates the Milo, a motion-control system that captures precise shots to create a fluid moment in films like ''Spider-Man''; visits Hydraulx, the company that created visual effects for ''Terminator 3'' and ''Aliens vs. Predator 2: Requiem''; and talks with Gary Thieltges about his inventory of camera mounts, including the body mount and the sparrow head, each of which won an Oscar for technical achievement. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Adam Lambert, the ''American Idol'' runner-up, shows off his chops.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) THE 51ST ANNUAL GRAMMY AWARDS Lil Wayne, right, has the most nominations, eight, at this ceremony, broadcast live from the Staples Center in Los Angeles. Coldplay is second, with seven nominations, and Jay-Z, Ne-Yo and Kanye West have six each. The performers include Taylor Swift, Radiohead, Robert Plant, Alison Krauss, Paul McCartney, Carrie Underwood, T. I., Justin Timberlake, Jennifer Hudson, the Jonas Brothers, Katy Perry, Adele, Chris Brown, Sugarland, Miley Cyrus and Jamie Foxx. E! and TV Guide start reporting from the red carpet at 6. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOSLawrence Summers, director of the National Economic Council (who also appears on ''Fox News Sunday With Chris Wallace'' at 10), and Michael Steele, chairman of the Republican National Committee, discuss President Obama's economic stimulus package.

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 8 P.M. (13, 49) JEAN-MICHEL COUSTEAU: OCEAN ADVENTURES The third season begins with a two-part river adventure: a 10-month trip along the Amazon basin, where the crew encounters rarely seen animals like an anaconda, pink river dolphins and a jacaré, above, a type of crocodile. 8 P.M. (CW) AMERICA'S NEXT TOP MODEL The models divide into two teams for go-sees with Shoshanna Lonstein, Pamella Roland and Stacey Bendet of Alice & Olivia. Then they are photographed through a plastic sheet while lying face down in water on Broadway.

headline: Defining the American Dream
summary: In the recession, the American Dream is alive, if not entirely well, according to a poll by The New York Times and CBS News.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) CARNEGIE HALL OPENING NIGHT 2008: A CELEBRATION OF LEONARD BERNSTEIN In honor of the 90th anniversary of the birth of this composer and conductor, Michael Tilson Thomas, above, leads the San Francisco Symphony in an all-Bernstein program, with ''Danzon'' from ''Fancy Free,'' excerpts from ''A Quiet Place,'' Meditation No. 1 from ''Mass,'' Symphonic Dances from ''West Side Story'' and songs from ''On the Town.'' Dawn Upshaw, Thomas Hampson, Yo-Yo Ma and Christine Ebersole are the soloists in this ''Great Performances'' presentation. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW News from the campaign trail; Aretha Franklin performs.

headline: ARTS, BRIEFLY COMPILED BY DAVE ITZKOFF
summary: New Guare Play Is Postponed The Public Theater's much-anticipated production of ''A Free Man of Color,'' a new play by John Guare, right, won't be mounted this season after all. Citing the tightening economy and a loss of financing, the theater said it was postponing the play, which was scheduled to open in the winter. A hybrid of history and sex farce under the direction of George C. Wolfe, it would have starred Mos Defand Jeffrey Wright mixing it up in 1802 New Orleans with Napoleon and Thomas Jefferson. In a statement, Oskar Eustis, the artistic director of the Public, said, ''This is a tough and disappointing decision, but one we made with great thought and care, and one that will ensure the Public's health and stability.'' The theater said that it still planned to present the show next season.

headline: Colonizing a Little Corner of Oxford
summary: For years, I missed out on March Madness. During my sophomore, junior and senior years at Penn, we dropped games in the first round. It's tough to turn on the television for games when you've let your dream slip out of your fingers. So for three years, I avoided tournament pools like the plague, licked my wounds and recovered in time to watch the Final Four. This year, I thought I'd lose the best weeks in sports for a different reason. When I won a Marshall scholarship to go to Oxford University, giving up basketball was just part of the bargain. The time difference meant games didn't typically end until 3 a.m., and worse, the British aren't exactly basketball fans. It's almost impossible to catch a game on TV. Naturally, I assumed that when March Madness rolled around, I'd find myself hunched over my laptop, streaming games from CBS.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 8 P.M. (13, 49) ARCTIC DINOSAURS One of the most intriguing enigmas in paleontology is how dinosaurs managed to survive, let alone thrive, in the dark and chilly polar regions. This ''Nova'' season premiere travels to the North Slope of Alaska, where new fossil clues, extreme engineering, computer-generated imaging, above, and a permafrost tunnel will reveal a prehistoric world. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW A report on the second presidential debate; also, 10 mistakes that changed the presidential race.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 9 P.M. (Animal Planet) WHALE WARS Capt. Paul Watson and his Sea Shepherd Conservation Society return for a second season of battling Japanese whaling ships. Mr. Watson has charged that this season's campaign resulted in the use of aggressive defenses by the whalers, including high-powered water cannon and long-range acoustical devices that can cause pain and even hearing damage. The crew's troubles continued when the society's vessel, the Steve Irwin, docked in Tasmania in March and was met by Australian police who confiscated hundreds of hours of videotape. The televised action begins as the Irwin heads south to Antarctica and hits a storm on the way. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Neil Patrick Harris, Dolly Parton, Allison Janney and Denise Richards are the guests. Mr. Harris moves over to ''The View'' on ABC at 11; Lionel Richie performs.

headline: What's On TODAY
summary: 8 P.M. (GSN) THE GAME SHOW AWARDSHowie Mandel of ''Deal or No Deal'' hosts this inaugural ceremony, broadcast from the Wilshire Theater in Los Angeles, honoring game shows past and present. Categories include best show, best host, favorite classic, favorite sound effect, most outrageous contestant, favorite parting gift and favorite celebrity player. ''Jeopardy!,'' ''The Price Is Right,'' ''Wheel of Fortune,'' ''Hollywood Squares'' and ''Match Game,'' as well as Pat Sajak, Vanna White, Betty White, Regis Philbin, Mr. Mandel and the gong from ''The Gong Show,'' are among the nominees. Bob Barker (above), Monty Hall and Mark Goodson will be honored with tributes. 8 P.M. (Fox News) HUCKABEERod R. Blagojevich, the ousted Illinois governor, discusses the participation of his wife, Patti, in ''I'm a Celebrity ... Get Me Out of Here!,'' the NBC reality show, and their future as a couple. Kathie Lee Gifford chats about current events. Dion performs.

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 10 P.M. (Sundance) NATHALIE . . . (2003) Catherine (Fanny Ardant, above) fears her husband (Gérard Depardieu) is unfaithful and hires a prostitute (Emmanuelle Béart) to seduce him and report back all of the details of their private encounters. They continue on ''This Week With George Stephanopoulos,'' at 10 on ABC, with Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, and Senator Hatch; ''Face the Nation,'' at 10:30 on CBS, with Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona; Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California; Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts; Michael Eric Dyson, a professor of sociology at Georgetown University; and Senator Hatch; and ''Meet the Press,'' at 10:30 on NBC, with Robert Shrum, a former press secretary and speechwriter for Senator Kennedy; Kathleen Kennedy Townsend, a niece of the senator; the historian Doris Kearns Goodwin; and Senator Kerry.

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 9 P.M. (CBS) MOONLIGHT When last we saw the bloodsucking private eye Mick St. John (Alex O'Loughlin, above center), he had witnessed his friend Josef (Jason Dohring) survive an assassination attempt; Coraline (Shannyn Sossamon) had given him a taste of mortality; and he was anxious to sidle up to the object of his affection, Beth Turner (Sophia Myles), who was angry with him. (O.K., so Mick didn't save her boyfriend. Who could blame him?) This first of four new episodes finds Beth kidnapped by the perpetrator of her boss's murder -- and Mick debating whether to put his newfound human status on the line in order to save her. 8 P.M. summary: Add Dan Rather to the list of those who have made that dreaded political gaffe when discussing Senator Barack Obama. On Friday, while appearing on ''Morning Joe'' on MSNBC, Mr. Rather, the former CBS News anchor who is now managing editor of HDNet, mistakenly referred to Mr. Obama as Osama bin Laden. Yup, the full name.

headline: Canadian TV Import Draws Viewers
summary: With good ratings for the premiere of ''Flashpoint,'' a police drama produced with a Canadian television network, CBS says it will consider importing other shows and concepts. The pilot of ''Flashpoint,'' which is filmed and set in Toronto, was produced by CTV in Canada last year. With CBS as a co-producer, the show had its debut in Canada and the United States on July 11, making it the first Canadian series to be broadcast simultaneously in both countries since ''Due South'' in 1994. On CBS it was the most popular program of the night, with 8.1 million viewers. Speaking at the summer press tour for critics, Nina Tassler, president of CBS Entertainment, said, ''It's a global playground.'' One of CBS's shows coming this fall, ''The Ex List,'' is based on the Israeli drama ''Mythological Ex.''

headline: New Mogul Ascends With Old Hollywood Clout
summary: In 1992, Ariel Zev Emanuel, a young operative with the struggling InterTalent agency, had a problem with the rent on a $639-a-month walk-up in the city's modest Fairfax district. The landlord took him to court seeking eviction, and won. Today, Mr. Emanuel has a $10 million home in the Brentwood neighborhood; a pipeline to the White House through his brother Rahm, its chief of staff; and a sprawling new talent agency of his own design, called William Morris Endeavor Entertainment.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths Lieber, Eric
summary: LIEBER--Eric, Producer, passed away on Wednesday, July 2, 2008 at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. Lieber has worked in television for more than 30 years. He has been the Executive Producer of programs for ABC, NBC, CBS, FOX and PBS. He has produced the talk-show series of Dick Cavett, Mike Douglas and Sammy Davis, Jr. Among his other producer credits are: "Omnibus," "Musical Comedy Tonight," "The AFI Salute to Henry Fonda," and "The Secret Files of J. Edgar Hoover." In 1976, he served as television consultant to Chairman Robert S. Strauss for the Democratic National Convention in New York. He was also the creator and Executive Producer of the long-running dating show "Love Connection." He has won two Emmys and a Peabody Award. He is survived by his wife Peggy; daughter, Christine and granddaughter Rachel. Memorial services will be held at a later date, please do not send any flowers. It would be appreciated, if you care to make donations, that they are directed to: The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society, 1311 Mamaroneck Ave., White Plains, NY 10605.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (CNN) CNN PRESENTS: SCREAM BLOODY MURDER Christiane Amanpour, above, reports on the failure of world governments to stop genocide -- from the Holocaust and ethnic massacres of Armenians to systematic terrorism and violence in Cambodia, Rwanda, Iraq and Darfur -- and those unsung heroes who raised their voices to urge the world to help end the atrocities. The program commemorates the approaching 60th anniversary of the United Nations Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Tips on having a low-budget wedding, dangerous holiday decorations, and ways to celebrate a holiday -- frugally -- during a recession.

summary: Just when you thought they were over. Two more Democratic presidential debates were announced Thursday, the first to take place in Philadelphia on April 16, and the second in North Carolina on April 19.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 11 P.M. (A&E) CRIME 360 On March 5, three days after Davon Crawford married for the second time, his Cleveland home erupted in gunfire. Mr. Crawford had killed his new wife, Lechea, 30, and her sister, Rose Stevens, 25. Before fleeing, Mr. Crawford, 33, also shot Ms. Stevens's three small children, killing all of them. (Another child was wounded, and a baby was unhurt.) A camera crew from ''Crime 360'' happened to be tagging along that night with two Cleveland police detectives, Tim Entenok and Tom Armelli. At the crime scene a visibly shaken police sergeant briefed the detectives. ''I just want you guys to know, it's one of the worst things I've ever seen,'' he said. This graphic program pairs computer-generated illustrations with documentary footage to show how police solve real crimes. A day after the shooting, Mr. Crawford killed himself as police tried to arrest him. (Above, neighbors outside the house.) 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW The United States Open gets some publicity with an appearance here by Roger Federer, the No. 1 men's seed. Venus Williams, the No. 3 women's seed, is on ''Today'' at 7 on NBC.

But his past won't let him escape quite so easily. Luke Perry plays the menacing Laredo, who wounded Quirt and now intends to finish the job. Brendan Wayne, above, the Duke's own grandson, plays Randy, Quirt's former partner. He wants to make a deal. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. is the guest.

In one segment Ms. Couric and the actress Abigail Breslin will visit Children's Hospital of Philadelphia; in another, Dana Delany will undergo a mammogram. Celebrities including the cancer patients Lance Armstrong, Christina Applegate and Elizabeth Edwards are scheduled to appear. ''Just Stand Up,'' a single recorded to support cancer research, will be performed by a group including Mariah Carey, Beyoncé, Sheryl Crow and Melissa Etheridge. 9 A.M. (ABC) LIVE WITH REGIS AND KELLY Shannen Doherty talks about reprising her role as Brenda Walsh on ''90210,'' and Rachael Ray cooks with Regis Philbin and Kelly Ripa. In ''Rachael Ray,'' at 10, fifth graders test school supplies, after which Ms. Ray concocts some lunches students will actually want to eat.

headline: Cable Guise
summary: After Walter Cronkite died earlier this year, Frank Mankiewicz, the onetime Democratic operative, recalled in The Washington Post how he had proposed that George McGovern select the CBS anchorman as his running mate during the 1972 presidential campaign. Cronkite was, of course, one of the most admired men in America and a known skeptic of the war in Vietnam. And yet McGovern's others advisers unanimously rejected the Cronkite gamble, not just because they feared he would say no but also because the boundary between journalism and elective office was so absolute that the thought of merging them struck aides as too desperate a ploy. Cronkite was ''wholly outside of politics,'' as Mankiewicz described it. Voters and party leaders, it was thought, could no more accept a newsman as a Democratic spokesman than they could imagine a politician broadcasting the evening news. Now it seems that Cronkite's brief moment as a vice-presidential contender may have been the first inevitable step down a treacherous path. Today we're not at all surprised to hear names like Chris Matthews and Lou Dobbs tossed around as candidates for higher office. And while it used to be that only political aides of notable talent, people like Bill Moyers and Pat Buchanan and George Stephanopoulos (and, well, Chris Matthews), could make the tricky transition from politics to TV news, now it's the politicians themselves -- Joe Scarborough, Mike Huckabee -- who find themselves ensconced as hosts on a cable-TV set. The door between politics and television news now isn't merely revolving; it spins so fast and so continuously that a fair number of people no longer seem to belong neatly on one side or the other. Is Sarah Palin, at this point, a politician, or is she the star of some ''frontier family'' reality show? In fact, she seems to realize that the changed environment allows her to be both at the same time.

headline: 'Survivor: Samoa' Proves the Fittest
summary: ''Survivor: Samoa'' helped lift CBS well ahead of its competitors on Thursday in the prime-time ratings race, as the reality show neared the conclusion of its 19th season. According to Nielsen's estimates, 12.4 million viewers tuned in at 8 p.m. for the penultimate installment of this season's show. Although that tally fell short of CBS's audiences at 9 and 10 for new episodes of ''CSI'' (15.5 million) and ''The Mentalist'' (15.7 million), ''Survivor'' still ranked as Thursday's highest-rated program among 18- to 49-year-olds. With ABC and Fox in reruns, NBC earned a solid second place, averaging 7.8 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m. for its ''Saturday Night Live'' special, ''A Very Gilly Christmas.'' At 10, NBC's ''Jay Leno Show'' delivered 5.2 million viewers, outpacing ABC's repeat of ''Private Practice'' (3.1 million). Fox was third with reruns of ''Bones'' at 8 (6.9 million) and ''Fringe'' at 9 (3.9 million), while ABC ranked fourth with back-to-back reruns of ''Grey's Anatomy'' at 8 and 9 averaging 3.9 million and 4.1 million viewers, respectively. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (TCM) PRIME TIME FEATURE: GEORGE PAL PRODUCTIONS George Pal was working on ''When Worlds Collide'' (1951) at Paramount Pictures when, in the studio's story library, he came across several unproduced scripts based on the H. G. Wells novel ''The War of the Worlds.'' But even Cecil B. DeMille hadn't been able to get the film made. In 1952 Mr. Pal hired Barré Lyndon to update Wells's Victorian tale. This three-film tribute to Mr. Pal begins with his 1953 version of ''The War of the Worlds,'' set in a California town not far from Los Angeles and featuring Martian war machines with cobralike control arms designed by Albert Nozaki and created by Gordon Jennings. (Gene Barry, above left, and Ned Glass are among the cast members.) Next, at 9:30, is ''The Time Machine'' (1960), based on another Wells novel and starring Rod Taylor as an Edwardian scientist who creates a machine that carries him to the year 802701. The tribute closes at 11:30 with ''Houdini'' (1953), starring Tony Curtis as the magician and escape artist and his new real-life bride, Janet Leigh, as his future bride. 7 A.M. (ABC) GOOD MORNING AMERICA The primatologist Jane Goodall talks about her new book, ''Hope for Animals and Their World.''

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths Pryor, Hubert
summary: PRYOR--Hubert, an editor who started the AARP publication "Modern Maturity" on its climb to becoming the largest circulation magazine in the world, died July 15 in his home in South Palm Beach, Florida at age 92. Pryor became editor of "Modern Maturity," now known as "AARP, The Magazine," in 1967, in the early years of the American Association of Retired Persons. A former senior editor of Look Magazine and editor of Science Digest, Pryor hired an editorial staff and called on writers, photographers and artists around the country to produce a magazine meeting the needs of America's fast-growing retirement population. When he joined the magazine in 1967, its circulation stood at 700,000. Fifteen years later, when he retired, the magazine's circulation had increased tenfold to 7 million. Upon retirement in 1982, he was an associate director of AARP. Born in Argentina of British and American parents, Pryor was educated at English schools in Buenos Aires and the University of London. He began his career as South American correspondent of the wire service then known as United Press. In 1940, in the United States, he went to work as a reporter for the New York Herald Tribune. Later he was director of shortwave news for CBS and also covered the United Nations in its earliest days following World War II. During the war years, he served as an officer in U.S. Naval Intelligence. For 15 years after that, he worked as a senior editor of Look Magazine and for four years was editor of Science Digest. After his retirement, he was a free-lance writer in South Palm Beach, Florida, and in 1995 published "Soul Talk," a book of meditations. In 1940 he was married to Ellen May Ach. He later married Roberta Baughman Smith and Luanne Williamson van Norden. All three marriages ended in divorce. He had three sons with the former Ellen Ach, Alan of Novato, California, and Gerald and David, both of New York City. They survive him, along with six grandchildren and a brother, Louis Pryor of Palm Beach. A memorial service is planned in Palm Beach this Fall. Remembrances to pryor.alan@gmail.com

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: VALUING BAD ASSETS As the government prepares a plan to buy or guarantee banks' troubled assets, the biggest problem is how to value them. Getting this right won't be easy, and hundreds of billions of taxpayer dollars are at stake. The governments of the United States, Germany and Britain are all close to adopting ''bad bank'' solutions to the economic crisis. Such measures must be properly structured. Breaking Views. [B2.]

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (ABC) DIRTY SEXY MONEY Nick (Peter Krause, above left), who agreed to defend Letitia (Jill Clayburgh) in the murder of Dutch George -- Nick's father and Letitia's secret lover -- isn't pleased to discover that his estranged mother (Caroline Lagerfelt, above right, with Michael Lerner), is a witness for the prosecution. Meanwhile, Jeremy (Seth Gabel) surprises his own secret lover, Nola (Lucy Liu), with a private concert by the Weepies. And Dan Rather (playing himself) moderates a debate between the Senate candidate Patrick Darling (William Baldwin) and his opponent. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Patti LaBelle, Sarah Dash and Nona Hendryx reunite as LaBelle; also, affordable ways to spruce up your home. Martha Stewart is a guest.

headline: McCain Faces Letterman
summary: He made it. After a high-flying adventure, Senator John McCain finally sat down next to David Letterman on the set of the ''Late Show'' on CBS on Thursday and offered his mea culpa: ''I screwed up.''

headline: Focus, People! There's Work to Do
summary: THE writing crew of the CBS sitcom ''How I Met Your Mother'' once had a light saber battle in the dark. There haven't been many other accessories in their room, except for a massage chair that was originally in the ''Friends'' writing room, said Craig Thomas, a creator and executive producer of the series. ''We like to stay as focused as we can,'' he said. ''We all have personal lives that we like.'' Not that there has been much time for goofing off. Mr. Thomas likens the post-writers'-strike intensity required to crank out 9 episodes in 10 weeks to the Discovery Channel crab-fishing series ''Deadliest Catch'': ''It feels like a writers' room. It's these guys stuck in this nasty boat, and they have to do the job.''

headline: Excerpts From the Debate
summary: Excerpts from the presidential debate on Wednesday night in Hempstead, N.Y., between Senator John McCain and Senator Barack Obama, as recorded by Federal News Service. The moderator was Bob Schieffer of CBS News. A full transcript and video: nytimes.com/politics. MR. MCCAIN A couple of days ago Senator Obama was out in Ohio, and he had an encounter with a guy who's a plumber. Name is Joe Wurzelbacher. Joe wants to buy the business that he's been in for all these years. Worked 10, 12 hours a day. And he wanted to buy the business, but he looked at your tax plan and he saw that he was going to pay much higher taxes. You were going to put him in a higher tax bracket, which was going to increase his taxes, which was going to cause him not to be able to employ people. Joe was trying to realize the American dream.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8:30 P.M. (13); 10 P.M. (49) NOW ON PBSThe alarming increase in violence in Afghanistan is being noticed. A recent Pentagon report said the Taliban were likely to ''maintain or even increase the scope and pace of its terrorist attacks and bombings in 2008.'' ''Now'' reporters travel to Helmand Province, where the 24th Marine Expeditionary Unit has had some success in disrupting Taliban supply lines. But can these marines, some of the 34,500 American troops fighting in Afghanistan, stem the tide? 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY David Beckham talks about soccer and the perils of life in the United States; Natasha Bedingfield performs; and the photojournalist David Turnley discusses his book ''Mandela!''

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 10 P.M. (Discovery) AMERICAN LOGGERS Fifty years ago Gerald Pelletier began a logging business with $100 and a truck. Now his sons oversee the company, which employs dozens of men who use hundreds of machines to harvest timber on thousands of acres in Maine's rural northwest backcountry. This new series follows the Pelletier brothers and their sons as they climb into their big rigs and follow the logging route known as the Golden Road, the lone passage between civilization and the largest swath of unprotected forest north of the Mississippi. 8 P.M. (ABC) WIFE SWAPSusan Peters, who, with her tiara-wearing husband, teaches yoga and allows their 10-year-old son to rule the household, trades places with Beth Vaughn, the wife of a dairy farmer and a strict disciplinarian who wants her children to know that life is not a barrel of laughs.

headline: Keeping an Eye on the Prize
summary: After all the Sturm und Drang at the Democratic Party's rules committee meeting over the weekend, the delegates from Michigan and Florida may end up getting full voting strength at the Democratic National Convention in August. Why should it matter, when a nominee will have already been picked?

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (13, 49) ANTIQUES ROADSHOW The series heads to the heartland, specifically Wichita, Kan., where Mark L. Walberg, the host, and the appraiser Nicholas Lowry take in vintage air travel posters at the Kansas Aviation Museum. At the Century II Performing Arts & Convention Center, a 1949 payroll check, above, made out to a teenage Mickey Mantle is valued at $30,000 to $50,000. 10 A.M. (ABC); 2 P.M. headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (13, 49) NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC OPENING NIGHTS GALA CONCERT Alan Gilbert, above, makes his debut as the music director of the New York Philharmonic -- he is the first native New Yorker to assume the role -- at the orchestra's 168th-season premiere, and ''Live From Lincoln Center'' is there. The program opens with ''Expo,'' an overture written for the occasion by Magnus Lindberg, the Philharmonic's composer in residence, and includes Berlioz's ''Symphonie Fantastique'' and Messiaen's ''Poèmes Pour Mi,'' performed by the soprano Renée Fleming. Alec Baldwin, the new voice of ''The New York Philharmonic This Week,'' the orchestra's weekly national radio broadcast, is host. In ''Vienna Philharmonic Summer Night's Concert 2009,'' presented at 10 by ''Great Performances,'' Daniel Barenboim conducts the orchestra on the grounds of the Schönbrunn Palace. The night-theme program features ''A Little Night Music'' by Mozart, ''A Thousand and One Nights'' by Johann Strauss and ''A Night on Bald Mountain'' by Mussorgsky. Mr. Barenboim does double duty as the pianist in de Falla's ''Nights in the Gardens of Spain.'' 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAYAmy Poehler promotes the return of ''Parks and Recreation'' (Thursday at 8:30 p.m. on NBC) before moving to ''The View,'' and its guest host La Toya Jackson, at 11 on ABC.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: AWASH IN A FLOOD OF DEBT Like water rushing over a river's banks, the federal government's rapidly mounting expenses are overwhelming the federal budget and increasing an already swollen deficit. CRAMER VS. CRAMERJim Cramer, CNBC's star stock-picker, is more muted after making some bold predictions that were proved wrong during the crisis. But even with the finger-pointing, Mr. Cramer still loves running his show and his mouth about the market, even if the market is not loving him back. David Carr: The Media Equation. [B1.]

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (NBC) THE BIGGEST LOSER In this Season 8 premiere, 16 contestants get second chances to transform their bodies and their lives. The roster includes Daniel Wright, above, who went from 454 to 312 pounds during Season 7 and is returning to finish the job; Shay Sorrells, a social worker who spent much of her childhood in foster care and whose weight of 476 pounds makes her the heaviest player in the show's history; Sean Algaier, a youth minister who wants to help himself so he can help others; Amanda Arlauskas, a college student; and Abby Rike, a teacher who lost her family in an accident. The season begins with a bus trip to the weight-loss ranch and an unexpected stop at a beach where the contestants face their first challenge: complete the last mile of the marathon the four finalists ran at the end of the previous season. The winner will receive immunity at the week's weigh-in and get the chance to pick his or her teammate. 7 A.M. (ABC) GOOD MORNING AMERICASerena Williams rehashes her performance at the U.S. Open.

headline: Really, Really Short Workouts
summary: Think you’re too busy to work out? We have the workout for you. In minutes, high-intensity interval training (H.I.I.T.) will have you sweating, breathing hard and maximizing the health benefits of exercise without the time commitment. Best of all, it’s scientifically proven to work.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 10 P.M. (Comedy Central) RUSSELL BRAND IN NEW YORK CITY The irresistibly salacious Mr. Brand, right, who won for best live stand-up at the 2008 British Comedy Awards and recently stole scenes in ''Forgetting Sarah Marshall'' and ''Bedtime Stories,'' takes the stage at El Museo del Barrio for his first stand-up show for Comedy Central. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, discusses the spending bill and pork. Gov. Tim Kaine of Virginia, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, talks about President Obama's housing and health care plans.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 7:30 P.M. (NBC) OLYMPIC SUMMER GAMES 2008 In the opening ceremony held at the Beijing National Stadium, competing teams will enter during the Parade of Nations according to the stroke count in the first character of the country's name in Chinese -- a traditional method of ordering names and objects -- placing Italy 191st and Australia 203rd, right before Zambia. The filmmaker Zhang Yimou (''Raise the Red Lantern,'' ''House of Flying Daggers'') is the chief director of the event, with 10,000 performers, including Celine Dion; Jay Chou and A-One, a Chinese pop act; more than 100 indigenous Taiwanese dancers; and a fireworks spectacular (which was tested in a dress rehearsal at the stadium, above) in which the Olympic Rings will be formed in the sky. 6 P.M. (Animal Planet) PUPPY GAMES 2008 In this three-hour spinoff of the super-cute ''Puppy Bowl,'' more than 30 puppies representing countries from around the world (but retrieved mostly from Washington-area Petfinder shelters) will demonstrate strength, agility and charm in the Animal Planet Stadium as they compete for gold, silver and bronze medals in canine versions of Olympic events. The festivities begin with a Parade of Puppies, after which kittens will put on an artistic display. The athletes (including Vince, above, an Australian cattle dog mix) and their sports include Labs, spaniels and huskies in the dog paddle; retrievers, bulldogs and mastiffs in boxing; beagles, cattle dogs and Westies on the soccer field; and Shih Tzus, poodles and terriers in gymnastics. A pair of goldfish will judge.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (ABC, CBS, CNBC, CNN, Fox, Fox Business Network, Fox News Channel, MSNBC, MyNetwork TV, NBC, 13) PRESIDENTIAL ADDRESS TO THE JOINT SESSION OF CONGRESS President Obama will outline the challenges facing the nation and present his plans for meeting them in a speech from the House chamber. A Republican response will follow. 10 A.M. (55); 3 P.M. (NBC) THE ELLEN DeGENERES SHOWSerena Williams and Richard Simmons are the guests. Raphael Saadiq performs.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (ABC Family) AU PAIR 3: ADVENTURE IN PARADISE When Oliver Caldwell (Gregory Harrison, left) and his au pair turned bride, Jenny (Heidi Saban), decide to take the family to Puerto Rico, they imagine a bonding experience. But Katie (Katie Volding), who has completed her first year of college, and Alex (Jake Dinwiddie), who has just graduated from high school, have different ideas. Kathleen Mealia plays Ariana, a friend of Katie's who tags along on the vacation and throws everything into turmoil. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH JOHN KING Former Vice President Dick Cheney is the guest.

headline: Trailer: Swingtown
summary: A trailer for Swingtown, CBS's new one-hour drama about life in the '70s.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (BET) HARLEM HEIGHTS For young and fabulous African-Americans in New York, Harlem is the place to be. This new documentary series offers a glimpse into the lives of eight men and women from different backgrounds as they make the leap from college to adulthood. The cast, above, includes a budding lifestyle magazine editor, a man from a troubled family working to find success while giving back to his community, and the hard-partying son of a Harlem politician who is considering a political career of his own. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Gabrielle Anwar of ''Burn Notice'' is a guest. Segments look at teaching parents to deal with stress and aggression; obesity and the recession; and Australian animals.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (Sundance) FULL FRONTAL FASHION The Sundance Channel begins its twice-yearly tribute to New York Fashion Week with seven nights of sartorial-theme programming. First is ''The Day Before,'' a new documentary series from the director Loïc Prigent (''Signé Chanel'' and ''Marc Jacobs & Louis Vuitton'') that follows final preparations for runway presentations by four high-profile fashion houses. The series begins with Sonia Rykiel (above, seated at center), a k a the Queen of Knits, as her family-owned company gears up to celebrate its 40th anniversary in Paris. Other episodes focus on Fendi (Thursday), Proenza Schouler (Friday) and Jean Paul Gaultier (Saturday). ''Somebody Told Me About ... Carla Bruni,'' at 11, looks at the model and singer, and features a cameo from her husband, President Nicolas Sarkozy of France. 7 A.M. (ABC) GOOD MORNING AMERICAPresident Obama is interviewed. Darius Rucker and Lee Ann Womack announce the Academy of Country Music Awards nominees.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) THE 10TH ANNUAL A HOME FOR THE HOLIDAYS WITH FAITH HILL Ms. Hill, above, who was adopted as an infant, sings in support of the more than 129,000 children in the United States foster care system -- more than 25,000 of whom reach 18 each year without being adopted. Melissa Etheridge, Tim McGraw, Gavin Rossdale and Jamie Foxx also perform, while Kristin Chenoweth, Patricia Heaton, Rene Russo and Martin Short share stories about adoption. Film segments look at the experiences of families and organizations that have dealt in foster care adoption, while some of the foster children featured in past years will appear with their new adoptive families. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Roger Daltrey and Pete Townshend are interviewed.

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 9 P.M. (CW) FARMER WANTS A WIFE Matt Neustadt is a third-generation farmer in Portage des Sioux, Mo. In high school he played football and baseball, was crowned prom king and voted ''most desired.'' And yet Mr. Neustadt is single -- a result, he says, of long days spent hauling grain, milking cows and balancing the books. The 10 city women in this new dating series, above, are out to end his bachelorhood, but first they'll have to prove that they can get up with the roosters and lie down with the chickens, while tending to chores in between. ''Finding out a little bit about what their goals are in life, what their personality is, that's more beautiful than anything,'' Mr. Neustadt says. Does that include the personality of the self-described beauty Josie, whose first question is, ''Is there gonna be a maid?'' 8 P.M. (13, 49) ESCAPE FROM AUSCHWITZ By 1944 some 12,000 Jews were being murdered each day inside Auschwitz, Hitler's largest death camp. As record keepers for Nazi guards, Rudolph Vrba and Alfred Wetzler, both Slovak Jews, were allowed to see details of deportations and executions unknown to outsiders. In April 1944 they escaped from the camp and trekked to the Jewish Council headquarters in Zilina, Slovakia, to inform the Allies of the atrocities. This ''Secrets of the Dead'' episode traces Vrba and Wetzler's journey, which, despite unforeseen obstacles, helped save 120,000 Hungarian Jews.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 8 P.M. (ABC) UGLY BETTY Betty (America Ferrera) makes a surprising discovery when she is assigned to analyze Mode's budget for the past year for the Young Editors Training Initiative. Meanwhile all that extra attention from Matt (Daniel Eric Gold, above, with Ms. Ferrera) is starting to make her uncomfortable, and the unexpected news just posted on Facebook by her old beau Henry (Christopher Gorham) doesn't help matters. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAYDonald Trump and his children Donald Jr. and Ivanka discuss the new season of ''Celebrity Apprentice.''

headline: Letterman, Spurned
summary: Senator John McCain may have disappointed many expectant voters with the decision to suspend his campaign, but none more so than a late-night talk-show host on CBS. The host, David Letterman, was so unhappy that Mr. McCain canceled his scheduled ''Late Show'' appearance on Wednesday that he spent much of the first segment assailing the senator's decision.

headline: Inside The Times: October 11, 2008
summary: INTERNATIONAL AS FOCUS TURNS TO PIRATES,

headline: Dick Cheney, Role Model
summary: In all the talk about the vice-presidential debate, there was an issue that did not get much attention but kept nagging at us: Sarah Palin's description of the role and the responsibilities of the office for which she is running, vice president of the United States. In Thursday night's debate, Ms. Palin was asked about the vice president's role in government. She said she agreed with Dick Cheney that ''we have a lot of flexibility in there'' under the Constitution. And she declared that she was ''thankful that the Constitution would allow a bit more authority given to the vice president also, if that vice president so chose to exert it.''

headline: Peabody Award Winners
summary: Three news reports about Iraq war casualties were among the winners of the 2007 Peabody Awards. Announced on Wednesday by the Grady College of Journalism and Mass Communication at the University of Georgia, the awards are intended to honor the best in electronic media. CBS received two Peabody awards for war coverage, one for a Scott Pelley report on ''60 Minutes'' about the killings of civilians in the Haditha, Iraq, and another for the report by Kimberly Dozier, above, on ''CBS News Sunday Morning: The Way Home'' about two female veterans who lost limbs in Iraq. Ms. Dozier was wounded in Iraq in May 2006. Similarly, the ABC News correspondent Bob Woodruff, injured in Iraq in January 2006, received an award for ''Wounds of War,'' a series about wounded veterans. Among entertainment series, awards went to ''30 Rock,'' the NBC sitcom inspired by ''Saturday Night Live''; ''Mad Men,'' the AMC drama about a 1960s advertising agency; ''The Colbert Report,'' the cable news satire on Comedy Central; ''Project Runway,'' the fashion reality show on Bravo; and ''Nimrod Nation,'' a d Sundance Channel documentary series. The Discovery series ''Planet Earth'' and PBS's ''Nature: Silence of the Bees'' also received awards.

headline: What's On TODAY
summary: 9 P.M. (CBS) COLD CASEFrank Sinatra provides the background music -- oldies but goodies like ''Come Fly With Me,'' ''Too Marvelous for Words,'' ''I've Got the World on a String,'' ''Little Girl Blue'' and ''Someone to Watch Over Me'' -- in this episode about the 1960 murder of a flight attendant who was trying to organize a union. Adrienne Barbeau, Mariette Hartley and Lee Majors guest star as former members of the dead woman's flight team. Raymond J. Barry (''Born on the Fourth of July''), above with Kathryn Morris, joins the cast in a recurring role as, yes, the long-lost father of Lilly (Ms. Morris). 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY WITH CHRIS WALLACE Vice president Dick Cheney talks about the last eight years, the future of the Republican Party and the incoming Obama administration.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (Nickelodeon) $TRE$$ED OUT! THE ECONOMIC CRISIS AND YOU Some parents have lost their jobs; others have lost their homes or property. And often their children suffer right along with them. In this latest edition of ''Nick News With Linda Ellerbee,'' boys and girls from across the country discuss the current economic crisis and its effect on their lives. (Ms. Ellerbee is shown with some of them above.) ''I just can't help them,'' David says of his parents. ''And I wish I could. We're losing our home. And there's nothing I can do about it.'' The psychologist Dr. Jeff Gardere offers strategies for coping. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH JOHN KING In a segment broadcast live from the Minnesota State Fair, Gov. Tim Pawlenty, a Republican, and Senator Amy Klobuchar, a Democrat, are the guests. Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, discusses swine flu preparation efforts.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (Sundance) 14 WOMEN (2007) Since 2000 the number of women serving in the United States Senate has risen to 16 from 9. In this documentary, filmed from 2004 to 2006, Mary Lambert, whose sister is Senator Blanche Lincoln, Democrat of Arkansas, profiles the 14 women serving in the Senate at the time. Ms. Lambert travels from these women's offices and homes to the campaign trail and the floor of the Senate as they discuss topics like their inspirations for entering politics, the joys and hazards of campaigning and the importance of family support. Senators Barbara Boxer, Maria E. Cantwell, Hillary Rodham Clinton, Susan Collins, Elizabeth Dole, Dianne Feinstein, Kay Bailey Hutchison, Mary Landrieu, Barbara Mikulski, Lisa Murkowski, Patty Murray, Olympia Snowe, Debbie Stabenow and Ms. Lincoln (above, at the Democratic National Convention this year)are interviewed. Annette Bening narrates. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Judy Shepard discusses the 10th anniversary of the murder in Wyoming of her son, Matthew. Also on the program, a performance by Olivia Newton-John.

headline: From General's Mouth to Obama's Ear
summary: When President Obama looks at the screen in the Situation Room on Wednesday, he will find a face he has not seen lately except in newspapers. There, via secure video from Kabul, will be Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, his commander in Afghanistan, explaining directly to the president for the first time why more troops are needed. General McChrystal has not spoken with Mr. Obama since submitting his grim assessment of the war a month ago and has spoken with him only once in the 100 days since he took command of all American and NATO forces in Afghanistan. The lack of direct communication has generated criticism and fueled suspicions of strains between the White House and Kabul.
