His family (four young girls and a wife, Angela, above left, he dubs ''supermom'') live in Houston, and they all push and shove for his affection anytime he can make a visit. Jo Frost, who isn't afraid to stand up to the 6-foot-2 athlete, turns domestic disarray into a home court advantage. 10 A.M. (55); 3 P.M. (NBC) THE ELLEN DeGENERES SHOWAmanda Peet and Jon Hamm are the comely guests; Barry Manilow performs.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 9 P.M. (Sundance) SPECTACLE: ELVIS COSTELLO WITH ... Mr. Costello wraps up his first season by interviewing the velvet-voiced Smokey Robinson, who discusses his 50-year career as a singer, songwriter, producer and record executive and tells a few tales about Stevie Wonder, Ray Charles and Marvin Gaye. Above, Mr. Costello, left, and Mr. Robinson end the show by crooning Mr. Robinson's classic ''You've Really Got a Hold on Me.'' 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Martha Stewart prepares pasta; Mercedes Ruehl chats about her role in ''The American Plan'' at Manhattan Theater Club; and Anthony Delorenzo discusses his book ''28 Tell-Tale Signs of a Cheating Spouse.''

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 8 P.M. (ABC) WIFE SWAP Don your tin-foil antenna and tune in. In October ABC asked viewers which families from past episodes they would like to see undergo a new swap in honor of the series's 100th episode. The result is an exchange between the Heenes, above, a family of storm chasers from Colorado who look for extraterrestrials and have built a flying saucer to send into the eye of the storm, and the Silvers, a Florida family with a psychic matriarch who speaks to the dead and believes that she can control her husband and children as well as the weather. In a first, the children from the two families will face off in a table meeting. 7 A.M. (ABC) GOOD MORNING AMERICA Michelle Obama gives her first network television interview as first lady.

headline: The Fifth Down
summary: Terrible to the Towels Tennessee's Keith Bulluck and LenDale White created something of a furor in Pittsburgh by kicking at a Terrible Towel in the closing seconds of a victory over the visiting Steelers on Sunday.

summary: LET THE BATTLE BEGINPresident Obama's call for curbing offshore tax havens could open a big battle with some giants in American commerce. Transfer pricing is not regulated under the Obama plan. [A3.]

summary: The top-rated CBS sitcom returns for another season on Sept. 21.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 9 P.M. (NBC) FRIDAY NIGHT LIGHTS The team's new quarterback, J. D. McCoy (Jeremy Sumpter, above right, with D. W. Moffett), becomes a victim of freshman hazing. But all that changes when he wins his first game. Meanwhile Tyra (Adrianne Palicki) and Cash (Zach Roerig) have a wedge shoved between them when a woman shows up and claims that Cash owes her child support. 9 A.M. (CBS) THE DOCTORS Segments look at five shocking reasons for weight gain, how lovers can keep fat off together, getting more sleep and relieving stress.

headline: Leading Among the Unpledged
summary: Three weeks into the presidential nominating process, many of the unpledged delegates to the Democratic National Convention are still undecided, but more who have made up their minds are expressing support for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton than for Senator Barack Obama, according to a survey by The New York Times and CBS News. If the penalties imposed on Florida and Michigan stand, there will be 796 unpledged delegate votes cast at the Democratic National Convention in August. These delegates, not bound by any state elections, are commonly called superdelegates and include all of the members of the Democratic National Committee and elected officials like members of Congress and governors.

headline: On the Trail With 'Hunter's People'
summary: Among the members of the news media covering Senator John McCain on Thursday at the Aspen Institute was Anita Thompson, the widow of Hunter S. Thompson, the legendary journalist who brought his gonzo style of personal reporting to politics in the 1970s for Rolling Stone. ''These are Hunter's people, and I'm happy to be back with them,'' said Ms. Thompson, who is writing for The Huffington Post and was sitting in the press section at the McCain event.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (Comedy Central) SOUTH PARK Stan, Kyle, Cartman and Kenny (front row from left) are back for a 12th season of making a foulmouthed mockery of just about everything in their Colorado town. The trash talk continues at 10:30 in a new season of ''The Sarah Silverman Program,'' with Ms. Silverman discovering the high life after trying marijuana for the first time. Yes, she inhales. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW An analysis of the second presidential debate and an examination of how men communicate with one another.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: NEXT REAL ESTATE WOES Vacancy rates in office buildings exceed 10 percent in nearly every major American city, and are rising rapidly. The Urban Land Institute predicts 2009 will be the worst year for the commercial real estate market ''since the wrenching 1991-1992 industry depression.'' EXPECTING GRIM CAR SALES The six largest carmakers are expected to say on Monday that their sales in the United States fell at least 30 percent in December, capping what analysts say will be the worst year for selling autos since 1992. And they are facing 2009 with dread. [B1.]

headline: What's On TODAY
summary: 8 P.M. (13, 49) ANTIQUES ROADSHOW Mark L. Walberg and his team of experts head to Palm Springs, Calif., where Alasdair Nichol of Freeman's auction house discovers the most valuable object ever appraised on the series: a 1937 painting by Clyfford Still, above, given as a housewarming gift and conservatively valued at $500,000. Parts 2 and 3 of this Season 13 opener will be shown on Jan. 12 and 19. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Anne Hathaway talks about transforming into a bridezilla for her latest movie, ''Bride Wars,'' and then repeats her performance on ''Live With Regis and Kelly'' at 9 on ABC. Robin McGraw discusses her new book, ''What's Age Got to Do With It?,'' before moving to ''The Doctors,'' at 9 on CBS.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10 P.M. (13) BETTY FORD: THE REAL DEAL Drawing on several resources, including a 2002 interview with the historian Michael Beschloss and official White House photographs by David Hume Kennerly, this documentary profiles the former first lady, above, now 90, and recounts the battles with alcohol and substance abuse that led her to found the Betty Ford Center in California. Jane Alexander narrates this MacNeil/Lehrer production. 10 A.M. (55); 3 P.M. (NBC) THE ELLEN DeGENERES SHOW Ms. DeGeneres's guests include her wife, Portia de Rossi.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths White, Lawrence
summary: WHITE--Lawrence, innovative early producer of programming on radio and television, died on April 27, 2008 at the age of 94. He is survived by his wife of 71 years, Evelyn, their children Joshua, Deborah and Rebecca and grandchildren Mathew and Sarah Barnett. His long career in media arts began as an assistant to the legendary manager/producer Leland Heyward. Soon White was representing artists on his own including Walter Huston and Charles Laughton. Eventually he began to produce independently. He had the original idea of producing weekly radio series based on classic detective fiction like that of Dashiell Hammett. His first success was Sam Spade based on the detective in the book and movie, The Maltese Falcon. Sam Spade was quickly followed by a another series called "The Fat Man", in which an original detective in the Hammett style was successfully created. Both series ran for many years on CBS Radio. In the early fifties, White moved to the growing medium of television. He was the creator and sole producer of The Pinky Lee Show. At the height of its popularity, The Pinky Lee Show was broadcast six hours a week live on NBC. The legendary studio in Burbank currently occupied by The Tonight Show was built for Pinky. At the same time and in partnership with Leland Heyward he produced the ground breaking Ford 50th Anniversary Show, one of the very first "specials", which starred Ethel Merman and Mary Martin and was directed by Jerome Robbins. At the time, the show was so important that two networks, NBC and CBS both carried it live. Later, White was active in bringing Jazz to a huge audience by producing a series of classic Jazz Shows on Television sponsored by Timex watches. He also pioneered using Videotape at classic circuses in Europe, bringing them to America as "International Showtime," a long running series hosted by Don Ameche on NBC. He is remembered for his originality, creativity and intelligence. Final services are incomplete.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (13) THE OLD MAN AND THE STORM During Mardi Gras 2006, six months after Hurricane Katrina devastated New Orleans, June Cross met 82-year-old Herbert Gettridge, left, who had skipped the festivities to clear debris from his lawn. In this ''Frontline'' episode Ms. Cross, a correspondent for the series, follows Mr. Gettridge, a master plasterer and builder, for 18 months as he; his wife, Lydia; and five of their nine children endure political turmoil and painstaking bureaucratic processes in order to rebuild their homes -- and their lives -- in the Lower Ninth Ward. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Kate Hudson promotes ''Bride Wars,'' her new film, before moving to ''Live With Regis and Kelly'' at 9 on ABC, on which Bob Harper (see below) talks about tightening the tummy.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (TBS, TNT) THE 15TH ANNUAL SCREEN ACTORS GUILD AWARDS Actors honor their peers in movies and television in this annual ceremony, broadcast live from the Los Angeles Shrine Exposition Center. (Above, preparations for the event.) Film nominees include Frank Langella, Sean Penn, Brad Pitt, Mickey Rourke, Anne Hathaway, Angelina Jolie, Meryl Streep and Kate Winslet; television nominees include Ralph Fiennes, Paul Giamatti, Laura Linney, Susan Sarandon, Michael C. Hall, Jon Hamm, William Shatner and Tina Fey. Forest Whitaker will present James Earl Jones with the 45th Life Achievement Award. E! counts down to the red carpet, starting at 5, and then interviews celebrities as they arrive, beginning at 6. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY WITH CHRIS WALLACE Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, discusses how he plans to interact with the Obama administration, and Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, talks about Caroline Kennedy's failed bid to become senator.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (ABC) THE 42ND ANNUAL C.M.A. AWARDS Brad Paisley and Carrie Underwood, above, are hosts of this country music awards ceremony, broadcast live from the Sommet Center in Nashville. Other scheduled performers include Trace Adkins, Kenny Chesney and the Wailers, the Eagles, Alan Jackson, Kid Rock, Lady Antebellum, Miranda Lambert, George Strait and Taylor Swift. Mr. Chesney, the reigning Country Music Association entertainer of the year, leads the roster of nominees with 7 nominations; Jennifer Nettles of Sugarland comes in second, with 6; and Mr. Strait, in a tie for third place with Sugarland, adds 5 for a career total of 75. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Daniel Craig talks about his latest stint as 007 in ''Quantum of Solace'' (and then moves on to ''Live With Regis and Kelly'' at 9 on ABC). Annie Leibovitz discusses photographing the British royal family (see below) and her latest book, ''Annie Leibovitz at Work.'' Also, the conclusion of an interview with Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 7 P.M. (ABC) EXTREME MAKEOVER: HOME EDITION Rev up the weep-o-meter: Ty Pennington and his crew begin a sixth season of speedy renovations for worthy candidates. This round's first recipient is Felicia Jackson of Rockville, Md., a single mother of four struggling to fulfill a vow to keep her 10 nieces and nephews out of foster care after her sister died of cancer. Chris Cooley of the Washington Redskins and the Academy Award-winning actress and singer Jennifer Hudson add celebrity touches to the Jacksons' new home in this two-hour episode. (Above, the series regulars Paul DiMeo, left, and Michael Moloney, right, lending a hand to Keyon Budd.) 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS Senator John McCain is the guest.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 9 P.M. (CNBC) INSIDE TRACK: REFUELING THE BUSINESS OF NASCAR Its roots are in Southern bootlegging, but in the last decade Nascar has become the fastest-growing sport in the country, routinely filling speedways that seat up to 200,000 fans. But what happens when the automobile industry implodes and sponsorship budgets shrink? Darren Rovell investigates the state of racing through interviews with Tony Stewart, above, the two-time Sprint Cup Series Champion; Kyle Busch, the driver of the No. 18 M&Ms car; and Brian France, the chairman and chief executive of Nascar, whose family has sole control over the sport. 9 A.M. (ABC) LIVE WITH REGIS AND KELLY Rupert Grint talks about his latest stint as Ron Weasley, in ''Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince.'' Sugar Ray performs, and Regis Philbin gets a sleep analysis.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
summary: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Dec. 5 through Dec. 10 with 708 adults throughout the United States who said they were currently unemployed. Households containing the unemployed were identified in two ways: respondents to 12 nationwide polls by The Times and CBS News during the past year were asked about unemployment in their household; and during November, thousands of additional random phone numbers across the country were screened for unemployment in the household.

headline: What's On TODAY
summary: 8 P.M. (TCM) '70s THRILLERS Friday night frights: this triple feature begins with ''The Day of the Jackal'' (1973), starring Edward Fox (above right, with Cyril Cusack) as an assassin hired to kill the French president, Charles de Gaulle. ''The Stepford Wives'' (1975), in which Katharine Ross plays a New York wife and photographer transplanted to an upstate suburb where the neighbors have a ghastly secret, follows at 10:30. And ''The Little Girl Who Lives Down the Lane'' (1976), the creepy shocker starring Jodie Foster as a precocious 13-year-old who lives alone and pretends that her father is alive so that she won't be assigned a guardian, wraps up the scarefest at 12:30 a.m. 8 P.M. (ABC) WIFE SWAP Barbara Kinsman, a lobster fisherman's wife who lives in a log cabin in Maine and wears her clothes until they fall apart, trades lives with Michelle Thompson, a Californian who shops every day and whose proudest possessions were bought from a plastic surgeon.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths SHAYON, ROBERT LEWIS
summary: SHAYON--Robert Lewis passed on Saturday, June 28. Born in New York City, August 15, 1912, he spent his career in media as a writer, producer, director for WORMutual, and CBS Radio where he worked with Edward R. Murrow and created You Are There. Shayon was the first television critic for the Christian Science Monitor and Saturday Review. He was Professor Emeritus at The Annenberg School for Communication, University of Pennsylvania-on the faculty from 1965 to 1990. His first wife of 47 years, Sheila Russell, passed on in 1983. He worked with her late mother, Frances Russell, an Australian opera singer, as a music/ lyrics team. He is survived by his wife, Nash Cox, Frankfort, KY, daughters, Diana and Sheila Shayon and three grandchildren, Kristyn and Keith Shayon and Leah Novak. A memorial service will be held in New York, September 20, 11am at All Souls Church, 1157 Lexington Avenue at 80th Street.

headline: WHAT'S ON TODAY
summary: 8 P.M. (TCM) TCM PRIME TIME FEATURE: BURT LANCASTER A presentation of four films starring this New York City street kid turned leading man of the 1950s and '60s. The tribute begins with ''Sweet Smell of Success'' (1957), in which a press agent (Tony Curtis) helps a powerful columnist (Lancaster, above left, with Susan Harrison and Mr. Curtis) break up his sister's relationship with a musician. In ''Trapeze'' (1956), at 10, Lancaster and Mr. Curtis play trapeze artists who fall for a trampolinist (Gina Lollobrigida). In ''Elmer Gantry'' (1960), at midnight, Lancaster stars as a ne'er-do-well salesman turned evangelist preacher running from his troubled past; he won a best-actor Oscar for the role. And in ''The Rainmaker'' (1956), at 2:30 a.m., Lancaster plays Bill Starbuck, who tries to coax the rain in a drought-stricken Kansas town. Katharine Hepburn is the spinster whose heart he warms. 11:30 A.M. (13) TO THE CONTRARY WITH BONNIE ERBÉ Ms. Erbé discusses women's health care and whether President Obama has abandoned the issue; Representative Marcia L. Fudge, Democrat of Ohio, talks about the political representation of black women.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths WHITE, LAWRENCE
summary: WHITE--Lawrence , innovative early producer of programming on radio and television, died on April 27, 2008 at the age of 94. He is survived by his wife of 71 years, Evelyn, their children Joshua, Deborah and Rebecca and grandchildren Mathew and Sarah Barnett. His long career in media arts began as an assistant to the legendary manager/producer Leland Heyward. Soon White was representing artists on his own including Walter Huston and Charles Laughton. Eventually he began to produce independently. He had the original idea of producing weekly radio series based on classic detective fiction like that of Dashiell Hammett. His first success was Sam Spade based on the detective in the book and movie, The Maltese Falcon. Sam Spade was quickly followed by a another series called ''The Fat Man'', in which an original detective in the Hammett style was successfully created. Both series ran for many years on CBS Radio. In the early fifties, White moved to the growing medium of television. He was the creator and sole producer of The Pinky Lee Show. At the height of its popularity, The Pinky Lee Show was broadcast six hours a week live on NBC. The legendary studio in Burbank currently occupied by The Tonight Show was built for Pinky. At the same time and in partnership with Leland Heyward he produced the ground breaking Ford 50th Anniversary Show, one of the very first ''specials'', which starred Ethel Merman and Mary Martin and was directed by Jerome Robbins. At the time, the show was so important that two networks, NBC and CBS both carried it live. Later, White was active in bringing Jazz to a huge audience by producing a series of classic Jazz Shows on Television sponsored by Timex watches. He also pioneered using Videotape at classic circuses in Europe, bringing them to America as ''International Showtime,'' a long running series hosted by Don Ameche on NBC. He is remembered for his originality, creativity and intelligence. Final services are incomplete.

headline: Enberg Back In Baseball
summary: After a 24-year absence from calling local baseball, Dick Enberg will become the lead play-by-play voice of the San Diego Padres next season. Enberg last called baseball for the Angels in 1985, following a stint with the team from 1969 to 1978. ''I still think I have my fastball,'' Enberg, 74, said during a news conference, reflecting on his age and time away from calling baseball. ''A lot has changed. Music has changed. Hairstyles have changed, but 6-4-3 hasn't changed, and I still remember that and will handle it O.K.''

summary: 8 P.M. (TCM) 31 DAYS OF OSCAR: PRINCIPLES OF ANIMAL BEHAVIOR Turner Classic Movies presents films about our furry friends, starting with Carroll Ballard's ''Never Cry Wolf'' (1983), about a government researcher (Charles Martin Smith) stranded in Canada, and followed by ''Lassie Come Home'' (1943), with Roddy McDowall, at 10; ''National Velvet'' (1944), with Elizabeth Taylor (above, with Mickey Rooney), at 11:45; ''The Jungle Book'' (1942), starring Sabu, at 2 a.m.; and ''The Day of the Dolphin'' (1973), with George C. Scott, at 3:45 a.m. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Jessica Simpson performs. Clive Owen promotes his latest film, ''The International,'' while his co-star Naomi Watts appears on ''Live With Regis and Kelly,'' at 9 on ABC. Annie Lennox is that show's musical guest.

headline: Popular Demand
summary: News Web sites are the third most popular destination in the information category, just behind search and weather, with sports a close fourth, according to M:Metrics, which measures mobile use. Other activities in the news and information category include choosing movies and restaurants and calling up traffic reports and maps to find the way. If the sports component were included, then ESPN places strongly, along with Fox and CBS. Most of the mobile users said they got their news and information through Yahoo, which is excluded here because it is also a portal. SHELLY FREIERMAN

headline: Dance' Lifts Fox
summary: A two-hour installment of the reality series ''So You Think You Can Dance'' led Fox to victory in the ratings on Wednesday as 8.8 million viewers tuned in from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates. NBC and CBS shared runner-up status for the night in total viewers, with NBC faring better among adults 18 to 49 thanks to a 90-minute ''Deal or No Deal'' at 8 (8.2 million) followed by ''Celebrity Circus'' from 9:30 to 11 (5.7 million). CBS finished fourth in that demographic, just slightly behind ABC. Both ABC and CBS broadcast lineups of repeats.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (21) FROST/NIXON: THE ORIGINAL WATERGATE INTERVIEWS Before he interviewed Richard M. Nixon, the British television personality David Frost (above left, with Nixon) told the CBS correspondent Mike Wallace that he was hoping for a ''cascade of candor'' from the disgraced president. ''A cascade of candor from Richard Nixon?'' Mr. Wallace asked incredulously. ''Is this what you expect?'' Mr. Frost replied, ''No, it was just a phrase I thought would appeal to you.'' On May 4, 1977, more than 45 million Americans tuned in for the first chapter of Mr. Frost's four-part interview, which is rebooted here. That dramatic encounter inspired ''Frost/Nixon,'' a play by Peter Morgan that was adapted last year for a film by Ron Howard. 8 P.M. (ABC) SUGARLAND: LIVE ON THE INSIDE Jennifer Nettles and Kristian Bush of the Grammy-winning country duo Sugarland perform some of their hits, including ''Stay'' (about a cheating lover), ''All I Want to Do'' (about doing nothing) and ''Settlin' '' (about wanting everything). The concert was recorded at the Rupp Arena in Lexington, Ky.

headline: Sam Cohn, Talent Broker in Film and Stage, Dies at 79
summary: Sam Cohn, whose nearly endless client roster of top actors, writers and directors and imaginative engineering of deals for them made him the most powerful talent broker in theater and film during the 1970s and 1980s and a progenitor of the Hollywood superagent, died Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 79. His death was confirmed by Maarten Kooij, a longtime colleague of Mr. Cohn's at International Creative Management, the mammoth talent agency widely known as I.C.M. Mr. Kooij gave no cause other than to say Mr. Cohn died after a short illness.

(ABC) SIEGFRIED & ROY: THE MAGIC RETURNS ''20/20'' travels to Las Vegas to witness a one-night-only performance by the animal illusionists Siegfried & Roy, featuring Montecore -- the 380-pound Bengal tiger that mauled Roy Horn, in October 2003 -- as part of a Power of Love gala benefiting the Lou Ruvo Brain Institute. Elizabeth Vargas (above, with Siegfried, right, and Roy) interviews the two men at their home, where they speak about their career and Mr. Horn's recovery before making their appearance at the Bellagio Hotel and Casino, which was taped on Saturday. 10 A.M. (55); 3 P.M. (NBC) THE ELLEN DeGENERES SHOW Will this never end? Jason Mesnick of ''The Bachelor'' infamy talks about his do-over with Molly Malaney, who reveals what made her take him back.

Bernadette Peters, Kathy Baker and Mariette Hartley guest star in this two-hour season premiere. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Former President Bill Clinton speaks; Alanis Morissette sings. headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
summary: The West Virginia exit poll was based on questionnaires completed by voters on Tuesday as they left primary election polling places throughout the state. The poll was conducted by Edison Media Research of Somerville, N.J., and Mitofsky International of New York City for the National Election Pool, which consists of ABC News, The Associated Press, CBS News, CNN, Fox News and NBC News.

headline: '60 Minutes' Gets Obama
summary: ''60 Minutes'' has landed the first post-election interview of President-elect Barack Obama and his wife, Michelle. for this Sunday. CBS News announced Thursday that the Obamas would sit down Friday in Chicago to speak with the ''60 Minutes'' correspondent Steve Kroft. The interview is expected to fill more than one segment on the broadcast. It may fill the entire hour.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (Discovery) SWORDS: LIFE ON THE LINE This newest entry in the deadliest-catch oeuvre explores the risks inherent in long-line swordfish hunting, above. The boats include two out of Fairhaven, Mass.: the 100-foot-long, steel-hulled Eagle Eye II, captained by Scott Drabinowicz, and the 70-foot-long Sea Hawk, overseen by Linda Greenlaw, who survived the infamous ''perfect storm'' in the Hannah Boden, the sister ship to the Andrea Gail. There's also the dilapidated, 58-foot-long fiberglass Big Eye run by Chris Hanson of Wanchese, N.C., and owned by his fiancée, as well as the Frances Anne, a 72-foot-long, forward-housed boat run by Chris Kleme and several New Jersey surfer dudes. In this premiere episode the crews take a voyage to hell on the Grand Banks off the coast of Newfoundland. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOWNeil Diamond croons some of his hits. Topics include raising children to avoid drug abuse and cooking with corn.

(ABC) 20/20 Juju Chang, Deborah Roberts and Elizabeth Vargas, left, report on ''extreme motherhood'' and trends like giving birth at home; serial surrogacies, including one woman who has given birth 12 times; women who care for fake babies; extended breast feeding, with a look at a mother who was investigated by child welfare officials for nursing her 8-year-old; and women who have discovered how to turn the pain of childbirth into pleasure. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW A look at life inside a mother's womb.

Kim Greylek (Michaela McManus), a new assistant district attorney, is brought in to help in this opening episode of Season 10. 7 A.M. Jennifer Hudson, above, and Seal are scheduled to perform; Sean Combs, Taraji P. Henson, Keke Palmer, Regina Taylor and Kerry Washington are among the presenters. Al Gore and Wangari Muta Maathai will each be honored with the Chairman's Award; Russell Simmons is the recipient of the Vanguard Award. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Katie Lee Joel concocts a Valentine's Day party for single women.

headline: INSIDE THE TIMES: May 31, 2008
summary: INTERNATIONAL PACT FOR FUTURE OF U.S. IN IRAQ MEETS GROWING OPPOSITION

headline: INSIDE THE TIMES: May 29, 2008
summary: INTERNATIONAL OLMERT AIMS TO STAY IN PLACE Despite Call for Resignation More straws landed upon the back of Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel as Ehud Barak, the Minister of Defense called for him to step down pending the outcome of his corruption inquest. Mr. Olmert refused, saying that he did not believe that he should step down simply because of an investigation. An official close to him said that Mr. Olmert did not want the political machine to trump the legal one, and believed it would become clear during the inquest that he had done nothing wrong. Page A10 THE GERMAN MILK PARTY? The Federation of European Dairy Farmers estimates that, on Wednesday alone, 10.6 million gallons of milk were dumped in a boycott by European dairy farmers. Why? While food prices have soared, the price of milk has not, in part because the European Union has raised quotas but not prices. As the price of milk fell, prices of fuel and feed rose. But cows keep producing and will sicken if not milked, so dairy farmers will keep working, and dumping, as long as the boycott lasts. Page A6 THE LAST DAYS OF NEPAL'S MONARCHY Nepal's 239-year-long monarchy neared its end, as a newly elected assembly told Gyanendra, king of Nepal, to step down from his throne in 15 days. The assembly is led by former Maoist guerrillas who emerged from the jungle after 10 years of war and traded gunplay for politics. They also demanded an end to the monarchy. Winning more than a third of Parliament's 601 seats, they hold a majority position and the party's leader is expected to take over as prime minister. Those suspected of remaining loyal to the monarchy have spoken by detonating small bombs in Katmandu. Page A8 SOUTH AFRICA WEIGHS SHELTER PLAN Waves of xenophobic violence have been visited against immigrants in South Africa, leading them to flee the impoverished squatter areas they had been living in. Relief organizations have proposed shelters intended as a temporary solution that could house as many as 70,000, but have been delayed pending a government decision. Doubts have been raised about South Africa's ability to run them, and international agencies fear that the camps could become rife with conflicts and sexual violence. Page A12 NATIONAL A PARTIAL PICTURE Of Carbon Footprints A new study by the Brookings Institution rating energy use showed, in general, smaller carbon footprints for the West Coast, with the Honolulu area ranked No. 1 followed by the area including Los Angeles and Orange Counties in California, the Portland-Vancouver area in the Northwest and the New York metropolitan area. At the bottom: a cluster of rust-belt urban areas including Cincinnati; Indianapolis; Lexington, Ky.; and Toledo, Ohio. PAGE A21 A PLAN FOR THE OCEANS With numerous projects being proposed for the waters off its shores, Massachusetts is now the first state to have a framework for a protection plan for its ocean waters. It sets ground rules for all offshore projects and businesses, including energy ventures and conservation areas that lie within three miles of the coast. PAGE A15 FINDING THE TABLES TURNED As President Bush's press secretary, Scott McClellan was part of the apparatus used by the White House to take on Mr. Bush's critics. Having departed that job, and with a new book that now casts him as one of those critics, Mr. McClellan is learning that the apparatus still functions without him. PAGE A14 CARE FOR THOSE WHO GIVE CARE The Army has begun to recognize that the war in Iraq is taking a toll not only on the troops, but also on those who counsel those troops, the chaplains. None have been killed, but some have been wounded, some in ways that cannot be seen. ''I've been really pushed to my limits and beyond,'' one said. ''At times, I've really wondered if I could get through.'' PAGE A19 SECT MOTHERS SPEAK OUT As the highest court in Texas prepares to rule on whether child welfare authorities had the right to take 468 children from a ranch early last month, the mothers are trying to make their case with the public by speaking out more forcefully about the harm they think the separation has already done to their children. PAGE A14 BUSINESS WITH FURTHER MERGERS UNLIKELY, Airlines Face Making Own Cuts Mergers other than the already-announced deal between Delta and Northwest seem unlikely, so airlines seeking to offset rising fuel prices are likely to cut costs, cut routes and park planes without the camouflage that a merger would have provided. And that means that the grumbling will come through unfiltered. PAGE C1 EXXON CHALLENGE DEFEATED Exxon Mobil's chairman and chief executive, Rex W. Tillerson, defeated a shareholder effort supported by many members of the Rockefeller family that would have divided the chairman and chief executive positions. The vote was at an annual meeting punctuated by a debate of the company's policy toward renewable energy and global warming and, though nonbinding, would have been a serious rebuke. PAGE C3 NATURAL GAS RISING LIKE GASOLINE A longstanding assumption of American energy policy -- that natural gas will be plentiful abroad, and therefore readily available for importation, as production falls off in North America -- is being challenged as the supertankers that were supposed to deliver cargoes of gas from Africa and the Middle East to the United States are taking them to places like Spain and Japan instead. PAGE C1 LIFE VALUES IN THE CORPORATE WORLD Students who join Stewart Friedman's management class at the Wharton business school commit to sharing intimate details with their classmates about their most important relationships. And though that may not sound like the stuff of business school education, Mr. Friedman and others have tapped into a desire by both students and established entrepreneurs for more integration of their careers and personal lives. PAGE C5 Strength in Durable Goods econ C4 METRO EXERCISER'S LOUD NOISES Lead to Assault Trial Stuart Sugarman adjusted the stationary bicycle for his frame, clicked his specialty cycling shoes into the pedals and, when spinning class started, began the most conspicuous part of his ritual: his loud noises. Christopher Carter, who was two bikes down, took issue with the noises. Now a trial in Manhattan Criminal Court is to determine whether what Mr. Carter did to stop Mr. Sugarman from making those noises qualifies as assault. PAGE A25 DEFENDING A PERK Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo of New York says giving members of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's board free E-ZPasses to drive across its bridges and tunnels without paying tolls, as well as passes to ride the subways, buses and commuter railroads without paying, violates a state law requiring that members serve without compensation. The authority disagrees, and plans to go to court to fight for the perk. PAGE A24 STYLES STILL TURNING A PROFIT In Fashion's Fast Lane One survey this month found more than half the respondents saying they planned to spend less on apparel; another found almost a third of people reporting ''severe anxiety'' about their personal finances. All of which can be good news, it seems, if you happen to be in the fast-fashion business. ''The least vulnerable brands now are the ones at the lower end of the luxury market and the upper end of the midtier market,'' one analyst said. PAGE E1 YOGA FOR THE MASSES The explosion in popularity of yoga has been good news for novices looking for classes -- there is seemingly one on every corner, and maybe another upstairs. But for the advanced student looking for something a little -- or a lot -- more challenging, the result is not so good. In seeking to be accessible to the many, classes become less desirable for the few. PAGE E10 FEEL THE STRETCH, AVOID THE MARK Various concoctions are marketing as being able to prevent stretch marks resulting from pregnancy. Can they? The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists says no. But the American Pregnancy Association suggests that women can reduce the probability of stretch marks (the key word being ''probability''). But be aware that genetics and race play a role in stretch marks, too. skin PAGE E3 NO ORDINARY JOE This sort of thing used to be reserved for wines, but beers have gotten into the act, along with single malt scotches. And so it follows that coffee tastings -- known to aficionados as cuppings -- now appear, at which the devoted might pay $20 each to taste three coffees, each from a different country. Take along a sophisticated palate if you want to pick up the hints of basil and jasmine. PAGE E6 SPORTS AT 17, READY TO RUN Against Sport's Elite Chanelle Price is a high school senior with some typical items on her to-do list this time of year: finish writing two papers, take two final exams. She also has one most unusual item: run the 800 meters at the Prefontaine Classic in Eugene, Ore., on June 8. From there, who knows, maybe the Olympics in Beijing. PAGE C12 WHEN IT WENT TO THE WIRE The occasion of this year's run at horse racing's Triple Crown cannot help calling forth memories of the last one, 30 years ago, when two outstanding horses not only faced off in each of the three races but also finished 1-2 in each of them. ''Seen through the current prism of fragile, transient champions, Affirmed and Alydar seem from another planet, another age, another breed,'' George Vecsey writes in Sports of The Times. PAGE C14 HOME FINDING AN ALTERNATIVE To That Chlorine Smell For those who want -- or have -- a swimming pool, but do not want the smell and possible other side effects of a chlorine sanitation system, other options exist. Pool installers may not tell you about them, and they are not cheap, but for some people they are a must. ''Our target audience is the person who shops at Whole Foods,'' said one installer. PAGE F1 PUTTING DOWN (SHALLOW) ROOTS Move often enough, Peter Moore says, and ''you realize quickly how you are burdened by your past, and so you become a ruthless editor.'' And Mr. Moore, an architect and developer, and his wife, Kathryn Lynch, a painter, have moved often enough. But they've been in the same place for three years now: the top floor of an 1890s brick warehouse on Washington Street. ''Our semipermanent home,'' he calls it. PAGE F5 Shopping for Newlyweds F4 OBITUARIES DAVID GAHR, 85 He turned his back on a promising career as a scholar to take pictures and listen to music and as a result landed among the pre-eminent photographers of American folk, blues, jazz and rock musicians of the 1960s and beyond. PAGE C11 SOPHIE B. ALTMAN, 95 In 1961 she started a television quiz show for precocious high school students, later added pep bands and cheerleaders and was as surprised as anybody when the show, ''It's Academic,'' became the world's longest-running quiz show. PAGE C11 ARTS ABC IN ANCHOR TALKS With Charles Gibson ABC passed over Charles Gibson in 2005 as anchor of ''World News,'' but events put him in the job anyway, success followed, and now he is in talks to stay there for the foreseeable future. Does he want to? ''I honestly don't know,'' he says. One person who must be anxiously waiting the outcome is Diane Sawyer, whose future probably is linked to the result. PAGE B1 AN ETHICS DISCLAIMER The media reporter (and sometimes ethics arbiter) Howard Kurtz invited Kimberly Dozier, the CBS journalist wounded in Iraq, onto his program on CNN on Sunday to talk about her memoir, ''Breathing the Fire.'' After the interview, he revealed that his wife had ''done some promotion work'' for the book. He and his employers see no problem with that. Some media ethicists do. PAGE B3 'LOST' LEADING THE LOST Even committed viewers of the ABC series ''Lost'' might be forgiven for not being able to follow every twist of its anarchic plot or not being aware of the relevance -- even the existence -- of the many obscure allusions made. And anyone who has looked even briefly at ''Lost'' blogs knows that some people are trying way too hard. Season Four concludes tonight. PAGE B1 Gliding Through Space B5 EDITORIAL IN DEFENSE OF WORKERS The Supreme Court upheld the rights of employees who charge age and race discrimination. Perhaps the justices realized that Americans want a court that does not stack the deck for the powerful. Or, they may simply be getting better at respecting precedent. PAGE A26 I KNEW IT ALL ALONG A new memoir by President Bush's former press secretary, Scott McClellan, could be named: ''I Knew It Was a Terrible Mistake, but I Didn't Mention It Until I Got a Book Contract.'' PAGE A26 NEW JERSEY PRIMARY CHOICES The Editorial Board endorses Frank Lautenberg for the Democratic Senate primary and former Representative Richard Zimmer for the Republican race. Republicans should pick Leonard Lance for the Seventh Congressional District. PAGE A26 OP-ED NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF Does Islamic terrorism threaten this year's Olympic Games? The Chinese authorities have warned of terror plots emanating from the mostly Muslim region of Xinjiang. On a trip to the ancient Silk Road oasis of Kashgar, signs abound of the authorities' anxiety about stability in China's Muslim west. PAGE A27 GAIL COLLINS South Dakota, along with Montana, is going to have the Last Primary on Tuesday. When you live in a reliably red state with only three electoral votes and no real fund-raising potential, it takes being overlooked in the presidential races to a whole new level. The people here, like Hillary, can use a good moment. PAGE A27

headline: In Ratings Arena, 'Gladiators' Defeat 'Dance War'
summary: "Dance War," a spinoff of ABC's popular "Dancing With the Stars" series, attracted only modest interest in the ratings on Monday, drawing 11 million viewers from 8 p.m. to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates. Among adults 18 to 49, the reality competition between choreographers Bruno Tonioli and Carrie Ann Inaba earned approximately half the ratings of the most recent premiere of "Dancing With the Stars" in September.

headline: CBS News And Writers Reach Agreement
summary: CBS News and a union representing 500 of its employees announced Wednesday that they had reached an agreement on a new contract, ending a two-and-a-half-year dispute that contributed to the cancellation of a presidential primary debate last month.

headline: A One-Night Shift in the Late-Night Wars
summary: For the first time since television’s late-night shows returned to the air last week, David Letterman was able to nose out Jay Leno in the ratings. It was just for one show, Monday night, and Mr. Letterman’s lead was not sizable, but Mr. Leno had won the first three nights. Their competition resumed last Wednesday, when most of the late-night hosts came back after supporting the writers’ strike for two months. Mr. Leno is working without his writing staff, which is still on strike against his “Tonight Show” on NBC, while Mr. Letterman, above, was able to return with writers to his CBS show because of a separate deal his production company made with the Writers Guild of America. Mr. Letterman has also been able to book the normal roster of movie-star guests; on Monday night he had Tom Hanks, while Mr. Leno had the upstart Republican presidential candidate Ron Paul. In the overnight ratings, measuring the country’s 65 largest cities, Mr. Letterman had a 4 rating on Monday to Mr. Leno’s 3.8. (Each point is worth 787,659 households.) But in their shows’ first half-hour, when Mr. Leno is performing a monologue over the opposition of the writers’ guild, he still beat Mr. Letterman, with a 4.5 rating to a 4.3. CBS’s thin victory margin continued on the 12:35 a.m. shows, where Craig Ferguson enjoyed a rare ratings victory over NBC’s Conan O’Brien, with a 1.9 rating to a 1.8 for Mr. O’Brien.

headline: The People's Choice: Tune Out the Awards

The show attracted 6 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates, down from the 11.3 million people who watched the show's live broadcast on the same night last year.

headline: Primaries: Startled By Clinton's Surge, TV Pundits Recast The Democratic Race

Hillary Rodham Clinton's surge of support was deemed a surprise by media commentators who largely expected another win by Barack Obama.

At 8 p.m., "Deal or No Deal" on NBC attracted nearly twice the number of viewers as "Power of 10" on CBS, 13.3 million versus 6.1 million, according to Nielsen's estimates.

headline: Strike Nips Awards Show
summary: The two-month-old writers strike took a significant toll on the “People’s Choice Awards” on Tuesday as the taped, scaled-down version of the awards show on CBS lost nearly half its audience compared with a year ago, attracting just 6 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m., Nielsen reported. A year ago, the show’s live broadcast averaged 11.3 million. For the night, CBS ranked third overall, trailing second-place Fox with its all-repeat lineup. NBC finished first, leading every hour of the night among adults 18 to 49 with a two-hour episode of “The Biggest Loser” (10.2 million), followed by “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” at 10 (15.2 million). CW delivered its best Tuesday ratings since March thanks to “One Tree Hill,” which averaged 3.5 million viewers from 8 to 10 in its fifth-season debut. ABC trailed CW in last place among adults 18 to 49.

But “Grey’s Anatomy” (17.6 million) led among viewers ages 18 to 49, putting ABC on top in that demographic. CBS’s "Without a Trace" won at 10 p.m. in total viewers (13.8 million), while “ER” on NBC (9.1 million) ranked first in the hour among the 18-to-49 group. South produced three playoff teams, each of which won at least 10 games. That has to be good training for the playoffs.

headline: CSI Gives CBS a Lift

Combined, the three-hour broadcast delivered a dismal 1.3 rating in the critical demographic of adults 18 to 49, a far cry from the 6.5 rating the show earned in prime time on a Monday last January.

headline: Correction: For the Record

While its ratings that night were the strongest for the series since 2005, it was not until the next week, on Jan. 10, that the show faced “stiff competition” from original episodes of “C.S.I.” on CBS and “Grey’s Anatomy” on ABC. On Jan. 3, both of those shows were repeats.

Villaraigosa for the post in 2001 and lost to him in a 2005 rematch. He is James Hahn — not Kenneth Hahn, who was his father.

headline: Though Idol Returns, Some Viewers Don't
summary: Fox’s “American Idol” came roaring back to prime-time television on Tuesday, dominating the night’s ratings as usual, but in a sign that the series, now in its seventh season, might have reached a plateau this year’s premiere fell more than 4 million viewers short of last year’s record-breaking debut. Nielsen estimated that 33.2 million viewers tuned in for the first rounds of auditions from 8 to 10 p.m., compared with 37.4 million a year ago. Among adults 18 to 49, the show’s ratings were down by about 13 percent. CBS finished as runner-up for the night with the second most viewers, thanks to “NCIS” at 8 (15.9 million) followed by “Comanche Moon” from 9 to 11 (12.5 million). NBC ranked third with a two-hour “Biggest Loser” at 8 (7.2 million) and “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” at 10 (12.1 million). Despite modest audiences, the two shows lifted NBC well ahead of CBS for the night in the 18-to-49 group. Meanwhile, with a mix of reruns and new comedies, followed by “Boston Legal” at 10 (7.4 million), ABC lagged behind its competitors in fourth place overall.

headline: Charlie Rose Joins 60 Minutes
summary: Charlie Rose, the PBS interviewer, will moonlight as a contributor to the CBS newsmagazine “60 Minutes” beginning this season, the network announced Thursday. Mr. Rose is expected to provide several reports each season for the program. He served as a correspondent for the spinoff series “60 Minutes II” for six years until it was canceled in 2005. “It will be great to have Charlie working with us again,” Jeff Fager, the executive producer of “60 Minutes,” said in a statement. “His considerable talents will make our all-star team even better.” Mr. Rose will continue to produce and be the host of his long-running public television series.

headline: Gladiators and Deal Deliver One-Two Punch
summary: NBC led every hour of prime time in Monday night’s ratings, buoyed by the successful combination of its new hit “American Gladiators” followed by the game show “Deal or No Deal.” Those shows earned the night’s top ratings among adults 18 to 49, according to Nielsen’s estimates, with “Deal or No Deal” also drawing the largest audience of the night, 14.1 million viewers at 9 p.m. “American Gladiators,” meanwhile, delivered a more modest 10.1 million viewers at 8. NBC’s “Medium,” which also drew 10.1 million viewers, led the 10 p.m. hour in the 18-to-49 group. Fox finished second for the night in that demographic, thanks to its new show “Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles,” which attracted 8.6 million viewers while tying CBS’s comedy repeats in the 9 p.m. hour among adults 18 to 49. CBS, which broadcast reruns all night long, ranked third in that age group, but second in total viewers behind NBC. ABC was a distant fourth. Its “Dance War” averaged 9.8 million viewers from 8 to 9:30, but its “October Road” continued to struggle during the 10 p.m. time slot with just 5 million viewers.

Although the show’s third installment is down 4.6 million from the same night a year ago, it still had more than double the audience of any other network broadcast. Fox’s rerun of “House” came closest, leading the 9 o’clock hour after “American Idol” with 14 million viewers. NBC’s “Biggest Loser,” meanwhile, trailed both programs as runner-up during 8 to 10 p.m. among adults 18 to 49, averaging a modest 8.9 million viewers. NBC ranked second for the night, leading at 10 with “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” (13 million). CBS was third, and ABC finished fourth.

headline: Ghosts of 1984
summary: Imagine this. For the first time in years, New York’s Democratic presidential primary actually counts. The leading candidates have opened campaign offices, held fund-raisers, bought TV ads and scheduled visits. Angering some of his fellow black politicians, Representative Charles B. Rangel, the dean of Harlem politics, has endorsed the establishment candidate over an insurgent African-American challenger. It sounds a lot like 2008 — but this was New York 24 years ago.More than 1,350,000 New York State Democrats went to the polls on April 3, 1984, to choose among three leading candidates for the party nomination — former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, Senator Gary Hart of Colorado and the Rev. Jesse Jackson. Black New Yorkers turned out in record numbers. The contest exposed social and racial divisions that would affect future state and city elections for years to come. And many of the operatives from that race are still active in local politics.

headline: More Torture Debate, Courtesy of Saddam Hussein
summary: In the days after Saddam Hussein's capture, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld was tossing wisecracks on subjects serious and trivial. The cab that the former Iraqi leader hid inside? "He didn't have the meter running." Who's going to be responsible for interrogation? "It was a three-minute decision, and the first two were for coffee."

headline: CBS and ABC Win
summary: CBS and ABC shared the lead in the ratings on Sunday, with CBS averaging the most total viewers and ABC earning the highest ratings among adults 18 to 49. ABC got a lift in that demographic group from the night’s top-rated show, a two-hour edition of “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition,” which averaged 13.6 million total viewers at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. CBS, meanwhile, got a boost at 7 p.m. from “60 Minutes,” the night’s most-watched show (14.4 million), followed by “Shark” at 8 (11.1 million) and the made-for-TV movie “The Russell Girl” from 9 to 11 (12.7 million). Fox ranked third for the night but ahead of CBS in second place in the 18-to-49 segment thanks to its comedy lineup, including “The Simpsons” at 8 (7.6 million) and “King of the Hill” at 8:30 (7.5 million). NBC, in fourth place, broadcast back-to-back specials, the “U.S. Figure Skating Championships” from 7 to 9 (4.8 million), followed by the “Guinness World Records: Top 100” from 9 to 11 (6.3 million).

headline: Clinton Booked On Letterman
summary: "Democrat Hillary Rodham Clinton will yuk it up on CBS's 'Late Show with David Letterman' on Monday, a day before the Feb. 5 Super Tuesday contests," the Associated Press notes.

headline: 'Raymond' and 'Family Guy' Are Rare Bright Spots in Syndication Firmament
summary: LAS VEGAS - The last few years have been particularly rough for syndicated television shows. Local stations that are affiliated with the major networks purchase the rights to these shows and sell advertisements against them, but those ads can be a tough sell in the absence of hit shows.

headline: Ratings: State of the Union Down, ABC News Up
summary: Because of last night's State of the Union address, final ratings data will not be issued by Nielsen until late on Tuesday, but overnight estimates suggest that ratings for the president's speech may be down considerably from a year ago. Then again, one difference last year was that Fox broadcast "American Idol" in the hour preceding the speech, which could have given President Bush a ratings bump.

headline: 'Like Regis and Kelly'
summary: Aired Monday night on CBS: You know what happened earlier tonight? It was the annual State of the Union address. ... By the way, this is President Bush's last State of the Union address. The next one will be given by co-presidents Bill and Hillary Clinton.

headline: An 'Idol' Creator Predicts More Growth in Reality
summary: LAS VEGAS -- How much reality is too much reality?

headline: 'Idol' and 'House' Dominate Tuesday's Ratings
summary: Fox overwhelmingly dominated the ratings Tuesday night thanks to the one-two punch of the popular shows "American Idol" and "House." At 8 p.m., "Idol" delivered an average of 28.1 million viewers, and "House" reeled in 22.5 million at 9 p.m.

headline: Pettitte Will Discuss Clemens, Lawyers Say
summary: Andy Pettitte will provide the first account of conversations with Brian McNamee about Roger Clemens’s alleged use of performance-enhancing drugs in earlier years.

headline: Imus Closer to a Return to TV in Big Cities
summary: Viewers in several big cities moved a step closer on Wednesday to being able to see a simulcast of Don Imus’s morning radio show on television.

headline: After 40 Years, Schieffer Plans to Quit CBS in Early 2009
summary: Bob Schieffer, a reporter for CBS News for nearly four decades and the host of “Face the Nation” for 17 years, said Tuesday night that he would retire next January.

headline: For Giuliani, a Dizzying Free-Fall
summary: As Rudolph W. Giuliani ponders his political mortality, many observers point to the hubris and strategic miscalculations that plagued his campaign.

headline: ABC News in Front
summary: In the extremely tight ratings race between the two leading evening news broadcasts, ABC’s “World News With Charles Gibson” last week edged past its rival, NBC’s “Nightly News With Brian Williams,” for the first time in eight weeks. Nielsen estimated that the ABC newscast drew 9.8 million viewers, its highest average in nearly a year and slightly more than the 9.6 million who tuned in to NBC. ABC’s slim margin of victory was only modestly higher in the age bracket of adults 25 to 54, a demographic the two networks split evenly during the previous week. The last time ABC finished No. 1 was during the November sweeps period. Last week CBS’s “Evening News With Katie Couric” remained a distant third (7.13 million).

headline: Foreign Retailers Follow Their Shoppers to New York
summary: New York’s chic shopping districts seem to be teeming these days with foreign tourists taking advantage of the weak dollar. Foreign retailers are now joining them.

headline: Among TV Judges, 'Judy' Is Renewed but 'Hatchett' Is Axed
summary: "Judge Judy," the longest-running and highest-rated courtroom show in syndication, earned a two-year renewal this week, which will extend its run through 2012.

headline: Counting Down To Digital TV
summary: There are 383 days until the end of analog television.

headline: 'The Angina Monologues'
summary: Aired Wednesday night on CBS: How about this presidential race? It's getting crazier and crazier. Yesterday in Florida they had the primary. Rudy Giuliani came in third, so he "dropped out of the presidential race. But don't worry about him. He's already busy looking for wife number four. So he's got his hands full.

headline: Two Hits Buoy Fox
summary: Fox dominated the ratings on Tuesday, thanks to two popular shows, “American Idol” at 8 p.m. and “House” at 9. Those shows delivered 28.1 million and 22.5 million viewers, Nielsen estimated. A repeat of CBS’s “NCIS” at 8 attracted the night’s third-largest audience (11.7 million). CBS’s all-rerun lineup tied NBC for runner-up on the night, but NBC fared better among adults 18 to 49 with “The Biggest Loser” at 8 (8.3 million) followed by “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” at 10 (9.4 million). ABC finished fourth overall. On Monday President Bush’s final State of the Union address attracted the smallest audience of his two terms, 37.5 million viewers. That tally was 8 million fewer than a year ago, but 6 million more than President Clinton’s last State of the Union address in 2000. The speech was broadcast live at 9 p.m. on a total of nine network and cable channels.

headline: 'Doctor, It Hurts When I…' And Other Questions
summary: CBS Television Distribution is hoping "The Doctors" can do for medical information shows what "Dr. Phil" did for the mental health genre.

headline: Farewell 'Montel'
summary: After 17 years, "The Montel Williams Show" will cease production in May.

headline: What Should a Candidate Read?
summary: CBS asked the presidential candidates to choose the one book they think would be essential to take to the White House, other than the Bible. Only one chose a book related to economics, and that was Senator John McCain, a Republican candidate who has been criticized for lacking economic expertise.

headline: Lost Boosts ABC
summary: The return of “Lost,” albeit a two-hour repeat of last season’s finale, buoyed ABC’s ratings on Wednesday during a night otherwise dominated by Fox’s “American Idol” and “The Moment of Truth.”

headline: The Biggest Tech Deal Ever, Sort Of
summary: Microsoft's $44.6 billion offer for Yahoo is easily the largest takeover bid in the software giant's history. It could also be the world's largest technology deal ever, depending on how you define technology.

headline: 'A Sequined Pantsuit'
summary: Aired Thursday night on CBS: Anybody see the Republican debate last night? Nasty, nasty debate. At one point, Mitt Romney got so upset, so agitated, so worked up, that his hair cracked.

headline: 'Is That a Man or a Woman?'
summary: Aired Thursday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: You know it is a great day for Barack Obama. He raised $32 million last month. That is incredible! You know how he did it? He was on Oprah. He found it down the back of the couch.

headline: Viewers Find 'Lost'
summary: The premiere of the fourth season of "Lost" delivered 16.1 million viewers on Thursday, Nielsen estimated, lifting ABC to a No. 1 finish on the night, though the audience was down from the 18.8 million who watched last season's debut. The premiere followed an 8 p.m. show summarizing the series's complicated back story (13.1 million).

headline: Viewers Find ‘Lost’
summary: The premiere of the fourth season of “Lost” delivered 16.1 million viewers on Thursday, Nielsen estimated, lifting ABC to a No. 1 finish on the night, though the audience was down from the 18.8 million who watched last season’s debut. The premiere followed an 8 p.m. show summarizing the series’s complicated back story (13.1 million).Fox and NBC ranked second and third on the night among adults 18 to 49. CBS was fourth in that demographic but managed to finish second in total viewers. And CNN’s broadcast of the debate between Senator Barack Obama and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton drew an average of 8.3 million viewers, the most ever for a primary debate on cable news.

headline: Belmondo, Bond and Now Kerviel
summary: France has always had a soft spot for the lawbreaker. Now Jérôme Kerviel, the trader who cost Société Générale more than $7 billion, has attracted a fan club of his own.

headline: 3 Cheers for the Home Team! (But, Uh, Which One Is It?)
summary: A close look reveals that the New York Giants might be able to stake more of a claim to the hearts and minds of Connecticut fans than the New England Patriots.

headline: 'Happy Groundhog Day'
summary: Aired Friday night on CBS: Happy Groundhog Day, ladies and gentlemen. It's funny. Earlier today in Washington DC, a confused President Bush pardoned a turkey.

headline: Super Bowl Watching With Romney
summary: NASHVILLE-Somehow it became me versus the Governor.

headline: Evangelicals a Liberal Can Love
summary: Bleeding-heart liberals could accomplish far more if they reached out to build common cause with bleeding-heart conservatives.

headline: 'Age Does Not Define Him'
summary: Aired Friday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: Big debates in the race for the White House. At the Republican debate, John McCain insisted his age does not define him. Then he told everyone to "get off my lawn!"

headline: Without Writers, Leno Still Wins
summary: One month after returning without writers, Jay Leno is winning the late-night talk-show race "even though his main competitor, David Letterman, was widely thought to have an advantage: a deal with the Writers Guild of America that brought his writers back and allowed him to book A-list Hollywood guests," Bill Carter reports.

headline: McCain Looks Confident; Tighter Democratic Race
summary: John McCain was striving to end the Republican race on Tuesday, while polls showed Hillary Rodham Clinton’s lead over Barack Obama was narrowing.

headline: Strike May End Soon, but Writers May Confront a Hostile Hollywood
summary: Some fear a less lucrative future for writers as studios turn to alternatives.

headline: Days After CBS, NBC Orders A Canadian Drama
summary: Days after CBS said it would broadcast a Canadian television drama, NBC announced a parallel acquisition on Friday, revealing that CTV's "The Listener" will come to the United States sometime later this year.

headline: In Election of Change, TV Gives Voice to Insiders
summary: The best-known television pundits who hold politicians to account are entangled in old partisanship and past allegiances.

headline: Leno’s Art of Late-Show Maintenance
summary: Jay Leno has maintained his customary position atop the ratings in late-night television despite the Hollywood writers’ strike.

headline: Two Views of Digital Music Subscriptions
summary: There is another Seattle-Sunnyvale deal to talk about today: RealNetworks' assumption of Yahoo's subscription music service, Yahoo Music Unlimited. This wasn't a big surprise; Yahoo has been saying for a long time that it wants to get out of the music subscription business. And Real is the largest player left in that market with its Rhapsody service.

headline: Clinton Leading Among the Unpledged
summary: Updated | Feb. 4 Heading into Tuesday's nominating contests, many of the unpledged delegates to the Democratic National Convention are still undecided, but more who have made up their minds are expressing support for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton than for Senator Barack Obama, according to a survey by The New York Times and CBS News.

headline: Apartments for Rent: Loopy Hollywood Types O.K.
summary: If you have just about lost your tolerance for portrayals of Los Angeles involving the oversexed and underappreciated, “Welcome to the Captain” could send you to the nearest virologist.

headline: Former Credit Suisse Banker Convicted of Insider Trading
summary: A former banker at Credit Suisse accused of leaking confidential information about several major deals, including the $45 billion buyout of TXU, as part of a $7.5 billion insider trading scheme was convicted Monday in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

headline: Super Tuesday: A Comfortable Couric Leads The Conversation On CBS
summary: Katie Couric, the "CBS Evening News" anchor, hosted two hours of prime time primary coverage on Tuesday.

headline: Super Tuesday: Calling California, Monitoring Missouri, Counting Delegates

headline: The Upfronts Will Go On, Perhaps With Less Pageantry
summary: May is the month when the annual beauty contest known as the upfronts takes place: the networks introduce their fall programs to advertisers, who place their bets on the series by purchasing airtime in advance.

headline: Isn't America Great?
summary: Days after becoming a United States citizen, Craig Ferguson will get a chance to zing President Bush. Mr. Ferguson, host of the “Late Late Show” on CBS, said he had been booked as the entertainer at the annual White House correspondents’ dinner in Washington on April 26. Mr. Ferguson, born in Glasgow, was sworn in as an American citizen on Friday. Customarily attended by the president, the dinner, described by Mr. Ferguson as “like the Oscars for politicians,” is a gathering not without pitfalls for comics. Barbed political jokes led to criticism of Don Imus and Stephen Colbert.

headline: 'Remove the Duct Tape From Bill's Mouth'
summary: Aired Tuesday night on CBS: Hi, welcome to "Late Show." I'm Super Tuesdave ... Well, Super Tuesday is all over now. Hillary can remove the duct tape from Bill's mouth.

headline: Not Even the Primaries Can Dislodge 'Idol'
summary: Super Tuesday may have been an important night for the presidential primary process, but Fox came away the big winner in the television ratings race, easily outpacing its rivals' election coverage. As usual, "American Idol" led overall, drawing 27.8 million viewers at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates. At 9 p.m., Fox's "House" earned a similarly dominant 23.2 million viewers.

headline: Super Tuesday: Night Of The Touch-Screens
summary: Television news has come a long way since the NBC anchor Tim Russert infamously scribbled his 2000 election calculations on a plain white board.

headline: Super Bowl: The Giants Win, and So Do the Giant Balloons
summary: Just when you thought you were safe from additional post-mortems of how the Super Bowl commercials performed, along came the results on Wednesday of three surveys from IAG Research.

headline: A Sizzle Among the Young (at Least Some)
summary: Barack Obama is the Pied Piper of the race, walking off with more young voters than any other recent presidential candidate.

summary: CBS plans to announce on Wednesday that it is trying one of the first serious experiments with cellphone advertising that is customized for a person’s location.
