summary: Interviews across the country produced anecdotal evidence that some younger people carried their enthusiasm into the polling place.

headline: The Early Word: Money Matters
summary: Yes, policies are important and character is key, but another gauge of a campaign's health is the amount of money coming in from supporters. And Wednesday's news cycle was all about the Benjamins.

headline: 'I'm Not Sure if That's His Delegates or Age'
summary: Aired Wednesday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: Hey, I was watching the primaries last night, and on the Republican side, the delegates are in. John McCain is up to 660. I'm not sure if that's his delegates or age, but it's a lot.

headline: 'Mitt Romney Got the Well-Tanned Vote'
summary: Aired Wednesday night on CBS: Anybody go and vote in the big Super Tuesday elections? You ever have problems with the voting machines? I mean, there was a time I yanked on the lever and turned the whole damn thing over. So this time, I pulled the lever, and a Snickers bar comes out.

headline: Mexican Robin Hood Figure Gains a Kind of Notoriety in U.S.
summary: Immigrants from Mexico have brought the legend of Jesús Malverde, widely considered the patron saint of drug dealers, to the United States.

headline: Winehouse Drama Shadows Grammys
summary: Amy Winehouse has been denied a visa to enter the United States, but Grammy producers plan to have her appear via satellite during the program.

headline: Ratings: Good News for Writers – 'Lost' Lasts, 'Survivor' Drops Off
summary: The sixteenth edition of CBS's "Survivor" series made a subdued debut onThursday, earning the lowest ratings yet for a premiere in the franchise'seight-year history. According to Nielsen's estimates, the latestinstallment, set in Micronesia, drew just 13.9 million viewers at 8 p.m.

headline: Fox Pairing Undoes Rivals
summary: Fox’s combination of “American Idol” and “The Moment of Truth” lifted it far ahead of its rivals in the Wednesday night ratings.

headline: Rescuers Script a Possible Ending for a Strike
summary: The writers’ strike is on the brink of ending in true Hollywood fashion: through connections.

headline: Media and Candidate Methods of Counting Delegates Vary and So Do Totals
summary: Voters are left with a frustratingly unfocused picture of who is ahead in the Democratic field.

headline: Surviving, Just
summary: The 16th edition of the CBS series “Survivor” made its debut on Thursday with the lowest ratings for a premiere in the show’s eight-year history. Nielsen estimated that the show, set in Micronesia, drew 13.9 million viewers at 8 p.m., short of the 15.4 million who tuned in for the start of “Survivor: China” in September (which matched the previous all-time low, set by the series’s first episode in 2000). Still, “Survivor” easily won its time slot, helping CBS deliver the most viewers on average for the night. The runner-up, ABC, led the night among adults 18 to 49, with “Lost” at 9 (15.1 million) taking first in that demographic. ABC’s “Eli Stone” (9.4 million) also managed to lead the 10 p.m. time in that group, although CBS’s “Without a Trace” rerun in that hour had more viewers (10.2 million). Also at 10, the premiere of NBC’s “Lipstick Jungle” drew a disappointing 7.6 million viewers; in January, ABC’s similarly themed “Cashmere Mafia” attracted 10.6 million viewers. NBC ranked fourth for the night but tied Fox for third among the 18-to-49 set.

headline: 'The Insider' Host Seeks Alcoholism Treatment
summary: Pat O'Brien, a host of the entertainment newsmagazine "The Insider," has entered a rehabilitation center for treatment of alcohol abuse, his show's syndicator, CBS Television Distribution, announced on Friday.

headline: The Insider Host Seeks Alcoholism Treatment
summary: Pat O’Brien, a host of “The Insider,” has entered a rehabilitation center for treatment of alcohol abuse, his show’s syndicator, CBS Television Distribution, announced on Friday. Mr. O’Brien acknowledged his alcoholism in an interview on CBS in 2005. The “Insider” correspondent Thomas Roberts is expected to be co-host with Lara Spencer in Mr. O’Brien’s absence.

headline: Allowed In, Winehouse Chooses to Stay Home
summary: Amy Winehouse, right, the British soul singer, will perform via satellite for the 50th annual Grammy Awards in Los Angeles on Sunday despite an unexpected reversal of the State Department’s rejection of her visa, her spokesman said Friday. Officials at the Department of Homeland Security issued a waiver that in effect overturned a decision by the United States Embassy in London to deny her visa request, according to an administration official. But the shift came too late for Ms. Winehouse, who recently entered a rehabilitation clinic after a video purporting to show her using drugs surfaced online, to prepare for a live performance in Los Angeles. Her spokesman, Chris Goodman, said, “Unfortunately, due to the logistics involved and timing complications, Amy will not be traveling to the U.S. to perform at the Grammys in person.” Ms. Winehouse, who is nominated in six categories, including album of the year for “Back to Black,” will join a long list of performers on the broadcast, which grew longer on Friday with the announcement that Kanye West, whose eight nominations are the most for anyone, will take the stage at the ceremony. John Mayer and Bebe Winans will also perform on the live CBS broadcast. Organizers previously announced a lineup including Beyoncé, Rihanna, Kid Rock and the Foo Fighters.

headline: Pebble Beach’s 18th Hole Is a Perfect Intersection of Golf and Nature
summary: As captivating as the CBS pictures are from the Pebble Beach National Pro-Am, stepping on the 18th tee is necessary to grasp the magnitude of this “most felicitous meeting of land and sea.”

headline: 'Comes Apart at the Seams'
summary: Aired Friday night on CBS: It's Fashion Week in New York City. And everybody in New York gets into Fashion Week. As a matter of fact, Hillary Clinton today was wearing her strapless pantsuit.

headline: The Week Ahead: Feb. 10-16
Shows Prepare To Resume Production
summary: "The switch that controls the television business is expected to be flicked on all the way early this week, initiating a flurry of activity that may begin to restore the regularly scheduled programming interrupted when the writers' strike shut down major parts of the television season," Bill Carter reports.

headline: Amy Winehouse Wins Big at Grammy Awards
summary: The troubled British soul singer picked up five trophies, keeping her in tight competition with Kanye West.

headline: After Strike, TV Shows Hurry Up and Wait
summary: The switch that controls the television business is expected to be flicked on all the way early this week.

headline: Speaking Out: Show-Runners Talk About the Guild Deal
summary: As the tentative writers' deal is reviewed and the ratification vote is held, the opinions of the show-runners ­ people who work as both writers and producers, bearing both creative and professional control over shows ­ will be critically important. They serve as informal ring-leaders of the television community.

headline: Ex-Washington Post Reporter to Lead a Rival
summary: The Washington Times taps John F. Solomon, an alumnus from its more liberal cross-town rival, The Washington Post, as its new executive editor.

headline: Viewership Down For Grammy Awards
summary: CBS's broadcast of the "50th Annual Grammy Awards" was the highest-rated program on Sunday night, both among overall viewers and within the choice demographic of adults 18 to 49. But the good news for the program pretty much ends there.

headline: Sunday Ratings: 'Makeover' Draws 16 Million
summary: The Grammy Awards helped CBS finish No. 1 for the night over all, leading the 7 p.m. hour prior to the Grammy's with "60 Minutes" (13 million viewers). ABC ranked second for the night thanks to a two-hour "Extreme Makeover: Home Edition" at 8 p.m. (15.8 million) followed by "Brothers & Sisters" at 10 p.m. (8.6 million).

headline: Two CBS Journalists Missing In Iraq
summary: "Two CBS journalists are missing in the southern Iraqi city of Basra, the network said in a brief statement on Monday," James Glanz reports.

headline: A CBS Newsman’s Serenade: Give My Regards to Mr. Redstone
summary: “Face the Nation” anchor Bob Schieffer paid a musical tribute to his boss, Sumner Redstone, at a gala honoring the media mogul.

headline: CBS Applies Its Brand to a College Sports Channel
summary: CBS announced today that CSTV, the college sports media company that the network bought two years ago, will be renamed the CBS College Sports Network in March.

headline: 'Jericho' Resurrection Inspires Other Save-Our-Show Campaigns
summary: When a show is axed (think "The 4400" on USA) or at risk of being canceled (think "Friday Night Lights" on NBC), passionate viewers point to CBS and think, "The 'Jericho' fans did it, why can't we?"

headline: When Kissinger Met the Bloggers
summary: It was a bit like the great-grandson having a party for the patriarch. On Monday night, the six-year-old conservative blog Power Line gathered a group of luminaries — including Henry A. Kissinger, William Kristol and Paul D. Wolfowitz (with his companion, Shaha Ali Riza, in tow) — to honor Norman Podhoretz with a book award.

headline: Grammy Awards Slump
summary: The Grammy Awards achieved Sunday night’s top ratings despite falling almost two million viewers short of the show’s audience a year ago. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 18.2 million tuned in to CBS’s broadcast of “The 50th Annual Grammy Awards,” down from 20.1 million a year ago. Although the awards show outpaced all other programming for the night among adults 18 to 49, the preliminary overnight numbers suggest that it may be the lowest-rated Grammy show in more than a decade. CBS finished No. 1 for the night over all, leading the 7 o’clock hour before the awards show with “60 Minutes” (13 million). ABC ranked second for the night, thanks to a two-hour “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition” at 8 (15.8 million), followed by “Brothers & Sisters” at 10 (8.6 million). Fox was third with coverage of the National Football League’s Pro Bowl, followed by a lineup of comedy repeats and a new episode of “King of the Hill” at 8:30 (6.1 million). NBC finished fourth with reruns of “American Gladiators” at 7 (3.6 million) and 8 (3.7 million), followed by a two-hour special “100 Most Outrageous Moments” (8.2 million).

headline: High Ratings for 'Deal'
summary: A 90-minute edition of "Deal or No Deal" lifted NBC to another No. 1 finish in the ratings on Monday. According to Nielsen's estimates, 13.1 million viewers tuned in to the game show from 9:30 to 11 p.m., making it the night's top-rated broadcast. NBC also fared well earlier in the night as "American Gladiators" won its 8 to 9:30 p.m. time slot among adults 18 to 49, though it drew a modest 8.8 million total viewers.

headline: Agencies See a Window to Alter the Business of Television
summary: Madison Avenue is optimistic that there can be long-term benefits from the disruptions caused to the broadcast television season by the writers’ strike.

headline: A TV Show Hopes to Cover a Lot of Ground in Postapocalyptic Kansas
summary: “Jericho” may be remembered as the postapocalyptic drama canceled by CBS and only temporarily revived by vocal and Internet-savvy fans, but its executive producers would have it otherwise.

headline: Yahoo's Purchase of Maven Adds Complexity
summary: Yahoo is buying Maven Networks, a company that helps outfits like CBS and Sony put their video online. Its press release is full of all sorts of ways this will help Yahoo: It gets video technology. Yahoo will be able to use its sales force to sell video ads on partner sites. And it will be able to syndicate its content to other sites and bring other video content onto Yahoo.

headline: Hillary’s Health Plan: Hot Peppers
summary: Eating hot peppers may do more than just spice up your diet.

headline: CBS Reports 2 Journalists Missing in Iraq
summary: Basra has repeatedly been the venue of attacks on both Iraqi and Western journalists.

headline: Yahoo Acquires Ad Technology Company
summary: Even as Yahoo tries to stay out of Microsoft's grip, the company is busy closing acquisitions of its own.

headline: Beagle, a Breed Long Unsung, Wins Best in Show
summary: Uno became the first beagle to win best in show in the 100 times the Westminster Kennel Club has picked a winner.

headline: No Pause Button: TV Studios and Writers Play Catch-Up After Strike
summary: With writers expected to return to their posts on the television production assembly line first thing Wednesday morning, the enormous machinery that generates episodes of series will get a massive restart.

headline: Yahoo Acquires Ad Technology Company
summary: Yahoo said it has paid $160 million to acquire Maven Networks, an Internet company that sells a system for managing advertisements in online videos.

headline: 'A Size 48 Neck Is Completely Normal'
summary: Aired Tuesday night on CBS: Cold here in New York City today. Were you folks cold outside? Here's a tip. Here's what savvy New Yorkers do on a cold day like this, I did it earlier today myself. Try it out, let me know what you think. You go over to Grand Central Station - you know where that is, the big train place? There's the Oyster Bar up there. And on a really cold day like this, go up there and fill your pants full of steamed clams.

headline: Iraqis Search for 2 Kidnapped Journalists
summary: The journalists were taken from the Sultan Palace hotel on Sunday by men who appeared to be members of the security forces.

headline: Spring Awakenings at CBS
summary: Today is the day that the writers return to work, and -- perhaps not coincidentally -- CBS has announced the anticipated return dates for its popular shows that were sidelined by the work stoppage.

headline: 'Idol' Delivers Again
summary: "Hollywood Week" on "American Idol" got off to a promising start on Tuesday as a two-hour edition of Fox's talent competition trounced its competitors in the ratings, drawing 29.9 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates. Although Tuesday's "Idol" audience grew by 2 million compared with a week ago, the first installment of "Hollywood Week" last year attracted 31.2 million viewers.

headline: Will Zuckerman Bid for the G.M. Building?
summary: As Harry Macklowe, the New York real estate magnate, prepares to sell the iconic General Motors Building to pay off a $1.2 billion loan, it appears a fellow high-profile rival may be interested in picking it up.

headline: Oscar Night Starting to Seem Like Another Super Bowl
summary: Marketers will spend an estimated $1.6 million for a 30-second spot during the program, and many are planning to run ads previously unseen by consumers.

headline: Valentine's Day on the Trail With Clinton
summary: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio - It's sugar and spice with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on Valentine's Day in Ohio, as she delivered some tough new attack lines against Senator Barack Obama and then served chocolates to her traveling press corps to mark the day.

headline: Hollywood Produces for Idol
summary: “Hollywood Week” on “American Idol” had a promising start on Tuesday as a two-hour edition of that Fox talent competition trounced its competitors in the ratings, drawing 29.9 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Although Tuesday’s “Idol” audience grew by 2 million compared with last week’s, the first installment of “Hollywood Week” last year attracted 31.2 million viewers. Trailing far behind Fox in the night’s ratings, CBS drew the second most viewers, earning a solid 11.7 million at 8 p.m. for a rerun of “NCIS.” Later in the night, however, a more modest 7.3 million viewers tuned in at 9 for the premiere of “Big Brother: ’Til Death Do You Part,” the first winter edition of that CBS summer mainstay. At 10 the second season debut of “Jericho” attracted 7.2 million viewers, tying ABC’s “Boston Legal,” but trailing a repeat of NBC’s “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” (8.3 million). NBC finished third for the night while edging past CBS for second place among adults 18 to 49 thanks to “The Biggest Loser,” from 8 to 10 (7.5 million). ABC was a distant fourth overall.

headline: 'Maybe One Day a Schnauzer?'
summary: Aired Wednesday night on CBS: I don't know about the rest of the country, but here in New York City, rainy couple of days. A lot of rain, soggy - am I right? A lot of soaking rain here. So rainy - listen to this - Amy Winehouse's hair jumped up and shook itself dry.

headline: Interpreter Freed, but CBS Journalist Still Held

headline: So, What Were We Writing About Again?

headline: Surviving in Style

ABC also had the top-rated show, “Lost,” which led at 9 with 13.6 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. “Survivor” won the 8 o’clock time slot with 13.1 million viewers; NBC’s “Deal or No Deal” had 12 million. Trailing “Lost” at 9 were CBS’s “CSI” repeat (11 million) and NBC’s “Celebrity Apprentice” (9.1 million). NBC tied CBS for second among the 18-to-49 set and tied ABC for second in total viewers. Fox finished fourth over all.

headline: Superdelegate Poll: Unsettled Ground
summary: Despite Senator Barack Obama's strong showing in recent primaries, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton continues to hold onto more support from superdelegates, the Democratic Party elites, according to a survey by The New York Times and CBS News.The current count is 189.5 superdelegate votes for Mrs. Clinton and 142.5 for Mr. Obama. But in a similar survey conducted last month, Mrs. Clinton led Mr. Obama by 204 to 99. About 8 percent of the total 795 superdelegates changed their minds over the last few weeks, as many states held their primaries and caucuses. Few delegates switched allegiance from one candidate to the other; the main changes were among the undecided delegates. Among the previously undecided delegates who now are endorsing a candidate, Mr. Obama got more of their support. Some of Mrs. Clinton's previous supporters are now undecided.

headline: Games Pay Off for NBC
summary: The combination of “Deal or No Deal” and the new game show “My Dad Is Better Than Your Dad” lifted NBC to a solid No. 1 finish in the ratings on Monday. Nielsen estimated that the new series, which pits father-child teams against one another, attracted 9.8 million viewers at 9 p.m., a respectable showing, but far less than the 16.9 million who tuned in for “Deal or No Deal” at 8 p.m. Opposite the game shows, however, the finale of ABC’s “Dance War” averaged 9.1 million viewers while earning the show’s lowest ratings among adults 18 to 49. ABC ranked fourth over all, trailing with “October Road” (4.4 million) at 10 p.m. behind NBC’s “Medium” (8.5 million) and CBS’s “CSI: Miami” repeat (9.6 million). CBS finished second for the night behind NBC, but third among adults 18 to 49, behind NBC and Fox, which got a boost in that demographic from the finale of “Prison Break” at 8 (7.4 million) and “Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles” at 9 (8.1 million). On Sunday NBC’s “Knight Rider” (12.7 million) drew the highest ratings in the 18-to-49 age group for a made-for-television movie on any network in almost three years.

A made-for-television movie, it won every hour of prime time except the 8 p.m. slot, when it trailed NBC’s “Deal or No Deal” (15.3 million). After a six-week streak of leading on Monday nights among adults 18 to 49, NBC finished in second place over all as its new game show, “My Dad Is Better Than Your Dad,” at 9 (7.8 million), suffered a decline of 2 million viewers from its debut a week ago. CBS and Fox were third and fourth for the night, with CBS drawing more total viewers and Fox, buoyed by “The Moment of Truth” at 8 (8.6 million), faring better with the 18-to-49 set. headline: 'Lyrics' Outdraws 'Lost'

ABC ranked third for the night, trailing Fox and CBS, which ranked second, thanks to “Survivor: Micronesia” at 8 (12.5 million), followed by reruns of “CSI” (11.6 million) and “Without a Trace” (10.4 million). ABC ran close behind CBS in the 18-to-49 set. NBC was a distant fourth over all, drawing its highest ratings at 9 with “The Celebrity Apprentice” (7.6 million) but struggling at 10 with “Lipstick Jungle” (5.7 million).

headline: Letters: Readers Speak
summary: Re "What That McCain Article Didn't Say" (Feb. 24): The beauty of the Feb. 21 front-page article about Senator John McCain is that it was constructed in such a way that The New York Times could go either way with it, depending on how the public responded.If the public bought in, the paper could leverage the impact with expanded editorial and Op-Ed coverage. If the public thought it was a lot of hooey, which they did, they could go to Plan B and send the public editor into the fray to apologize for any misunderstanding and point out that the story did not actually say what it was intended to suggest.Either way, The Times would keep alive a story that the public correctly recognized as insubstantial.Margaret McGirrGreenwich, Conn., Feb. 25, 2008

A two-hour documentary about the British monarchy attracted 14.1 million viewers to ABC on Monday, making the network No. 1 for the night despite a poor performance for “October Road” at 10 p.m. The game show “Deal or No Deal,” in a new time slot at 9 p.m., averaged 10.8 million viewers, enough to earn NBC a second-place finish. CBS placed third, as strong showings by “Two and a Half Men” (9.9 million at 9) and “CSI: Miami” (9.2 million at 10) offset lower-rated sitcoms like the new series “Welcome to the Captain” (5.6 million at 8:30). In the 18- to 49-year-old demographic, ABC and Fox were tied for first place. Almost eight million viewers watched the conclusion of “Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles” on Fox.

Along with the nominations, announced in Nashville, came word that for the first time fans will choose the winner of the entertainer of the year prize. Voting will begin May 5; the awards will be presented on May 18 in a program to be telecast on CBS from Las Vegas.

headline: 'A Hunting Trip With Dick Cheney'

headline: ‘Idol’ Lends Life to Dead Detective
summary: Television audiences preferred unscripted fare on Tuesday, as an hour of “American Idol” on Fox dominated the night’s ratings and two hours of “The Biggest Loser” on NBC gained viewers every half-hour from 8 to 10 p.m. Fox hoped that the 28.2 million viewers of “Idol” would stay tuned for the premiere of “New Amsterdam,” and almost half did. The drama about an immortal New York homicide detective averaged 13.7 million viewers. On NBC, “The Biggest Loser” drew 7.2 million viewers in its first hour and 10.2 million viewers in its second. A repeat of “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” delivered 9.4 million viewers, easily doubling the time period’s average from last week, when the Internet series “Quarterlife” made an attempt at television. CBS started the night strong with 10.5 million viewers for a repeat of “NCIS” but lost traction at 9 with “Big Brother” (7 million). At 10, “Jericho” delivered 5.9 million viewers, a million fewer than the previous week. Sitcoms did not draw many viewers to ABC, ranking it fourth for the night, although a “Primetime” hidden-camera newsmagazine averaged 7.6 million viewers, making it the most popular program at 10 p.m.

headline: So Many Characters, Yet So Little Resolution
summary: “The Wire” went out the way it came in five seasons ago, not so much tying up loose ends, though it did, as meticulously proving that there is no end.

headline: Cable Firms Join Forces to Attract Focused Ads
summary: The nation’s six largest cable companies are planning a jointly owned company that would allow national advertisers to buy customized ads across their systems.

headline: Britney Spears Will Guest Star on CBS' 'Mother'
summary: The Associated Press reports:

headline: 'A Guy Who Is Dating Your Mom'
summary: Aired Monday night on CBS: The big news scandal here in New York City just breaking a couple of hours ago is that New York Gov. Eliot Spitzer was caught in one of those sting deals. They caught Spitzer with a wire, recording him soliciting a prostitute. And I'm thinking holy cow! We can't get bin Laden but by God, we got Spitzer. We got Spitzer!

headline: The Late-Night Comics Take on Spitzer
summary: These days, a political scandal does not seem real until the late-night TV comics start cracking jokes about it. The first round in the Eliot Spitzer joke-fest was Monday night.

headline: Fox Goes Kind of Cable-y
summary: Monday night's premiere episode of "Canterbury's Law," a new legal drama on Fox, felt dark, mature and realistic -- fare found more often on cable than broadcast. But viewers in the choice demographic seemed to show little interest in it, and the program finished in fourth place among 18- to 49-year-olds.

headline: A Scandal Tailor-Made for Late Night
summary: The saying "the jokes write themselves" certainly applies to Monday's revelations about New York Governor Eliot Spitzer's links to a prostitution ring.

headline: Younger Viewers Spurn New Legal Drama
summary: “Canterbury’s Law,” the new Fox legal drama, felt dark, mature and realistic  fare found more often on cable than on broadcast television. Julianna Margulies, the show’s star, said the network wanted to “bring a little FX to Fox.” But young viewers showed little interest in “Canterbury’s Law,” as the show’s premiere finished in fourth place in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic at 8 p.m. on Monday, Nielsen reported. Fox suggested that the transition to daylight saving time might have had some impact on the ratings. “Canterbury’s Law” averaged 7.6 million viewers, enough to place second in total viewers behind ABC’s “Bachelor,” but delivered a disappointing 1.7 rating in the 18-to-49 demographic favored by advertisers. At 9 p.m. “New Amsterdam” picked up some viewers for Fox, averaging 8.8 million viewers and a 2.5 rating in that demographic. The 11.7 million viewers for “Two and a Half Men” and the 10.1 million viewers for “CSI: Miami” put CBS into first place for the night. NBC was a close second, as ho-hum viewership for “My Dad Is Better Than Your Dad” (6.9 million) was offset by high ratings for “Deal or No Deal” (11.6 million) and “Medium” (9.2 million). ABC placed fourth for the night with two episodes of the low-rated “October Road” (4.6 million at 9, and 4.8 million at 10).

headline: 'There but for a Declined Master Card Go I'
summary: Aired Tuesday night on CBS: You folks are in a great mood, and I know why: because it's a beautiful day in New York City. Isn't it lovely outside? Beautiful blue skies, sunny, very, very sunny -- it's so sunny and bright outside that earlier today, Eliot Spitzer came out of a brothel squinting.

headline: How Big Was Tuesday's 'Idol?'
summary: More than 31 million people watched the top 12 finalists perform on "American Idol" Tuesday night, down slightly from the same episode in previous seasons but still enough to bring Fox more viewers than all the other broadcast networks combined.

headline: Once Again, 'Jericho' Is on Thin Ice
summary: The ratings for "Jericho," the CBS drama imagining life after a series of nuclear attacks, appear to have stabilized. Unfortunately for the show's fans, the viewership is stabilizing at a lower number than CBS would like.

headline: ‘Idol’ Hands Rivals a Tuneful Defeat
summary: More than 31 million viewers watched the top 12 finalists perform on “American Idol” Tuesday night, down slightly from previous seasons, but still attracting more viewers to Fox than all the other broadcast networks combined, according to Nielsen. New viewers tuned in every half-hour of the performances, from 25.6 million at 8 to 31.6 million at 9:30 p.m. The two-hour broadcast averaged 29.3 million viewers and a 10.8 rating in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic. Behind “Idol,” NBC’s programs fared best. “The Biggest Loser” averaged 7.7 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., and a repeat of “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” was the second most popular show of the night, averaging 9.4 million viewers at 10 p.m. for NBC. On CBS, a repeat of “NCIS” attracted 8.6 million viewers, but many tuned out “Big Brother” at 9 and “Jericho” at 10 (5.9 million each). ABC’s sitcoms drew fewer than 5 million viewers, but the network showed life at 10 p.m. when a new installment of the “What Would You Do?” hidden-camera investigation show averaged 7.5 million viewers.

headline: The Return of the Democratic Debates
summary: Just when you thought they were over.

headline: Putting a Hard Number on Retirement
summary: The United States arm of ING is launching a “Your Number” campaign, which refers to the amount of money that you will need to retire comfortably.

headline: 'Like Dinner With the Spitzers'
summary: Aired Wednesday night on CBS: Last night -- what a horrible audience. And I really don't like talking about people when they're gone, but, oh, I mean, it's not so much that they were horrible, they were just quiet. I mean, my God, it was like dinner at the Spitzers.

headline: Ratings: Jeff, Sawyer, The Skipper and Mary Ann
summary: Island castaways ruled the night on broadcast television, with "Survivor: Micronesia" drawing 13.1 million viewers to CBS at 8 and "Lost" attracting 11.9 million viewers to ABC at 9.

headline: Fox Wins as Viewers Get a Dose of Reality
summary: Fox’s “American Idol” easily beat the competition at 9 p.m. on Wednesday, averaging 26.7 million viewers and a 10.1 rating in the 18-to-49 demographic.

headline: The Upfronts: Return of the Sundance Kid
summary: The Sundance Channel knows how to attract advertisers to its upfront presentations: take Robert Redford.

headline: Conquering Castaways
summary: On Thursday CBS’s “Survivor: Micronesia” led with 13.1 million viewers at 8 p.m., followed by ABC’s “Lost,” with 11.9 million at 9, Nielsen estimated. “Lost” placed first in the coveted 18- to-49 demographic, but CBS won the night over all in total viewers and in the 18-to-49 set, thanks to “Survivor” and repeats of “CSI” (11.4 million) and “Without a Trace” (9.9 million). Fox placed second in total viewers , but third, behind ABC, among 18- to-49-year-olds. Low ratings for repeats of “My Name Is Earl” (4.3 million at 8) put NBC in fourth place, though “The Celebrity Apprentice” picked up some steam (8.1 million) at 9.

headline: Setting the Stage for a Showdown in San Antonio
summary: The Final Four is set, at least according to the early returns. And, based on completed brackets on ESPN's Men's Tournament Challenge Web site, North Carolina is the projected winner. The top-seeded teams all received the highest percentage of votes in their respective regions to win it all.

headline: Selection Sunday
summary: Update, 6:58 p.m. Speaking on CBS, Tom O'Connor, the head of the selection committee, said there were five contingency plans in place depending on what happened in the various conference title games today. Georgia (17-16) won the Southeastern Conference tournament with its third victory in two days, likely knocking out an at-large team. Illinois, with a sub-.500 record would have also knocked a team out had it won the Big Ten tournament.

headline: Tranghese On Expansion
summary: As we mentioned earlier this week on The Quad, there's always talk this time of year about N.C.A.A. tournament expansion. Big East Commissioner Mike Tranghese said on Saturday night that it would not happen for two reasons. One was Tiger Woods and the other was cash.

headline: 'Down a Fireman's Pole Into a Pantsuit'
summary: Aired Wednesday night on CBS: The drinking water in New York City, have you heard about this? I mean, like we don't have enough problems; 15 different prescription drugs, in our drinking water. You need a doctor's prescription to turn on the faucet.

headline: Lacey Tisch, Lowell Sidney
summary: Lacey Ann Tisch, the daughter of Susan Tisch Allen and Andrew H. Tisch, both of Manhattan, was married on Saturday evening to Lowell Jay Sidney, a son of Marcia Sidney and Steven L. Sidney of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. Rabbi Philip Hiat, the bride’s maternal grandfather, performed the ceremony at Central Synagogue in Manhattan.

headline: Return of the Rock Lobsters
summary: The B-52s, new wave pioneers from the ’70s, are back with an album and a planned tour.

headline: On CBS, the Return of the Scripted Series
summary: In January, Jon Cryer, an actor on the sitcom "Two and a Half Men," was walking the writers' guild picket lines in Burbank. In February, with the strike resolved, he was on a soundstage taping a new television episode for the first time in months. Tonight, the episode debuts on CBS.

headline: Superdelegates: A Shift Toward Obama
summary: The number of undecided superdelegates has fallen in recent weeks as both candidates have picked up support - Barack Obama more so than Hillary Rodham Clinton, according to a survey by The New York Times and CBS News.

headline: A Second Chance at West Virginia
summary: One year ago, the West Virginia assistant Billy Hahn was watching the N.C.A.A. tournament at an efficiency apartment in New Jersey. Hahn was working for the basketball instructional organization Hoop Group.

headline: A Hollywood Family Takes on Medical Mistakes
summary: Hospital errors are a leading cause of death.

headline: Network News Trimming Staff, Especially Producers
summary: Most of the recent news about media industry layoffs has come from newspapers, where buyouts and layoffs are increasingly common. But television news operations have trimmed their employee rolls as well, according to The State of the News Media 2008, a report by the Project for Excellence in Journalism.

headline: ABC Takes Sunday Night
summary: ABC had the most viewers on Sunday night, thanks to new installments of “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition” and “Oprah’s Big Give,” which delivered 12 million and 9.7 million viewers at 8 and 9, respectively, Nielsen estimated. ABC’s “Here Come the Newlyweds” at 10 (7 million) led its time slot among adults 18 to 49, but trailed NBC’s “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” rerun (7.7 million) over all. CBS’s “Dexter” was third in the hour (6.4 million). CBS and NBC finished in a virtual tie for second place that night. CBS’s “60 Minutes” drew the network’s largest audience, with 11.1 million at 7. Fox placed fourth in total viewers, but second in the 18-to-49 set.

headline: 'Idol' Blows Past 'Dancing'
summary: ABC's celebrity dancers were no match for Fox's would-be celebrities in Tuesday's ratings. According to Nielsen's estimates, Fox's "American Idol" outpaced ABC's "Dancing With the Stars" by more than 10 million viewers during the 9 p.m. hour, when the two series went head-to-head.

headline: Dancing to the Top
summary: The sixth-season premiere of ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” attracted 20.9 million viewers on Monday, Nielsen estimated, leading ABC to first place for the night. The premiere of “The Bachelor,” which followed “Dancing With the Stars,” averaged considerably less: 9 million viewers from 9:30 p.m. to 11 p.m. CBS earned a solid second place thanks to the return of its comedy lineup: “The Big Bang Theory” at 8 (9.1 million), “How I Met Your Mother” at 8:30 (9.7 million), “Two and a Half Men” at 9 (14 million) and “The New Adventures of Old Christine” at 9:30 (11.5 million). NBC was third over all, with “My Dad Is Better Than Your Dad” at 8 (4.7 million) and “Deal or No Deal” at 9 (9.9 million).

headline: Gay and Lesbian Group Gives Awards
summary: Barbara Walters, right, and “60 Minutes” shared the award for television news magazines at the 19th annual Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation Media Awards in New York on Monday, Reuters reported. Ms. Walters won for “My Secret Self: A Story of Transgender Children,” on ABC’s “20/20,” and “60 Minutes,” on CBS, won for “Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell,” about the United States military’s policy on gay and lesbian service members. The award for outstanding film in limited release went to the Hebrew- and Arabic-language film “The Bubble,” about a love affair between and Israeli soldier and a Palestinian man. “For the Bible Tells Me So” was named outstanding documentary. Among the other honorees for coverage of gay and lesbian issues were The New York Times, GQ magazine, CNN.com and the television series “Boston Legal.”.

headline: How Far Has the World Turned?
summary: Among the recipients of the Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation Media Awards on Monday night, one stood out: "As The World Turns," which won the award for outstanding daily drama, has been criticized by viewers for what they perceived as a deliberate attempt to treat gay characters differently.

headline: Poll: Racism More of Problem Than Sexism
summary: Americans think racism is a more serious problem than sexism in the United States today. In a CBS News poll taken last weekend, a plurality of Americans, 42 percent said racism was a more serious problem for the country compared to 10 percent who said sexism was the more serious problem. Twenty-three percent said neither racism nor sexism was a problem for the country and another 23 percent volunteered that the problems were equally serious for the nation.

headline: A Call Girl's Story
summary: In the debate about prostitution that has unfolded on this blog and elsewhere, one of the thorniest issues has been those women who are not obviously coerced and participate in the high-priced call girl services. After I wrote about the topic, a reader named Basil Hero sent this story about one such woman:

headline: "Adopted by Angelina Jolie'
summary: Aired Tuesday night on CBS: On Monday, right after being sworn in, the new governor...of New York, David Paterson, he announces that he cheated on his wife. I'm thinking, this guy didn't waste any time, did he?

headline: An Announcer Arrives
summary: Carter Blackburn, 28, will announce his first N.C.A.A. tournament games for CBS this week. He stopped by The Quad to describe the experience of getting ready for the games.

headline: Opinion: How the Grinch Stole March Madness
summary: The N.C.A.A. tournament is one of the few events that brings together sports fans of every stripe. But since we're feeling ornery and contrarian today -- like Dick Vitale before his first 15 cups of coffee -- we thought we'd weigh in on the downside. So here are five things we are rooting against:

headline: The Obama Speech: The Ratings
summary: On a typical weekday morning, about two million Americans are watching the three cable news channels. This Tuesday, when Barack Obama delivered a speech about race, more than four million viewers tuned in.

headline: Sundance Channel Up for Sale
summary: The Sundance Channel, a joint venture of NBC Universal, the CBS Corporation and the actor and director Robert Redford, is up for sale, a media analyst said Wednesday. Sundance, a 12-year-old cable channel currently accessible to 26 million homes, is seeking more than $400 million, according to the analyst, Richard Greenfield of Pali Research. A spokeswoman for the channel declined to comment in an e-mail message. If neither NBC nor CBS decide to take full ownership, Mr. Greenfield said, Cablevision, Time Warner and Viacom could be interested. Some cable customers receive Sundance as part of a digital channel package; others must subscribe separately. The Sundance Channel promotes itself as “independent-minded” and shows films, documentaries and original programming. It operates separately from the Sundance Film Festival but seeks a similar audience. Its programs include “Iconoclasts,” in which two famous people interview each other, and the environmentally oriented series “The Green.” Rather than running standard commercials, the channel has allowed marketers to sponsor specific programs.

headline: 'Threatening To Resign' I
summary: Aired Wednesday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: The Dalai Lama, the spiritual leader of the Tibetan people, is threatening to resign if the conflict with the Chinese doesn't stop. Not only that, he also says he might refuse to be reincarnated again.

headline: Tune in Elsewhere
summary: I made a great discovery this week: there is a TV right here in the office that gets the Golf Channel. So while the March Maniacs -- many of whom don’t pay any attention to sports the rest of the year -- are tuned into CBS this afternoon, I’m going to be watching Tiger Woods at the CA Championship in Florida. A month from now, who will remember which beanpole hit the 3-pointer from the corner for the mid-major from Ohio? But Tiger right now is on a streak -- seven tournament wins in a row -- that people will be talking about for many years. We don’t often get to see perfection in sports, but lately he’s come close, and if you think it’s more fun this weekend to watch guys run around in a gym than to see Tiger tackle the Blue Monster at Doral, then that’s really Madness.

headline: Tune in Elsewhere
summary: "I made a great discovery this week: there is a TV right here in the office that gets the Golf Channel. So while the March Maniacs -- many of whom don't pay any attention to sports the rest of the year -- are tuned into CBS this afternoon, I'm going to be watching Tiger Woods at the CA Championship in Florida," Charles McGrath wrote in this week's Play newsletter. "A month from now, who will remember which beanpole hit the 3-pointer from the corner for the mid-major from Ohio? But Tiger right now is on a streak -- seven tournament wins in a row -- that people will be talking about for many years. We don't often get to see perfection in sports, but lately he's come close, and if you think it's more fun this weekend to watch guys run around in a gym than to see Tiger tackle the Blue Monster at Doral, then that's really Madness."

headline: Obama and Race
summary: The Obama campaign has led many white Americans to listen in for the first time to some of the black conversation — and they are thunderstruck.

headline: NBC Will Sell Two Stations
summary: NBC Universal is shedding two of its owned-and-operated stations, leaving the company with eight English-language affiliates in top television markets.

headline: Cornell Goes Back to High School
summary: I'll provide a quick recap of our first evening in Anaheim after a long day of traveling. We practiced at Loara High School, the alma mater of the pop star Gwen Stefani, for a couple of hours. It was a surprisingly crisp and energetic practice, considering we had just been traveling for seven hours. After a team dinner at our hotel, the Hilton Anaheim, we spent the rest of the night relaxing in our hotel rooms getting ready for another day of preparation and practice.

headline: How the Grinch Stole March Madness
summary: The N.C.A.A. Tournament is one of the few events that brings together sports fans of every stripe. But since we’re feeling ornery and contrarian this morning — like Dick Vitale before his first 15 cups of coffee — we thought we’d weigh in on the downside. So here are five things we are rooting against:.

headline: 'Slice Me Eight More Years of That'
summary: Aired Wednesday night on CBS: John McCain recently said he supports George Bush's Iraq policy. I said, "Well, sure, slice me eight more years of that, will you? Let's go!"

headline: Streaming Every Dribble and Dunk
summary: One of the hottest search terms on Google Thursday was "MMOD." That can only mean one thing: March Madness on Demand is back.

headline: Photo Dealer Takes CBGB Gallery Space
summary: The Morrison Hotel Gallery will open a location at 315 Bowery on March 27, with a plan to preserve some of the original, grungy GBGB décor.

headline: Fox Leads CBS in Household Viewers
summary: First 18- to 49-year-olds, then total viewers, now households: the recognition of Fox as the most-watched television network in America continued last week as it displaced CBS among households in prime time.

headline: Update: 'Jericho' Is Really Really Really Really Really Really Cancelled by CBS
summary: It's dead. For the second time. And this time, it looks permanent.

headline: 'Idol', as Usual
summary: “American Idol” on Fox easily outpaced its four network competitors combined in the 9 p.m. time slot on Wednesday.

headline: Tournament Is a Hit Online
summary: The number of viewers for NCAA March Madness on Demand, the free Internet companion to CBS's broadcast of the men's basketball tournament, more than doubled during Thursday's first round to 1.75 million unique users.

headline: Reports That 'Jericho' Has Been Cancelled (Again)
summary: Update: 5:14 p.m.: CBS has confirmed that the series finale will be shown next week. "Without question, there are passionate viewers watching this program; we simply wish there were more," Nina Tassler, the president of CBS Entertainment, said in a statement.

headline: Sunday's Breakfast Menu, March 23
summary: If you like your Easter eggs over easy, then stick to painting them with your children. This Sunday's talk show menu is filled with heavy topics like the economy and the war in Iraq.

headline: ‘President Bling-Bling’
summary: For a politician who worked so hard to get into the Élysée Palace, President Nicolas Sarkozy of France has demonstrated a curious notion of how to behave once there.

headline: Obama’s Speech on Race Played Well, a Poll Finds
summary: Seven in 10 said the senator did a good job talking about race relations, and as many said he did a good job explaining his relationship with the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr.

headline: A British Dynasty for All Seasons
summary: Among the many things for which he will be remembered, Paul Scofield helped to usher in a whole era of classy, lushly produced costume films set in the Tudor period.

headline: Deal Provides an Edge
summary: NBC eked out a rare victory in Thursday’s ratings, attracting the most viewers for the night by the slimmest of margins, thanks largely to the strength of “Deal or No Deal.” According to Nielsen estimates, “Deal” drew 10.2 million viewers at 8 p.m., finishing second to ABC’s “Lost” (11.3 million) for the night’s largest audience. But that was enough to win the night, because ABC attracted only 6.3 million viewers to its new 8 p.m. comedy, “Miss Guided.” Up against “Lost” at 9 p.m., NBC’s “Celebrity Apprentice” earned a modest 8.6 million viewers. At 10, the network’s “Lipstick Jungle” (7.2 million) delivered its best ratings since its debut in February, but still trailed ABC’s “Eli Stone” (7.5 million). Despite the edge in total viewers, NBC finished third among adults 18 to 49 behind ABC and CBS, which led the night in that demographic with its coverage of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament. Fox ranked fourth for the night.

headline: 'Jericho' Is Gone Again
summary: CBS has canceled the postapocalyptic drama “Jericho” for the second time in two years. Tuesday’s season finale will also be the series finale, the network said Friday. The series, which starred Skeet Ulrich and followed the events in a small Kansas town after nuclear attacks devastated cities across the United States, was first canceled in May 2007. A campaign by fans combined with data showing that the show was being recorded and watched outside its broadcast time persuaded CBS to order a short second season. But the show has performed poorly since the new episodes began appearing last month. The most recent episode attracted fewer than six million viewers and a 1.9 rating in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic. “Without question, there are passionate viewers watching this program; we simply wish there were more,” Nina Tassler, the president of CBS Entertainment, said in a statement. Carol Barbee, an executive producer of “Jericho,” said she was “pursuing other venues” for the series, giving credence to reports that a cable network could pick it up.

headline: At Cineplexes, Sports, Opera, Maybe a Movie
summary: Movie theaters are not just for movies anymore. As ticket sales slow, theaters are turning to the Mets and the Met.

headline: The Supreme Court and Indecency
summary: The Federal Communications Commission has used its new expletives policy to turn itself into a roving censorship board.

headline: Clinton 'Misspoke' About Bosnia Trip, Campaign Says
summary: The Clinton campaign says Senator Hillary Clinton may have "misspoke" recently when she said she had to evade sniper fire when she was visiting Bosnia in 1996 as first lady.

headline: 'They're Really, Really Out to Get Us'
summary: Thirty-five years ago, I never thought I would miss Richard Nixon. But let's face it, the guy was - is - endlessly entertaining. In a new book, "In Nixon's Web: A Year in the Crosshairs of Watergate," L. Patrick Gray recalls an audience he and his wife were granted at the White House in May 1972. At the time Gray had just been named acting director of the F.B.I., after the death of J. Edgar Hoover. Nixon, of course, could never stop talking about the press and broached the subject almost immediately, offering Gray a master class in media relations:

headline: Clinton Says She ‘Misspoke’ About Dodging Sniper Fire
summary: The backpedaling about her description of a trip to Bosnia as first lady in 1996 was a rare instance of Hillary Rodham Clinton acknowledging an error.

headline: Spears Goes for Laughs on CBS' 'Mother'
summary: The Associated Press reports:

headline: How I (the Viewer) Met Britney Spears
summary: Entertainment newsmagazines already know that Britney Spears is a ratings magnet. Now "How I Met Your Mother" has apparently proven it as well.

headline: Thailand may be next for global investment surge, CBRE says
summary: Economists these days are raving about the continued growth of "cross border transactions," the movement of investment money from country to country. Even with the much-discussed property slowdown, the amount of money flowing around the world is at unprecedented levels, they say, bolstering markets and creating quick run ups.

headline: Spears’s Bit Part: Not a Comeback
summary: Britney Spears's small guest appearance on the CBS show “How I Met Your Mother” was a boon for the network, but that doesn’t mean that Ms. Spears is well again and on her way back to former glory.

headline: Behind in the Ratings, CBS News Hopes for Help From a Debate
summary: CBS News, which lags well behind its competitors in most areas of television news, wants a debate between Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton in the worst way.

headline: Wednesday's Links: One Day More of Waiting
summary: While Michael Beasley toils over whether to become filthy rich now or next year, feel lucky that you don't have such difficult decisions hanging over your head.

headline: Britney Spears Lifts CBS
summary: A guest appearance from Britney Spears helped CBS’s “How I Met Your Mother” attract its largest audience of the season on Monday, as 10.6 million viewers tuned in to the sitcom at 8:30 p.m., Nielsen reported. The series, in its third season, also earned its highest ratings on record among adults 18 to 49, lifting CBS into first place on the night in that demographic. Although ABC drew more total viewers, thanks to “Dancing With the Stars” from 8 to 10 (20.3 million), CBS’s “Two and a Half Men” at 9 (14.3 million) eked out a victory as the top-rated show with the 18-to-49 set. CBS also led during the 10 p.m. hour with “CSI: Miami” (15.8 million), which easily outpaced both NBC’s “Medium” (8.8 million) and ABC’s “Bachelor” (8 million). ABC ranked second for the night in the 18-to-49 age bracket, followed by NBC and Fox in a tie for third. NBC garnered solid ratings at 9 for “Deal or No Deal” (10 million) but lagged behind at 8 with “My Dad Is Better Than Your Dad” (4.3 million). Fox broadcast a “House” repeat at 8 (7.6 million) and “New Amsterdam” at 9 (6.3 million).

headline: Transactions
summary: $36 MILLION.

headline: McCain, in Foreign Policy Talk, Turns His Back on Unilateralism
summary: John McCain’s speech was an apparent effort to draw attention to his positions on topics other than his insistence on staying the course in Iraq.

headline: A Towel Exchange
summary: Few folks in the U.S. Airways Arena on Wednesday could come up with first-hand recollections of the former Western Kentucky coach E.A. Diddle. But the CBS announcer Bill Raftery spun a few yarns about the Diddle, who is still among the top 20 in career victories (759) for men's coaches.

headline: Corrections
summary: BUSINESS DAY.

headline: Mourners Absent From Jericho Finale
summary: CBS’s sci-fi show “Jericho” limped across the finish line on Tuesday, attracting just under six million viewers for its series finale, Nielsen reported. “Jericho,” first canceled last spring but revived over the summer after an outcry from devoted fans, only to be canceled once again, finished third in its 10 p.m. slot, behind ABC’s “Primetime” (10.4 million) and a repeat of NBC’s “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” (8.5 million). CBS ranked fourth for the night, despite drawing higher ratings with an “NCIS” rerun at 8 (9.4 million), followed at 9 by “Big Brother,” which also attracted 6 million viewers but fared better than “Jericho” among adults 18 to 49. Fox easily led over all, thanks to a 90-minute edition of “American Idol” from 8 to 9:30 (24.4 million). ABC was second with “Dancing With the Stars” at 9 (17.2 million). NBC finished third.

headline: No One Comes Close To Fox's 'Idol'
summary: No other network came close to catching Fox in the ratings on Wednesday as 25.4 million viewers tuned in for the results edition of "American Idol," according to Nielsen's estimates. The 9 p.m. episode, which included the elimination of 22-year-old Chikezie Eze, followed one hour after Fox's game show "Moment of Truth" led the 8 p.m. time slot with 10 million viewers.

headline: The Great Cornball Anthem
summary: One moment, not exactly shining: It’s 1986, and in a bar in East Lansing, Mich., a woman approaches a struggling folk musician named David Barrett. "A waitress," Barrett recalled last year, "too beautiful for words. What do I say to this woman?" He panics, glances at the TV, sees Larry Bird "using someone like soap." So he starts talking about Larry Bird, “how amazing he is, blah blah blah." The woman is unimpressed. Barrett slinks out of the bar, thinking that he might write a song about basketball, and a phrase pops into his head, out of nowhere, and the next morning he sits down for lunch and scribbles on a napkin the great cornball anthem that, two decades later, still makes grown men cry.

headline: NBC Pokes CBS In the Eye, Which Is Legal In Mixed Martial Arts, Apparently
summary: There's no better lead than this one, so: "NBC beat CBS to the punch," TV Week reports.

headline: Fox's 'Idol' and 'Truth' Pile Up Numbers
summary: No other network came close to catching Fox in the ratings on Wednesday, as 25.4 million viewers tuned in for the results edition of “American Idol.”

headline: Comments of the Week: Leaving 'Jericho'
summary: The series finale of "Jericho," shown Tuesday on CBS, left fans with some hope that the show could go on -- albeit on another network. At the end of the episode the lead characters defused a nuclear bomb threat but instigated a new American civil war between the eastern and western states.

headline: Game Put on a Pedestal for Teams at Ford Field

headline: Ratings: A Revived 'Apprentice' Finale Wins Out

headline: College Basketball Propels CBS Forward
summary: With a boost from its afternoon coverage of the N.C.A.A. college basketball tournament, CBS eked out a slight ratings victory on Sunday, edging past ABC as the night’s most watched network. According to Nielsen’s overnight estimates, the 23-minute college basketball overrun into the 7 p.m. time slot meant that more than 17 million viewers were tuned in to CBS during the first half-hour of prime time. Directly after the live coverage ended, CBS drew about 12.3 million viewers for “60 Minutes,” followed by an above-average audience of 8 million viewers for CBS’s “Big Brother.” Despite its second place finish, ABC outpaced CBS among adults 18 to 49 thanks to “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition” at 8 (12.8 million) and “Oprah’s Big Give” at 9 (11.3 million). Fox was third for the night in that demographic, trailing both ABC and CBS with its animated comedy lineup. NBC, which drew slightly more total viewers than Fox, finished a distant fourth in the 18-to-49 set. NBC broadcast repeats from 9 to 11, following a special showing of MSNBC’s “Countdown With Keith Olbermann” at 7 (3.4 million) and “Dateline” at 8 (6.7 million).

headline: Winning Combination: Food and Song
summary: Fox trounced its competitors Tuesday thanks to the combination of “American Idol” and a strong showing for the start of “Hell’s Kitchen,” with Gordon Ramsay, left. Nielsen estimated that the fourth season premiere of the reality cooking show drew 12.6 million viewers, a considerable improvement over the 8.4 million the series averaged last summer. That 9 p.m. show also delivered the night’s second-highest ratings among adults 18 to 49, outpacing a direct competitor, the results episode of “Dancing With the Stars,” even though that ABC show delivered more total viewers in the hour (16.9 million). Fox’s “American Idol,” meanwhile, achieved the top ratings over all with 25.2 million viewers at 8 p.m. ABC ranked second in total viewers, but fourth among the 18-to-49 set behind CBS and NBC, which tied for second. CBS led the 10 p.m. hour with “CSI: Miami” (14.3 million), easily outperforming ABC’s Barbara Walters special “Live to be 150 ... Can You Do It?” (10.2 million).

headline: Peabody Award Winners
summary: Three news reports about Iraq war casualties were among the winners of the 2007 Peabody Awards. Announced on Wednesday by the Grady College of Journalism and Mass Communication at the University of Georgia, the awards are intended to honor the best in electronic media. CBS received two Peabody awards for war coverage, one for a Scott Pelley report on “60 Minutes” about the killings of civilians in the Haditha, Iraq, and another for the report by Kimberly Dozier, above, on “CBS News Sunday Morning: The Way Home” about two female veterans who lost limbs in Iraq. Ms. Dozier was wounded in Iraq in May 2006. Similarly, the ABC News correspondent Bob Woodruff, injured in Iraq in January 2006, received an award for “Wounds of War,” a series about wounded veterans. Among entertainment series, awards went to “30 Rock,” the NBC sitcom inspired by “Saturday Night Live”; “Mad Men,” the AMC drama about a 1960s advertising agency; “The Colbert Report,” the cable news satire on Comedy Central; “Project Runway,” the fashion reality show on Bravo; and “Nimrod Nation,” a d Sundance Channel documentary series. The Discovery series “Planet Earth” and PBS’s “Nature: Silence of the Bees” also received awards.

headline: 48 Hours Gets Religion
summary: “48 Hours,” the CBS newsmagazine usually known for investigating murder mysteries, is about to tackle a very different subject: teenagers who are training to be Christian missionaries. On Tuesday the network is expected to announce a collaboration with two Oscar-nominated filmmakers for a one-hour report titled “The Lord’s Boot Camp.” Heidi Ewing and Rachel Grady, the producers of the acclaimed 2006 documentary “Jesus Camp,” gained access to an evangelical camp in Florida last year and followed three teenage girls. The resulting report will be shown on Saturday at 8 p.m., Eastern and Pacific times, on CBS. Susan Zirinsky, the executive producer of “48 Hours,” said she hoped the project would open the door to future collaborations with filmmakers. “We love the crime genre, but this is another interesting way to expand our base,” she said.

summary: CBS’s coverage of the men’s college basketball championship led the network to a ratings victory on Monday, while “Dancing With the Stars” buoyed ABC in second place. Nielsen’s overnight estimates suggested that CBS’s live broadcast attracted slightly fewer viewers than the championship game a year ago, which drew 19.6 million. Even so, the basketball game, which followed repeats of CBS’s “Big Bang Theory” at 8 p.m. (10.2 million) and “Two and a Half Men” at 8:30 (12.2 million), still dominated its time-slot competitors. ABC earned its highest ratings early in the night thanks to “Dancing With the Stars,” which averaged 19.5 million viewers from 8 to 9:30. The rest of ABC’s lineup, “Samantha Who?” at 9:30 (11 million) and “The Bachelor” at 10 (7.2 million), struggled to attract comparable ratings. NBC ranked third over all, drawing its largest audience for “Medium” at 10 o’clock since May 2006 (10.7 million). Fox finished fourth for the night.

NBC and Fox finished in a virtual tie for third, although Fox fared better in the 18-to-49 age group, as new episodes of “The Simpsons” at 8 (6.9 million) and “King of the Hill” at 8:30 (6 million) drew particularly strong ratings in that demographic.

headline: About Last Night...
summary: RALEIGH, N.C. - Senator Barack Obama delivered a mocking critique of Wednesday night's Democratic presidential debate, telling an audience here that the 90-minute session with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton exemplified the problems with Washington by not focusing on issues that truly matter to the American people."They like stirring up controversy and they like playing gotcha games, getting us to attack each other. And I have to say Senator Clinton looked in her element," Mr. Obama said. "She was taking every opportunity to get a dig in there. You know, that's all right. That's her right. That's her right to kind of twist the knife a little bit."

headline: The Costs of Solving the Air-Traffic Mess
summary: Last week in this space, I offered an excerpt from my CBS News interview with Robert Sturgell, head of the Federal Aviation Administration, about the new ADS-B air-traffic control system that the agency will install by 2020, at a cost of $20 billion. It's a GPS-based system that would replace or supplement our 50-year-old, hopelessly overstressed radar system. It's the core of an even larger air-traffic overhaul nicknamed NextGen.

headline: Long Looks at the Pope, but a Glimpse of the Man

headline: The Costs of Solving the Air-Traffic Mess

headline: CBS Survives
summary: CBS earned the most viewers on Thursday, thanks partly to “Survivor,” the most-watched show of the night, with 12.1 million viewers at 8, Nielsen estimated. Afterward, repeats of “CSI” at 9 (10.7 million) and “Without a Trace” at 10 (9.1 million) extended CBS’s lead. Among adults 18 to 49, CBS was runner-up to NBC, which took that demographic from 9 to 11 with “The Office,” followed by “Scrubs” and “ER.” "The Office" was the night’s top-rated show among those 18 to 49. Fox ranked third in that age group and second in total viewers, with “Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader?” at 8 (9.2 million) and “Don’t Forget the Lyrics” at 9 (9.5 million). ABC was fourth over all.

headline: Moonves Schmoozes
summary: Leslie Moonves, below, the chairman of CBS, and Sean McManus, the president of CBS News, made a surprise visit to the regular noon meeting at CBS News headquarters on Friday and delivered pep talks to the news division, which has endured a week of reports of uncertainty about the future of Katie Couric, the anchor of the network’s nightly news. “The genesis was, both were getting frustrated with everything being written about CBS News,” said one executive who attended the meeting and asked not to be named because the meeting was intended to be off the record. Mr. Moonves was “very forceful,” the executive said, quoting him as saying that he “could not be happier with the content of CBS News and with the ‘Evening News’ anchor” and that Ms. Couric would be the anchor “today, tomorrow and in the future,” while acknowledging that the ratings for the evening newscast were “very frustrating.” CBS executives held a meeting in February to discuss possible changes in Ms. Couric’s role, but the executive who was at the meeting said no decisions would be made until after the presidential election. Ms. Couric also addressed the meeting and thanked the staff for working hard despite the rumors, specifically thanking the London bureau for setting up an exclusive interview with the prime minister of Britain, Gordon Brown. Mr. Manus was also “looking to buck people up,” the executive said, and emphasized that there was no better news division than CBS’s.

headline: Sunday Ratings: Ten Million For 'Oprah's Big Give' Finale

The reality charity competition has seen its ratings decline steadily after drawing 15.7 million viewers in its debut on March 2. Still, the finale managed to dominate its 8 p.m. time slot ahead of CBS's "Big Brother" (6.8 million) and NBC's "Monk" (5.7 million).

headline: N.F.L. Draft: Second Round
summary: 1/32. Miami: Phillip Merling, DE, ClemsonI'm surprised Merling fell this far, but that's a boon for the Dolphins, who passed on a defensive lineman with the first pick and still got a good one.2/33. St. Louis: Donnie Avery, WR, HoustonThe first wide receiver selected in the draft is not the one many expected it to be.3/34. AtlantaWashington: WR Devin ThomasThis was the receiver many expected to go first, even in the top-15. But Washington has a big target now to go with their scrappers.4/35. Kansas City: Brandon Flowers, DB, Virginia Tech5/36 Jets Green Bay: Jordy Nelson, WR, Kansas State6/37. Atlanta: Curtis Lofton, LB, Oklahoma7/38. Baltimore Seattle: John Carlson, TE, Notre DameNow the Seahawks trade up for a tight end, a position they were expected to fill in the first round. The Ravens receive the No. 55 and No. 86 pick in return.8/39. San Francisco: Chilo Rachal, G, Southern California9/40. New Orleans: Tracy Porter, CB, Indiana10/41. Buffalo: James Hardy, WR, Indiana11/42. Denver: Eddie Royal, WR, Virginia Tech12/43. CarolinaPhiladelphiaMinnesota: Tyrell Johnson, S, Arkansas StateThe Eagles fans here just want a pick to react to, but Andy Reid won't give them one. The Eagles fans will have to be a bit more patient. Barring another deal, Philadelphia will have two picks in the quick succession in, oh about, 21 minutes. The Eagles also gained an additional fourth-round pick (No. 117) in the deal, while giving up a fifth-rounder (No. 152). Philadelphia now has three fourth-round selections.13/44. Chicago: Matt Forte, RB, Tulane14/45. Detroit: Jordan Dizon, LB, Colorado15/46. Cincinnati: Jerome Simpson, WR, Coastal Carolina16/47. MinnesotaPhiladelphia: Trevor Laws, DT, Notre Dame.Eagles fans, prepping for their first pick of the draft, were dancing to Barry White's "Can't Get Enough of Your Love."17/48. AtlantaWashington: Fred Davis, TE, Southern California18/49. Philadelphia: DeSean Jackson, WR, CaliforniaMinutes before the selection was announced, Jackson was seen on the big TV screens here receiving a phone call and celebrating, which caused a celebration among the Eagles fans. An electrifying player whose draft stock was hurt by his size, Jackson will probably play a significant role in the return game. As one excited Eagles fan told me after the draft, "Goodbye, Reno Mahe."19/50. Arizona: Calais Campbell, DE, Miami (Fla.)20/51. Washington: Malcolm Kelly, WR, OklahomaWe are starting to see teams drafting highly-regarded players whose stock dropped after the combine and pro days. Campbell is one, and Kelly, coming out of college, was considered one of the top receivers available, but injuries and perceived attitude problems hurt him. But Washington may have gotten a steal, particularly when paired with its earlier pick of Devin Thomas.21/52. Tampa BayJacksonville: Quentin Groves, DE, AuburnThe Jaguars also send a fifth-round pick (No. 158) this year and a seventh-round pick next year to Tampa Bay to move up six spots.22/53. Pittsburgh: Limas Sweed, WR, TexasThis seems like another steal.23/54. Tennessee: Jason Jones, DE, Eastern Michigan24/55. Seattle Baltimore: Ray Rice, RB, Rutgers25/56. Green Bay: Brian Brohm, QB, LouisvilleThis pick got a mini-ovation from a row of Packers fans in the first mezzanine. Now that the Aaron Rodgers era has begun, Rodgers was going to need a backup. Or maybe it's competition?26/57. Miami: Chad Henne, QB, MichiganAnd here come the quarterbacks. This year's class is not deep, but it is a bit surprising that we have gone 57 picks and only four quarterbacks have been taken.27/58. JacksonvilleTampa Bay: Dexter Jackson, WR, Appalachian StateThe Buccaneers, after trading down for this pick, used up all of their seven minutes, the first team to see the clock go down to 0:00 so far in this "streamlined" draft, as the N.F.L. likes to call it. And they used all the time for a player they already had. Oh, different Dexter Jackson. That Jackson, a safety now with the Bengals, was the Super Bowl MVP for Tampa Bay in 2003.28/59. Indianapolis: Michael Pollak, OG, Arizona StateThis was the Colts' only first-day pick, but the last offensive lineman on a day for the trenches, which was expected. Ten offensive lineman and 11 defensive linemen were selected. Eight tackles were taken in the first round, a record.29/60. Green Bay: Patrick Lee, DB, Auburn30/61. Dallas: Martellus Bennett, TE, Texas A&M31/62. New England: Terrence Wheatley, CB, Colorado32/63. Giants: Terrell Thomas, CB, Southern CaliforniaAgain, not surprising considering the depth at the position, 10 cornerbacks were taken in a truly streamlined draft. The first two rounds took less than six hours, less time than it took to complete the first round last year.

headline: ABC Dominates Prime Time
summary: ABC proved unbeatable in the ratings on Sunday, as new installments of “Desperate Housewives,” right, with Eva Longoria, “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition” and “Brothers & Sisters” led all four hours of prime time. Nielsen reported that “Desperate Housewives” earned the largest audience over all, drawing 16.2 million viewers during the 9 p.m. hour. Preceding it a two-hour edition of “Extreme Makeover” delivered 9.6 million viewers from 7 to 9, while at 10 “Brothers & Sisters” attracted 11.6 million, easily outpacing a “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” repeat on NBC and “Dexter” on CBS, both of which averaged 6.5 million viewers. CBS finished second for the night, drawing 6.7 million viewers at 8 p.m. for “Big Brother 9.” CBS fared better both before and after the reality show’s finale, earning 9.7 million viewers for “60 Minutes” at 7 p.m. and 11.5 million for “Cold Case” at 9. Meanwhile Fox, led by “Family Guy” at 9 (8.5 million) and “The Simpsons” at 8 (7.7 million), finished third in total viewers but second among adults 18 to 49, well ahead of CBS. NBC was fourth for the night.

headline: CBS Newscast Rating Drops Even More
summary: The downward trend for the CBS News anchor Katie Couric continued last week as the network’s evening newscast dipped again in the ratings. One week after setting a record low, with about 5.39 million viewers, the newscast attracted about 50,000 fewer people, averaging about 5.34 million. The number is the lowest total for the “CBS Evening News” since Nielsen research introduced its new rating system in 1987. The broadcast was far more popular before that date. Ms. Couric’s ratings have been sliding since reports that she and the top management of CBS have held discussions about her future at the network, although network executives, including the chairman, Leslie Moonves, have expressed faith in her and the program. The race at the top of the newscast competition was closer than the prior week as NBC’s program beat ABC’s by about 227,000 viewers. A week earlier the gap was about 700,000 viewers as ABC faced possible negative fallout from widespread criticism of its presentation of the Democratic presidential debate in Pennsylvania. For the week NBC averaged about 8.01 million viewers, with ABC at about 7.79 million.

headline: ‘House’ Buoys Fox
summary: After a 12-week absence from Fox’s schedule, “House” returned with a new episode, lifting the network to first place in the important demographic of adults 18 to 49. Nielsen estimated that the medical drama led the night in that age group while drawing 14.5 million total viewers during the 9 p.m. hour. Fox finished first in the 18-to-49 set despite drawing more modest ratings at 8 p.m. with “Bones” (9.7 million). Fox did trail ABC in total viewers for the night, as ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” remained the night’s most-watched show with 17.9 million viewers from 8 to 9:30 p.m. CBS ranked third in total viewers behind both ABC and Fox, but second in the 18-to-49 set ahead of ABC, earning solid ratings from its comedy lineup. CBS also won the 10 p.m. hour with “CSI: Miami” (13.6 million), which outperformed both ABC’s “Bachelor” (7.8 million) and NBC’s “Medium” (9.6 million). NBC was fourth over all.

headline: Tuesday Night Was All About Fox

According to Nielsen's estimates, 24.4 million viewers tuned in to watch the five remaining "Idol" contestants square off at 8 p.m. Following it, Fox's "Hell's Kitchen" delivered 12.3 million viewers, the largest audience ever in the series' three-year history.

headline: Pizza and Pop Lift Fox
summary: Pizza night on “Hell’s Kitchen” and the start of Neil Diamond week on “American Idol” lifted Fox to No. 1 in the ratings on Tuesday. Nielsen estimated that 24.4 million viewers tuned in to watch the five remaining “Idol” contestants square off at 8 p.m. After “Idol,” Fox’s “Hell’s Kitchen” delivered 12.3 million viewers, the largest audience ever in the series’ three-year history. The cooking competition led the 9 p.m. time slot among adults 18 to 49, but trailed ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” in total viewers in the hour (16.7 million). Despite its edge at 9, ABC ranked third over all, struggling early in the night with two episodes of “According to Jim,” each averaging around 4 million viewers. CBS won second place, thanks to “NCIS” at 8 (14.6 million) and “Shark” at 9 (10.3 million). NBC was fourth for the night, despite leading the 10 p.m. hour with “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” (12.1 million), which easily outpaced both ABC’s “Women’s Murder Club” on ABC (8.1 million) and a rerun of “CSI” on CBS (7.6 million).

headline: CNet: CBS Gives Us Air Cover
summary: You often hear about the costs of being a public company: investor relations, regulatory compliance and so on. But few companies have been hurt by their public status as much as CNet. At a time when the Internet ad market was growing and changing rapidly, CNet has had to confront investigations into its option granting practices and a group of dissident shareholders (who raised some good questions about the company's efficiency).

headline: Kitchen Spices Tuesday
summary: Fox’s “Hell’s Kitchen” drew its best ratings ever on Tuesday as 12.4 million viewers tuned in to the competitive cooking show at 9 p.m., Nielsen estimated. The series attracted the night’s second highest ratings among adults 18 to 49, trailing only Fox’s “American Idol,” which dominated the 8 p.m. hour with 24 million viewers. Fox easily led the night over all, while CBS took second place thanks largely to “NCIS” at 8 (14.7 million). CBS remained solid the rest of the night with “Shark” at 9 (10.2 million) and a rerun of “Criminal Minds” at 10 (8.3 million). ABC was third. Despite outpacing “Hell’s Kitchen” during the 9 p.m. hour in total viewers with “Dancing With the Stars” (16.6 million), ABC struggled at 8 with two episodes of “According to Jim,” which together averaged 4.4 million viewers. At 10 ABC’s “Women’s Murder Club” garnered 8.5 million viewers, well short of the season finale of NBC’s “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” in the hour (11.3 million). NBC finished fourth for the night over all.

headline: Finales Boost CBS
summary: Finales of “CSI” and “Without a Trace” lifted CBS into first place in the ratings on Thursday. According to Nielsen’s estimates, “CSI” attracted 17.7 million viewers to CBS at 9 p.m., the night’s largest audience, while “Without a Trace” won the 10 p.m. hour with 14.5 million viewers. Despite CBS’s edge in total viewers, the network ranked third for the night among adults 18 to 49, just behind NBC, which got a boost from the season finales of “My Name Is Earl” at 8 (7.1 million), “The Office” at 9 (8.1 million) and “ER” at 10 (8.4 million). ABC, trailed by both networks in that demographic, broadcast the night’s top two shows among the 18-to-49 set, “Grey’s Anatomy” at 9 and “Lost” at 10, which delivered 15.2 million and 11.4 million total viewers respectively. Fox finished fourth overall.

headline: Housewives Future: Not as Good as Its Past
summary: ABC’s “Desperate Housewives” delivered Sunday’s top ratings, as the closing minutes of the show’s fourth season gave viewers a brief flash-forward five years into the future. According to Nielsen’s estimates, the two-hour finale attracted 16.8 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m., in line with its performance earlier this spring but down two million from its third-season finale a year ago. ABC led the night’s ratings over all. The finale of “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition,” from 7 to 9 p.m., attracted a modest 9.4 million viewers, although the show’s second hour averaged 3.5 million more viewers than its first. CBS was runner-up for the night thanks to “60 Minutes” at 7 (10.7 million), followed by the Academy of Country Music Awards, which drew 11.7 million viewers from 8 to 11 p.m., an increase of 2.4 million from a year ago. Fox finished third over all, with season finales of “The Simpsons” at 8 (6.1 million), “King of the Hill” at 8:30 (5.4 million) and “American Dad” at 9:30 (5.6 million). NBC was fourth.

headline: ABC's Dancers Draw Eyes
summary: ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” attracted Monday’s largest audience as 18.8 million viewers tuned in for the show’s final performances of the season at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. The reality competition led its time slot but failed to lift ABC to No. 1 for the night overall as the network’s premiere of “The Bachelorette” struggled from 9 to 11 p.m., averaging 8.8 million viewers. CBS eked out a victory as the night’s most watched network thanks to solid ratings for finales of its comedy lineup from 8 to 10 p.m. CBS’s “CSI: Miami” also led the 10 p.m. hour with 16.1 million viewers. Fox, meanwhile, despite a third-place finish in total viewers, ranked second among adults 18 to 49 behind CBS but ahead of ABC, earning the night’s top ratings in that demographic with the finale of “House” at 9 p.m. (16.2 million). NBC finished a distant fourth over all, drawing just 4 million viewers for “American Gladiators” from 8 to 9:30.

headline: New Multi-Year Deal for Bob Schieffer
