headline: Bob Schieffer Makes a Golden Years Deal
summary: Bob Schieffer has reached agreement with CBS News on a new contract that will probably keep him hosting “Face the Nation” for “several more years.” The deal does not specify how long he will host the Sunday morning public affairs show, Mr. Schieffer, 71, said on Monday. But when his tenure on the program does eventually end, said Mr. Schieffer, above, the new contract ensures that he will stay on at CBS News to provide on-camera analysis, including on election nights. “That’s kind of the way Tom Brokaw works at NBC,” Mr. Schieffer said. “Tom’s kind of my model for how to live out the golden years.” Mr. Schieffer said in January that he planned to leave “Face the Nation” soon after the inauguration of the next president, but he later said he had decided to postpone his retirement at the request of CBS News executives. The network has been unable to identify a successor to Mr. Schieffer, at least one who was available. The Washington Post reported on Monday that Mr. Schieffer and CBS had reached a long-term agreement.

headline: 'Are You Excited? Do You Care?'
summary: Aired Wednesday night on CBS: Folks from all over the country are visiting here tonight. Good to have you with us. A lot of out-of-towners? That took a little too long, didn't it? Listen to this: in New York City -- and maybe they do this in your home town, I doubt it -- there's a restaurant downtown in the financial district, down on Wall Street, and I don't know the name of it and I don't even care. But you can go in there and you can order yourself a hamburger. Oh, that's nice, you're saying, "A hamburger -- jeez, I'd like a hamburger." Who doesn't like a hamburger? I'm not done here. How much do you pay for a hamburger? One hundred seventy-five dollars -- now, that seems to me like an incredible waste, especially when you can get a really good steak in New York City for only $250.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD

headline: 'Anatomy' Is Down but Still on Top
summary: The two-hour season finale of “Grey’s Anatomy” vaulted ABC to No. 1 in the ratings on Thursday, attracting 17.8 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. Although the number of viewers for the show’s fourth-season conclusion declined by nearly 5 million from a year ago (22.6 million), it still led the night by a wide margin over its nearest competitor, NBC’s “Deal or No Deal,” which garnered 10.3 million viewers from 8 to 9:30 p.m. NBC finished third for the night, earning mediocre results from 9:30 to 11 with the start of the sixth edition of “Last Comic Standing” (5.9 million). Fox ranked second over all, thanks to the fourth-season premiere of “So You Think You Can Dance,” which averaged 8.6 million viewers from 8 to 10. Despite its modest number of total viewers, the Fox dancing contest fared particularly well among adults 18 to 49, winning the 8 o’clock hour in that demographic, ahead of ABC’s finale of “Ugly Betty,” which drew 8.8 million total viewers. CBS finished fourth with a lineup of all repeats.

headline: For Bear, Fear in the Market Was Fatal
Nascar Wins Ratings
summary: Ratings were low all around for prime-time television over the Memorial Day holiday, as repeats on CBS ranked first on Monday, and Nascar coverage lifted Fox to No. 1 on Sunday. Opposite mostly low-rated repeats, Fox’s live broadcast of the annual Nascar All-Star race drew an average of more than seven million viewers from 7 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. One day later, on Monday, only reruns of CBS’s regular Monday lineup managed to earn more viewers. Led by “Two and a Half Men” at 9, the night’s most watched show with 10.7 million viewers, CBS easily outdrew its Monday competitors, ABC, NBC and Fox, which finished in a virtual tie for runner-up. ABC was closest, attracting 5.5 million viewers for “The Bachelorette” from 9 to 11. Meanwhile, NBC’s “American Gladiators” delivered 5.2 million viewers from 8 to 9:30, followed by a 90-minute edition of “Dateline,” which also earned 5.2 million viewers. Fox broadcast an encore of its two-hour “So You Think You Can Dance” premiere from 8 to 10 (4.9 million).

headline: Even Without 'Idol,' Fox Leads the Ratings

Although CBS's "NCIS" repeat earned slightly more total viewers at 8 p.m. (9.7 million), the Fox reality series remained far and away the night's leader among adults 18 to 49.

headline: Fox Is King in the Kitchen
summary: “Hell’s Kitchen” lifted Fox to No. 1 in the ratings on Tuesday as 9.4 million viewers tuned in to that reality series cooking competition at 9 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. Although CBS’s “NCIS” repeat earned slightly more total viewers at 8 p.m. (9.7 million), “Hell’s Kitchen” remained far and away the night’s leader among adults 18 to 49. Meanwhile, Fox’s “Moment of Truth” delivered the second-highest results in that demographic, despite garnering a modest audience of 7.3 million viewers at 8 p.m. Ratings for that game show, in which contestants are questioned after being strapped to a polygraph machine, were down three million viewers, compared with the last time it appeared on Fox’s schedule eight weeks ago (although the show had preceded “American Idol” then). CBS ranked second for the night in total viewers with a rerun of “The Unit” at 9 (6 million) and a “48 Hours” special at 10 (8.3 million). Among adults 18 to 49, CBS finished third behind Fox and NBC, which got a boost from repeats of “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” at 9 (7.1 million) and at 10 (7.3 million). ABC was fourth over all.

summary: Adam Sandler’s production company, Happy Madison, is branching into thrillers with a new division called Scary Madison, according to The Hollywood Reporter. The division’s first picture is “Shortcut,” about two brothers who find a neglected — and presumably frightening — route in their town. Not counting Happy Madison’s latest movie, “You Don’t Mess With the Zohan,” which stars Mr. Sandler and opened on Friday, the company has produced 18 films that have grossed more than $1.1 billion in ticket sales, according to Baseline, an entertainment database. ... Columbia Pictures and CBS Films will make a new version of “My Fair Lady,” the classic Lerner and Loewe musical, the companies announced on Friday. It will be produced by Duncan Kenworthy (“Four Weddings and a Funeral”) and Cameron Mackintosh (“Cats,” “Les Misérables”), who said in a statement that they would use the songs from the original Broadway show and shoot part of the film on location in London. Variety reported that the studios were in discussions with Keira Knightley to play Eliza Doolittle, but a Columbia spokesman declined to comment on casting.

headline: CBS Swings on Thursday
summary: The debut of the CBS drama “Swingtown” attracted moderate interest on Thursday, delivering an audience of 8.6 million viewers at 10 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. The new series, set among suburban libertines in the 1970s, has drawn scrutiny for its depictions of sex and drug use. Among adults 18 to 49, it was far from the night’s highest-rated show, but “Swingtown” did improve on CBS’s performance in that demographic earlier in the night. In the 8 and 9 p.m. time slots, the network broadcast two repeats of “CSI,” which, despite low ratings among the 18-to-49 set, fared well in total viewers, with 8.2 million and 9.4 million respectively. CBS ranked third for the night over all, just behind Fox and its two-hour installment of “So You Think You Can Dance” from 8 to 10 (9.1 million). ABC led over all with live coverage of the first game of the N.B.A. finals, which averaged approximately 10 million viewers from 9 to 11.

headline: Password Helps CBS
summary: A special Thursday edition of “Million Dollar Password” gave CBS a ratings lift as 9.4 million viewers tuned in at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen. That tally made it one of the night’s most-watched programs, even with CBS’s repeat of “CSI” at 9 (9.4 million) and ahead of the network’s “Swingtown” at 10 (7 million). CBS earned a second-place finish for the night, trailing only ABC and its live broadcast of Game Four of the N.B.A championship series between the Boston Celtics and the Los Angeles Lakers. On par with earlier games in the series, Thursday’s broadcast averaged 13.8 million viewers. Fox, in third place, edged past CBS for second place among adults 18 to 49, thanks to “So You Think You Can Dance” at 9 (8 million). NBC finished a distant fourth over all, broadcasting a repeat of “My Name Is Earl” at 8 (3.3 million) followed by “Last Comic Standing” from 8:30 to 10 (4.1 million).

headline: Cablevision Buys Sundance
summary: The future of the Sundance Channel is being defined this week after Cablevision closed a deal to acquire it. Rainbow Media Holdings, a subsidiary of Cablevision, said on Tuesday that it had completed the acquisition of Sundance from NBC Universal, CBS and Robert Redford for $496 million. On Wednesday, Rainbow executives are scheduled to meet Sundance employees in New York. Rainbow officials plan to announce a new structure for the channel that is meant to unify it with Rainbow’s other cable entities, including IFC, according to two people involved in the negotiations who spoke on condition of anonymity because the announcements had not been made. Sundance and IFC both showcase independent films, and some analysts have speculated that Cablevision may try to merge the two channels, although this week’s announcement is expected to keep the brands separate.

headline: Reruns Fuel TV Ratings
summary: Reruns ruled the ratings once again on Monday, as Fox and CBS finished first and second for the night over all. According to Nielsen’s estimates, repeats of CBS’s “Two and a Half Men” and Fox’s “House” led the night, with the half-hour CBS sitcom drawing 8.9 million viewers at 9 p.m. and the Fox medical drama averaging 8.6 million viewers over the 9 p.m. hour. Fox edged past CBS for first place by winning the 8 p.m. time slot with a rerun of “Bones” (7 million). CBS led the 10 p.m. hour with a repeat of “CSI: Miami” (8 million). ABC and NBC finished in a virtual tie for third place over all. ABC earned decent ratings for “The Bachelorette” at 9 (6.9 million), but trailed with a “Bachelorette” special at 8 (5.9 million) and especially with “The Mole” at 10 (3.9 million). NBC broadcast “American Gladiators” at 8 (5.1 million), followed by “Nashville Star” from 9 to 10:30 (6.1 million), with a short edition of “Dateline” afterward (4.7 million).

headline: '60 Minutes' Takes Its Brand Global

headline: Talent Draws a Crowd
summary: “America’s Got Talent” lifted NBC on Tuesday, as 12.8 million viewers tuned in from 9 to 11 p.m. for that talent show’s third-season premiere, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The show drew 13 million for its 2007 premiere, but faced new competition this time. The final game of the National Basketball Association’s championship series led the night’s ratings with estimates indicating that it earned an audience somewhere between Game 4 on Thursday (13.8 million) and Game 5 on Sunday (17.4 million). At 9 p.m. Fox’s “Hell’s Kitchen” drew a modest 8.2 million total viewers, but was runner-up to basketball for the night’s highest ratings among adults 18 to 49. For the night, Fox tied NBC for second place in that demographic. CBS finished fourth over all with a three-hour special, “AFI’s 10 Top 10” (5.5 million).

Also at 10, NBC’s “Fear Itself” drew only 4.7 million viewers, as did NBC’s 90-minute episode of “Last Comic Standing,” from 8:30 to 10. NBC finished in third place over all. headline: The Olympics Compete
summary: NBC’s coverage of the United States Olympic Trials gave the network a boost in the ratings on Sunday, making it No. 1 for the night among adults 18 to 49. But that was not enough to pull NBC ahead among total viewers. According to Nielsen’s estimates, the women’s gymnastics contenders put NBC in the lead in the 18-to-49 demographic during the 7 and 8 p.m. hours despite averaging only a modest total audience of 6.2 million. That tally fell short of CBS’s programming in those time slots: “60 Minutes” (8.9 million) followed by “Million Dollar Password” (8.3 million), helped CBS edge past NBC for the night in total viewers. NBC’s “Dateline” ranked first during the 9 and 10 p.m. time slots with 8.2 million viewers, outpacing CBS’s repeats of “Criminal Minds” (7.3 million) and “The Unit” (6.9 million). ABC finished third for the night with a lineup of all repeats. Fox was fourth, although it fared particularly well with the 18-to-49 set. Fox’s “Family Guy” rerun at 9 earned the night’s highest ratings in that age group but just 5.5 million total viewers.

headline: Fox Tops Slow Night
summary: Fox ranked No. 1 in the ratings on a slow summer Thursday of network television, as “So You Think You Can Dance” led the night over all with 8.6 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The 9 p.m. dance competition followed Fox’s 8 p.m. game show, “Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader?” (6.9 million), which edged past CBS’s rerun of “Million Dollar Password” (6.8 million) to win its time slot. CBS finished second for the night, attracting 7.2 million viewers at 9 for a “CSI” repeat and 5.7 million for “Swingtown” at 10. NBC was third, with “Last Comic Standing” from 8 to 10 (5.3 million) followed by “Fear Itself” (4.5 million). ABC earned a fourth-place finish with reruns of “Ugly Betty” at 8 (3.5 million) and “Grey’s Anatomy” at 9 (3.4 million). At 10, the first part of “Hopkins,” ABC’s six-part documentary filmed inside the Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, led its time slot by a slim margin with 5.8 million viewers.

headline: News Ratings at a Low
summary: “World News,” the evening newscast on ABC, received its lowest measured ratings last week, according to Nielsen Media Research. The newscast, anchored by Charles Gibson, averaged 6.9 million viewers for the week of June 30, ranking second to “NBC Nightly News,” which attracted 7.4 million. The third-place “CBS Evening News” averaged 5.6 million. The audience was ABC’s lowest since Nielsen introduced its people meter ratings system in 1987. The record is largely symbolic, as it occurred in a traditionally low-rated week leading up to the holiday. (July 4 was excluded from the averages of the three newscasts.) But it underscored the declines that evening newscasts are experiencing more broadly. Three times this year, the CBS newscast set new lows in ratings among total viewers. For the last two weeks, “World News” has set new lows in the 25- to 54-year-old demographic that advertisers covet.

headline: ABC Takes Monday
summary: The fourth season finale of “The Bachelorette” helped lift ABC to No. 1 for the night over all on Monday. According to Nielsen’s estimates, the two-hour conclusion of the reality dating series, a spin-off of “The Bachelor,” attracted 9.5 million viewers, leading during both the 8 and 9 p.m. time slots. A “Bachelorette” special, “After the Final Rose,” won the 10 p.m. hour with 10 million viewers. Fox and CBS tied for second place on the night. Fox broadcast repeats of “Bones” at 8 (6.5 million) and “House” at 9 (7.9 million), while CBS earned solid ratings from reruns of its comedy lineup followed by “CSI: Miami” at 10 (8.4 million). NBC was fourth with “American Gladiators” at 8 and “Nashville Star” at 9, both of which drew 5.3 million viewers, fewer than NBC’s “Dateline” at 10 (6 million).

headline: Last Words: Economic Game-Changer

This is an effort to grasp onto the meaningful. And sometimes, to offer up what's available for laughs along the way. We're calling this feature "Last Words," but by no means will it be the last word of the day or night. We'll note what's catching our fancy, and feel free to suggest what's caught your eye.

headline: The Early Word: Palin's Day at the U.N.

headline: NYT/CBS News Poll: Going Negative
summary: Months of aggressive campaigning by both candidates have significantly altered the way voters perceive them - Senator John McCain is largely seen as someone who is spending more of his time attacking his opponent than spelling out what he would do as president, while Senator Barack Obamacontinues to be seen as a candidate who is spending more of his time explaining what he would do as president rather than attacking his opponent, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. This was not the case earlier this summer. In early July, both candidates were thought to berunning positive campaigns.In the latest poll, a majority of voters, 56 percent, said Mr. Obama is spending his time making it clear what he would do if elected, rather than attacking the Republican candidate. Most voters say the opposite of Mr. McCain. Only 38 percent of those polled said Mr. McCain was explaining what he would do as president, while 53 percent said he was attacking Mr. Obama. In July, 63 percent of the voters surveyed said Mr. McCain was running a positive campaign.

headline: ‘Dancing’ Steps High
summary: “Dancing With the Stars” helped ABC remain No. 1 in the ratings on Monday, as an average of 18.6 million viewers tuned in, according to Nielsen’s estimates. CBS, at second place in total viewers, led the night in the demographic of adults 18 to 49 thanks in large part to the sitcom “Two and a Half Men,” the night’s top-rated show in that age group; it drew 14.6 million total viewers, improving on the network’s audience for its comedies “The Big Bang Theory” (10 million) and “How I Met Your Mother” (9.7 million). NBC ranked third for the night, lagging behind with “Chuck” (6.2 million) and “Heroes” (7.8 million). Fox was fourth with “Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles” (5.2 million) and “Prison Break” (5.4 million).

headline: Weekly Matchups: The Quiet Before the Chaos?
summary: This is like that moment in the horror movie where things get quiet as you catch your breath following a terrifying series of events. Clearly, there are no blockbuster match-ups this weekend, (although some ranked teams do play on the road) and two undefeated teams sit atop the rankings. Things seem to be tied up in a neat little package, right? But things are a little too quiet. And, just like watching that horror movie, it should makes you nervous. Something is lurking in the shadows. We are still not sure what it is, but something is out there. It might not happen this weekend, but do you really think Texas Tech and Alabama will be playing for the national title in January? I did not think so.

headline: New Wrinkle in Wardrobe Malfunction Case
summary: It’s the wardrobe malfunction that won’t die: four months after a federal court ruled that CBS was not liable for a 2004 incident in which Janet Jackson’s breast was partly uncovered during a televised Super Bowl halftime performance, the United States government has appealed that decision to the Supreme Court, Agence France-Presse reported. In its appeal, lawyers for the government asked the Supreme Court to reinstate a fine of $550,000 levied against CBS by the Federal Communications Commission for what the government called “the most widely viewed broadcast public nudity in television history.” In a statement, CBS said it hoped the Supreme Court “will recognize there are rare instances, particularly during live programming, when it may not be possible to block unfortunate fleeting material, despite best efforts.”

headline: Feeling Like Dancing
summary: ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” continued to dominate the ratings on Monday, earning an average audience of 21.3 million, according to Nielsen’s estimates. No other show on the night came close, a fact that lifted ABC to first place overall. CBS was runner-up, finishing No. 1 among adults 18 to 49, delivering the night’s top ratings in that age group with “Two and a Half Men” (which drew 14.9 million total viewers). CBS’s other comedies also fared well: “The Big Bang Theory” with 10.2 million, and “How I Met Your Mother” with 10 million. CBS’s “CSI: Miami,” at 14.1 million viewers, finished ahead of ABC’s “Boston Legal” (8.7 million) and NBC’s “My Own Worst Enemy” (4.2 million). NBC was third overall with “Chuck” (6.6 million) and “Heroes” (7.8 million).

headline: Footnotes
summary: William Petersen, above left, the star of the CBS series “C.S.I.: Crime Scene Investigation,” has solved the mystery of his next job: he has joined the ensemble of the Steppenwolf Theater Company in Chicago, the company announced. Mr. Petersen, who currently appears in Steppenwolf’s production of “Dublin Carol,” will become the 42nd member of the group. He previously announced that he would step away from a full-time role on “C.S.I.” after this season but would continue to appear as a guest star and serve as an executive producer. ... Britney Spears, above right, has announced her first concerts in five years, The Associated Press reported. Her tour, to promote her new album, “Circus,” is to begin on March 3 in New Orleans and visit 27 cities en route to its final show on April 28 in Chicago. ... The Soho Rep Theater has announced its next production, following its extended run of Sarah Kane’s graphically violent (though popular) play “Blasted.” On Jan. 15, the theater will begin previews of “Sixty Miles to Silver Lake,” a new play written by Dan LeFranc and directed by Anne Kauffman. Co-produced by Page 73, the play stars Joseph Adams and Dane DeHaan as a father and son on a memorable drive. It is scheduled to open on Jan. 22 and to end a limited run on Feb. 8.

headline: ‘Fantasticks’ Star is ‘Amazing Race’ Winner

Mr. Spangler shared the prize with his sister, Starr, a former Dallas Cowboys cheerleader, after the siblings won a worldwide race that brought them to Cambodia, India, Kazakhstan and Russia. Replying to questions sent via e-mail, Mr. Spangler said that the prize money would help him continue to pursue a career in which “the salary is not exactly illustrious. “I’ve truly had to learn how far I can stretch a dollar to pay my absurd New York rent and eat absurdly priced New York food,” Mr. Spangler wrote. He is scheduled to make his first post-victory performance in “The Fantasticks” at the Snapple Theater Center on Wednesday afternoon.

headline: Warner Brothers Sues CBS Over ‘Two and a Half Men’
summary: Like a pair of squabbling mismatched brothers forced to live together, Warner Brothers Television and CBS now find themselves feuding over the hit sitcom “Two and a Half Men.” On Tuesday, Warner Brothers, the studio that produces the show, filed a $49 million breach-of-contract suit against CBS, which broadcasts it, The Hollywood Reporter said. In the suit, Warner Brothers said that the network had refused to pay additional fees the studio said it was owed if the show achieved certain ratings numbers in its fourth season, which aired from 2006 to 2007. That season, “Two and a Half Men” was ranked 19th in the ratings; in its current season it is frequently a Top 10 show, and often the only sitcom to reach such heights.

headline: Extra! Extra! (An Addendum on Page 1 Ads)

The reasoning goes something like this: There is a strong likelihood that almost any feature or phenomenon has been known before, in relatively similar form. And if anyone is aware of that, it will be the knowledgeable Times reader, a discerning creature only too happy to deflate our incorrect use of a superlative and compel us to publish a correction.

headline: Hefty Returns for Biggest Loser
summary: NBC won big in the ratings with “The Biggest Loser” on Tuesday. According to Nielsen’s estimates, the seventh-edition premiere of the reality weight-loss competition drew Tuesday’s highest ratings among viewers 18 to 49 and a series record 11.8 million total viewers. CBS earned the night’s largest audiences with “NCIS” (19.1 million), “The Mentalist” (19.6 million), and “Without a Trace” (13.2 million). ABC was third, attracting 7.8 million viewers for the premiere of “Homeland Security USA” and 7 million for “Primetime: What Would You Do?” In between, ABC broadcast two new episodes of “Scrubs” at 9 (6.8 million) and 9:30 (6.6 million), which delivered ratings in line with its previous average on NBC last season. Fox finished fourth with repeats, although the network dominated Monday night’s ratings with live coverage of Texas’ victory over Ohio State in the Fiesta Bowl, which averaged 17.1 million viewers.

headline: CBS Trumps the Globes
summary: NBC’s broadcast of the Golden Globes ceremony attracted 14.6 million viewers during prime time on Sunday, according to Nielsen’s estimates, lifting the network to second place in the night’s ratings. Although the broadcast was down more than 5 million viewers from two years ago (20 million), it was up considerably over last year’s show (6.2 million), when a news conference substituted for the regular awards ceremony because of the writers’ strike. CBS led Sunday’s ratings, averaging nearly 30 million viewers during the 7 p.m. hour with postseason football coverage. CBS’s “60 Minutes” followed at 8 (15.7 million), but the network gradually lost viewers as the night went on with “Cold Case” at 9 (12.4 million) and “The Unit” at 10 (10.4 million). ABC finished third, attracting 13.8 million viewers at 9 for “Desperate Housewives,” well below average for the series. At 8 ABC drew 10.3 million for “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition,” and at 10 “Brothers & Sisters” garnered 9.1 million. Fox ranked fourth over all as the two-hour seventh-season premiere of “24” delivered 12.5 million viewers from 8 to 10, well short of the 15.8 million who tuned in to the show’s last season debut, in 2007.

NBC’s “Saturday Night Live Presidential Bash 2008,” a comedic tribute to chief executives past and present, attracted a meager audience of just 4.9 million viewers on Sunday. Over all the network ranked third for the night, faring little better early in the evening with a “Dateline” special (5.8 million). ABC finished in second place with its regular lineup of “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition” (8.6 million), “Desperate Housewives” (13 million) and “Brothers & Sisters” (8.9 million). headline: When Two and a Half Is More Than 24
summary: Jack Bauer may leave international terrorists quaking in their boots, but he’s still no match for the combined might of Charlie Sheen and Jon Cryer. The CBS comedy “Two and a Half Men” handily won its Monday-night showdown with the Fox action series “24,” although Fox averaged the most viewers for the night over all, according to Nielsen’s estimates. At 9 p.m., “Two and a Half Men” was the evening’s most-watched show with 16 million viewers, topping the first half-hour of “24”; “24” averaged 12 million viewers for the night, enough to put it well ahead of NBC’s hourlong “Superstars of Dance” (6.8 million) and the CBS sitcom “Worst Week,” which drew 9.5 million viewers at 9:30. A two-hour episode of “The Bachelor” on ABC averaged 9.3 million viewers from 8 to 9, and 10.6 million from 9 to 10. Earlier on Fox, a new episode of the medical drama “House” (14.8 million) performed strongly at 8 p.m., while CBS’s “CSI: Miami” (14.5 million) won the 10 p.m. hour.

headline: Networks, Producers Settle Reality-Show Suits
summary: A consortium of television networks and production companies will pay more than $4 million to settle two class-action lawsuits filed by several hundred reality-show employees who said they had been subjected to unlawful working conditions, The Hollywood Reporter said. The employees, including segment producers and story editors for shows like “The Bachelor” and “Trading Spouses” sued in 2005, saying that they were told by the networks and production companies to forge time cards and forgo meal breaks while working 18-hour days. The Writers Guild of America helped organize the employees who filed the suits as part of a larger effort to have story editors of reality series recognized as writers. A judge in Los Angeles gave preliminary approval to a $2.57 million settlement in a suit brought against Fox and the production company Rocket Science Laboratories, and a $1.54 million settlement in a suit against ABC, CBS and other production companies.

headline: U.S. Airways Pilot to Give First Interview
summary: CBS News announced on Friday that “60 Minutes’’ had secured the first interview with Captain Chesley B. Sullenberger III, the pilot who successfully landed his U.S. Airways jet on the Hudson River, along with his crew. But word of the interview, to be conducted by Katie Couric, set off immediate recriminations at her former employer, the “Today’’ program on NBC. That’s because Matt Lauer of “Today’’ had received assurances from the captain’s family and other representatives last weekend that he would have the first interview with Mr. Sullenberger, which was to have been conducted live, on Jan. 19. Soon after NBC began publicizing that appearance, it was abruptly canceled, at the request of the Airline Pilots Association, which had expressed concern about its bearing on the ongoing investigation into the emergency landing. Asked in an interview on Friday why the captain had since decided to pass over “Today’’ for “60 Minutes,’’ a Sullenberger family spokesman, Alex Clemens, said, “The five members of the crew spoke with each other and made a joint decision of how they would like to proceed.’’ In a statement, NBC said, “What Captain Sullenberger did in the cockpit on Flight 1549 was heroic and admirable. Unfortunately, people close to him have not acted nearly as admirably.’’

headline: White House Pushing Stimulus Package
summary: President Barack Obama and his top advisers sought over the weekend to broaden the appeal of his proposed $825 billion economic-stimulus package and to defend the way they are pushing it through Congress. But some senior Republicans said Sunday that as the stimulus plan stands, they would oppose it. The new administration has begun a campaign to build momentum behind the economic-stimulus plan and propel it to passage by mid-February. The White House released a report Saturday revealing details about the package, which would pay for a variety of projects, like laying 3,000 miles of transmission lines for a national electric grid, securing 90 major ports and guaranteeing health insurance for 8.5 million Americans in danger of losing coverage.

headline: 'A Brand-New Miss America'

headline: Ratings: 'House' and '24' Dominate
summary: Fox proved dominant in the ratings on Monday with the combination of "House" and "24," leading both the 8 and 9 p.m. time slots with 15.6 million and 12.1 million viewers, respectively, according to Nielsen's estimates.

headline: Pakistan an Early Test of Obama’s Approach
summary: President Obama is clearly in no rush to terminate some Bush administration policies. The not-so-covert attacks into Pakistani territory are a prime example.

headline: Ratings Calm Before Super Bowl Storm
summary: On a football-free weekend before the Super Bowl, CBS earned a No. 1 finish on Sunday as “60 Minutes” delivered prime-time’s largest audience.

headline: 'Oprah For Senate'
summary: Monologue | Aired Monday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: It's a great day for America, everybody, but it is a bad day for Illinois Governor Rod Blagojevich, whose impeachment began today. It turns out that Blagojevich said he had considered Oprah Winfrey for the Senate. That's ridiculous! Oprah's way too powerful to waste her time in the Senate, although she has enough money to buy the seat.

headline: Cash-Hungry Companies Turn to Leaseback Deals
summary: A few years ago, AT&T became an active player in the real estate market - not as a buyer but as a seller. The telecommunications giant sold its office towers in a number of cities, including Dallas, Cleveland and Chicago, but has continued to occupy and control these buildings.

headline: Ratings: Strong Night for 'Idol' and 'NCIS'
summary: CBS's "NCIS" attracted its third largest television audience ever on Tuesday, 19 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates, despite being broadcast opposite Fox's "American Idol" during the 8 p.m. time slot.

headline: A Big Monday for Fox
summary: Fox dominated the ratings on Monday with the combination of “House” and “24,” which led their time slots at 8 p.m. and 9 p.m. with 15.6 million and 12.1 million viewers, respectively, according to Nielsen’s estimates. ABC was the night’s runner-up with “The Bachelor” (10.6 million) and “True Beauty” (7 million). CBS ranked third with repeats of its comedy lineup followed by a rerun of “CSI: Miami,” which led the 10 p.m. hour with 9.2 million viewers. NBC finished in fourth place, earning 6.7 million viewers for the finale of “Superstars of Dance,” followed by the two-hour conclusion of its mini-series “The Last Templar” (8.3 million).

headline: Blagojevich Speaks at Impeachment Trial, in Wiretaps Only
summary: Recordings of Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich’s intercepted phone calls were played at his impeachment trial on Tuesday.

headline: 'Just One Complaint'
summary: Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on CBS: Cold outside right now. And I'm not a weatherman, but they say this frigid weather is coming off a cold front between New York Gov. David Paterson and Caroline Kennedy. That's causing a frost.

headline: 'That Media Tour'
summary: Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: It's a great day for Illinois Gov. Rod Blagojevich, who is continuing on that media tour he's doing. Yesterday, he was on "The View," the "Today" show, and "Good Morning America." Today, his hair was on "Animal Planet" and "Unsolved Mysteries."

headline: Ask the Coach: Pete Gillen
summary: Pete Gillen, the former coach of Xavier, Providence and Virginia and now an analyst for CBS College Sports, answered a few e-mail questions from The Quad for this week's installment of "Ask the Coach." You can catch some of Gillen's recent broadcast work in the video below, where he and his broadcast partner Carter Blackburn react to the ejection of Rice's mascot, Sammy the Owl. Do you have any questions that you want the coaches to answer in the coming weeks? Just let us know by dropping them in the comments section.

headline: 'He's a Crook'
summary: Monologue | Aired Wednesday night on CBS: You folks know about this Rod Blagojevich, the governor from Illinois? Well, they're trying to get him out of there because he's a crook. And he was having an impeachment trial, and he said, "You know what, you kids go and have your little impeachment trial. I'm going to New York City, and I'm going to be on every TV show." Did you see the guy on TV? He was everywhere. I mean, this guy, he looks like the guy that tells you need new brake pads, you know?

headline: Digital TV Beckons, but Many Miss the Call
summary: For viewers who still use set-top rabbit ears, the switch to digital television has often proven a bewildering and cumbersome burden.

headline: Ratings: 'CBS Evening News' in Prime Time Averages 6.5 Million Viewers
summary: Competing opposite the most watched show on television, Fox's "American Idol" at 8 p.m., a special edition of "The CBS Evening News With Katie Couric" in prime time struggled to attract many new viewers on Wednesday.

headline: Bonuses for Bad Performance
summary: Wall Street doled out $18.4 billion in bonuses for 2008. How does a compensation system allow for such pay in the midst of a financial industry collapse?

headline: ‘Idol’ Brings Back Fox
summary: CBS’s “NCIS” attracted its third-largest audience ever, 19 million viewers, on Tuesday night, despite competing with Fox’s “American Idol” at 8, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Although Fox easily led the night over all, garnering 25.2 million for “American Idol” and 12.1 million for “Fringe,” CBS finished a not-too-distant runner-up, winning the remainder of the night with a repeat of “The Mentalist” (15.1 million) followed by a new episode of “Without a Trace” (12.8 million). NBC was third in total viewers but got a boost from “The Biggest Loser,” which averaged 11 million total viewers from 8 to 10. At 10, NBC’s rerun of “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” (7.1 million) edged past “Primetime: What Would You Do?” (6.3 million) on ABC, which was fourth for the night.

headline: 'A Great Day For Gore'
summary: Monologue | Aired Wednesday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: It's a great day for Al Gore, who went to Washington today to make a speech about the dangers of global warming, which is a bit embarrassing because Washington is in the middle of a huge ice storm right now.

headline: 'One Headache After Another'
summary: Monologue | Aired Thursday night on CBS: Cold everywhere. Listen how cold it is. It is so cold out in Illinois, the state of Illinois impeached Al Roker.

headline: Television Networks Make Plans for Upfronts
summary: Despite the economic turmoil, several broadcast television networks still plan to hold their upfronts, the costly annual presentations at which they announce their new programs to advertisers and the press, Variety reported. Fox will lead the week of presentations on May 18, followed by ABC on May 19; CBS will have its upfront event on May 20 at Carnegie Hall, though Variety said the network was unlikely to follow that with its customary party at Tavern on the Green. CW is scheduled to hold its presentation on May 21 at the Madison Square Garden Theater. NBC, which last year opted out of the upfronts with an early April presentation it called an “infront,” will do so again this year.

headline: Springsteen Promises ‘12-Minute Party’ at Halftime
summary: When Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band perform in Tampa, the only new wrinkle will be the size of the audience.

headline: Katie Couric Interviews Lil Wayne
summary: By now most cultural authorities have weighed in on President Obama … except Lil Wayne, the bawdy New Orleans rapper who is nominated for eight Grammy Awards for his album “Tha Carter III.” In an interview with Katie Couric to be part of her “All Access Grammy Special” on CBS on Wednesday, he tells her: “Music is another form of journalism to me. So I have to cover all the areas with my album. You get Lil Wayne’s take on the new president, Lil Wayne’s take on money, the economy, Lil Wayne’s take on women, Lil Wayne’s take on whatever.” When Ms. Couric asks Lil Wayne, who has rapped about the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, what question he would put to former President Bush about it, he answered: “I’m a gangster, and gangsters don’t ask questions.” But they do answer them, apparently. Watch a preview of the interview here.

headline: Ratings: A Thursday 'Idol' Lifts Fox
summary: Fox won a rare first-place finish in the ratings on Thursday thanks to the premiere of the fifth edition of "Hell's Kitchen" and a special installment of "American Idol" on the night.

headline: Pfizer's New Deal Model
summary: On Thursday evening, Wyeth filed the agreement for its $68 billion takeover by Pfizer. As the press release on Monday hinted, the Wyeth-Pfizer deal offers a new model for strategic transactions.

headline: 'A Fat D.J.'
summary: Monologue | Aired Thursday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: It's a bad day for Illinois Governor Rod Blagojevich. The state senate kicked him out. So today, Blagojevich did what any smart criminal in Illinois would do. He asked Oprah for a pardon.

headline: Strong Week for Fox
summary: Fox earned a rare first-place finish on Thursday night with the premiere of the fifth edition of “Hell’s Kitchen” and a special installment of “American Idol.”

headline: Sunday's Breakfast Menu, Feb. 1
summary: Opening arguments in the coming week's Senate debate over the stimulus package will take place Sunday morning, with each program featuring at least one member of the 100-member club.

headline: Republicans Confident About Holding Gregg's Senate Seat
summary: How can Republican Senator Judd Gregg - the likely Obama pick for commerce secretary - guarantee that whoever replaces him in the Senate will vote with the Republican caucus?

headline: A Digital Copy of Inauguration Day
summary: A digital copy of Inauguration Day | Just as millions of Americans saved copies of newspapers on the day after President Obama's election, television executives are hoping that consumers will want digital memories of Inauguration Day. ABC, CBS, CNN and NBC are all selling DVDs of the day's festivities through online stores.

headline: Obama Predicts Support From G.O.P. for Stimulus Proposal
summary: President Obama is now on a quest to reshape the legislation in a way that will bring Senate Republicans, and perhaps eventually some House members as well, on board.

headline: The Week Ahead in Congress: Senate Seeks Consensus
summary: The clash over how to deal with the economy preoccupies the Senate today while Tom Daschle fights for his Cabinet slot and Eric Holder heads for confirmation as attorney general.

headline: Democrats Indicate Areas of Compromise on Stimulus
summary: Democratic senators said they are open to considering Republican amendments to the stimulus bill, particularly in the areas of housing and infrastructure.

headline: Ratings: On Super Bowl Sunday, 'Wipeout' Earns Runner-Up Status
summary: Opposite NBC's Super Bowl broadcast, the biggest television ratings event of the year, ABC, CBS and Fox barely bothered to court audiences of their own.

headline: To Relive the Inauguration, a Wave of Network DVDs
summary: Television executives are hoping that consumers will want digital memories of Inauguration Day.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
summary: Webdenda.

headline: Strong Early Ratings for Super Bowl
summary: Overnight "metered-market" estimates indicate that NBC's live broadcast of Super Bowl XLIII from Tampa, Fla., attracted fewer viewers than last year's game, which averaged a record 97.4 million viewers for Fox. If the estimates prove correct, the audience should be in line with CBS's broadcast of Super Bowl XLI in 2007, which drew 93.2 million viewers.

headline: The Early Word: Battle Lines Firming Up on Stimulus
summary: Congressional leaders return to the White House this afternoon, for yet another summit meeting with President Obama that will likely focus on the economic stimulus package that is facing considerable Republican resistance in the Senate.

headline: Los Angeles Steps Up Fight on Large Ads
summary: The city ordered building owners to remove advertisements draped across multistory structures after deeming them fire hazards.

headline: Blagojevich on 'The Late Show'
summary: Blagojevich on 'The Late Show' | The showman Rod R. Blagojevich, former governor of Illinois, is on a second media tour, a few days after being impeached. Notably, he'll be making a late-night appearance on CBS's "The Late Show with David Letterman" (11:35 p.m.). The Los Angeles Times has highlights. He'll also appear on CNN's "Larry King Live" (9 p.m.) and Fox News Channel's "On The Record" (10 p.m.). 2/3, 7:21 p.m.

headline: CBS Enters the 'Arranged Marriage' Business
summary: CBS enters the 'Arranged Marriage' business | CBS has ordered a series "that puts lovelorn singles into arranged marriages," according to The Hollywood Reporter. Under the working title "Arranged Marriage," four people will have their spouses selected for them by family and friends. "The series follows their marriages." Read more... 2/3, 11:22 a.m.

headline: 'Stuff Always Goes Haywire in Alaska'
summary: Monologue | Aired Monday night on CBS: Right after Sunday's Super Bowl, President Barack Obama placed a congratulatory phone call to the Steelers from his BlackBerry. Meanwhile, John McCain called the Cardinals from his ham radio.

headline: 'Not a Great Day For Batman'
summary: Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: It was a great day for us here at the show but not a great day for Batman, or as he's known in real life, actor Christian Bale. Bale was all over the Internet today. Have you heard that tape? We can't play it for you, because some of the language is not appropriate for TV. Almost everyone who's heard this tape says it's offensive, but former Illinois Gov. Rod Blagojevich disagreed, calling it "amateur," and "not cussy enough."

headline: ‘House’ Can’t Stop CBS Powerhouse
summary: The 100th episode of “House” gave Fox a boost in the ratings on Monday night as 14.7 million viewers tuned in to the medical drama.

headline: Ranking the Rankings in Fantasy Football, 2008
summary: Sara Holladay leads a dual life blogging as the Fantasy Football Librarian and working as a university librarian in Colorado. She's a devoted fan of the Denver Broncos and the Northwestern Wildcats and has a soft spot for the Redskins as a Washington native.

headline: 'Some Tax Problems'
summary: Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on CBS: Former Illinois Gov. Rod Blagojevich is on the show tonight, ladies and gentlemen. I hope that thing on his head doesn't bite me.

headline: For Sale in ... Greece
summary: A villa in the Cycladic Islands furnished in traditional Greek style is on the market for 880,000 euros ($1,126,000).

headline: Court Filings Show Real Estate Families' Madoff Losses
summary: New York's real estate industry is not only coping with a troubled market that shows few signs of life in the coming months and even years. Now some of the city's most prominent real estate figures have been hit with a double whammy. Many of them are investors and now appear to be victims of Bernard L. Madoff.

headline: ‘Idol’ Goes Hollywood
summary: In its first Hollywood episode of the season, “American Idol” soared past its competitors on Tuesday night with 26.3 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates.

headline: CBS to Devote Entire Morning Show to Hero Pilot
summary: CBS to devote entire morning show to hero pilot | "Sensing a rare opportunity to get noticed, CBS is setting aside its entire morning show Monday to the story of U.S. Airways pilot Chesley "Sully' Sullenberger and the crew that helped land a disabled jet in the Hudson River with no fatalities," the Associated Press notes. "The Early Show" will even include "a performance from a singer who was on the flight and moved to write about what happened." 2/5, 6:13 p.m.

headline: Signing Day's Winners and Losers
summary: In a telephone interview Thursday, the CBS College Sports recruiting analyst Tom Lemming broke down which teams had reasons to be pleased with Wednesday's signing day and which teams didn't.

headline: Ratings: Modest Audience for Couric's Grammy Special
summary: Round Two of Hollywood week on "American Idol" attracted 26.3 million viewers on Wednesday, according to Nielsen's estimates, catapulting Fox into first place in the night's ratings.

headline: Grammys Hope for the Unexpected
summary: The people behind the Grammy Awards are hoping that star power and advertising will boost the ceremony’s ratings.

headline: Was Flight 1549’s Pilot Fearful? If So, His Voice Didn’t Let On
summary: “Which runway would you like?” a controller asked Capt. Chesley B. Sullenberger III. “We’re gonna be in the Hudson,” the pilot replied.

headline: News Corp. Loss Shows Trouble at Dow Jones
summary: The media company, controlled by Rupert Murdoch, reported a quarterly loss of $6.41 billion on a write-down of Dow Jones & Co. and other assets, as the recession hit advertising revenue.

headline: In Hospital Battle, ABC Beats NBC
summary: With CBS in reruns on Thursday night, ABC soared to No. 1 in the ratings, according to Nielsen’s estimates. ABC earned the night’s largest audience, 15.2 million viewers, with “Grey’s Anatomy” at 9 p.m., and retained many of those viewers at 10 with “Private Practice” (13 million), which outperformed its competitors, NBC’s “ER” (7.3 million) and CBS’s repeat of “Eleventh Hour” (8.2 million). But at 8, ABC’s “Ugly Betty” (7.3 million) struggled opposite Fox’s “Bones” (10.8 million), which led the hour and helped Fox place second on the night. CBS ranked third for the night over all. NBC lagged behind in total viewers with its comedy lineup from 8 to 10, but delivered its best ratings in the 18-to-49 age group during the 9 p.m. hour with “The Office” (8.4 million total viewers) and “30 Rock” (6.3 million).

headline: Sunday's Breakfast Menu, Feb. 8
summary: Not surprisingly, some of the top figures in the nation's economic policy are appearing on the talk shows this Sunday.

headline: 'Groomed, Blow-Dried and Flea-Dipped'
summary: Monologue | Aired Friday night on CBS: People are sick and tired of the cold weather. Here's how cold it was today in Washington, D.C. Vice President Joe Biden put his foot in his mouth just to keep it warm.

headline: Live Blogging the Grammy Awards
summary: Ben Sisario’s full report on the 2009 Grammy Awards can be found here.

headline: Rodriguez Said to Test Positive in 2003
summary: Alex Rodriguez tested positive for steroids in 2003 while playing for the Rangers, two people with knowledge of the results said.

headline: Grammy's Record a Ratings Increase
summary: Ratings for the 51st annual Grammy Awards on Sunday perked up considerably from a year ago, but they were still less than the award show's 2007 audience of 20.1 million viewers and far less than the 26.3 million who tuned in as recently as 2004.

headline: Flight 1549 Pilot Tells of Terror and Intense Focus
summary: In his first interview since the crash landing, Capt. Chesley B. Sullenberger III said he was terrified as he guided the plane into the Hudson River.

headline: Full-Tilt Performances and Defiant Bravado
summary: To hold the attention of a television audience that has increasingly been ignoring the Grammy Awards show in recent years, performers cranked up the instruments and unleashed their vocals.

headline: Live Blogging the Obama News Conference
summary: That's a Wrap | 9:33 p.m. So the first presidential press conference of the Obama administration is now in the books. At the White House, the senior administration officials seem to be smiling. Why? First, Mr. Obama made no obvious blunders. While he has delivered thousands of speeches, he has never held forth for so long before reporters during a prime-time setting.

headline: More Liquor Ads Pour Onto Broadcast TV
summary: Fifteen months after the flagship local station owned by NBC began running commercials for liquor, the local flagship of CBS is starting to accept them as well.

headline: A Polite Forum for a Careful Confession
summary: ESPN had a huge platform and Alex Rodriguez had the interviewer he wanted, but viewers needed tougher questions to be asked.

headline: 'No Surprise Here'
summary: Monologue | Aired Monday night on CBS: Last night, right here on CBS, they aired the annual Grammy Awards, and no surprise here, the Grammy for Best Duo went to Aretha Franklin and her hat.

headline: Rodriguez Admits to Use of Performance Enhancers
summary: Alex Rodriguez said that he used a banned substance while he played for the Texas Rangers.

headline: 'Cogent, Eloquent, and in Complete Command'
summary: Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on CBS: How about President Barack Obama's first primetime press conference last night? He was cogent, eloquent, and in complete command of the issues. I'm thinking to myself, what the hell am I supposed to do with that?

headline: Ratings: CBS Crime Shows Come Close to Beating Fox
summary: CBS's crime shows on Tuesday came close to beating Fox's lineup of "American Idol" and "Fringe" in the ratings, according to Nielsen's estimates.

headline: Hundreds of TV Stations Will Drop Analog Signals Next Week
summary: "The next four months may prove to be a rolling transition for the nation's estimated 1,700 local TV stations," The New York Times reported last week. Now the Federal Communications Commission is confirming that, as expected, the digital TV switch will occur as scheduled for hundreds of stations.

headline: ‘Big Bang’ Goes Pop
Sirius XM Prepares Possible Bankruptcy Filing
summary: Last summer, Mel Karmazin was rattling off his trademark one-liners to talk up the future of Sirius XM Radio, the combined company he ran that had just been blessed by regulators.

headline: Some Hong Kong buyers 'emboldened'
summary: Luxury residential activity in Hong Kong slowed dramatically in the fourth quarter, but started to pick up near the end of the year, according to a new report from CB Richard Ellis.

headline: Ratings: About 25 Million for 'Idol'
summary: A two-hour edition of Fox's "American Idol," in which the judges whittled the slate of contestants down to 36 semifinalists, dominated Wednesday night's prime time ratings.

headline: 'How Strange Things Are'
summary: Monologue | Aired Wednesday night on CBS: You know, this Treasury Secretary, Timothy Geithner? He gave testimony on Capitol Hill today, but it drew lukewarm response. So, Timothy, welcome to the club!

headline: 3 ‘Billy Elliot’ Actors Eligible for Joint Tony Nomination
summary: If you thought competition for the Tony Awards had threatened the solidarity among the young actors in the Broadway musical “Billy Elliot,” fear not: A Tonys committee took the unusual step on Thursday of ruling that the three teenagers who rotate in the title role would be considered jointly for a single nomination for leading actor in a musical.

headline: White Stripes to Reunite for Conan’s Last ‘Late Night’
summary: Jack White and Meg White, the rock duo better known as the White Stripes, will reunite to perform on the Feb. 20 broadcast of NBC’s “Late Night with Conan O’Brien,” the band’s publicist said in an e-mail message. The show is Mr. O’Brien’s final episode as host of “Late Night” before Jimmy Fallon, the “Saturday Night Live” star, takes over on March 2; Mr. O’Brien becomes host of NBC’s “Tonight” show on June 1.

headline: Maker of Mortal Kombat Lands in Chapter 11
summary: Midway Games, the video game maker known for the 1990s hit Mortal Kombat, has lost its fight to stay out of bankruptcy court.

headline: Judge Dismisses Large Part of Clemens Defamation Suit
summary: A federal judge in Texas dismissed a portion of a defamation lawsuit filed by Roger Clemens against his chief accuser and former trainer, Brian McNamee.

headline: Ratings: Nearly 14 Million Watch 'Survivor' Premiere
summary: The return of "Survivor" to CBS's line-up on Thursday helped the network claim victory as the night's most watched network, but a "Grey's Anatomy" crossover episode with "Private Practice" gave ABC an edge in the demographic of adults 18 to 49.

headline: 'It Is so Windy ...'
summary: Monologue | Aired Thursday night on CBS: I don't know what the deal is, but all of a sudden, we have 40- and 50 mile-an-hour gusts of wind blowing around outside. In fact, it is so windy, former Illinois Gov. Rod Blagojevich's hair actually moved.

headline: White Stripes Together for O’Brien’s Last ‘Late Night’
summary: Jack White and Meg White, the rock duo better known as the White Stripes, will perform for next Friday’s broadcast of NBC’s “Late Night With Conan O’Brien,” the band’s publicist said in an e-mail message. The band has appeared together infrequently since its 2007 album “Icky Thump.” The show is Mr. O’Brien’s final episode as host of “Late Night” before Jimmy Fallon, the former “Saturday Night Live” star, takes over on March 2; Mr. O’Brien becomes host of NBC’s “Tonight Show” on June 1. ... U2 will be the musical guest for a full week on CBS’s “Late Show With David Letterman,” from March 2 through 6, The Associated Press reported. The band’s new album, “No Line on the Horizon,” will be released on March 3.

headline: Viacom Profit Falls 69% as Revenue Remains Flat
summary: The company’s executives are pessimistic about the future for the media industry, where ad growth is weak.

headline: Viacom’s Head Optimistic as Profit Falls
summary: The media conglomerate, controlled by Sumner M. Redstone, reported solid earnings although its profit fell significantly, partly to reflect a big restructuring change.

headline: A Photographer Shares the Works That Fed His Soul
summary: Anthony Barboza’s photographs of celebrity artists, athletes and other prominent African-Americans form a solo exhibition.

headline: They Sure Showed That Obama
summary: In the stimulus battle — just as in the presidential campaign — Barack Obama has once again outwitted the punditocracy and the opposition.

headline: This Just In: The Market Is Still Dead
summary: Financial journalists still can’t figure out how to cover the recession.

summary: With CBS's prime-time lineup mostly is repeats on Presidents' Day, Fox was first and ABC ranked second in Monday night's ratings.

summary: Correspondents who exposed corruption in Zimbabwe and reporters who unraveled the mysteries of the mortgage crisis were among the winners of 14 George Polk Awards.

summary: Seems at least a few brave investors are toying with residential real estate after the subprime fallout slashed real estate investment trusts, or REITs, more than 37 percent last year.

headline: 'Fashion Week Fever'
summary: Monologue | Aired Monday night on CBS: Everybody has got Fashion Week fever in New York City, where they had a big 50th anniversary tribute to Barbie. Can you believe that Barbie has been around 50 years? During that time, they have had Preppie Barbie, Wedding Barbie, and Republican Running Mate Barbie.

headline: 'Married to Bubba'
summary: Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on CBS: You remember Hillary Clinton? She has been married to Bubba for quite a while. Well, she is now the Secretary of State, and she is on her first big round the world tour. She is on her big Asian tour. She wants to normalize relations with North Korea. No word yet about normalizing relations with Bill.

headline: Ratings: Fox First, CBS Second
summary: A two-hour installment of "American Idol" lifted Fox far ahead of its competitors in the ratings on Tuesday, averaging 25.1 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates.

headline: Ben Blank, Innovator of Graphics for TV News, Dies at 87
summary: Mr. Blank introduced the concept of using logolike images behind anchors as signatures for major news coverage.

headline: With Four More Months to Switch, Hundreds of Television Stations Are All Digital
summary: More than 400 stations have stopped broadcasting in analog form, months before the rescheduled transition to digital TV.

headline: 'A New Study'
summary: Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: A new study says that the bad economy can lower testosterone levels in men. Scientists say at this rate, by the end of the decade, Ann Coulter could be a woman!

headline: Hulu Will Cut Off Users of Boxee Video Software
summary: The dream of a free and easy way to watch Internet video on a television set just ran into some harsh reality.

headline: Ratings: 'Lost' Sees Highest Ratings of the Season
summary: ABC's "Lost" delivered its highest ratings of the season on Wednesday, according to Nielsen's estimates. Although the 9 p.m. show's total viewership was a somewhat modest 11.3 million, Wednesday's episode drew the drama's best ratings among adults 18 to 49 since April, trailing only Fox's "American Idol" on the night in that age group.

headline: Building a Home in Late Night’s Shifting Sand
summary: Friday will be Conan O’Brien’s last night on “Late Night” before he decamps for Los Angeles to prepare to replace Jay Leno as host of NBC’s “Tonight Show.”

headline: 'News for Sarah Palin'
summary: Monologue | Aired Wednesday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: Good news and bad news for Sarah Palin. The bad news is that the IRS says she owes thousands of dollars in back taxes. The good news is that she now qualifies to be in Obama's Cabinet.

headline: Lawmakers Can Defy Governors to Get the Stimulus Money
summary: For all the tough talk and media chatter about whether some (or one or two) of the nation's governors will refuse to accept the billions of dollars in stimulus money beginning to surge its way out of Washington's pipelines, a few paragraphs tucked into the stimulus bill lay bare how hollow those threats may be.

headline: Profit Falls 52% at CBS as Advertising Revenue Declines
summary: Weaker advertising sales in the quarter has forced the network to cut its dividend.

headline: Inevitable as the Tides, ‘Idol’ Wins the Night
summary: A two-hour installment of “American Idol” lifted Fox ahead of its competitors on Tuesday.

headline: 'Cheney and the Saudis'
summary: Monologue | Aired Thursday night on CBS: Sarah Palin, the governor of Alaska, owes $70,000 in taxes, but listen to this. She's blaming it on Alex Rodriguez's cousin.

headline: Ratings: A Healthy Night for 'Anatomy'
summary: CBS attracted the most viewers on Thursday during prime time, but for the third consecutive week, ABC won the night in the important demographic of adults 18 to 49.

headline: Is Revenge a Pot of Beans Best Eaten Cold?
summary: Less than two weeks after the Beanpot, the eyes of the college hockey world are back on Boston, where No. 1 Boston University and No. 4 Northeastern square off in a home-and-away this weekend. The Terriers knocked off the Huskies by 5-2 to win the Beanpot title on Feb. 9, and there's no question that they're the best team going in college hockey. B.U. has lost just once since Thanksgiving, and that was more than a month ago.

headline: A Good Night for ‘Lost,’ a Better One for ‘Idol’
summary: ABC’s “Lost” delivered its highest ratings of the season on Wednesday, according to Nielsen’s estimates.

headline: 'Secret Client List'

headline: Quad Q&A: Big East Commissioner Mike Tranghese
summary: Big East Commissioner Mike Tranghese will be retiring after this academic year, ending at 19-year reign atop one of the première conferences in college sports. Tranghese sat down in his office for a recent interview to reflect on his career, delivering answers in the same blunt and effusive style that defined his stint as commissioner. He began as the Big East's first employee, just he and a secretary in a three-room suite. (Dave Gavitt, the first commissioner, also served as the athletic director at Providence when the league was formed.) During the interview, Tranghese touched on everything from Patrick Ewing's influence on the Big East to the league's vote to not take Penn State as a member to receiving a head butt from Jim Boeheim. He reflected on his favorite year, his favorite Big East tournament moment, the league's relationship with ESPN and what challenges he thinks face his successor, John Marinatto. And he made one final plea: Please, don't ask him for anymore tickets.

headline: 'Dancing' Dances Off With the Night

That's roughly a million more than the debuts of its last two editions, in the fall and spring of 2008, attracted. The premiere of ABC's new show ''Castle'' drew 11.6 million viewers at 10, trailing CBS's ''CSI: Miami'' (14.8 million), but ABC still led the night with its most Monday viewers on average in close to three years. Fox was runner-up with ''House'' (12.1 million) and ''24'' (11.3 million), while CBS finished a close third with ''Two and a Half Men'' (13.3 million viewers). NBC ranked a distant fourth with ''Chuck'' (5.7 million), ''Heroes'' (6.6 million) and ''Medium'' (7.1 million).

headline: Set Faces to Stunned: ‘Star Trek’ Writer Sues Over Episode
summary: Updated | 11:32 a.m. A vintage “Star Trek” episode about the perils of time travel has created unpleasant present-day repercussions for the CBS Paramount studio, which produced the original television series. Harlan Ellison, the author and screenwriter of the “Star Trek” episode “The City on the Edge of Forever,” has filed suit against CBS Paramount, saying that the studio has not paid him merchandising and publishing revenue it earned from the episode, Variety reported. The episode, which was first broadcast in 1967, follows Captain Kirk as he travels back to the Great Depression and falls in love with a social worker played by Joan Collins. In his suit, Mr. Ellison said he had not been paid for merchandise based on the episode, including a series of books and a talking Christmas tree ornament. Under the terms of a master contract with the Writers Guild of America, Mr. Ellison is entitled to 25 percent of revenues from derived from the licensing of publication rights. Mr. Ellison is also suing the Writers Guild, for $1 plus court costs, for not acting on his behalf.

The author Harlan Ellison, the screenwriter of the episode “The City on the Edge of Forever,” has filed suit against CBS Paramount, saying that the studio had not paid him merchandising and publishing revenue it earned from the episode, Variety reported. The episode, first broadcast in 1967, follows Captain Kirk as he travels back to the Great Depression and falls in love with a social worker played by Joan Collins. In his suit Mr. Ellison said he had not been paid for merchandise based on it, including a series of books and a talking Christmas tree ornament. Under the terms of a master contract with the Writers Guild of America, Mr. Ellison is entitled to 25 percent of revenues derived from the licensing of publication rights.

headline: 'While You Were Laughing'

The network easily led Monday night over all even as its new crime show, “Castle,” (11.5 million), trailed CBS’s “CSI: Miami” (13.3 million) during the 10 p.m. hour. “Castle” did show slight improvement over its debut last week. Fox was runner-up for the night with “House” at 8 (12.8 million) and “24” at 9 (11.3 million). CBS finished a close third thanks to “CSI: Miami” and its comedy lineup, which included “Two and a Half Men” at 9 (14 million) and “Rules of Engagement” at 9:30 (11.4 million). NBC ranked a distant fourth with repeats.

It's tough to turn on the TV for games when you've let your dream slip out of your fingers. So for three years I avoided tournament pools like the plague, licked my wounds, and recovered in time to watch the Final Four. This year I thought I'd lose the best weeks in sports for a different reason.

headline: Cult Shows Live Again on DirecTV
summary: Canceled shows never die; they’re just rebroadcast on DirecTV. Variety reported that the satellite broadcaster DirecTV had acquired the rights to broadcast three short-lived network series – some so short-lived that their first seasons weren’t shown in their entirety – on its 101 Network. The three series are “Smith,” a 2006 CBS crime drama about a gang of professional criminals, whose cast included Simon Baker, Virginia Madsen and Ray Liotta; “The Nine,” a 2006 ABC drama about a group of strangers linked as hostages in a bank robbery; and “Eyes,” a 2005 ABC series about a high-tech detective agency. In January, DirecTV began rebroadcasting “Wonderland,” a well-reviewed if abbreviated ABC series from 2000; its new batch of resurrected shows will begin showing in April.

headline: Rescue Plan, With Fine Print, Dazzles Wall St.
summary: This time President Obama directed some of the stagecraft. This time Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner fleshed out the substance of their long-anticipated program to remove banks' toxic assets and revive the financial system. And this time the reaction was widely positive, giving the embattled Mr. Geithner a critically needed boost. Mr. Geithner had a lot on the line in Monday's announcement, despite Mr. Obama's repeated insistence that his job was safe. The Treasury secretary's highly publicized unveiling six weeks ago of his plan's ''framework'' had been panned for lacking details, hobbling Mr. Geithner as he was trying to build credibility with the financial markets and clout in Washington.

headline: Restraining Order Issued Against ‘Dancing With the Stars’ Fan
summary: A Los Angeles County court has issued a restraining order against a man who tried to break into the set of the ABC reality series “Dancing with the Stars” in an attempt to meet one of its contestants, The Associated Press reported. The man, Robert O’Ryan, was arrested Tuesday after an incident Monday in which he jumped a fence at CBS Studios, where “Dancing with the Stars” is produced. Mr. O’Ryan was said to be seeking out Shawn Johnson, 17, the Olympic gymnast featured on the current season of the show. A search of Mr. O’Ryan’s car yielded two loaded guns as well as duct tape and love letters written to Ms. Johnson, the police said. He is being held on $35,000 bail, on suspicion of carrying a loaded firearm in public; an April 14 hearing has been set to consider an extension of the restraining order.

headline: Not Guilty Plea in ‘Dancing with the Stars’ Incident

The man, Robert O’Ryan, was arrested after an incident Monday in which he jumped a fence at CBS Studios, where “Dancing with the Stars” is produced. A search of Mr. O’Ryan’s car found two loaded guns as well as duct tape and love letters written to Ms. Johnson, the Olympic athlete, the police said. At an arraignment in Los Angeles County Superior Court, Mr. O’Ryan was charged with one felony count of stalking and two misdemeanor counts of carrying a loaded gun in a vehicle, and his bail was raised to $220,00 from $35,000. A trial was scheduled for April 27.
