headline: Letters:Economic Crisis and Anonymous Sources
summary: Re "Bad News, and More Bad News" (March 15): Not being a 5-year-old child anymore, I'd much rather hear the truth (however grim) than a fairy tale (however rosy and upbeat).So let The Times continue to tell it like it is. Until we know, in full, what's happening, we won't be able to tell what's wrong, much less how to counteract it.I think that people who object to The Times's reporting of the whole picture are mostly those who don't want the rest of us to put two and two together and come up with four equals Bush.Tamara P. DuvallLexington, Va., March 15, 2009 ● I usually read your column with interest, if not always with agreement. But I am, after all, a consenting adult and know what I am letting myself in for when I read the Op-Ed pages of The Times. But today's column touched bottom in a way that the economy probably hasn't yet done.You excuse Peter S. Goodman, a national economics correspondent, for his use of the word "depression" in a way that strains belief. First, you quote him as saying, "My master is reality." What sort of reality is he referring to? I would hope he means an evidence-based reality, but support for his reality takes the form of the "Nine out of 10 dentists recommend Crest" advertisement - true if you pick the right 10 dentists.In Mr. Goodman's case, he refers to "two respected economists" - an easier group to assemble even than the 10 dentists - but one does worry about who is doing the respecting. These two economists volunteered, "in separate interviews" (that's important, since it implies no collusion on their part), that the use of the word "depression" was allowable (for the Mark Zandi quote) on the grounds that "the odds of a 'mild depression' were up to 25 percent."This is ambiguous. It might mean that the odds had now increased to 25 percent (one in four, presumably), having previously been lower, or that those odds were now less than or equal to 25 percent, in which case one should ask, "How much less than 25 percent could that mean?" Which of these interpretations was implied?On top of this, the other economist, Allen Sinai, saw a 20 percent chance of a "depressionlike possibility," which does tend to boggle one's mind a bit. Since a 20 percent chance is a 20 percent possibility, he sees the possibility of a possibility that resembles a depression.On these two opinions does Mr. Goodman justify himself, and you support him! Really!Anthony PoëOttawa, March 15, 2009 ● While I agree that it is not the responsibility of the news media to be a cheerleader, or to falsely represent that things are better than they perceive them to be, I think that you missed a bigger point.No one can deny that much of what is happening in this economy is psychologically driven. The psychology of a market will drive it up (think "bubbles"), and it can, as is now happening, drive a market down.I think the point is that reporting in the present situation implies that the "bad news" is independent of the personal decisions of the public. The result is that people react to the bad news, creating a cycle that becomes self-fulfilling.You should do an in-depth study focused on how many people are sitting on the sidelines waiting for the "bottom" to then get back into the market (whether it be housing, stocks, business expansions, startups, etc).I don't doubt that the bad news is real. I just think that the element of how the bad news in and of itself creates a downward spiral is missing from the coverage.Bruce GorenLos Angeles, March 15, 2009 ● I think The Times needs to tell it like it is and not sugarcoat things because there are those who want something less than the truth.I think The Times does a fine job! I do think, however, that The Times, and the media in general, did less than a fine job of sounding the warning and challenging the Bush administration on the thinking and events leading up to war in Iraq. Everyone was going easy on telling the truth because of the public mood and for fear of losing advertising dollars.We must not repeat that mistake again. A free society cannot exist without newspapers that tell the truth.Larry A. DeyssDelmar, N.Y., March 16, 2009●●Re "Those Persistent Anonymous Sources" (March 22): Since you indicate that some critics of anonymous sources were themselves insisting on anonymity, let me help with comments that are on the record:In every job I have had in 45 years of journalism, from PBS to CBS News to Westinghouse (later the same company) to ABC to NPR and even as far back as college radio, anonymous sources have done their best to obscure and mislead to serve their own (or their bosses') interests, hiding disinformation behind a cloak of anonymity. Best is to treat them just as you would treat an anonymous letter: that is where reporting should start, not stop.When I was head of NPR News, over and over again anonymous sources attempted to manipulate us in all of the usual ways. But when I insisted that NPR reporters try to get sources to go on the record, in every case - every case - the story was strengthened.For example, the anonymous source's criticisms of the F.B.I. were, stripped of anonymity, then confirmed by the F.B.I. itself. That made it a better story, no?Another anonymous source's accusations about a Supreme Court nominee were, when pressed, eventually confirmed by the judge himself - and before our deadline that afternoon. Better, don't you think?And a classic election-eve anonymous source unloading a late hit against a presidential candidate was unmasked when his information, just too good to be true, was in fact, as usual, too good to check out (which is not to say that others don't fall for that clichéd gambit).When I was a reporter, when my editors asked me to go back to my sources to insist they go on the record, my sources either relented or showed how I could document their information by other means. After all, the reason they become sources is (in almost all cases) to get the story published, right?Four decades of journalism have convinced me that anonymous sources are almost never needed. Rather, they have become the crack cocaine of the newsroom, peddled everywhere for a quick hit. It's time to break the habit.Adam Clayton Powell IIIHong Kong, March 26, 2009 ●Some of the stories by the sources you cite would be inadmissible in a trial, being mostly gossip or uncorroborated.You mention 2004 as the time that this policy was adopted. I think back to stories in The Times that helped drum up the war pre-2004. And, of course, the story that Robert D. Novak let out was and still is, I think, criminal.I've been a lifelong reader of The Times, but I don't put much faith is today's so-called journalists caring much about "the truth." Filling space and time 24/7 seems the primary need of news organizations. I have to trust my own radar to delete the gossip, misleading statements and downright lies I read and hear.J. T. HollandWashington, March 22, 2009 ● There are questionable ethics involved when The Times publishes statements by officials who request anonymity "because they are not authorized to comment publicly." These officials are breaking the rules and perhaps even the law, and The Times, by publishing their comments, is abetting them. Perhaps you could comment on this in a future column.Jim LincolnConcord, Mass., March 22, 2009 ● As a reporter who covered Washington for more than 30 years, I am increasingly annoyed by the nonattribution explanations that slow up reading The Times and other papers.Why should I care that a source was "not authorized to speak to the press"? What I care about is the information provided by the source. What I rely on is not the identity of a source but the reputation of the reporter whose byline appears on the story and the reputation for accuracy of the newspaper that publishes the report. When I was covering the Pentagon for The Washington Star and U.S. News & World Report, almost everything worth knowing was secret or above. Of course my sources for such information were anonymous, often to the chagrin of secretaries of defense and other officials who wanted to know: "How did he know that?"Often, there was no single "source" at all. Reporters covering such a Byzantine place as the Pentagon get a bit of information here and another there, putting them together into a revealing story. When I went to one source with what I thought was the basis for a story, he would tell me: "No, that's not right. Now, if you asked me . . . I would say that's classified and I can't talk about it."My non-source was thus in a position, if asked, to say truthfully that he told me he couldn't talk about that subject while, of course, he had steered me in the right direction. I know The Times and other papers have been burned by reporters who simply lied about sources or were misled by trusted sources. But the answer to that problem is not silly rules that simply slow up the reader, but the hiring of reporters and editors of the highest integrity.Orr KellyBethesda, Md., March 22, 2009● While there are certainly times when anonymity is needed or deserved, as you point out, lately the reference to those sources seems to be used too often. And that makes one wonder whether there is really any basis to what is being reported.For instance, I read with great interest "Love Was Blind," about Bank of America and Merrill Lynch (Business Day, Feb. 8) - until I hit the following paragraph: "Interviews with almost 30 current and former Bank of America and Merrill executives and employees convey just how messy the merger has been. All of them asked not to be identified because they either did not have permission from the banks to speak or because they had signed confidentially agreements with their former employers."Almost 30 people! All of whom spoke without authority to do so or broke their written word not to do so. At that point the reporters lost me. How could I believe the story when none of their almost 30 sources could be independently verified?John L. GoldmanRochester, March 23, 2009 ● Hats off to you for taking on the issue of anonymous sources. The difficulty of the challenge was obvious - again - in the very same issue in which your column appeared.At the end of a long business story about the so-called food revolution - hardly the kind of story that would seem to require cloak and dagger secrecy - "a prominent food industry lobbyist who requested anonymity because he wasn't authorized to speak to reporters" was mentioned.The earth-shattering revelation that justified this cover-up by the reporter? That the lobbyist was "amazed" to see many members of Congress carrying a best-selling book ("The Omnivore's Dilemma"). Secrecy won out in the business section on March 24, when Andrew Sorkin in the Dealbook column quotes "one senior Goldman executive who insisted on not being quoted by name for fear of crossing the Treasury Department."This in a newspaper that has constantly railed in recent months about the lack of transparency in the gargantuan financial industry bailout. Seems like the reporters and columnists are being permitted - maybe encouraged? - to be enablers of the very lack of transparency that they decry.There's little reason to think that the flood of unnamed sources will slow down much. But you shining a light on this problem at least makes the reporters and editors squirm a bit.Frank HamsherSt. Louis, March 24, 2009 ● It seems as though when discussing non-people facts, the source should be available and be willing to be quoted.When talking about opinion or theory, who cares about the source? The important aspect is for people to evaluate the message - not the messenger.All messengers are consciously or unconsciously biased anyway. And to a large extent the news media do no favors by substituting messenger evaluation for message evaluation.Paul F. HosmanKalamazoo, Mich., March 22, 2009 ● I enjoyed your column discussing the reasons informants are not identified.I've been fascinated by the endless number of explanations. I like the variety - there seems to be an obligation to come up with new excuses for granting anonymity. I particularly like it when explanations are at least somewhat factual - "feared the consequences of identifying himself," "did not have permission to speak" or "because of the sensitivity of the subject."To be really factual, how about, "We were afraid we would be sued," or "The Editor is a coward"?Dick SherwoodSouth Dartmouth, Mass., March 22, 2009 ●One major problem with the practice of offering sources anonymity is that it is simply extraordinarily contagious. People read the paper, notice the prevalence of unnamed sources, and wonder why they should speak on the record when no one else does.The reasons for desiring to remain out of the spotlight in our increasingly polarized and dangerous society are entirely understandable. Newspaper reporters certainly have a daunting task of persuading people to speak on the record added to the chore of writing a thorough and fair piece, but if editors and publishers don't enforce standards with consistency, the whole enterprise becomes indistinguishable from gossip mongering.Think for a moment of newspapers' main competition - television newscasts.How often do we see TV relying on unidentified sources? Sure, once in a while we get the blurred face, anonymous silhouette, or distorted voice, but it's remarkably rare. If you want to provide information or comment on a TV news story, you not only get your name used, but you are usually photographed. Why can't print news make the same demands?Charles ClouseSanta Barbara, Calif., March 24, 2009 ● You write, "The policy says anonymous sources should be used only as 'a last resort when the story is of compelling public interest and the information is not available any other way.'"Maybe if editors designated assignments in advance so that reporters knew which stories they would be covering would not be news of "compelling public interest," the reporters would recognize that they simply could not get certain stories published with any anonymous sources.It also seems as if reporters covering compelling news should have to justify in writing their use of anonymous sources. They should have to explain at a minimum why anonymity is a last resort, efforts they have made to get the source on the record and how their investigation has led them to conclude that the information could not be obtained from another reliable open source.Although it may not always be possible, the reporter's pledge of anonymity should be given only after the reporter has obtained prior written approval from an editor, with that editor's written conclusions as to why anonymity is being granted.While forcing reporters and editors to document in writing the grant of anonymity in each case might be somewhat burdensome at first, it seems that if the procedures were put in place as regular expectations, both reporters and editors would adapt. It is also likely that both groups would become less willing to grant anonymity, except in extraordinary cases.As with the corrections page of The Times, it is possible that the newspaper could include a daily anonymous sourcing note, explaining in which story (or stories) anonymity had been granted and why.Patrick MattimoreGex, France, March 22, 2009 ● Consider this: A reporter quotes an anonymous source in an article and a lawsuit is filed, perhaps for defamation of character or false accusations. Should the reporter have to testify and name the anonymous source who gave the information that resulted in the lawsuit?Over the last 15 years, and even more so during the last 8, I believe there are a number of factors that contributed to the rise in the use of anonymous sources: (1) A real fear that making an accusation on the record could result in losing one's job or being ostracized by a community; (2) the fast pace at which news breaks means that reporters don't always have the time to look for other sources before writing a story; and (3) a general sense that citing an anonymous source adds credibility to any story.Unfortunately, the overall acceptance of anonymous source reporting means we have now found ourselves living in a culture where all one has to do is make an anonymous accusation or give an anonymous tip and it becomes fact in newsrooms around the world. No confirmation required. Lives and careers have been destroyed as a result of that policy.Rebekah JensenMorrisville, N.C., March 22, 2009●●Re "No Comment. But You Didn't Hear It From Me" (March 29): I hope that you will take a look at The Times's policies and practices in identifying "people in the street" in articles from places with repressive governments, particularly when they make critical comments.I have the impression that too often The New York Times relies on interviewees to request anonymity rather than expecting its reporters and/or editors to provide it, even if not requested, in potentially risky situations.The exact name of a noodle salesman in Shanghai really does not add enough to a story to justify putting his freedom or even life at risk.Minot NettletonWoodbridge, Conn., March 29, 2009 ● As a onetime ink-stained wretch and later a P.R. man, your column on anonymous sources and spokesmen grabbed me. I find objectionable the widespread use of aides or P.R. people as spokesmen for decision-makers. Whatever happened to the management maxim, "The buck stops here"- the code that disapproved of leaders passing the buck down the line and shirking their duties?I was taught that the media-relations role of a P.R. person is as a liaison between management and the press: to arrange for a reporter to speak directly to the person responsible for the part of the organization in which the reporter is interested.Management people are often reluctant to speak to the press and prefer to hide behind a spokesman. Fortunately, my boss accepted my perspective and, as C.E.O., was able to insist that except for requests for commonplace information, appropriate managers, not P.R. people, speak with reporters.Hal HoldenNorth Vancouver, British Columbia, March 29, 2009 ● I don't want to know why anonymous quotes are unattributed or off the record. That answer is usually vague, vacuous and formulaic, and provides no useful context or resulting import.I want to know why these sources are talking. Every reporter should ask this every time. "Why are you telling me this?" That's the context I need to understand the information (spin?) that sources are providing.Yes, in many (most) cases you'll get hand-waving and fatuity. And in many cases the reporter knows the answer perfectly well already. But your readers don't.And if reporters don't ask the question, they are quite reasonably precluded from imputing the source's motive(s) in print. This leaves your readers to do that imputing (and they will do so) absent the context necessary to do so.If the question is asked - and pressed - every time, it could have some small effect on the culture of anonymity. Sources might have to actually ask themselves the question. Even if they spin the answer, they might not be able to do so with complete success. (Think: reporters' Spidey senses.) In some cases, the source's answer would provide a necessary context or frame or lens through which I can discern the true import of what is being reported and quoted. The source's statements, so framed, might take on a significantly different or even opposite meaning. In some cases, the frame is the story.Over time the pressure of the question being consistently asked and pressed - and the answer being reported - could result in a salutary change to the overly cozy culture in whose talons reporters so often find themselves pinioned.Steve RothSeattle, March 30, 2009

headline: Vikings, 2009 Draft Countdown, 22nd Pick
summary: A late-season run into the postseason saved Brad Childress's job, but another lackluster offensive effort -- especially at quarterback -- would probably doom him. Childress hopes Sage Rosenfels will either claim the starting quarterback spot or push Tarvaris Jackson to new heights (editor's note: can there be new heights if there were no heights to begin with?) We know Rosenfels or Jackson will be handing off to Adrian Peterson, but whom will they pass to? This question and more must be addressed by training camp.

headline: A Rematch of a Mismatch
summary: DETROIT - There are plenty of storylines heading into Monday night's national title game between North Carolina and Michigan State.

headline: The Week Ahead: April 5-11
Eddie & The Robbers at the Hard Rock Cafe KL
summary: Yes, that race today was dynamite. At least I thought so, as you can see in my Malaysian Grand Prix race report.

headline: New G.M. Chief Doesn't Rule Out Bankruptcy
summary: A week into his new job as chief executive of General Motors, Fritz Henderson said on Sunday he was confident in the future of the company but a structured bankruptcy remains a possibility, The New York Times's A. G. Sulzberger reported.

headline: New G.M. Chief Doesn’t Rule Out Bankruptcy
summary: Fritz Henderson said he felt confident in General Motors but that a structured bankruptcy was still possible.

headline: Fox Soccer Channel Living Up to Its Name
summary: Perhaps it did not register on many TV dials across the United States, but last week Fox Soccer Channel, with 35 million subscribers, nabbed the North American rights to the UEFA Champions League from ESPN (with ESPN2, the channels are available in 98 million homes). FSC will take over next season through 2012.

headline: Masters Remains a Singular Experience
summary: A different world, one that never seems to change, greets competitors, caddies, officials and spectators inside the grounds at Augusta National Golf Club.

headline: More Tough Times for Banking Chiefs
summary: Being a banking chief means facing more pressure now than ever.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
summary: AbelsonTaylor, Chicago, promoted three employees. Paul Tursky and Holly Wright, account supervisors, become senior account supervisors. And Rich Campbell, senior account executive, becomes account supervisor.

headline: Live Blogging the Men's Title Game
summary: The Quad will be providing commentary and updates throughout the Final Four. In addition to Times reporters in Detroit, Connor Ennis is blogging from the Times office and Mike Ogle is blogging from Linda's Bar and Grill in Chapel Hill, N.C.

headline: Latest Poll on President Obama's Approval Ratings
summary: Americans have grown more optimistic about the economy and the direction of the country in the 11 weeks since President Obama was inaugurated, suggesting that Mr. Obama is enjoying some success in his critical task of rebuilding the nation's confidence, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: Poll Preview: Trade
summary: Americans continue to favor trade - the buying and selling of products - with other countries. Sixty-six percent of those surveyed in the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll called trade good for the economy; 23 percent described it as bad.

headline: The Economy's 'Green Shoots,' Real or Imagined
summary: Ben Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, said on CBS's "60 Minutes" that he is seeing "green shoots" showing up in the economic landscape, "as some confidence begins to come back."

headline: Buccaneers, 2009 Draft Countdown, 19th Pick
summary: A collapse over the final month of the season cost Jon Gruden his job, and led to a small-scale roster purge: the release of Derrick Brooks, Joey Galloway, Warrick Dunn and Cato June. With question marks at key positions, Tampa Bay cannot afford to miss on many of its draft picks, especially in the first round. Does Gruden's dismissal mean Tampa Bay can finally settle on one quarterback? Could it be U.S.C.'s Mark Sanchez or Kansas State's Josh Freeman, should either one last to the 19th pick?

headline: At Home on the Outskirts, With Goofy, Grumpy Dad
summary: This family comedy about a goofy suburban dad — played by Bob Saget — is ABC’s relapse.

headline: Ratings: With Country Music Awards, CBS Wins Ratings Race
summary: CBS's broadcast of the "44th Annual Academy of Country Music Awards" attracted 14.8 million viewers on Sunday, an increase of three million compared with last year and easily the night's largest audience, according to Nielsen's estimates.

headline: Outlook on Economy Is Brightening, Poll Finds
summary: President Obama is enjoying some success in rebuilding confidence, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: Touch of Stage Fright for the Spartans?
summary: DETROIT -- At halftime Monday, when the Michigan State Spartans trailed the North Carolina Tar Heels by 21 points in the N.C.A.A. men's tournament championship, Magic Johnson said on the CBS telecast that his old team played as if it had stage fright.

headline: The A.P.'s Real Enemies Are Its Customers
summary: If The Associated Press could completely win its war on search engines and news aggregators, it's hard to see that the news association or the newspaper companies that own it would be even the slightest bit better off.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
summary: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted April 1 through April 5 with 998 adults throughout the United States.

headline: For N.C.A.A.’s Myles Brand, Tough Battles Behind and Ahead
summary: For the last three months, the challenges facing the N.C.A.A. have been dwarfed by a much larger challenge facing its president, who has pancreatic cancer.

headline: Ratings: Basketball and Ballroom Dancing Compete
summary: North Carolina's big victory over Michigan State in the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament delivered solid ratings for CBS on Monday, but the less-than-competitive game helped ABC edge past CBS as the most watched network on the night over all.

headline: Country Music Awards Corral Ratings Win
summary: CBS’s broadcast of the Academy of Country Music Awards attracted 14.8 million viewers on Sunday night, an increase of 3 million over last year and easily the night’s largest audience.

headline: Bloomberg Spends $3 Million on TV Ads in Mayoral Race
summary: Michael R. Bloomberg is accelerating the race for mayor with the release of two commercials, one in English and one in Spanish, that emphasize his handling of the city’s economic crisis.

headline: Championship Ratings Are Lower
‘Dancing’ Grabs the Ball
summary: North Carolina’s victory over Michigan State in the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament final on Monday delivered strong ratings for CBS, but the less-than-competitive game helped ABC edge past CBS as the night’s most-watched network. According to Nielsen’s preliminary ratings estimates, CBS’s live coverage attracted just more than 16 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m.; on ABC, 19.6 million viewers tuned in “Dancing With the Stars” from 8 to 9:30. Fox was third in total viewers for the night, drawing 11 million for “24” and 13 million for an episode of “House” featuring the surprise departure of Kal Penn, who plays Dr. Lawrence Kutner. (The actor left the show to take a job in the White House Office of Public Liaison.) NBC finished in fourth place.

headline: Kellogg’s Analysis Was Fluid, but Incomplete
summary: Clark Kellogg filled Billy Packer's lead analyst role amiably during the Final Four, but fell short in analyzing Michigan State's championship game defensive woes.

headline: A New Television Murder Series Keeps Its Own End in Sight
summary: Watching “Harper’s Island” can be compared to seeing the blurry outlines of a relationship’s future on the first date.

headline: Tar Heels Will Have Lots of Talent Next Year
summary: DETROIT — Just after the University of North Carolina won the national championship in men’s basketball on Monday night, Larry Drew II ate chicken fingers and French fries from a plastic box while sitting in front of his locker.

headline: Chargers, 2009 Draft Countdown, 16th Pick
summary: The Jay Cutler trade makes the Chargers big favorites in the A.F.C. West, but they need to add depth to ensure a deeper run in the playoffs. With LaDainian Tomlinson aging, the Chargers could use their first-round pick to select his eventual replacement. Offensive tackle could also be addressed in the first round.

headline: Set Phasers to Stun: 'Star Trek' is Coming to a Store Near You
summary: The "Star Trek" prequel doesn't arrive in theaters for another month, but Paramount Pictures already has the nerd universe vibrating with anticipation, and retailers are doing everything they can to take advantage of it.

headline: Recession Anxiety Seeps Into Everyday Lives
summary: Experts see signs that stress is becoming more common as a result of the economic downturn.

headline: Misguided, She Yearns to Guide
summary: NBC’s “Parks and Recreation,” starring Amy Poehler, is charming and funny in its own right, even though it relies on the exact same approach as “The Office.”

headline: Shelving Done Right
summary: An investment banker who gave up securities trading to deal in rare and out-of-print books shopped for bookcases and shelves.

headline: Death as Wedding Guest: Bride’s or Groom’s Side?
summary: “Harper’s Island,” beginning Thursday, is a 13-episode mystery-thriller-psychodrama with CBS’s dopey but shamefully watchable whodunit imprimatur all over it.

headline: Ratings: Sluggish Debut for 'The Unusuals'
summary: ABC's new police drama "The Unusuals" made a sluggish debut in the ratings on Wednesday, earning just 6.8 million viewers in its 10 p.m. time slot, according to Nielsen's estimates. The new show, with Amber Tamblyn and Jeremy Renner, trailed behind CBS's "CSI: NY" in its time period with half the audience (12.5 million), but it did outperform NBC's 10 p.m. repeat of "Law & Order" (4.7 million).

headline: Texans, 2009 Draft Countdown, 15th Pick
summary: The Texans' 8-8 record in 2008 lands them smack in the middle of round one in this month's draft, where they will probably again select a defensive player in an effort to catch up with their A.F.C. South rivals. Houston's slow rise toward respectability might not have been as rapid as Jacksonville's or Carolina's, but another solid draft haul should put it firmly in the A.F.C. wild-card hunt.

headline: Unmemorable Start for ABC’s ‘Unusuals’
summary: ABC’s new police drama, “The Unusuals,” made a sluggish debut on Wednesday.

headline: Scientific Football: Cornerback and Receiver Statistics
summary: The Football Scientist, KC Joyner, is a Fifth Down contributor. His latest book, Scientific Football 2009, is now available for pre-order.

headline: Promising Start for ‘Parks’ on NBC
summary: The debuts of “Parks and Recreation” and “Southland” gave NBC a boost on Thursday night, according to Nielsen’s estimates.

headline: Bears, 2009 Draft Countdown, 49th Pick
summary: The Bears' trade for Jay Cutler leaves them with only one pick on the first day of the draft, the 49th selection. Though quarterback is no longer a concern, the Bears need help at wide receiver and on the offensive line. Building depth at cornerback should be another point of emphasis.

headline: Ratings: CBS Takes First Place on Low-Rated Easter Evening
summary: On a low-rated Easter evening of prime-time television, CBS captured its seventh straight win as the most watched network on Sunday night over all.

headline: Redskins, 2009 Draft Countdown, 13th Pick
summary: The wise call at No. 13 for Washington would be any of the following positions: offensive tackle or guard; defensive end or tackle; outside linebacker; cornerback. Unfortunately for long-suffering Redskins fans, the front-office team of owner Dan Snyder and executive Vinny Cerrato will be making the decision, exponentially multiplying the chance that a player from a position other than those above will be the pick.

headline: The 24-Hour Musicals: The Action Starts
summary: It’s 10:30 at the Gramercy Theater, and an hour’s worth of introductions have just ended. About 30 people sat round robin and introduced themselves by providing their name and their function (actor, director, etc). Each person was also asked to bring a costume piece and a prop that may be used in one of the shows.

headline: Giants' 2009 Schedule Announced
summary: The Giants' schedule was announced a few minutes ago on the NFL Network.A couple of bullet points:The Giants will ....1) Help open the Cowboys' new stadium with a Sunday night game in Week 22) Play three straight road games, Weeks 2-4. That's far from ideal, and something the N.F.L. tries to avoid.3) NOT play the final regular-season game at Giants Stadium (the new stadium will open in 2010). That honor will fall to the Jets, on Jan. 3 against the Bengals. But the Giants can rectify things by making the playoffs and earning home-field advantage for at least one game.

headline: 'It Was a Tough Deal'
summary: Monologue | Aired Monday night on CBS: They had a big Easter egg hunt in Central Park yesterday. And the kids, as usual, were great at finding stuff. They ought to send them out looking for bin Laden, that's what they ought to do.

headline: CBS Masters Sunday Night
summary: CBS was the most-watched network on Sunday night for the seventh week in a row, according to Nielsen’s estimates.

headline: Schedule Announced: Jets to Play Last Game at Giants Stadium
summary: The Jets' schedule was announced about half an hour ago. They will play the final regular-season game at Giants Stadium, on Jan. 3, in what will probably be a non-marquee matchup with the Bengals. Of course, it will be the final game only if the Jets and the Giants don't qualify for home games in the playoffs. (The new stadium opens in 2010.)A few bullet points:1) The Jets will play only two prime-time games, and one will be on the NFL Network on a Thursday night (Dec. 3).2) Rex Ryan will be tested quickly, in Week 2 against New England and a week later against Tennessee, which had a 10-game winning streak snapped by the Jets last November.3) Hmmm. It doesn't get easier in Weeks 4-5, at New Orleans and at Miami. The first month looks tough.

headline: Live From the Masters, It’s Not the Leaders
summary: Neither Tiger Woods nor Phil Mickelson took the lead during the final round at Augusta National. Still, CBS Sports treated them as if they had — until it no longer could.

headline: Bills, 2009 Draft Countdown, 11th Pick
summary: Outside of adding a big receiver in Terrell Owens, the Bills haven't shaken up their roster. (Editor's note: North America can only stand so much shaking.) A season removed from an 0-6 record in the A.F.C. East -- a division that should be stronger in 2009 -- Buffalo needs a great draft to catch up to its division rivals.

headline: A Distinctive Facade Is Recreated at New Yankee Stadium
summary: The Yankees have recreated the look of the frieze that topped the original House That Ruth Built in their new stadium.

headline: Developers Struggle to Fill Manhattan Office Space
summary: To attract prospective tenants to new or rehabbed buildings, landlords are tailoring their marketing efforts to today’s economic realities.

headline: Victory for ABC
summary: ABC earned the most viewers during prime time on Monday due largely to “Dancing With the Stars,” which attracted 19.1 million viewers from 8 to 9:30 p.m.

headline: Modern Villa on a Thai Island
summary: Lynn Grebstad and her business partner, Paul Hicks, built a villa named Baan Suralai, or Home of the Angels, which was designed to maximize its location in Bophut Hills.

headline: Arraignment Is Delayed for Kanye West
summary: Lawyers for Kanye West were granted an extension for the rapper’s arraignment.

headline: 49ers, 2009 Draft Countdown, 10th Pick
summary: Hope is high in San Francisco after the 49ers' 5-4 finish with Mike Singletary. He was able to motivate the team, but do the Niners have the talent to overtake N.F.C. champion Arizona in the N.F.C. West? The Niners will need to address their offensive line and defensive front seven, but will they be able to pass up quarterback Mark Sanchez of U.S.C.?

headline: Packers, 2009 Draft Countdown, 9th Pick
summary: The Packers have mostly stayed quiet this off-season while their N.F.C. North rivals Chicago and Minnesota have made all the noise. Now a year removed from the Brett Favre saga, can Aaron Rodgers and the rest of the team begin making their own history in Titletown? With four first-day picks (an extra third-round selection from the Jets via the Favre trade), Green Bay has the ammunition to address their issues on both sides of the line.

headline: 'Are You Like Me?'
summary: Monologue | Aired Wednesday night on CBS: Here's something that caught my attention as I was leafing through the paper this morning. NBC is making a reality show starring former Illinois Gov. Rod Blagojevich. This is the same network that didn't want me.

summary: John Madden, the Hall of Fame coach and one of the most recognizable voices in sports broadcasting, has decided to put down his microphone.

headline: 'They Might Secede'
summary: Monologue | Aired Thursday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: Yesterday, the governor of Texas, Rick Perry, said Texans are fed up with Washington. He said they might secede from the rest of America. If Texas forms their own country, they could be invaded by Mexico. They'll have to change their name to Texico.

headline: Jaguars, 2009 Draft Countdown, 8th Pick
summary: The eighth pick is Jacksonville's reward for having the worst locker room in the N.F.L. in 2008, a matter the front office hopes to rectify by releasing or not re-signing many veterans who had been a key to recent success. These moves may improve the team in the long term, but will the 2009 Jaguars have enough weapons to challenge the Titans and Colts in the A.F.C. South? Jack Del Rio, in what should be a make-or-break season, sure hopes so.

headline: Deal Brings TV Shows and Movies to YouTube
summary: In another step to become a destination for mainstream TV programs and movies, YouTube said it had signed deals with Hollywood studios to showcase their content.

summary: After 30 years of broadcasting, John Madden is leaving a weekly discipline that he revolutionized.

headline: Raiders, 2009 Draft Countdown, 7th Pick
summary: Oakland holds the seventh pick, a nice improvement from its fourth overall pick in 2008 and the first selection in 2007. Following the logical progression, you can start penciling in Oakland for the 10th pick in 2010. (editor's note: Logical and Al Davis haven't gone together lately). So who will Davis and the Raiders take next weekend? Will it be the sub-4.3 skill player who wowed them at the combine? Or the troubled lineman who fits the old-school Raider outlaw image? How about a better question: Will the Raiders finally be competitive again?

headline: Browns, 2009 Draft Countdown, 5th Pick
summary: The former Jets coach Eric Mangini has already put his stamp on the Cleveland franchise. Is this a good thing? Gone are many of the veterans from the old regime, replaced by a handful of his former Jets and free agents from around the league. Mangini inherited a 4-12 team with the Jets in 2006, leading them to a 10-win season and a playoff berth. Any chance for a repeat in his first year in Cleveland?

summary: Demographic shifts and a recession are making older consumers — long shunned in favor of free-spending, younger age groups — into better bets.

summary: Adobe expects TVs that support its Flash format to start selling later this year, offering content creators a single format for an expanding ecosystem of digital devices.

headline: Can ‘Chuck’ Be Saved? Even Josh Schwartz Isn’t Sure
summary: You know it’s spring when the temperature goes up, the flowers bloom and bloggers begin their campaigns to save their favorite shows in danger of being cancelled. With just a few weeks before the networks announce their fall schedules, the Web seems to have coalesced around “Chuck,” NBC’s action satire about a computer geek (played by Zachary Levi) turned unlikely secret agent. Fan sites like Give Me My Remote as well as online columnists like Michael Ausiello of Entertainment Weekly and Alan Sepinwall of The Star-Ledger have encouraged viewers to call upon NBC to give the show a third season.

headline: Chiefs, 2009 Draft Countdown, 3rd Pick
summary: The Chiefs might have hit rock bottom in 2008, but the future looks brighter in the hands of the former Patriots executive Scott Pioli, who takes over for Carl Peterson as the face of the organization (editor's note: some Chiefs fans might say that that face was The Scream.) His first move as general manager was to fire Herm Edwards and replace him with the former Arizona offensive coordinator Todd Haley. His next step is to rebuild one of the thinnest rosters in the league. It all starts with the third pick.

headline: 'That Evil Hugo'
summary: Monologue | Aired Monday night on CBS: Well, recently, that evil Hugo Chavez from Venezuela slipped President Obama a book that is printed in Spanish. But President Obama does not read or speak Spanish. It would be like handing George W. Bush any book.

headline: Ratings: ABC Dominates on Monday

summary: ABC dominated the ratings on Monday night, as 20.3 million viewers tuned in to “Dancing With the Stars,” according to Nielsen’s estimates.

summary: With "The Biggest Loser" garnering its best ratings in almost three months, NBC earned a strong second place finish on Tuesday night, at least in the important demographic of adults 18 to 49, according to Nielsen's estimates. The audience for the NBC weight loss show grew by more than 2.5 million viewers over the course of its two-hour broadcast, averaging 9.3 million total viewers from 8 to 10 p.m.

Gone are Torry Holt and Orlando Pace, the last ties to the Super Bowl champions of 1999, closing the book on those successful and entertaining teams under former coaches Dick Vermeil and Mike Martz. So what now? Offensive line is one place to start, but there is a lot of work to be done. The former Giants defensive coordinator Steve Spagnuolo has inherited a difficult task.

headline: '15 Seconds of Waterboarding'
summary: Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: A journalist from Playboy magazine attempted to withstand 15 seconds of waterboarding. And he's going to write all about it in an article that no one will ever read.

headline: Kicking Her Kids Out of the Car

The Westchester County police certainly seem to be, which is why they arrested Madlyn Primoff, a lawyer with a prominent Manhattan law firm, for kicking her two daughters, ages 10 and 12, out of the car Sunday night and leaving them to walk home.

headline: Ratings: Networks Barely Bother to Compete With 'Idol'

In addition to the 9 p.m. hour with "Idol," Fox also won the earlier 8 p.m. time slot with "Lie to Me" despite its much smaller audience of 7.9 million.

Listen to this, according to a new poll, two out of three New Yorkers would like to have Spitzer back as their governor. I mean sure, two out of three New Yorkers are hookers.

summary: Despite a hefty lead in the polls, the mayor seems intent on vastly outspending his opponents, just as he did in the last two elections.

headline: Motorsports Links: Talladega Crash Injures 7 Fans
summary: Nascar: The Aaron's 449 at Talladega Superspeedway in Alabama will not be remembered for Brad Keselowski's first Sprint Cup win -- or anything that happened before the final stretch. Instead, the race will be remembered for a spectacular crash just before the finish line, injuring seven fans, though none seriously, said Nascar officials.

headline: Ratings: 'Desperate Housewives' Draws Highest Audience on Sunday
summary: "Desperate Housewives" earned Sunday night's largest audience as 13.5 million viewers tuned in to the 9 p.m. drama on ABC, according to Nielsen's estimates.

headline: Complex Patterns Within a Simple Key
summary: Any counterculture embraced by enough people becomes culture; works of art meant as blows against orthodoxy become classics worthy of enshrinement. A case in point is Terry Riley's ''In C,'' whose 45th anniversary was celebrated at Carnegie Hall on Friday night. When Mr. Riley created the piece, in 1964, modern music had long been dominated by serialism: rigorously controlled, intellectual in its appeal, often bone dry. Mr. Riley's simple recipe -- performers repeat each of 53 melodic kernels for as long as they like against a pulsating C in octaves, ending when everyone has played every section -- asserted a view of music as a communal action and a key to transcendence.

headline: Times/CBS News Poll: Obama is a Different Kind of Politician
summary: Update | 7:01 p.m. Barack Obama entered the presidency promising a new kind of leadership in Washington, and after observing him for nearly 100 days in the White House, most Americans do say he is not your typical politician, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: Ginia Bellafante on Bea Arthur, ‘Maude’ and Abortion
summary: Updated | 5:10 p.m. Bea Arthur’s death on Saturday, at the age of 86, reminds us how conservative television has become since the ’70s at least in regard to the subject of abortion.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
summary: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted April 22 through April 26 with 973 adults throughout the United States.

headline: Joost Shops Itself to Cable Operators, Report Says
summary: The online video site Joost is shopping itself around to different cable TV operators, but at least one has declined to buy it, The Associated Press reported, citing people with knowledge of the talks.

headline: The Morning Feed
summary: What we’re reading (and watching) on Tuesday morning.

headline: 'Housewives' Leads the Night For ABC
summary: A Nicollette Sheridan-less ''Desperate Housewives'' on ABC drew Sunday night's largest audience, 13.5 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates. But ABC finished second in total viewers. CBS won the night with ''60 Minutes'' (10.4 million), ''The Amazing Race'' (10.3 million), ''Cold Case'' (10.5 million) and ''The Unit'' (8.9 million). NBC, in third place, broadcast ''Dateline'' (5.1 million) and ''The Celebrity Apprentice'' (8.2 million). Fox lagged behind in fourth place with its comedy lineup. That network's new animated series, ''Sit Down, Shut Up,'' garnered 4.2 million viewers, a million less than its debut a week ago.

headline: Ratings: 'Dancing' Lifts ABC Into First Place
summary: With an average audience of 19.1 million viewers, ABC's 90-minute installment of "Dancing With the Stars" on Monday lifted the network to No. 1 in the ratings for the night, according to Nielsen's estimates. But aside from ABC's viewership advantage from 8 to 9:30 p.m., the ratings race was close on the night.

headline: How '07 ABC Interview Tilted a Torture Debate
summary: In late 2007, there was the first crack of daylight into the government's use of waterboarding during interrogations of Al Qaeda detainees. On Dec. 10, John Kiriakou, a former C.I.A. officer who had participated in the capture of the suspected terrorist Abu Zubaydah in Pakistan in 2002, appeared on ABC News to say that while he considered waterboarding a form of torture, the technique worked and yielded results very quickly. Mr. Zubaydah started to cooperate after being waterboarded for ''probably 30, 35 seconds,'' Mr. Kiriakou told the ABC reporter Brian Ross. ''From that day on he answered every question.''

headline: Fox Will Limit Obama Event to Cable
summary: Fox said an on-screen graphic during its broadcast channel’s drama, “Lie to Me,” would alert viewers to coverage of Wednesday’s news conference on the Fox News Channel.

headline: 'No Offense Mahmoud'
summary: Monologue | Aired Monday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: In a new interview, Iranian President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad complained that President Obama hasn't been returning his messages. No offense Mahmoud, but maybe he's just not that into you.

headline: Obama Nudging Views on Race, A Survey Finds
summary: Barack Obama's presidency seems to be altering the public perception of race relations in the United States. Two-thirds of Americans now say race relations are generally good, and the percentage of blacks who say so has doubled since last July, according to the latest New York Times/ CBS News poll. Despite that, half of blacks still say whites have a better chance of getting ahead in American society, the poll found. Black Americans remain among the president's staunchest supporters; 70 percent of black respondents now say the country is headed in the right direction, compared with 34 percent of whites.

headline: The Early Word: Emergency Response
summary: With the outbreak of swine flu providing another test for the Obama administration, top Cabinet officials and other key health administrators have been busily monitoring cases in the United States and in Mexico. As some officials hit the airwaves, they've been walking that fine line between educating the public and not contributing to heightened fears of a possible epidemic.

headline: Turmoil Stalls Phuket Vacation Home Boom
summary: Rampant development has ground to a halt since the onset of the global financial crisis and political unrest from a coup in 2006.

headline: Ratings: First Place for the Final 5 Idols
summary: As the final five contestants on "American Idol" competed for a chance at the top prize on Tuesday, Fox once again took first place in the night's ratings.

headline: New York Office Landlords Go Small
summary: Manhattan building owners are trying to make deals by chopping large spaces into smaller units and finishing off the space before a tenant is signed.

headline: 'Something Else I Didn't Want to Bring Up'
summary: Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on CBS: Well, the U.S. government is saying look out for the swine flu, which apparently comes from Mexico. Thank God we have an airtight border with that country. So, the U.S. is going to be fine.

headline: One Hundred
summary: In his first 14 weeks plus two days, President Obama has made a strong start at addressing the most critical of the failed policies and urgent threats that he inherited.

headline: Supreme Court Backs F.C.C. on Indecency Rule

headline: 'It's Very Odd'
summary: Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: Hey, did you hear about Arlen Specter, the senator? He left the Republican Party and became a Democrat. What?! It's very odd, to switch teams like this. Who does he think he is, Lindsay Lohan?

headline: Same-Sex Marriage Holds Peril for G.O.P.
summary: It was only five years ago that opposition to same-sex marriage was so strong that Republicans explicitly turned to the issue as a way to energize conservative voters. Yet today, as the party contemplates the task of rebuilding itself, some Republicans say the marriage issue may be turning into more of a hindrance than a help. The fact that a run of states have legalized same-sex marriage in recent months -- either by court decision or by legislative action -- with little backlash is only one indication of how public attitudes about this subject appear to be changing.

headline: Presidential Report Card
summary: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Signs G.O.P. Is Rethinking Stance on Gay Marriage
summary: Some Republicans say the issue of gay marriage may be turning into more of a hindrance than a help.

headline: Associated Content Said to Nab $6 Million

summary: Monologue | Aired Wednesday night on CBS: A beautiful day here in New York City, wasn't it? But it was cold, so cold that I was wearing two swine flu masks.

headline: The Early Word: Back to Business but Oh, Biden
summary: It's Day 101 of President Obama's presidency, the reviews are in from his Wednesday night news conference and he's already moving on to the next phase and the latest crises, and we do mean plural -- meaning the near pandemic of swine flu and Chrysler's precarious financial situation.

headline: Ratings: ABC and CBS Share a Win
summary: In the race to finish No. 1 in the ratings on Thursday, both ABC and CBS claimed victory on the night.

headline: CBS Wins Use of Data
summary: CBS Corp.’s Internet unit won the right to use N.F.L. players’ names and statistics for free in fantasy sports leagues it sponsors, after a judge ruled the information was in the public domain.

headline: 'Taking Every Possible Precaution'
summary: Monologue | Aired Thursday night on CBS: New York City is taking every possible precaution to avoid swine flu. For example, I was over at St. Patrick's Cathedral earlier today, lighting a candle, and I happened to notice that they have replaced the holy water with Purell.

summary: The network joins NBC and Fox in placing content on the advertising-supported site, which is vying to be the top destination for TV shows online.

headline: Death And Doctors Dominate Ratings
summary: CBS and ABC can each claim a victory in Thursday night's ratings. Nielsen's estimates indicate that CBS earned the most viewers during every hour of prime time, with ''Survivor'' at 8 (11.7 million), ''CSI'' at 9 (15.3 million) and ''Harper's Island'' at 10 (10.3 million). ABC averaged the night's highest ratings in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic, largely because of ''Grey's Anatomy'' (13.9 million) and the season finale of ''Private Practice'' (9.8 million). Fox ranked third for the night with ''Bones'' (8.8 million) and ''Hell's Kitchen'' (7 million). NBC was fourth over all, including its new shows ''Parks and Recreation'' (5.3 million) and ''Southland'' (6.7 million).

headline: Danny Gans, Impressionist, Dies at 52

He was 52. The death was confirmed by Jennifer Dunne, a spokeswoman for Wynn Resorts, which hired Mr. Gans early this year to perform at its new Encore resort.

summary: INTERNATIONAL.

"The high court on Monday directed the 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Philadelphia to consider reinstating the $550,000 fine that the Federal Communications Commission imposed on CBS over Jackson's breast-baring performance at the 2004 Super Bowl." Read more...

headline: Link to Economic Crisis Is Vital to Obama Agenda
summary: Team Obama has cast his initiatives on health care, energy, education and the auto and financial industries as responses to the downturn, but time is not on his side politically.

summary: Taken together, the cuts — including dismissed staff, dropped teams and reduced facility hours — could deeply alter the college sports landscape.

headline: The Quad Countdown: No. 120 Western Kentucky

Baseball hasn't reached the All-Star break, the N.B.A. and the N.H.L. are making their way through the playoffs, college lacrosse hasn't even reached its Final Four. But there's never a bad time to start getting ready for the football season. So why not begin here? Paul will be back every day with a new team, providing some gridiron knowledge to help you make it through the days until the season kicks off.

headline: NBC Offers Marketers an Expanded Fall Lineup
summary: With Jay Leno’s new hourlong comedy show to occupy one-third of the network’s weeknight schedule, NBC says its is building a strategy around the strongest pilots it has developed.

headline: Dom DeLuise, Comic Actor, Dies at 75
summary: The actor’s manic grin and air of desperation added comic bounce to films like “The Twelve Chairs,” “Blazing Saddles” and “The Cannonball Run.”

headline: 'That's Fast'

headline: Kerrey Will Leave New School in 2011

headline: Battered by Ad Decline, CBS Posts Quarterly Loss
summary: The CBS Corporation reported a quarterly loss as its core business, broadcast television, continued to be battered by a steep advertising recession.

headline: After Ratings Delay, the Usual Winners
summary: Sunday’s prime-time ratings, distributed late Wednesday, showed ABC’s “Desperate Housewives” on top that night with 13.5 million viewers.

headline: Catching Up With | Phil Keoghan
summary: No one travels the world quite like the competitors of "The Amazing Race" on CBS. This season, which concludes on Sunday at 8 p.m., the teams have done everything from transporting cheese down a steep hill in Switzerland (hilarious!) to running through Siberia in their underwear (tempting!) to eating fried starfish in China (no thanks!). The man who sees them through it all is Phil Keoghan, the host of the show, who himself has been on a cross-country bike tour since March 28. Sponsored by GNC, the trip is part book tour for Keoghan's "No Opportunity Wasted," part casting call for season 15, and part fundraiser for MS research. During a pit stop in Baltimore - "We didn't have to bike in the rain today; that was a blessing" - Mr. Keoghan called in to answer a few questions.

headline: Late Ratings: Two Days of 'Idol'
summary: In final numbers for Tuesday and Wednesday, which Nielsen released on a delay from its regular schedule, Fox finished No. 1 on both nights largely because of "American Idol," which earned well over 23 million viewers on each night. headline: Upfronts: What to Watch This Week

It generally refers to three activities:No. 1: The unveiling of new television network schedulesNo. 2: The cajoling of advertisers by the networksNo. 3: The selling of billions of dollars in advertising timeNo. 1 is the most important for fans who want to know if their favorite shows will return and which new shows will join the schedule. Nos. 2 and 3 are the most important to networks who want to keep shows in production and keep generating profit for their parent companies, an especially tough task this year.

headline: Footnotes
summary: The telecast of the Emmy Awards has been rescheduled for Sept. 13, a week earlier than originally planned, CBS said on Monday. The network said that it had moved the awards broadcast to avoid a conflict with a doubleheader of National Football League games. Emmy nominations are to be announced on July 16. ... The teenage vampire romance “Twilight” dominated the MTV Movie Awards, whose winners were announced on Sunday night. The film was named best movie by the votes of the cable channel’s viewers, and its stars Kristen Stewart and Robert Pattinson won for female performance and breakthrough male performance, as well as best kiss. Heath Ledger was named best villain for his performance in “The Dark Knight,” and Ben Stiller was given the MTV Generation Award, a lifetime achievement prize. ... The violinist Geoff Nuttall has been named the artistic director of the Spoleto Festival USA Chamber Music Series, the festival’s organizers said. His appointment will be effective with the 2010 festival, when he will succeed the longtime artistic director, Charles Wadsworth.

headline: Weekend Opinionator: Hawking Health Care in Prime Time
summary: It was a bit like planning the dream wedding only to have a hurricane rip away the chapel roof as you make your way down the aisle. ABC News and the White House probably thought they had scored a coup in arranging "Questions for the President: Prescription for America," a prime-time opportunity (with a followup session on "Nightline") for Barack Obama to explain his health care proposal to the voters and for ABC to monopolize an hour-plus with the most famous man in the world. And then came Iran. And Mark Sanford. And, well, there was the fact that it was about health care reform. The result: the 10 p.m. show drew 4.7 million viewers, or nearly 3 million fewer than a competing repeat of CBS's "CSI: New York" and less than half what the evening's top draw, NBC's "America's Got Talent," attracted in the previous hour. Well, could the president's plan have got a second-day bump at America's water coolers? Not likely.

headline: Sharing the Wealth
summary: On Wednesday all four major broadcast networks posted ratings highlights that they could brag about. While NBC garnered the largest audience with “America’s Got Talent” at 9 p.m.  an average of 11.7 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates  Fox’s two-hour installment of “So You Think You Can Dance” (7.5 million) lifted that network to No. 1 among adults 18 to 49. And although ABC and CBS finished in a virtual tie for third place, both claimed the lead during one time slot each with ABC’s “Wipeout” ahead during the 8 p.m. hour (8.1 million) and CBS’s repeat of “CSI: NY” on top at 10 (7.2 million). Opposite “Wipeout,” NBC’s encore showing of “America’s Got Talent” drew just 6.2 million viewers while CBS’s repeats of “The New Adventures of Old Christine” and “Gary Unmarried” averaged about 4 million each. NBC’s new show “The Philanthropist” struggled at 10 p.m. with 5.1 million viewers, finishing third in that time slot behind ABC’s “Primetime: Crime” (6 million).

headline: Paul McCartney Plays the Ed Sullivan Theater
summary: Before the world was turned utterly upside-down by the announcement of the Emmy nominations, we meant to point out that Paul McCartney on Wednesday evening made a return to the Ed Sullivan Theater in Manhattan, a performance space he played frequently (back when it was known as CBS-TV Studio 50) with a group called the Beatles. Appearing on CBS’s “Late Show with David Letterman,” Mr. McCartney spoke with the host about his time in the Beatles and his collaborations with Michael Jackson (“a lovely man, massively talented,” Mr. McCartney said). In the spirit of “Let It Be,” the musician then took to the marquee of the Ed Sullivan Theater where Mr. McCartney performed “Get Back” and his song “Sing the Changes.” Not content to stop there, Mr. McCartney played a 22-minute mini-concert for the crowd, which included the songs “Coming Up,” “Band on the Run,” “Let Me Roll It,” “Helter Skelter,” and “Back in the USSR.”

headline: Today Is Take Your Kid to the Moon Day
summary: If you were one of the children forced to watch the Apollo 11 landing on the Moon back in 1969, you probably can recall that it was hardly exciting. Hours of blurry black-and-white footage were narrated by droning grown-ups discussing things like "We're standing by for confirmation" and "they're getting ready for breakfast." Once the Eagle finally did land, there were no Moon creatures or green cheese just ... endless dust.

headline: Walter Cronkite
summary: Walter Cronkite’s death ends something larger and more profound than a single life or even a generation. He was a proxy for the nation, and stood for a world that no longer exists.

headline: Walter Cronkite

headline: Cellphone Etiquette for Kids
summary: Remember those triangle-shape notes you used to pass to friends between your classes? To today's middle-schooler, cellphones are like those -- times 50. They're also Polaroid cameras, tape recorders, CB radios, flashlights, a stack of favorite music albums and a photo scrapbook -- not to mention a social lifeline at a time when relationships seem as important as oxygen.

headline: Now Screening | 'Hotel'
summary: Ah, the heyday of Aaron Spelling! I was a wee lad when the TV series "Hotel" (full name: "Arthur Hailey's Hotel," since the show was based on his novel) had its debut back in 1983, so I don't have strong memories of it. It was on a little late for me - after "Dynasty," a show my parents probably didn't want me watching anyway - but I do remember James Brolin and his beard, a cavalcade of guest stars (Liberace! Scott Baio! Eva Gabor!) and, most of all, the marble columns, velvet banquettes and plush suites of the St. Gregory Hotel. Today Paramount Home Entertainment and CBS released the show's first season (it ran for five) on DVD, so I checked in for a stay on memory lane."Hotel" was often compared to "The Love Boat," which it certainly mirrored in structure: there were the St. Gregory's staff members - including the omnipresent manager, Peter McDermott (Brolin); his assistant, Christine Francis (Connie Sellecca); the guest relations manager, Mark Danning (Shea Farrell); and the security guy, Billy Griffin (Nathan Cook) - and an ever-changing roster of hotel guests, played by the aforementioned special guest stars. There were three or four plot lines per episode: always romance, sometimes mayhem, and typically some lighthearted humor.

headline: ‘Talent’ Wins the Day

NBC was the most watched network over all despite earning a more modest 8.5 million viewers at 8 for a repeat of “America’s Got Talent” and 7.2 million at 10 for a rerun of “Law & Order: SVU.” CBS was second with reruns of “NCIS” at 8 (9.3 million) and “Medium” at 10 (4.5 million), along with a new installment of “Big Brother” in between (6.2 million). Fox finished third with “Hell’s Kitchen” at 8 (6.8 million) followed by the series premiere of “More to Love” at 9 (4.2 million), but edged past NBC to win the night among adults 18 to 49. In fourth, ABC averaged just 3.3 million viewers for a rebroadcast of Monday’s “Bachelorette” finale, but at 10, its follow-up special, “After the Final Rose,” won its time slot with 7.8 million viewers.

headline: Corrections
summary: An obituary on July 18 about Walter Cronkite, using information from his autobiography, “A Reporter’s Life,” misstated the origin of the term “anchor.” While Mr. Cronkite was referred to as the anchor of CBS news coverage of the 1952 presidential conventions, that was not the first time that “anchor” and “anchorman” were used. Both terms had been applied to broadcasters in other contexts before the conventions. The obituary also included an erroneous anecdote from the autobiography about the extent of his fame. He was said to be so widely known that newscasters in Sweden were once called “Cronkiters,” but that term is not known to linguists in that country.

headline: From ‘60 Minutes,’ a Hewitt Tribute
summary: Don Hewitt will be remembered by the program he founded, “60 Minutes,” on Sunday evening. Mr. Hewitt, below, died Wednesday at 86. CBS said that the correspondents for the pioneering newsmagazine, including Steve Kroft, Morley Safer and Lesley Stahl, were preparing segments that would detail Mr. Hewitt’s life and his “lasting contributions to the television news industry.” Jeff Fager, the executive producer of “60 Minutes,” will produce the hourlong show, to be titled “Remembering Don Hewitt.” In a statement, Mr. Fager said Mr. Hewitt “will always have an impact on this broadcast — there’s a part of him in every one of us, and it affects every decision we make.”.

By comparison, NBC’s “America’s Got Talent,” which led the night over all, delivered 10.3 million viewers, helping NBC rank first. CBS and ABC finished in a virtual tie for second place. headline: Murder, They Rewrote: ‘Prime Suspect’ Planned for American Remake
summary: “Prime Suspect,” the long-running British police drama that let Helen Mirren wear a detective’s badge before she got to don the British crown, is being reinvented for American television. The Hollywood Reporter said that NBC has ordered a pilot episode of a new “Prime Suspect” series intended for audiences in the United States, to be written by Hank Steinberg, the creator of the CBS crime series “Without a Trace.” The original “Prime Suspect,” which was created by Lynda La Plante and first shown in Britain on the ITV network in 1991, starred Ms. Mirren (“The Queen”) as Jane Tennison, a detective chief inspector contending with her first substantial murder investigation as well as the sexist attitudes of her mostly male coworkers. Seven “Prime Suspect” series were produced through 2006, and broadcasts on PBS help introduce American viewers to Tom Wilkinson and Ralph Fiennes. No casting has yet been announced for the American version of the show.

headline: Corrections

(A motion by CBS to dismiss the suit is pending before an appeals court.).

headline: Has the Quality of TV Improved, or Just the Buzz About It?

headline: Times Poll: Public Leans Toward Obama Over Republicans on Health Care

headline: What to Watch This Weekend: ‘SNL,’ ‘Law & Order’ and a Very Big Sunday

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
summary: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Sept. 19 through Sept. 23 with 1,042 adults throughout the United States. The sample of land line telephone exchanges called was randomly selected by a computer from a complete list of more than 69,000 active residential exchanges across the country. The exchanges were chosen so as to ensure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population.

headline: Study Finds More Gay Characters on Broadcast Networks, Fewer on Cable
summary: The number of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender characters has grown in recent years on prime-time network television, but decreased on cable, the Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation said. For its recently published “Where We Are On TV” study, the alliance reviewed 79 scripted comedies and dramas announced to air on the broadcast networks during the 2009-2010 season, and found that of 600 series regulars on these shows, 18 are lesbian, gay, bisexual or transgender. The study said that ABC has the most such characters, with 8 out of 168 total series regulars; Fox has four (including cartoon characters from “The Simpsons” and “American Dad”), NBC has three, CW has two and CBS has none. In its review of mainstream cable channels, including HBO, Showtime, Comedy Central, AMC and others, the alliance found that the number of series regulars who are lesbian, gay, bisexual or transgender decreased this year to 25 from 32 last year. When the gay-oriented cable channels here! and Logo were accounted for, the study said, an additional 27 such characters were added to the tally.

headline: Study Finds Gay Roles Up on Broadcast TV
summary: The number of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender characters has grown in recent years on prime-time network television but decreased on cable, the Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation said. For its “Where We Are on TV” study, the alliance reviewed 79 scripted comedies and dramas announced for the broadcast networks during the 2009-10 season. It found that of 600 regulars on these shows, 18 are lesbian, gay, bisexual or transgender. The study said that ABC has the most such characters, with 8 out of 168 total series regulars; Fox has 4 (including cartoon characters on “The Simpsons” and “American Dad”), NBC has 3, CW has 2 and CBS, none. In its review of mainstream cable channels, including HBO, Showtime, Comedy Central, AMC and others, the alliance found that the number of series regulars who are lesbian, gay, bisexual or transgender decreased this year, to 25 from 32 last year. When the gay-oriented cable channels here! and Logo were included, the study said, 27 gay characters were added to the tally.

headline: Jon Gosselin Bars Film Crews From Home
summary: TLC said on Thursday that it had suspended filming of the Gosselin children, left, on its reality series “Jon & Kate Plus 8” after a lawyer for Jon Gosselin told the cable channel in a letter that production crews were forbidden to enter the Gosselin family home. The letter was reported on Thursday on CBS’s “Early Show,” which said it was dated Tuesday, the same day that TLC announced it would sideline Mr. Gosselin and rename the reality show “Kate Plus 8.” Mark Heller, a lawyer for Mr. Gosselin, said in a statement that he was confident his client “will be completely successful in his quest to take back control of his family and preserve, protect and ensure their future well-being by putting the brakes on his divorce and pulling the plug on TLC, the media giant that he perceives as a monster.” The “Jon & Kate” show drew a wide audience in the spring and summer, when the couple’s marriage effectively collapsed. In a statement on Thursday, TLC said, “We are aware of Jon Gosselin’s recent statements and remain deeply disappointed at his continued erratic behavior.” TLC said that Mr. Gosselin and his family were shooting for the show as recently as last Friday.

headline: CBS Picks Up ‘NCIS: Los Angeles’ and ‘The Good Wife’
summary: The fall television season has reached that improbable moment when the number of new series that have been picked up for a full year exceeds the number that have been canceled. On Tuesday, CBS announced that it was giving full season orders to its new dramas “NCIS: Los Angeles” and “The Good Wife,” both of which are shown on Tuesday nights. The decision should come as absolutely no surprise to anyone who keeps an eye on Nielsen ratings: “NCIS: Los Angeles,” a spinoff of CBS’s hit police procedural “NCIS” that stars LL Cool J and Chris O’Donnell, is already the most-viewed new show of the fall season (CBS said it averages just under 17.5 million viewers a week). “The Good Wife” is no slouch, either: that show, which stars Julianna Margulies as the purely fictional spouse of a politician embroiled in a sex scandal, has been drawing about 13.7 million viewers a week, according to CBS.

headline: Weekly Matchups: Playoff Time
summary: In every other sport you have to wait for the playoffs. As the regular season winds down teams with leads rest starters and begin to prepare for the postseason. Not in college football. As the season winds down the pressure on the top teams grows. The better you've been through the course of the season the more pressure is on you. You need to perform week in and week out. No resting anyone. In college football, the regular season is the playoffs. Think about this weekend's Alabama/L.S.U. game. A 3:30 p.m. game on a November Saturday at Bryant-Denny Stadium with the SEC West on the line definitely has a playoff feel about it. Ohio State/Penn State at Beaver Stadium is basically an elimination game in the Big Ten. At this point in the season, every week is a playoff game for teams like Iowa, Texas, Florida, Boise State, T.C.U. and Cincinnati. The more teams that are undefeated the more important it gets not to lose. No one can afford a let down. The weather is colder, the stakes are higher and total chaos always seems right around the corner. Gotta love the college football.

headline: Third Time Lucky for ‘CSI’
summary: CBS’s “CSI” earned its highest ratings of the season on Thursday with the conclusion of a crossover plot line that involved episodes of “CSI: Miami” and “CSI: NY” the same week. According to Nielsen’s estimates, the final episode of the “CSI” trilogy drew the largest audience of the three shows, with 16.9 million viewers at 9 p.m. on Thursday, enough to lead the night over all in the ratings. CBS’s “Survivor: Samoa” also delivered its best ratings of the season, leading the 8 o’clock hour with 13.2 million viewers. CBS won the night, and ABC placed second with “FlashForward” (8.3 million), “Grey’s Anatomy” (14.4 million) and “Private Practice” (10.2 million). Fox was third with “Bones” (9.8 million) and “Fringe” (5.9 million), and NBC was fourth with its comedy lineup.

headline: New York, From the Pages of Look

headline: Interrogated About 'The Daily Show' in Iran

headline: Adam Lambert Headed to CBS 'Early Show' After ABC Cancels His Concert

That awards show was broadcast Sunday on ABC, which said it was concerned that Mr. Lambert would give another "controversial" performance if he appeared on "Good Morning America."

headline: Adam Lambert Concert, Planned for 'Good Morning America,' Is Canceled

An ABC spokeswoman said, "Given his controversial American Music Awards performance, we were concerned about airing a similar concert so early in the morning." Mr. Lambert previously appeared on "Good Morning America" in August, when he performed the Muse song "Starlight," and discussed his sexuality in an interview with "20/20" in June. The American Music Awards show was broadcast on ABC on Sunday night.

headline: Weekend Matchups: Turducken for the College Fan
summary: For some reason, a couple of pro football games on Thanksgiving Day get all the credit. That's what people think of when they think of football and Thanksgiving. I would argue that Thanksgiving pro football is like turkey. It's good enough, but needs some accoutrement to go with it. Maybe some cranberry sauce, or at the very least some stuffing and sweet potatoes. A weekend of rivalry games like this one coming up? That's something a little more nuanced for a more delicate and refined palate. I would argue that this weekend of college games is more like the turducken, a complex and multi-layered Russian doll of food, that never fails to surprise with it's confusing flavor juxtapositions and horrific caloric implications.

headline: The Morning Feed
summary: What we're reading (and watching) on Tuesday morning.Couple Denies Crashing White House Party: Tareq and Michaele Salahi, the couple who made their way into President Obama's first state dinner while being followed by a crew for a television reality show, broke their silence in an interview on "The Today Show" Tuesday morning. The Salahis told Matt Lauer that they were not party crashers -- "There isn't anyone who would have the audacity or poor behavior to do that," Ms. Salahi said -- but declined to say who had invited them to the event, citing a Secret Service investigation.No Release Yet for Polanski: Swiss officials said they will not set Roman Polanski free from a prison near Zurich before Friday, Reuters reported. A spokesman for the Swiss Justice Department said it was still waiting for the director to pay his $4.5 million bail and fulfill other security requirements before he is placed under house arrest in his chalet in Gstaad. Mr. Polanski, 76, is awaiting possible extradition to the United States, which he fled in 1978 after pleading guilty to having sex with a 13-year-old girl.'Bar' Dropped, 'Rivers' Ebbs: Here are two more season passes you can erase from your TiVo playlist: TNT has canceled "Raising the Bar," its legal drama created by Steven Bochco of "Hill Street Blues" and "NYPD Blue" fame, citing low ratings, Variety reported. The trade publication also says that CBS has pulled its medical drama "Three Rivers" from its schedule; though the show isn't officially canceled, the network will probably replace it with another medical show, "Miami Trauma."Spoiling the Spoilers: In a comic rant in The Guardian, Grace Dent takes aim at spoilers -- not the people who give away plot details of television shows and movies, but the people who are constantly complaining about having the suspense of these programs and films spoiled for them. Ms. Dent writes, "My general rule of thumb is, if you're old enough to buy a flat screen Sony Bravia TV and a full-speaker Bang & Olufsen wall of sound to complement it, you're officially too old to cry like a girl" if someone reveals a crucial plot detail from "Up" or "The Wire."
